Title: My Top 4 Breakfast Spots in Barcelona — As a Local
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Intro
As someone who wakes up early, I have come to appreciate breakfast out of the house more and more. Either as a solitary occasion to gather my thoughts, take time out, and plan for the day, or as a social event with a like-minded early riser, usually a fellow entrepreneur in my case, such as my good friend and local businessman Gunter, who is in the sex shop business, but that is a curious side note. We all know having variety in your personal and business network is wise!
So, after doing the rounds and trying several breakfast places out, a few good, some mediocre, and many terrible, I want to document my own personal top 4 in Barcelona.
If you are looking for coffee shops or patisseries, this will not be the article for you. There is an abundance of these in the city. Being an amateur athlete (I say that very loosely, as if football and gym sessions count for something) and a growing boy, I need some protein for breakfast, so to qualify for my list, the places needed to have some solid egg-based or protein dishes as menu mainstays. Also, and I must be pedantic on this, I am talking strictly about breakfast, and not what has come to be the trend in recent years — dare I say it — brunch! Please allow me to go on a tangent here before we get to my list, but I am pretty much anti-brunch and anti a lot of what brunch represents. Don’t get me wrong, the dishes are nice, but the concept of mid-morning eating of what is essentially breakfast for late risers and posers is not my cup of tea. I’m here for the good old-fashioned pre-10:00 a.m. breakfast, or 08:00 on the dot if I can get it.
So here is my list, as a local in Barcelona and in no particular order of ranking:
№1: El Corte Inglés
Plaça de Catalunya, 14, 08002 Barcelona
Classic, no-nonsense, and great price point. Open from 09:00, you can choose from either an omelette and toast or freshly made Tortilla de Patatas with toast. Located pretty centrally in Plaza Catalunya.
№2: Café de l’Architecte
Rambla de Catalunya, 76, 08008 Barcelona (attached to Hotel Condes de Barcelona)
A bar and restaurant attached to the hotel Hotel Condes which sits on the corner of Rambla Catalunya with Passatge de la Concepció. It’s a nice spot and an intimate meeting point. Open from 09:00, it would be great if it opened at 08:00, but I guess they don’t see too much demand for that. They offer a nice variation of choices and additional ingredients for your omelette or scrambled eggs. If they were to add some artisanal coffee and tea options, to their menu it would be a plus, but I will cut them some slack on this, as the establishment has an air of the traditional to it.
№3: Billy Brunch
Various locations throughout the city.
One of the best for options, variety, and choice. It’s probably better known as a brunch spot, but it opens at 09:30 for people like myself who value breakfast over brunch. I’ve been to various locations of theirs throughout the city, and I’m yet to be disappointed by the service. There is thought attached to the attention to detail of the service at Billy Brunch, which I love especially because Barcelona restaurants often struggle to offer good service, mainly because they probably don’t feel they need to make an effort with such a high footfall of tourists and transient clientele walking in. Billy Brunch however bucks that trend, and they make a fantastic Chai Latte, one of the better ones in the city actually which is always a plus for me as someone who doesn’t drink coffee.
№4: Citizen Café
Pl. d’Urquinaona, 4, L’Eixample, 08010 Barcelona
One of the few good breakfast places in Barcelona that opens from 08:00. This spot became my place for post-early-morning gym session fuelling. Located in Urquinaona and with a wide variety of menu options, this is breakfast done well and at the proper time for those of us who have busy days ahead and things to get on with. The staff have been very pleasant here in my experience. Like the other options that serve brunch, this place starts to fill up quite quickly. It’s been a few weeks since I’ve been myself, so I’m looking forward to heading back here soon.
There might be some options that are new or that I am not aware of. I typically value a central location if I am meeting people, so maybe there are local spots in Barcelona’s neighbourhoods that I should consider. By the way, if you’re local and in business like myself and fancy joining me next time for a networking breakfast, shoot me a message. Remember, breakfast not brunch! And if you are visiting this wonderful city and looking for some early-opening, good options for breakfast, then I hope you enjoy these recommendations and let me know how you get on with them in the comments.

Title: FC Barcelona’s AI Revolution: Transforming Performance and Fan Experience
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Have you ever wondered how a storied club like FC Barcelona tackles financial challenges while enhancing fan engagement? In today’s evolving sports landscape, Barcelona has embraced artificial intelligence (AI) as a crucial tool for improvement. By integrating AI into various operations, the club aims to elevate on-field performance, enhance fan experiences, and make smarter financial decisions. This transformation illustrates how innovation can lead to sustainable success in a highly competitive environment.
In recent years, Barcelona has faced significant financial hurdles, accumulating a staggering debt of €1.35 billion. In light of this daunting reality, the club recognized the importance of harnessing technology to strengthen connections with its vast global fan base. The sports world has seen how data-driven approaches can personalize experiences, enabling organizations to better understand and cater to the preferences of their supporters. By leveraging AI, Barcelona is positioning itself to innovate and thrive amidst challenges.
One of Barcelona’s innovative steps into AI is the implementation of AI-powered chatbots designed to engage fans in real time. These chatbots provide personalized content based on individual preferences, making interactions feel tailored and efficient. Fans can quickly find answers to questions about ticket purchases or player stats, simulating a conversation with a knowledgeable friend. This not only enhances the fan experience but also drives merchandise sales. Studies show that 69% of consumers prefer chatbots for fast communication with brands, reflecting the growing expectation for swift responses in today’s digital world.
These chatbots are adept at handling up to 80% of routine customer service inquiries, freeing up human agents to focus on more complex issues. In many industries, organizations have turned to AI to enhance customer service, enabling faster responses and improving overall satisfaction. Barcelona’s approach illustrates a blend of technology and personal touch, emphasizing the importance of understanding fan needs and preferences.
Barcelona has also embraced AI algorithms to analyze fan data and deliver personalized content. By tailoring news articles, videos, and social media posts to individual preferences, the club significantly enhances the overall engagement of its supporters. The club’s dedicated Twitter account for personalized content has witnessed a remarkable 30% increase in engagement compared to its main account. This level of engagement mirrors the success of leading brands that utilize consumer data to create relevant experiences, ultimately driving sales.
Furthermore, this personalized content strategy has resulted in a 25% increase in the time fans spend on Barcelona’s digital platforms. Insights from behavioral psychology emphasize that when users feel valued and recognized, they are more likely to engage with a brand. By leveraging AI for tailored content, Barcelona fosters a deeper connection with its supporters, ensuring they feel appreciated and involved in the club’s journey.
Barcelona’s commitment to innovation extends to its training facilities through a partnership with Pixellot, which has developed AI-based video analysis systems. This technology automates the recording of training sessions and matches, providing coaches with in-depth insights into player performance. In the competitive world of sports, analytics have become essential, much like how successful teams leverage data to inform strategies and enhance player development.
The impact of AI-driven video analysis has been significant, with coverage now expanded to 16 pitches across Barcelona’s complexes. This increased visibility has enabled the club to broadcast previously unproduced youth matches, resulting in a staggering 40% increase in viewership. Such advancements illustrate how data analytics can reveal opportunities that might otherwise go unnoticed, allowing teams to engage more deeply with fans and cultivate future talent.
In addition to enhancing fan interactions and on-field performance, Barcelona utilizes AI tools to analyze fan preferences and behaviors. This strategic approach allows the club to create more effective marketing strategies and build deeper connections with its audience. For example, AI-driven insights have led to a remarkable 20% increase in merchandise sales, illustrating the power of targeted marketing efforts.
Moreover, Barcelona has achieved a 15% improvement in fan engagement metrics across its digital platforms. This proactive stance reflects the importance of data-driven decision-making in today’s business landscape, where understanding consumer behavior can lead to substantial gains. These insights highlight how critical it is for organizations to stay attuned to the needs and desires of their audience.
The cumulative impact of these AI-driven initiatives has been impressive. Barcelona has reported a 35% increase in digital engagement year-over-year and has expanded its global fan base from 250 million to an estimated 350 million supporters. This growth illustrates that fans are not just passive observers; they are actively involved in the club’s journey and development.
While the advancements in AI present a promising future, the club also faces challenges, particularly in data collection. Despite its massive fan base, as of 2022, Barcelona held detailed data on only about 1% of its supporters, highlighting a critical area for improvement. This situation emphasizes the need for organizations to continually enhance their data strategies to build stronger connections with their audiences.
Barcelona’s successful integration of AI not only enhances performance but also presents a unique business opportunity model for other clubs and organizations. By focusing on fan engagement, personalized marketing, and data analysis, sports teams can cultivate a loyal fan base and drive revenue growth. The lessons learned from Barcelona’s journey serve as a blueprint for others looking to navigate similar challenges and harness the power of technology in sports.
Moreover, this model isn’t limited to sports; businesses in various sectors can leverage similar strategies. The principles of personalization and data-driven decision-making are increasingly becoming standard practices across industries. In a world where consumer preferences are constantly evolving, understanding and adapting to these changes is essential for long-term success.
Ultimately, Barcelona’s journey into AI amidst financial struggles offers valuable life lessons. The ability to adapt to changing circumstances is vital, both in sports and in life. By embracing innovation, individuals and businesses can overcome obstacles and create new opportunities. As author and philosopher Alain de Botton reminds us in The Art of Travel: “We are often at our most interesting when we are in a state of uncertainty.” Barcelona’s story illustrates how a shared passion for the game can unite fans and inspire creative problem-solving.
As we reflect on Barcelona’s commitment to AI and fan engagement, it’s clear that the essence of connection — whether with fans, customers, or communities — remains paramount. Building relationships rooted in understanding and empathy can lead to enduring success. In a world of rapid change, the lessons learned from Barcelona’s experience serve as a reminder that with innovation and resilience, the future can be brighter than ever. (Dadang Irsyamuddin)

Title: My Barcelona Adventure: Embracing the Perilous Path
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
In the words of the celebrated author Paulo Coelho, “The danger of adventure is worth a thousand days of ease and comfort.” With this profound quotation in mind, I embarked on a thrilling journey to the captivating city of Barcelona. Armed with an open heart and a sense of wanderlust, I set out to explore the enchanting streets, immerse myself in the vibrant culture, and discover the untold stories that lay hidden beneath its façade. Little did I know that this adventure would lead me to encounter unexpected encounters with diverse souls from across the globe, each contributing to the kaleidoscope of experiences that shaped my time in Barcelona. Join me as I unravel the tale of my adventurous sojourn, where the allure of the unknown merged seamlessly with the promise of self-discovery. This is a chronicle of courage, resilience, and the magic that unfolds when we dare to step outside our comfort zones and embrace the uncharted path. Welcome to My Barcelona Adventure.
Making the trip
Attending an international school with the power of a Schengen passport and having a bunch of GenZ classmates, I felt the pressure to travel, explore the world, and find peace out of my comfort zone. It took me five months to gather the courage to leave Madrid. Initially, I had plans to visit a Liberian in Barcelona whom I didn’t know much about, but she had assured me of taking good care of me and showing me around the city. Our conversation started back in November 2022, and I had considered traveling in December 2022 during our most extended school break when everyone was going to their home country to see their family and loved ones. However, I had to prioritize completing my NIE process — to obtain a resident permit for my studies at IE Business School. Then, I postponed the trip to January 2023, and later to February 2023, feeling unsure and indecisive. Finally, I decided to take the plunge and booked a train within a week, thanks to the stipend from my scholarship.
I informed my Liberian “host” that I was finally coming to Barcelona. I shared my travel details and attempted to have a phone conversation, but she was primarily busy or unresponsive. Nonetheless, I didn’t ask her directly if she would be hosting me, as she had previously promised to show me around.
The scheduled trip was set for 8 pm after the end of our second term, and while everyone else seemed excited, I found myself feeling a bit bored (details that I will highlight in a subsequent blog). But despite the mixed emotions, there was an underlying sense of excitement as I was finally going to spend an amazing weekend in Barcelona. Everything was seemingly set for my adventure.
Dammit!
Just as I was about to board the train to Barcelona, I received a message from my host:
“Did you book an Airbnb?”
Oh no! I realized that I had made a mistake. I should have clarified the accommodation arrangements with her beforehand. I replied, admitting that I hadn’t booked an Airbnb, but I also didn’t explicitly mention my assumption that she would be hosting me. During the two-hour trip from Madrid to Barcelona, I frantically searched for a suitable and affordable Airbnb, but to my dismay, the prices were about 20% higher in Barcelona compared to Madrid. I couldn’t find any suitable option during the train journey, and so I arrived in Barcelona Sants, the train station, without a place to stay.
My Liberian “host” had initially assured me that she would pick me up from Barcelona Sants upon my arrival. However, as I reached out to inform her of my presence, she regretfully informed me that she couldn’t fulfill her promise. Her friend, who was supposed to provide the transportation, had become occupied with other matters. I found myself stranded at Barcelona Sants, the clock ticking closer to midnight, and the weight of the situation settling upon me.
In this unexpected situation, I had no choice but to find an available Airbnb and get myself out of the train station as soon as possible. The stress of the moment was mounting, and I knew I had to act swiftly to secure a place to stay for the night.
Fortunately, I managed to find a suitable place called Hola Hostel, which perfectly fit my criteria of being affordable and charming. The added bonus was its convenient location, just a short 3-minute walk away from Spotify Camp Nou. With a sense of relief, I made my way to the nearest metro station, ready to face the challenges of navigating Barcelona without the aid of Google Maps since my phone had switched off.
Despite the hurdles and occasional moments of uncertainty, I arrived safely at Hola Hostel. The staff was welcoming, and I arranged my accommodation for the next two nights. It felt like a small victory, given the earlier setback, and I was eager to make the most of my time in Barcelona, even without my phone’s constant guidance.
I went to bed by 2:00 AM
The Indian Couple
When I arrived at Hola Hostel, I immediately headed for a refreshing shower in one of the bathrooms. The following day, on February 25, 2023, I returned to the bathroom to brush my teeth but inadvertently left my toothpaste behind. Upon getting my toothpaste and exiting the bathroom, I bumped into a friendly lady named Divya, who was standing at the door. I could tell from her expression that she was a bit surprised to see me, as the bathroom was probably designated for females only. Realizing my mistake, I felt a bit embarrassed, but Divya was understanding and welcoming, which helped ease my discomfort.
In an attempt to make up for my awkward encounter, I struck up a conversation with Divya. Curious to know more about her, I asked where she was from. She shared that she was from India and currently studying in Austria. Learning that she was also a tourist like me, I asked about her plans for the day. I had little faith in my Liberian “host”, given the earlier miscommunication, and was looking for an enjoyable day out in Barcelona. Divya mentioned that she and her boyfriend, Kabir, were going to the stadium, specifically Camp Nou. To my surprise, she kindly invited me to join them.
Although I had initially hoped for a spontaneous adventure with a fellow solo traveler, I was still excited to explore Camp Nou with the couple. Despite my mixed emotions, I found Kabir to be friendly and welcoming as well. Our trip to the stadium turned out to be a wonderful experience, and I was grateful for the unexpected company and the opportunity to share this adventure with new friends.
After Camp Nou, what’s next?
Everyone should visit Camp Nou or a football stadium as beautiful and historic as Camp Nou at least once in their lifetime. Even though I am not a Barcelona fan, my visit to Camp Nou brought me closer to the team, enriched me with its history, and made me appreciate the beauty of football even more. We embarked on a comprehensive 360 tour of the stadium, and in my enthusiasm, I found myself lagging behind a couple of times, giving them some privacy for romantic moments, and bombarding them with numerous questions. Divya and Kabir, while initially patient, seemed to become a bit exasperated with my curiosity.
At the end of the tour, they mentioned that they were planning to find an Indian restaurant to have lunch. However, when I asked to join them, they hesitated and said they would be meeting some friends, leaving me to figure out my next move. It was already 1:00 pm, and I hadn’t received any communication from my Liberian “host” yet. The uncertainty of my situation started to weigh on me as I contemplated what to do next in this unfamiliar city.
After the somewhat awkward situation at Spotify Camp Nou, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I spotted a McDonald’s nearby and saw it as an opportunity to charge my phone and grab some lunch. It was a relieving break, allowing me to regroup and plan my next steps.
Around 2:00 PM, I finally received a response from my Liberian “host”. She once again apologized for not being able to pick me up from the Hostel as promised, explaining that her friend was occupied. While I appreciated her honesty, I couldn’t help but feel a bit disappointed by the turn of events. Nevertheless, we had a brief chat, and she recommended some places for me to explore in Barcelona.
Equipped with her suggestions and a charged phone, I set out to make the most of the remainder of the day. I embraced the idea of navigating the city on my own, using the newfound freedom to delve into the sights and sounds of Barcelona, appreciating every moment of this unplanned adventure.
With a sense of excitement and curiosity, I made up my mind to visit the renowned Sagrada Familia, the largest unfinished Roman Catholic church in the world. I navigated my way to the nearest metro station, and to my delight, I encountered a kind-hearted Colombian individual who communicated with me through sign language. Sergio’s warm demeanor and willingness to assist me made me feel at ease.
With Sergoi’s help, I confirmed that I was headed in the right direction to reach Sagrada Familia. He even suggested a sightseeing tour of the exterior of the magnificent building, which seemed like a wonderful idea to me. Instead of paying 50 euros to see the interior, I opted for the chance to marvel at the breathtaking architecture from the outside.
Throughout the journey on the metro, Sergio continued to wear a beautiful smile, making me feel grateful for their company and guidance. He reminded me to be careful and watchful during our ride together, emphasizing the importance of safety.
I arrived at my destination and bid Sergio farewell as he was stopping at the next metro and I couldn’t help but feel a sense of gratitude for this serendipitous encounter. I embarked on my sightseeing adventure, eager to explore the awe-inspiring beauty of Sagrada Familia, while cherishing the memory of the unexpected friendship formed through a shared moment of communication.
Oh my gosh!
Sagrada Familia is indeed a breathtaking marvel. This awe-inspiring cathedral, designed by the visionary architect Antoni Gaudí, commenced its construction in 1882. Gaudí’s artistic genius and innovative architectural concepts have left an indelible mark on the world, making Sagrada Familia a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate hearts and minds.
Standing outside Sagrada Familia felt like stepping into a diverse paradise. Conversations in English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese intermingled, creating a vibrant tapestry of languages and cultures. The scene was nothing short of beautiful, with a lively and diverse crowd filling the air with excitement and energy. Among the approximately 200 people surrounding me, all on their own purported pilgrimage to this grand cathedral, I stood as a solo traveler, somewhat frustrated with my Liberian “host”, yet elated to be present at Sagrada Familia in that very moment.
At the cathedral’s entrance, a multitude of tourists buzzed with activity, some trying to enter, while others were exiting. The atmosphere was warm and electric, as people chatted, danced, sang, and savored their meals. The ambiance was alive with a festive spirit.
I took my time exploring the surroundings, capturing precious moments through photographs, walking amidst the crowd, and savoring the melodic tunes of Spanish guitarists. However, after about an hour and thirty minutes, I craved a different experience. The time neared 5:00 PM, and still, there had been no word from my Liberian “host”.
Abdelali and how we found each other
Just as I was about to check my phone and prepare to leave the grounds of Sagrada Familia, a gentle touch on my back startled me. Hoping to find a fellow solo traveler, perhaps an English-speaking lady, eager to explore like myself, I turned around, only to meet the gaze of a fair-skinned young man with a shy expression. He stood at an average height, and with a friendly smile, he made a simple request, “Can you take my picture?”
Intrigued, I gladly obliged and inquired about his name. He introduced himself as Abdelali, a Moroccan student studying in France, who had come to Barcelona for a vacation. Abdelali, as it turned out, was quite the seasoned traveler himself. Having lived in Ukraine and explored various destinations within the Schengen area, he had accumulated a wealth of experiences and stories.
Our conversation flowed effortlessly as I expressed my eagerness for the next adventure and sought his recommendations. “Can we go to the beach?” I asked him. Graciously, Abdelali agreed to accompany me on this new escapade, explaining that he also had a booking issue to resolve with an Airbnb on the nearby beach.
With a newfound travel companion by my side, I felt a renewed sense of excitement and anticipation. Barcelona’s beach beckoned, and with Abdelali as my guide, I knew this impromptu journey would be filled with unforgettable moments and the shared joy of exploration. Together, we embarked on our beach adventure, ready to embrace the unknown and cherish the bond formed through the serendipity of travel.
Within about 30 minutes, Abdelali and I managed to find the nearest metro station, and with ease, we hopped on a bus that swiftly transported us to Barceloneta, the most renowned and beloved beach in Barcelona. As my eyes beheld the splendor of the beach, the swaying palm trees, and the vast expanse of the ocean, my soul felt an immediate revival. The stress and worries of the day seemed to dissipate, replaced by a profound sense of relief, and I prepared to immerse myself in the wonders of nature.
It had been a long five months since I last set eyes on a beach, and Barceloneta turned out to be the most stunning one I had ever encountered. The beach exuded a lively and vibrant atmosphere, adorned with the rhythmic sounds of Spanish music and the delightful aroma of typical Spanish cuisine that enveloped the air. The sun radiated warmth, casting its golden rays upon everything in its path, bringing joy to every heart and a smile to every face.
As I strolled along the shoreline, my spirit lifted with every turn and every glance at the people around me. The beach was a lively tapestry of young and old people engaged in joyful activities such as singing, dancing, riding bicycles, or simply relishing delightful conversations with their friends. After assisting Abdelali in resolving his Airbnb issue, I couldn’t resist the allure of the ocean any longer. With a hunger to inhale its salty breeze and bask in its refreshing embrace, I rushed towards the waves, ready to surrender myself to the soothing rhythm of the sea.
At that moment, under the azure sky, surrounded by laughter, music, and shimmering waters, I felt a profound sense of gratitude. Barcelona had unexpectedly gifted me a beautiful beach experience, and with Abdelali by my side, the day unfolded as a serendipitous tale of camaraderie and delight. The wonders of nature had worked their magic, and I couldn’t help but sigh in relief, cherishing the blissful escapade that was Barceloneta.
Abdelali and I continued our exploration of Barcelona, hopping on a bus that traversed the city’s vibrant streets. Our journey led us to two more captivating destinations — the Arena de Barcelona and the Barcelona Magic Fountain. At each location, I couldn’t help but marvel at the exuberant merrymaking, the infectious music, and the palpable joy of adventure that surrounded us.
Throughout our day together, Abdelali and I forged a deep bond, sharing laughter, stories, and a genuine sense of camaraderie. As the clock neared 8 pm, we found ourselves at the mesmerizing Barcelona Magic Fountain. The atmosphere was nothing short of enchanting, with the grand building overlooking the fountain, creating a mountain-like backdrop that added to the fountain’s allure. The music that resonated through the air had a captivating effect on Abdelali, making him hesitant to leave the scene.
However, despite the temptation to stay longer, I needed to see my Liberian “host” who had been elusive throughout the day. We made a compromise; I assured Abdelali that I would find her and catch up afterward. He understood my situation, and with a sense of excitement, we made plans to explore Barcelona’s vibrant nightlife, heading to clubs and reveling in the city’s after-dark magic.
Our shared adventure had been a rollercoaster of emotions, from the initial frustration with my “host” to the serendipitous encounter with Abdelali that led to a day filled with joy and discovery. As we set off on our respective paths for the moment, I knew that this chance encounter had added a touch of magic to my Barcelona adventure. With the promise of an exhilarating night ahead, I felt a renewed sense of anticipation, eager to embrace whatever the night had in store for us.
Dammit!
I must admit, I found myself in quite a predicament. As I bid farewell to Abdelali, my phone battery was barely holding on at a mere 1%. I felt a tinge of embarrassment, knowing that I had my charger with me but no power bank to rely on. The truth was, I had underestimated how terrible my iPhone 8’s battery life had become, simply because I spent most of my time either at school or home, where a stable electricity supply was always at hand.
Despite the low battery, I couldn’t shake the urge to meet my elusive Liberian “host.” There was an inexplicable determination within me, perhaps fueled by the need to confirm her existence or to consider this trip a resounding success. Regardless of the reason, I knew I had to see her. There was no room for giving up now.
With the address she sent me, I asked Abdelali to help me navigate using Google Maps. Together, we discovered the nearest metro station and embarked on the journey. The destination seemed distant, approximately 45 minutes away, spanning 11 metro stations, and requiring two train changes.
As I reached the final metro station, I finally managed to charge my phone and mustered the courage to call my Liberian “host.” A deep breath of relief escaped me as I spoke to her in our familiar Liberian parlance, “I am here oo, come for me na.” There was a mix of emotions swirling within me, ranging from anticipation to trepidation, as I eagerly awaited her arrival. This moment would mark the culmination of a day filled with unexpected twists and turns, making it all the more meaningful
But apparently, I had gone to a different province. The address Abdelali put on the map was the name of the address as my Liberian “ host”, but it was in the wrong province. She lived out of central Barcelona and when I checked Google Maps, it was about 1 hour by metro and 30 minutes by taxi at the cost of 35 euros. Should I visit my Liberian “host” by 11:00 PM? If yes, how?
Stuck on the train with a Chinese lady at midnight
After an intense period of brainstorming and careful consideration, lasting about 30 minutes, I finally reached a decision. I opted to take the metro, convinced that it would offer a relatively seamless journey, granted I exercised a fair amount of patience. Thus, I embarked on the one-hour metro trip to reach my elusive Liberian “host.”
As the journey commenced, I was filled with a mix of anticipation and determination. The initial phase consisted of the first two metro stops, followed by a train transfer to reach Cardanyola del Valles in the Ripollet province of Barcelona. Navigating my way to the train station posed quite the challenge, compounded by my phone’s meager 20% battery life and the time being around 11:45 PM. The streets were dimly lit, and the cold night air only added to the intensity of the situation.
Undeterred, I forged ahead, maneuvering through the darkness with a blend of courage and concern. The gravity of my determination to meet my Liberian “host” kept me going, outweighing the difficulties I faced. At this point, the journey had transformed into a personal mission — a testament to my refusal to surrender and my unwavering commitment to finally meet the person I had been seeking throughout the day.
I boarded the train to Cardanyola del Valles with a sense of immense relief. At long last, I had reached the final leg of my journey, even though I still had to walk approximately 12 minutes from the train station to my Liberian “host’s” residence. I repeatedly checked my phone, ensuring that I was on the correct train and that the timing was right. Everything seemed to be proceeding as planned until an unexpected turn of events occurred when the train abruptly stopped, just two stops away from my intended destination. The other passengers disembarked, and I couldn’t help but wonder if there were more people boarding, or if there was some other reason for the halt. However, my assumption was swiftly proven wrong when the train’s Spanish-speaking driver stepped off and exclaimed, “Estamos deteniéndonos aquí,” which translates to “We are stopping here” in English. Though my Spanish was quite rusty, I grasped the meaning of “aquí,” which meant “here.”
It was at that very moment that a surge of fear coursed through me. The time was around 12:45 AM, and after an entire night of navigating challenges to meet a fellow Liberian, I was now trapped on a stationary train. Looking outside, all I could see were bushes, and the sound of young Spaniards conversing loudly and smoking cigarettes filled the air. Inside the train, I encountered a Chinese lady who appeared shy and possessed a beauty reminiscent of my Chinese classmate, Shuwen. While I couldn’t recall her name, I distinctly remembered the flood of relief that washed over me upon seeing her. Unlike me, her English was limited, and her Spanish, much like mine, left room for serious improvement. Despite the language barrier, we managed to engage in conversation, during which she revealed that she was headed to the second-to-last stop to visit a friend.
At that moment, my sense of altruism took hold. I became more concerned about helping my newfound Chinese friend solve her predicament than I was about finding my Liberian “host.” The night had woven together a fusion of unexpected connections and challenges, revealing the shared threads of humanity that linked us all, regardless of language or origin.
About Alex, the Russian who save my life on the train tracks
After approximately 20 minutes of wandering and conversation, we spotted a train approaching. I halted, and my Chinese friend-in-adventure and I quickly boarded the train. We could not find a Spanish speaker to help us and after the first stop, my friend decided to get off the train. Outside, the night seemed even colder and darker. In the span of 30 seconds, I bombarded her with about five questions, seeking to understand her decision. It became clear that her exit wasn’t due to reaching her intended destination; rather, she appeared quite fearful. Driven by concern for her well-being and a genuine curiosity about her journey, I chose to disembark as well. The time was now around 1:00 AM. Once off the train, she explained that she needed to make this particular stop as it was en route to her destination. However, undertaking this part of her journey alone felt risky, and I pondered whether tagging along might be both a wise and foolish choice for me. I was now faced with the task of charting my own course, yet I had absolutely no clue about my whereabouts.
A few minutes later, we spotted a small group of people across the train tracks. Approaching them, we sought their assistance. As it turned out, they were all headed to the same destination as my friend-in-adventure. A train was due to arrive in just about two minutes. However, when I inquired about my own destination, they appeared to lack information. In those two minutes, I ensured my friend-in-adventure safely boarded the train and bid her farewell. By this point, it was around 1:30 AM, and I found myself alone in an unfamiliar place, my phone powerless and surrounded by the symphony of crickets and frogs. With no inkling of my next steps, I was neither exhilarated by the adventurous thrills nor paralyzed by fear for my safety. I existed in a state of numbness, yet my mind remained incredibly sharp, retaining every encounter and every detail of my intended destination. While placing my faith in God, I desperately needed a tangible guide to direct my earthly path.
After around 10 minutes of aimless contemplation under the dim, cold darkness, I spotted a figure on the other side of the train tracks. He had apparently been standing there for some time, but I hadn’t noticed until now. Swiftly, I made my way towards the man, who possessed distinct Asian features and carried a red Ghana must-go bag. Though I knew nothing about him other than his vague outline, he represented my best chance at finding my way. Upon reaching him, I initiated the conversation in English. While he didn’t respond verbally, his attentive gaze indicated he was listening. When I queried in broken Spanish, “¿Tú hablas español?” (Do you speak Spanish?), he didn’t reply verbally but signaled his inability. This encounter made it evident that he was neither fluent in English nor Spanish. I surmised that he might be from Eastern Europe or Asia, far from home like myself, wandering to his next destination.
Drawing from my limited knowledge of sign language acquired during my brief stint in the Ivory Coast and my early days in Madrid, I managed to communicate with him. Employing these rudimentary gestures, I conveyed my need to use his phone. He gave me his device, and we embarked on a conversation through Google Translate. He introduced himself as Alex, a Russian awaiting the last train that was bound for the same destination as mine. Alex was going to the final stop, and my destination, Cardanyola del Valles, was only one stop away.
Alex was the first Russian I had ever encountered, and his demeanor was as kind as Sergio’s and his willingness to help was reminiscent of Adullai’s. If Alex hadn’t been willing to engage in conversation, provide access to his phone, and offer assistance, I might have spent the night in the middle of nowhere. I might never have met my Liberian “host,” and the course of events could have taken an even more unpredictable turn.
Through a series of coincidences, connections, and the kindness of strangers, I was granted a lifeline just when I needed it most. Alex became an unwitting guardian angel, guiding me out of uncertainty and ensuring I continued my journey, determined to finally meet my Liberian “host” and unlock the mysteries that the night held.
Palm Butter at 3:00 AM
Around 2:00 AM, I arrived at Cardanyola del Valles. The early morning atmosphere was tinged with gloom and solitude. A final challenge lay ahead: a 12-minute walk to reach my Liberian “host.” As I disembarked from the train station, a faint light caught my attention in the distance. I presumed it was a shop, and with a willingness to seize any opportunity, I walked for about five minutes until I reached it. There, I intended to grab a drink and recharge my phone. The women at the shop were hospitable, providing a momentary respite. I used the opportunity to charge my phone and dialed my Liberian “host’s” number. She offered me the most quintessentially Liberian direction: “Walk straight, and as soon as you cross the bridge, turn right.”
Around 2:15 AM, while the ladies at the shop were accommodating, they were also closing for the night. Following my Liberian “host’s” instructions, I proceeded to walk straight and made a right turn after crossing the bridge. However, I couldn’t locate the street address on any of the buildings. After asking numerous strangers and continuing to walk straight while crossing the bridge, I found myself in a perplexing situation. It was then that a couple of helpful strangers informed me that I needed to cross the second bridge, which was around 5 minutes away from the first one I had crossed.
My unease was amplified by the darkness and the unpredictable behavior of some of the strangers I encountered. Observing a nearby McDonald’s, I decided to reach out to my Liberian “host” and inform her that I was unable to proceed any further. The sense of vulnerability I felt in that unfamiliar environment prompted me to prioritize my safety, especially given the hour and the unfamiliar surroundings.
I stayed at the McDonald’s, and within three minutes, I spotted my Liberian “host” walking in, accompanied by another woman. The sight of her erased the earlier feelings of anger, pain, and frustration I had experienced due to her initial inability to provide the support I had expected. In hindsight, I realized that my emotions were more about my own journey than just meeting my Liberian “host.” I felt a surge of happiness, not just because I was seeing her, but because I had refused to give up. I persisted, demonstrated resilience, and come out stronger despite the challenges.
Shortly thereafter, at around 3:00 AM, I found myself on my Liberian friend’s couch, indulging in a familiar dish from Liberia: palm butter and rice. It had been about seven months since I last enjoyed this meal, and its rich flavors and satisfying taste were a welcome treat. Sitting there, I felt a sense of belonging and comfort that I hadn’t experienced in a while. The moment was surreal — encountering a fellow Liberian, savoring a dish from my homeland, and conversing in our native Liberian parlance. No longer did I need to slow down my speech, alter my accent, or speak in standard English, nonstop. I could simply be myself, unapologetically embracing my identity and roots.
My Liberian host was nice after all
My Liberian host greeted me warmly, embracing me with open arms and a genuine sense of hospitality. She willingly shared stories of her own experiences living in Madrid, revealing the mutual connections we had. As we conversed, she emerged as someone who enjoyed a good time but was also driven by a hustling spirit. Having completed her MBA a few years back, she had chosen Spain as her home away from home, embracing it as a place of growth and opportunity.
Finally, the moment arrived when I had the chance to ride in my Liberian host friend’s car, a sleek gray Highlander. Throughout the journey, we played Liberian songs, immersing ourselves in the melodies that connected us to our roots. Eventually, they dropped me off at Hola Hostel, my Airbnb, around 4:00 AM.
The next morning, I awoke and embarked on the train back to Madrid by 1:00 PM.
My trip to Barcelona will forever hold a place as my second most cherished experience in Spain. I am grateful that I allowed myself to fully live through it and finally got the opportunity to share my story with you. I anticipate sharing this story with my grandchildren someday.
Above all, this adventure taught me the importance of proper planning, but even more significantly, it unveiled the beauty of embracing spontaneity.

The House on Tibidabo in The Shadow of the Wind
One day during our trip to Barcelona a few years ago we decided to ride all the way to the top of Mount Tibidabo, the highest hill in the city. We had to ride on three separate means of transportation to get to the top, but we did it!
First of all, we walked to the Metro station at Placa de Catalunya and boarded the brown line (L7) train which took us to the base of Avenguda Tibidabo. Then we walked across the street from the Metro exit to board the Tramvia Blau, an old streetcar line, which brought us halfway up the mountain. Finally, we transferred to the Funicular de Tibidabo to get to the top.
There at the top we found an old amusement park adjacent to a Catholic church called Temple Expiatori del Sagrat Cor (The Expiatory Temple of the Sacred Heart). You can see this church and some of the park’s rides from just about anywhere in Barcelona. And we soon found out that you can get one of the best views of Barcelona from the roof of this church.
In Carlos Ruiz Zafon’s masterpiece The Shadow of the Wind we follow Daniel Sempere as he traces the journey of Julian Carax (the author of a book also called The Shadow of the Wind) to the Tibidabo mansion where his love Penelope resides. Zafon himself loved to ride the tram and then the funicular to the top and gaze at the view of Barcelona. The tram opened in 1901 and the blue cars reminded me of San Francisco’s fabled cable cars. It was thrilling to consider that we may have ridden on the same car that carried both Zafon and Sempere up Tibidabo.
There are many turn-of-the-century mansions that line the slopes of Tibidabo. The most prominent is El Pinar, the home of the banker Manuel Arnus near the base of the funicular and the end of the line of the blue tram. I photographed this house after exiting the funicular on the way back down Tibidabo. I at first thought that this was Zafon’s mansion but later discovered that Zafon himself told us that the address of Torre Aldaya in The Shadow of the Wind was Avenguda Tibidabo 32, which is a few hundred meters down the hill. The building at this address is not as gothic looking like El Pinar and Zafon probably combined the appearances of several Tibidabo mansions when he imagined Torre Aldaya. The building at # 32 is now the Hotel Mirlo, a five-star boutique hotel.
El Pinar was designed by the famous architect Enric Sagnier in 1902 and the house was completed in 1904. Sagnier also designed the magnificent Sagrat Cor at the top of Tibidabo. The church’s crypt was built between 1902 and 1911 and construction of the upper church began in 1915. Sagnier’s son Josep Maria Sagnier completed the construction in 1961. The original statue of the Sacred Heart on the roof of the church was destroyed during the Spanish Civil War in 1936. The present statue, by Josep Miret, was completed in 1950. In this photo one of Christ’s apostles overlooks Barcelona and the huge communications tower on the next hill.
I understand the Tramvia Blau is presently closed for reconstruction. There is a bus (# 196) that now connects the Metro with the funicular.
Zafon wrote The Shadow of the Wind in 2002. It was translated into English by Lucia Graves in 2009. I came across it in early 2015 and immediately began plans for a trip to Barcelona and we flew to Spain later that year. The second book in the cycle Zafon has named The Cemetery of Forgotten Books is called The Angel’s Game. I read most of that book on the plane and finished it during our stay in Barcelona. It is a prequel to The Shadow of the Wind. I then read the third book in the cycle, The Prisoner of Heaven, shortly after returning from our trip. Lucia Graves, the excellent translator of Zafon’s Spanish works, completed the translation of The Labyrinth of the Spirits in 2019. I didn’t get around to reading it until last year. Then I reread the other three books and enjoyed them considerably. I’ll probably read all of them again someday.
Zafon was born in Barcelona in 1964 and later moved to Los Angeles where he wrote screenplays in English. But he wrote all of his fiction in Spanish. He died of cancer in 2020 at the age of 55.
Most of the actions in The Shadow of the Wind take place in the Bari Gotic and Raval neighborhoods south of Placa de Catalunya. Visitors to Barcelona can sign up for a three-hour literary walking tour that covers these areas. Tibidabo is too far away to be included in this tour, however. We didn’t take the walking tour, but we came across many of Zafon’s landmarks while following a couple of walks that Rick Steves recommends in his Pocket Barcelona.
Tibidabo gets its name from two Latin words: dabo meaning “I will give” and tibi meaning “to you.” For more info on Barcelona’s highest hill see my Crow Canyon Journal blog postings here and here. Better yet, read either an English version of the Bible or St Jerome’s translation into Latin of Matthew 4:09. And then read all four books in The Cemetery of Forgotten Books cycle for the full story of the Semperes, Daniel’s friend Fermin Romero de Torres, and that haunted mansion halfway up Mount Tibidabo.

Title: Why you too should travel to Barcelona, Spain
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Listen
Share
For me, Barcelona is the city of self-awakening. After my fair share of solo traveling between London, Prague, and Paris, I can passionately say that the connection I had with Barcelona is totally unmatched. It’s the people, it’s the culture, it’s the language (Catalan), it’s the food, it’s the art, it’s every little thing that has made me fall deeply in love with this beautiful Catalan city.
In just one week’s time (or less), you too can experience all that Barcelona has to offer, from its thriving street art scene to all the local cuisines, there is plenty to see in the city that truly never sleeps.
Day 1: My experience at Camp Nou Stadium
To my surprise, I landed in Barcelona at the perfect time! It was the weekend of the La Mercè festival where many people filled the streets for four days in celebration of the Roman Catholic Feast Day of Our Lady. Many celebrations happened all over the main streets of Barcelona where there was live music, various street entertainment, food vendors, and more. Just experiencing this festival was one of the many enriching cultural experiences that I had because I witnessed how one event brought many people together from different walks of life whether they were Catholic or not (the festival is for everyone though).
The day I landed, I made it just in time for the FC Barça vs. Girona FC game which resulted in a tied game (2–2). I can now cross off “seeing Messi score live” of my bucket list :)
Even though I hardly tune into fútbol, I love a good sporting event (after all, I was a sport studies minor in college) and attending a game was just one of the many cultural experiences that I had to undergo. From the collective singing of the FC Barça’s anthem (everyone stands up for this) to hearing the crowd cheer, boo, and shout “Força Barça” it was an unforgettable experience.
Day 2: “Pay What You Can” Walking Tour of Gothic Quarters + Interactive Group Cooking Class
Barcelona is such a huge city with groovy, intimate streets that you might overlook just because you read a post on TripAdvisor about strictly going to X, Y, and Z areas. I am a huge advocate of participating in a group walking tour because it is a great way to get to know the city with the help of a resident! I discovered streets that no one else talked about in other blogs / reviews and the streets that I walked through are perfect for a impromptu photoshoot (shoutout to all the local street artists who make the city even more beautiful). Although the link that I shared above advertises as “free” at the end of all tours the guides ask for a donation because they barely get paid without our help.
And to end my Monday night, I participated in a group cooking class. If you do not mind watching the chef prep and cook the dishes, then I recommend the link above. If you are looking for a more customized cooking class where you have your own hot plate to cook paella and more, then I recommend looking elsewhere. Overall my experience with the cooking class from Viator.com was fun because I got to meet really good people from all over, share stories, and drink sangrias together. All 30 of us at this activity gathered around the large pan to help stir the paella (the interactive part), but in the future I would like to do a smaller cooking class where I can have my own cooking station and follow the instructions of the chef.
Day 3: Sagrada Família + Park Güell
I am still in awe that I got to see Antoni Gaudí ‘s exquisite work! Gaudí was a mastermind architect who designed this beautiful Basílica more than a century ago. Officials say the church is set to be completed in 2026, which is a time I will return to see even more of its beauty. Just witnessing all of the intricate details put me in a place of serenity because no matter what was going on in the world, I felt secure and had peace of mind. I spent approximately 2.5 hours inside while the average person probably only spends an hour or so.
Since I am under 30 years old, I paid 27 euros to go inside the tower, which I highly recommend. The Nativity Tower has the best view because the view faces the beach.
After visiting Sagrada Família, take a short metro ride up to another one of Gaudí works and former residence, Park Güell. Park Güell is one of the best public parks I’ve ever walked through. It has a great combination of shade and sunshine, while also being extremely green because of all the trees, bushes, and cactuses.
The majority of the park is free of charge, but to visit the Gaudí house and the Monumental Core (aka the scene of the colorful benches in Cheetah Girls 2) has a fee. The photo above doesn’t do the park justice! There are so many beautiful designs missing from this photo that you just have to see for yourself when you arrive in Barcelona.
Day 4: Exploring Barceloneta
Along with the rich history and breathtaking scenery, Barcelona is a hot beach city. Sant Sebastià Beach is one of the best parts about Barcelona because there are so many things to do from bike riding to playing a game of volleyball with new friends. At night, the beach becomes even more alive because all of the touristy nightclubs, bars, and restaurants that reside on the end of the beach, making it a perfect night out.
Day 5: City Bus Tour + Picasso Museum
I would have never thought that I would do a “hop on hop off” bus tour ever in my life. There is just so much to see in Barcelona that I gave in to this activity. One of the perks of doing the bus tour is that it comes with a coupon booklet that gives you some good deals for other activities and food places around the city. The only stop that I got off was for the Tibidabo Cathedral del Segrat Cor, which sits at the highest peak in the city, giving viewers amazing 360 views of Barcelona. After the bus tour drops you off, you have to get on the historic Tramvia Blau or 196 red bus (2 minute ride) to the base of Tibidabo, then get on the Tibidabo funicular (7 euros round trip) which is a really cool cable railroad that takes you up the mountain to the Cathedral and mini amusement park. I highly recommend coming here if you have time. The inside of the Cathedral is spectacular as well as the city view.
Since there are many museums in Barcelona, the Picasso Museum is not one to be missed. As of now, it is free entry every Thursday evening. Unfortunately once inside, no photos can be taken of the artwork *sad face* but I can tell you that witnessing the artwork of Pablo Picasso, a phenomenal 20th-century Spanish artist, was a top 5 experience. You can see the passion in all of his work despite the fact that he suffered from imposter syndrome (which is a pretty common experience) and still produced greatness. The exhibit that I witnessed at the end of September was “Picasso and food” along with Impressionist and Symbolist pieces.
If you like Mexican food, I recommend Cantina Mexicana La Hacienda restaurant, which is around the corner from Picasso Museum.
Day 6: Restaurant day around La Rambla + Passeig de Gràcia + Carrer de Blai
La Rambla is a very touristy street in the center of Barcelona that I recommend walking down very attentive of your belongings just because it’s so crowded. One thing to note about La Rambla is to never eat at any of the restaurants on this street because they are usually overpriced and not that great. I came across a fabulous restaurant that was nearby calledLa Fonda (a local resident recommended this place to me), which has a super affordable menu during the lunch hour. I had a 3 course menu for 20 euros! The food was so good that I returned a second time before my departure. The hospitality is unmatched. The host acknowledges you as soon as you walk into the establishment and you are seated right away.
Another restaurant that I recommend is Cerveceria Catalana, which serves delicious tapas! Like most cities in Europe, the best time to eat dinner is after 9pm. Since I arrived solo, I was seated right away at the bar. For groups of two or more, a wait time of one hour should be expected. After checking out all the shops on Passeig de Gràcia, come here for lunch or dinner.
Fortunately enough, my Airbnb was located right on the famous Carrer de Blai, which is a street known for its tapas restaurants. One restaurant that I highly recommend is La Tasqueta de Blai. It’s a laid back eatery that allows you to grab the tapas straight from the bar and at the end you give all your toothpicks to the waiter and pay for your food. Very affordable, each tapas is 1 euro or 1.80 euros.
Notable areas of the city: La Boqueria Market, Montjuïc Fountains at night, Plaça Reial (a nice little square that can be experienced in the afternoon or late at night) I like Kane Roomfor late night cava aka champagne.

My First Love: FC Barcelona
Love has many forms. For some, it’s a person. For others, it’s a moment, a dream, or a place. But for me, love came dressed in red and blue stripes, roaring through the TV screen, dancing on the green fields of the Camp Nou. My first love was not a person—it was FC Barcelona.
I still remember the day it all began. I was barely ten, sitting in my uncle’s living room in Nepal, surrounded by laughter and the buzz of a Champions League night. On the screen, a team moved like poetry. There was elegance, unity, magic. And right at the heart of it all was a little magician—Lionel Messi.
That match changed everything.
It wasn’t just about the goals. It was about the way Barça played. The way Xavi pulled the strings, the way Iniesta glided past defenders like a painter with a brush, the way Messi turned impossible moments into memories. It was like watching art.
From that day on, I was no longer just a boy in Nepal—I was a culé. I read articles, watched every highlight I could find, begged for a jersey with the number 10. I started waking up at 1 or 2 in the morning just to watch La Liga matches live, my eyes sleepy but my heart wide awake.
When we won, I was on top of the world. When we lost, I felt the heartbreak. Every El Clásico became a festival in my house. My room slowly turned into a shrine—posters of Ronaldinho, Messi, and Puyol, stickers of the crest, and scarves with “Més que un club” boldly written across them.
As I grew older, life became more complicated—school, pressure, reality—but Barcelona remained my constant. In the hardest moments, watching Barça play felt like coming home. It reminded me who I was, and who I wanted to be: someone who plays with heart, who stands for something, who never gives up.
I’ve never been to Camp Nou, not yet. But my dream remains. One day, I’ll walk into that stadium, feel the roar of the crowd, and finally see in person what I fell in love with all those years ago on a small TV screen in Nepal.
People ask me why I love a club so far away. I tell them it’s simple: you don’t choose your first love—your heart does. And mine chose FC Barcelona.
