On November 6th 2021, Xavi Hernández Creus, one of Barcelona’s biggest legends and best midfielders ever, was appointed as the manager of FC Barcelona following the sacking of previous manager and club legend, Ronald Koeman — after a run of poor results, caused by the lack of identity and dynamism in football, that led to Barcelona being 9th on the La-Liga table when he was relieved of his said duties.
Xavi took the same team, with a couple of reinforcements in the following January transfer window of 2022, took the same team to 2nd place with an impressive period — playing some fluid and entertaining football, and also beating Real Madrid 4–0 in the process, ensuring the first El Clasico win since Ernesto Valverde’s departure.
The football witnessed initially under Xavi seemed very refreshing to a fanbase that had witnessed consistently underwhelming seasons of football prior to this — which prompted hyperbolic conversations regarding him being the ‘2nd coming of Pep Guardiola’.
He instilled an identity — provided a tactical foundation to a squad that lacked it very much; he deployed a 4–3–3, a more direct version than the conventional Barcelona style, but an entertaining and fluid style due to how the players inter-connected and understood their environment, which declined overtime due to the departures of some of the key ‘connectors’.
The following season (2022/23) — Barcelona proceeded to win La-Liga and the Spanish Super Cup very convincingly. Barcelona opted to play the box-midfield (midfield of 4) gradually as the season passed by, which helped neuter some of Barcelona’s core issues in the league, but were again exposed in some of the European nights (like Manchester United, Inter Milan).
Although Barcelona suffered a UCL group stage exit that season, the feelings around Xavi’s future / tenure were very positive, especially going into next season. Most seemed convinced that he was Barcelona’s man long-term. But, things went downhill this season with Barcelona’s levels of performance completely regressing while also going trophy-less, overall.
“Signing Xavi Is The Best Decision I’ve Ever Made Since I Became President”
These were the words of Joan Laporta, the Club President in April 2022, and in over 2 years — On 24th May, FC Barcelona announced that Xavi’s last game in charge as manager will be against Sevilla (the last game of the season) and he will not be continuing next season. There’s been such a drastic change in the perception of him as a manager over a year, something must’ve changed, and something did change.
Barcelona’s feelings coming into this season were relatively positive; the aim for this season was clear — an establishment of threat in Europe while maintaining the impressive domestic success we possessed, but did no one see coming this level of regression with regards to our overall style of play, rather than just losing out on trophies due to marginal differences.
Barcelona’s board parted ways with the previous sporting director, Jordi Cruyff (son of Johan Cruyff) and appointed Deco as the new sporting director; The club also parted ways with Mateu Alemany — which, essentially meant there was more responsibility in Yuste’s and Laporta’s hands — which was unhealthy, because neither have the credentials to be holding authority involving them to make sporting decisions.
Now, certain issues seemed to come with the power gradient — there was a lack of respect / consideration with respect to the manager’s decisions / preferences when it came to certain decisions that’d affect the manager the most, like the Vitor Roque situation. No board should sign a player with a manager you’re aiming to keep when he’s insisting against a particular signing, because it becomes unhealthy within the board & for the player’s future, as well.
A few issues became seemingly clear, and primarily, it was the unwarranted amount of influence Jorge Mendes (the agent) possessed on Barcelona’s footballing operations, when in reality — he has no authority to have such grave involvement, and it brings in an inherent level of bias in transfer operations, that could result in Barcelona settling for players with Mendes as agent, despite them being suboptimal for Barcelona’s squad, like the pressure make the Cancelo / Felix deals permanent, the heavy links with Ruben Neves last season etc.
So, in reality, there has always been suboptimal conditions in terms of board structuring and planning that can make it infeasible for managers to succeed at this club, and it was made much worse with the departures of Jordi Cruyff and especially, Mateu Alemany.
The handling of certain situations — including Xavi’s sacking has been extremely poor from the board. Poor treatment of personnel who genuinely commit their all towards the betterment of the club is an attitude that cannot last long at a club such as this, and will / can ultimately lead to the downfall of this particular mandate.
This was a ‘decent’ transfer window considering the financial limitations and there was a good initiative to complete sales of players that weren’t exactly contributing to the club in anyway, anymore. Oriol Romeu seemed like a very good signing at first, but it didn’t go as planned as the season went on due to confidence issues and also primarily — systematic issues that aggregated his flaws and didn’t provide him suitable conditions to succeed.
Felix and Cancelo seemed to be decent reinforcements due to their high technical potential and talent. The issue came with Cancelo’s and Felix’s mental profiles — often ignorant, unwarrantedly complex, reckless, more flair, less effectiveness, which, as expected, led to improper application of their high technical qualities and inconsistent showings in possession, combined with poor showings in general out of possession;
Regardless, Ilkay Gundogan, hands down, proved to be Barcelona’s best signing for this season by a mile. A footballer of the highest level — mentally, physically and technically. He is a true Swiss-Army Knife in every sense of the word due to how versatile, resilient and intelligent he is.
Transfers regarding personnel has been decent at best, but the overall squad planning and direction regarding overall club’s structure has been unconvincing and seems very unsustainable due to the lack of rational basis behind most decisions this particular dispensation has made. Far too ‘individualistic’ and preference-based without looking at the overall larger picture.
Despite current transfer planning / direction being slightly off, the investment in youth for the B team has been pretty impressive, especially under Deco, with signings like Noah Darvich, Ibrahim Diarra and Mikayil Faye. Although, there’s no balance with respect to elevating the 1st team while doing it sustainably on a financial level — hence, the lack of direction and planning I stated.
It’s been a disappointing season overall, from Barcelona, in the tactical domain, on both offensive and defensive fronts. As shown in a graph created by “Markstats” on X :
Barcelona’s deep entries in the opposition graph has massively declined while the opposition deep entries increased as the season progressed. Although, it is very important to note that most teams don’t look to threaten Barcelona through consistent entries / pressure in their box, rather — they use transitions / counter-attacks to try and exploit / attack Barcelona’s defense. But, Barcelona, being a dominant team in possession, in La-Liga, not being able to create enough deep entries, and it going to an extent that it’s not too dissimilar as opposition deep entries suggests poor effectiveness in and, also out of possession.
Barcelona’s issues this season showcase the fact that Xavi is an inexperienced coach with ideas that need proper maturing, multi-dimensionality and clarity in implication. It could, either, be an issue regarding a lack of transcendence of the ideas clearly or a lack of applying these ideas properly, or both — either way, both are co-related mechanisms. Let’s get into some detail.
Barcelona didn’t change much, in terms of their structural base or their formation in terms of positioning. There was a continuation on the 4–3–3 with often one forming a double pivot in build-up, as done last season, except it became more rigid, and horizontal relative to its surroundings. The reasoning is definitely due to Busquets’ departure — which essentially meant that Barcelona needed more dynamism / technical prowess in build-up, without a Busquets.
The replacement came in the form of Romeu, and the build-up responsibility gradually shifted more to Frenkie De Jong with Romeu assisting in build-up. Barcelona seemed ineffective on a consistent basis when it came to enabling effective progression when playing against opposition presses and already seemed to hit some road-blocks regarding fluidity last season, especially in terms of de-compacting opposition defenses (like Inter) but, this season, it got much, much worse.
What seemed to be the issue was — Barcelona had a structural idea in mind, but were incompetent in executing or even understanding how to utilize / implicate the structure to progress efficiently. Barcelona were too rigid / unpredictable, because of an obvious lack in fluidity.
This came due to one major factor, and that’s the DISTANCING. The distances between players became much larger to try and gain positional / numerical advantages, but it came at a cost of compromising for compactness and fluidity.
There was often the lack of an extra receiver between the lines, and instead there was an increased emphasis on playing extremely direct passes which came with the intent of exploiting space that exists, not creating or controlling. This can also be validated by how often Barcelona have to go long to feed runners, or put it on top of defenses to feed runners that does not sustain because it is a high ‘variance’ style and also, an easily readable and predictable style.
It also clearly explains how Pau Cubarsi’s inclusion has made Barcelona much more efficient on the ball — due to his immaculate tactical awareness and manipulation using his body language and footwork which results in creation of gaps / openings of lanes through which Barcelona can find a player better, like how Cubarsi often opens up the middle of the pitch to find Lewandowski directly.
Players do not move in closer proximities to combine, create space and release to the runners. Rather, Barcelona try to do the latter before-hand which is ineffective due to the opposition still maintaining numbers at the back, and the lack of proximity which can undermine the level of reception, and provide a higher risk to the pass.
This showcased the fact that this team had not culminated a set of consistent principles / a basis of automation in possession that would help them play through the opposition and utilize the potential of their structural knowledge into something much more useful and effective.
A conundrum that Barcelona often found themselves is that they were not given the clarity on when to keep the ball, how to keep the ball, and why to keep the ball. What leads to players playing extremely direct passes, and often turning games into chaos is a clear lack of clarity with regards to collective intent, and how to approach the game. That, combined with the larger distances between players, leads to what we call as — over-verticality.
Barcelona have become increasingly rigid in its style of play — a great example being, how often players out wide are completely isolated and have no pathway but to complete their take on, or lose the ball and concede a turnover — which made Balde an easy target to retrieve possession off if Barcelona ever went out wide to him, because he’s not a 1v1 monster; rather, he’s someone that would thrive on more rotations when wide, and more license to carry in the middle — that’s been clearly failed to be addressed due to the high and wide policy of our full-backs in build-up and attacking phases.
The rigidity and lack of fluidity transcends onto why the particular idea of Xavi’s Barcelona are so reliant / obsessed on / with 1v1 dribblers (Yamal / Dembele), and that’s primarily because that’s Barcelona’s only pathway (often) to creating space or progressing out wide due to the lack of rotations, when the whole idea of exploiting said ‘openings’ leads to not much good in the era of modern football due to the increasing amounts of compact defenses — opposition teams are constricting space very well and as often as possible.
There aren’t enough rotations, whether it is deep with the full-backs and midfielders, or whether it’s ahead with the wingers and full-backs. The rigidity prompts individual prowess and spontaneous solution-finding that leads to unreliability / inconsistencies in possession and often a chaotic style against better teams — because the players are playing at their own rhythm, understanding and intent, due to the lack of a collective idea of execution — which shows the lack of a principle base.
The lack of movement has caused Barcelona to become a static and predictable side, lacking basic combinations in possession due to rigid occupation of zones, rather than arrival and exchange of zones between players, often leading to predictable and pointless sideways circulation / forced passes forward to win 2nd balls or over the top of the last line.
The reason Barcelona look much more fluid with Pedri and looked more fluid with Busquets because these two players had a clearer picture of how to progress and play as a collective with the ball — they tried to receive and create shorter distances, dictate movements on the pitch and tried to retain possession when possible, as well.
Their INTENT was / is to extert control on the pitch, which is something Barcelona have massively lacked this season. There’s no quest for territory — that has led to the patchy form this season. Lack of territorial control leads to a game-model with high variance, which is basically, you don’t control enough possibilities to narrow games down to your favour and leave it out more in the open.
This can be validated by some of Barcelona’s poor field tilt statistics against competent opposition :
— Against Athletic Bilbao on March 4th (36.4%) — Against Real Madrid (30.1%) — Against PSG 1st leg (30.0%)
Barcelona play into chaos too much — there is such lack of re-organization for the team to even play in settled possession and when they do, these are the conundrums they face in possession. It’s very unlike a usual Barcelona team, to be honest.
To sum it up — lack of clarity, lack of emphasis on being more risk-averse, controlling and sustaining attacks / pressure has led to an incredibly patchy season, showcasing clear deficiencies with our play-style, despite Barcelona having the personnel to deploy a better style of football with more control, clarity and fluidity.
Barcelona have been very inefficient out-of-possession, and it shows in their massive increase in xGA (Expected Goals) by almost 6 (from 29.7 to 35), from last season. A more leaky defense, something that’s not anticipated from the team who was the best defensive team (on output) in La-Liga last season.
Barcelona’s press has been very lackluster against teams good on the ball. Teams like Girona and Real Madrid have been able to consistently play out of it with ease, and it goes beyond the personnel at the manager’s disposal.
Barcelona do press with a 4–4–2 structure, with often the advanced #8 and Lewandowski leading the front 2. Lewandowski, usually, aims to angle the opposition into playing out towards one flank, but the opposition can often find the free man pretty comfortably against the press, because the center is not compact, at all.
There’s a spacing issue with Barcelona — often, Barcelona find themselves so far apart from each other, that they cannot compact / constrict enough space to restrict their opponents. This is caused due to the extremely rigid man-to-man nature of the press. The players seem to be glued to one player of the opposition team irrespective of rotations / dropping deep that drives Barcelona’s key players out of position and also help teams find the free man with ease using overloads from deep.
(Source : @CaptnGuardiola from X)
This scatters the whole team — which leads to poor spacing and larger distances between each other. This level of complacency and rigidity in a team’s out of possession leads to a very exploitable approach — especially because Barcelona don’t have the highest intensity / dueling capacity, as well.
The last line of defense is also much deeper (out of cautiousness) which means the last line is looking to concede pressure / absorb pressure more than looking to close down / prevent the opposition’s by-passing to further continue until Barcelona’s box — which is one of the main causes of the uneven spacing. There’s also a clear lack of co-ordination on timing / jumps and collective movement when the press is initiated.
It seems very individualistic, with a lack of coherence and each individual with a different intent / approach to the press and that’s the sign of a lack of collective principles instilled; It’s clear that, this is more than just a personnel issue, and there’s an issue with Barcelona’s intent in covering space / the ball, that goes beyond the press.
A team’s ability to adapt to different game-states also depends upon how well-drilled and compact their blocks are. The low / mid blocks have been suboptimal from Barcelona — which, after the PSG games, many would consider a fair assertion.
Multiple games are evidence to this; the distancing between the lines has allowed too much central access to opposing teams BTL. The block tends to be too passive, allowing enough leverage around the box and solely relying on box defending, blocks and clearances.
The shifting leaves many gaps due to the larger distances between players and lack of coherence in intent. The intent in defending as an overall unit seems inherently flawed — too much of being ball-oriented and unnecessarily passive, rather than coverage of space, and compacting of space.
These are the major causes behind Barcelona’s inflation in xGA numbers and also general leakiness and lack of compactness in defense — defensive record being very poor compared to last year.
To sum it up — Barcelona have principle issues with how the football has been played, and that’s because the key enforcers on the pitch have left and we’ve been unable to put the structure to top use with coaching. Spontaneous dictators of play and solution finders like Busquets (mainly), Alba, Dani Alves and Dembele (1v1 prowess) leaving has caused a degradation in style of play due to Barcelona’s style of play, and effectiveness in style of play.
The core issue requires a manager change, unfortunately and that’s because the manager seems to be slightly inexperienced and his ideas on how to execute needs more maturation and learning — which is normal, but it also showcases that Xavi has a high potential if he can reflect on his mistakes, and what he needs to do to coach teams as a collective, better, without enforcers like Busquets.
Despite all the tactical shortcomings, Xavi has shown he is an excellent man-manager and can manage players very well by instilling a level of confidence and trust in them. He’s more than capable of pleasing a dressing room and motivating them, as a coach, and that’s an impressive quality to possess.
Barcelona have appointed Hansi Flick as the new manager, which is a slight philosophical change, but an ambitious and bold one — which only time will tell, if it pays off.
Thank you for reading; if you liked it, I would appreciate as many claps/likes, shares and comments as possible.
Much love, AM.

Title: Reflections from Barcelona & Italy: What I Learned Along the Way
Content:
Sign up

Share
I recently went on what should’ve been the trip of a lifetime to Barcelona (Spain) and cities Bari, Noci, Aversa, Florence, Caserta, and Naples in Italy.
Like many trips, it was full of mishaps, twists, and surprises. But I ended up learning a lot about many things, myself included, and walked away with valuable lessons and a deeper understanding of what truly matters when exploring the world and reflecting on my own life.
And don’t let anyone else tell you otherwise.
I had initially planned to visit Rome and Pompeii in Italy, but due to time constraints, my friend and I decided to explore nearby cities instead, including Caserta. We toured the Royal Palace of Caserta before catching a train to Florence. We also ventured into lesser-known cities like Bari and Noci and had the chance to experience the vibrant Carnival of Putignano during our stay.
In Barcelona, I omitted places like the Sagrada Familia from my itinerary for several reasons: I hated crowds, was terrified of being pickpocketed, and didn’t want to go just to say I went. Additionally, since it was Ramadan for us Muslims, attending Mass at the Sagrada Familia felt sacrilegious, even if it meant gaining free admission.
Instead, I immersed myself in experiences that were more meaningful to me. I spent most of my time trying out exotic fruits I couldn’t find at home, browsing local grocery stores, learning about racial demographics and local history, talking to locals in Urdu and broken Spanish, researching the Romani people (as known as Gypsies), and studying the architectural details of everyday buildings. I have a particular fixation on doors, so I snapped as many pictures of them as I could as I roamed the city.
And I was perfectly happy doing so.
This is not to say that I didn’t do touristy things. I took a paella-making class in El Raval, where I learned how to make paella, danced around the kitchen, and had enjoyable conversations with people from Moldova, Turkey, Argentina, and the US. I tried tiramisu from every cafe I could. Afterward, I oohed and aahed at paintings in the Picasso Museum, marveled at the World Culture Museum artifacts, got lost on my way to the Chocolate Museum, and pondered the different tastes of Coca-Cola in Europe and the US at a cafe. And I shopped till I dropped, with bags full of spices, magnets, postcards, keychains, and chocolates from La Rambla.
Truthfully, I did feel guilty about “wasting” my trip. The voice in my head shamed me, telling me, “What’s the point of flying all the way here if you don’t check out Park Guell and the other tourist spots?”
But I listened to my body — my anxiety — which was screaming to be heard and decided to conserve my energy for another day of exploration. Instead of pushing my feet to walk the scenic mile home at peak traffic hour, I opted for an Uber, where I enjoyed pleasant conversation with the driver and saved my aching feet from further torment.
It’s not to say I played it completely safe.
Despite being told to avoid El Raval in Barcelona, I ventured there to check out vintage clothing boutiques, satisfy my homesick cravings for Pakistani foods, and buy custard apples. On the way, I went into a Pakistani jewelry store where I bought earrings for upcoming weddings and spoke to the kind store owner in Urdu. She was more than happy to discuss her son’s engagement drama and gave me a discount and free earrings. I wandered alone in the evenings, avoiding the dark alleys and blending in with a tourist group, and enjoyed the city lights. It was a peaceful way to enjoy the city’s vibrant lights and grew my confidence in solo travel.
They say travel broadens the mind and sheds light on the true nature of friendship. During this trip, I was lucky enough to experience both.
In Naples, I reunited with my high school bestie, who went above and beyond to ensure I had the best trip possible. She planned most of our itinerary, booked us a stay at a beautiful old apartment in Noci as a surprise for me, handled our high-speed train tickets for Florence, drove me around everywhere I needed to be, and indulged my constant whims for tiramisu. When it became clear that Italian food wasn’t meant for me, we loaded up on groceries and decided to cook paella at home, where we laughed, sang, and enjoyed one another’s company as we did so.
She also offered me the best of what she had — the master bedroom in her home, her nicest jackets, and the choice of going to Rome or Florence, Bari or Materra. She didn’t want me to pay for anything, but I insisted anyway because, despite the many problems in the way I was parented, one thing I was taught was never to take advantage of anyone’s kindness.
Our parting was more bitter than sweet. Despite doing almost nothing on my travel to-do list, the permeating odor of rotting garbage on the streets, and the death-defying traffic, I had the time (and the best tiramisu) of my life in Naples, the “trash can” of Italy, and couldn’t wait to come back and explore everything else.
Fast forward to Barcelona, where nearly every interaction with my other friend was wrought with tension, resentment, and impatience.
She nitpicked everything I did and said, walked ahead without stopping to wait for me, and made it clear that she didn’t want me around. She also claimed the nice double room in our Airbnb and had me choose between two closet-sized rooms so she could use the remaining room as her closet. I put my foot down and voiced my disapproval, where she eventually relented but gave me the silent treatment for the next couple of days. Despite my initial reluctance to explore alone, I braved my fears instead of putting up with my friend’s rudeness. To socialize, I called friends and family in the US and talked to them for hours. As miserable as I felt, I was touched that many people back home were rooting for me to have a great time in Europe.
Needless to say, this “friend” and I have parted ways, and I realized how disrespected and dismissed I felt in our friendship, as well as the many insults and snide remarks I overlooked throughout our time together.
Piggybacking on my previous point, we didn’t have the nicest lodging. It was clean, in the Sant Antoni neighborhood, surrounded by many things to do. And affordable. You do pay for what you get, especially for AirBnBs.
Our AirBnB had one double room, two single rooms, and no laundry services (despite them being advertised) or microwave. Our AirBnB hosts also failed to mention that there were no elevators in the building and that the walls were very thin. The beds in our rooms were hard and we woke up with sore, stiff backs every morning. The AC unit often turned on when it wanted to and I sweated right through my bedsheets at night.
It wasn’t an entirely bad place to be. Still, I would’ve appreciated an actual dryer machine instead of relying on the unreliable solar-powered clothes dryer on the terrace. And neighbors who were less vocal in their babymaking.
In several cities across Italy and in Barcelona, I quickly became a target for street vendors who could spot me as a tourist from a mile away. At first, I indulged them, buying a few gifts for my family back home. But the problem arose when I started being followed out of shops and booths, bombarded with pleas to “buy this” and “buy that,” often accompanied by sob stories about being an immigrant in a foreign country with large families to feed.
I get it — trust me, I do. As a former people-pleaser, I understand the urge to help. Most people-pleasers are empaths who want to save the world and make life better for the less fortunate.
But let’s be clear: traveling isn’t the way to fix everything wrong with the world. Europe is full of scammers and hustlers who won’t hesitate to overcharge you for something you could easily buy for a couple of euros at the local bodega. Learn to recognize the red flags. If someone is overly pushy or offers you something “for free” on the street, respond firmly with a resounding “NO!” Don’t worry about being rude — nice people make easy targets.
If you do want to tap into your empathetic side, try supporting local small businesses rather than money-laundering souvenir shops or tourist traps. Take the time to learn about the culture around you, try exotic fruits and vegetables, and always assert your boundaries.
Travel is one of those rare situations where I genuinely appreciate my resting bitch face. If you’re a soft-spoken people-pleaser like I used to be, one of my best tips is to put on a serious resting bitch face. It may be hard if you weren’t born with one, but trust me — this facial expression helped me ward off scammers, pickpockets, and hustlers. It also made saying “no” a whole lot easier. People tend to leave you alone when they think you look like someone who won’t tolerate their bullshit.
If mastering a resting bitch face feels impossible, at least look like you know where you’re going. Project confidence. Don’t act shifty; whatever youdo, don’t pull out your GPS in the middle of a sketchy area. If you need to check your phone, step into a store and ask the shopkeeper for directions.
If you’re from a country where seasoning is a way of life, like I am, you might find most European food a bit lackluster. Your best bet is to seek out Latin American or Asian restaurants or bring your spices as you explore.
I’m a huge fan of what Americans consider Italian food. When I was in Italy, I expected the food to be mind-blowing. Instead, I was met with disappointment. I found the dishes surprisingly underseasoned, missing the bold flavors I was used to in the US. For example, the pizzas I ate felt like they were missing key ingredients — salt, dried red chili pepper, and garlic powder. The carbonara at the cute local diner was far from the creamy indulgence I knew and loved in the States. Even the curry chicken pasta tasted like it was seasoned with nothing more than a Maggi instant noodle packet. For a foodie like me, it was almost heartbreaking.
Barcelona had a much better food scene, but by then, the damage was already done.
Despite the confusion, panic, and disappointment I encountered during my trip, I still had an unforgettable time. If anything, I’d happily redo my Barcelona trip knowing what I know now. Along the way, I’ve learned to embrace spontaneity, find joy in the unexpected, and trust in the good people I know. I also learned not to question the blessings that come my way — like the $150 I saved in baggage fees thanks to the kindness of airport staff in Europe. My ability to appreciate life’s simple pleasures — like admiring doors, staircases, and the frames surrounding iconic artworks — turned out to be the perfect way to ground myself amid the chaos.

Title: Barcelona: the City with a Vibrant Soul
Content:

In May, my wife and I embarked on a long-awaited trip to the captivating city of Barcelona. Leaving behind the lackluster Stansted Airport, the excellent Barcelona Airport greeted us, setting the tone for an unforgettable cultural trip. This blog post isn’t a list of things to see as many travel articles are but our feelings and responses to the vibrant atmosphere and rich cultural tapestry that is Barcelona.
We had booked a city center hotel. As we arrived late, we caught a taxi to our hotel. We engaged the driver in conversation as we often do in our travels. He responded warmly to our questions, although a little reluctantly at first because he felt his English wasn’t good enough. It was good enough for us, so we persisted. He wasn’t a Barcelonian, he came from southern Spain, but had made his home here. That’s got to mean something.
Once the driver was comfortable with us he peppered our journey with stories and things to see as we progressed into the city, such as the university, the bull ring that they had converted into a shopping mall, La Rambla, the Plaça Catalunya, and Gaudí’s Casa Batlló. Finally, we got to our hotel which was just off the impressive Passeig de Gràcia with its grand shops. (Note: Passeig is a Catalan word, not Spanish, it means Passage or avenue.) His parting words to us was to eat in the nearby street, it is very famous he said in his broken English, although better than my non-existent Spanish or Catalan.
Our driver was right. After a warm welcome at the hotel we walked right round the corner into Rambla de Catalunya, a street lined with restaurants and bars, and down the tree lined center with “alfresco” seating and tables for the restaurants. These areas were buzzing with people, chatting and laughing while they enjoyed their meal, or just drinks.
No exploration of Barcelona would be complete without indulging in its culinary treasures. We ate in the hotel most mornings and a couple of nights. However, mostly we ate in the restaurants of Rambla de Catalunya, sampling the delicious tapas, paella, and sangria that the city is renowned for. During the days we roamed around Barcelona and embarked on a culinary adventure, stepping away from the touristy hotspots. We discovered hidden gems in the lesser-known neighborhoods, going through medieval alleyways where we savored authentic Catalan dishes bursting with local flavors or the authentic Indian restaurant recommended by the hotel staff. The blend of traditional, contemporary and exotic cuisine in Barcelona is a testament to the city’s gastronomic prowess.
Upon stepping foot in Barcelona, we immediately noticed the city’s lively atmosphere, the bustling streets, filled with locals and tourists alike, brimmed with an energy that was infectious. Wandering through the enchanting Gothic Quarter, we found ourselves captivated by the charming narrow alleyways and hidden squares. We found the medieval cathedral, the roman temple of Augustus, the medieval palace, the Basilica de la Mare (for those that saw the TV series), and George Orwell square. Reminding me of Orwell’s contribution to the Spanish Civil War and his memoir’s an homage to Catalonia. With each corner turned, we stumbled upon some new scene, curiosity or event, all adding to the unique rhythm of the city. We wandered into a pharmacy on the second day and talked to the owner for about an hour. He sold many herbal remedies including dope. We bought nothing but had an enchanting time. His family had been in the same shop for over 120 years.
To truly understand the soul of Barcelona, we immersed ourselves in its rich cultural traditions. Barcelona’s passion for art was clear in every corner, with its many galleries and street art scene providing a canvas for artistic expression. I was sad that I could not attend the Flamenco festival, which was held in March, but our hotel had recommended a venue on La Rambla with Flamenco performances, I wrote about this a week or two ago. We had an excellent night.
Barcelona is the heart of Catalonia, a region with a distinct culture and language. Engaging with the locals allowed us to gain a deeper understanding of the Catalonian identity. Conversations in small cafes and bars revealed the pride they held for their heritage and their ongoing pursuit of autonomy. Visiting the stunning architectural wonders of Antoni Gaudí, such as the iconic Sagrada Família and Park Güell, further reinforced the unique blend of art, history, and cultural identity that defines Barcelona, but funnily we were not driven to go into any of these. We found that just wandering the streets and exploring were a joy.
Barcelona’s prime location on the Mediterranean coast provides a perfect balance between vibrant city life and relaxing beach escapes. We soaked up the Mediterranean spirit by strolling along the picturesque seaside promenade, taking in the salty sea breeze and basking in the warm sun.
Our trip to Barcelona proved to be an enriching experience beyond our expectations. We did not see all the usual tourist attractions; but the city’s vibrant atmosphere, rich cultural traditions, and the friendliness and unwavering pride of its people captivated us. Barcelona left an indelible mark on our hearts. To describe Barcelona in a single word I would say color. But it has so much more, it’s filled with love and friendships. History is remembered, and the future embraced. The final take away: A week just wasn’t enough, you get a flavor of Barcelona but to do it justice you need much longer to savor Barcelona.
Thanks for reading all of this post! If you enjoyed it, or found it inspiring, please give it a clap or two so others can find it!

Title: Oh My Gaudi
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
How I Met Your Mother was one of my favourite shows growing up. Watching endless reruns became such a ritual that I could effortlessly complete the dialogues. In the show, New York becomes more than just a setting — it’s a character itself. Ted Mosby, the passionate architect lead, faces a tough decision to relocate to Chicago for his career. The struggle is real as he’s deeply attached to the city. But when he decides to do so, he goes to the Empire State Building and shares his feelings on how he “hates the thought of leaving Empy”.
When I watched this as a 14 year old, I delve deep into architecture as a concept and discover why Chicago and New York are renowned for their distinctive and influential architecture.
To bid farewell to 2023, I embarked on a trip to Europe, and Barcelona emerged as one of my final destinations. When Barcelona comes to mind, I think of a vivid mix of FC Barcelona, the iconic Camp Nou, Flamenco, the tapas and the beaches. Once I got to Barcelona, it hit me that the standout feature was the incredible architecture. And at the heart of it all was the work of the Catalan architect, Antoni Gaudí.
Antoni Gaudí is known for a variety of architectural creations, ranging from parks to basilicas. The first of his marvels that I explored was La Sagrada Familia, an unfinished basilica that began construction in 1882. It’s a UNESCO world heritage site despite still being a work in progress.
The first thing that struck me about this place was that there was not a single square feet left blank on the walls of the church. At this point in my Europe journey, I had seen a ton of churches that imbibe Gothic features, but this felt incredibly rich in character and detail. I could not immediately point out what it was, but thoroughly enjoyed exploring this spectacular place on a sunny Barcelona day.
The next day, I headed to Park Güell, a cool hilltop park. It’s a UNESCO world heritage site as well, and you don’t need a detective to figure out Gaudí was behind it. Something about his style stood out again — those mosaic walls and uniquely detailed, uneven shapes. Though these are part of his signature, I sensed I was still overlooking a crucial aspect.
Next on my agenda was a visit to two of his famous buildings on the same street — Casa Batlló and Casa Milà. As I saw a sea of people outside these buildings, I realised how Gaudi is deeply engrained into Catalan culture. These 2 buildings gave away the last and the most important trait that I was missing out on. A signature Antoni Gaudi building is not just extremely well detailed with figurines and mosaic tiles, but the beauty is that none of them have straight lines or sharp corners!
The more you inspect, the more unbelievable it is that he pulled it off. Buildings with no sharp corners or straight lines, be it on the corner of a street or one of the world’s largest churches, those classic (scaleable!) Gaudí traits just ooze out. I dug up the internet to know more about why he did what he did, and found out that Gaudi often said:
I do not want to create straight lines and sharp corners because they do not exist in nature. Nature is all curves, organic shapes, and flowing lines. My architecture is a reflection of the natural world, an attempt to capture its beauty and harmony.
While I had a great time visiting Barcelona, the only 2 things that will make me want to go back are: To watch an FC Barcelona game in Camp Nou, and to revisit the Sagrada Familia once it’s complete, which is estimated to be sometime in 2030. Until then, I can only wonder what he must’ve been sketching on his notepad here.
Happy new year, and thank you for reading!
To see my work, check out my website. In the mood for some tunes? Check out my Instagram. Write to me on LinkedIn if you want to have a chat.

I moved to Barcelona in September 2020, during the height of the pandemic. Although the world frowned upon travel at this time and many countries had locked down their borders, I quietly snuck in through Spain’s backdoor and never left. After flying from New York City to Dublin, Dublin to London, and then taking the Eurostar train to Paris and then two other trains to Barcelona, I entered the capital of Catalonia wild-eyed and travel-weary.
It’s been my home ever since.
I left New York with a suitcase, a carry-on, no job, and very little in my bank account. Somehow, I made things work. It was here that I wrote two books: the first about my travels in a faraway and forgotten region in Southern Siberia and the second about my years of living in New York City. Despite working in the printing industry most of my life, I stumbled into a career as a freelance content writer after my first year as a resident of Barcelona.
Looking back on how I saw things when I first moved here, my thoughts about the city have changed. Title: Madrid or Barcelona?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Career and life hacks from the McMaster alumni community

--
Listen
Share
By Chris Wildgen, McMaster Alumna, travel writer, photographer and tour leader.
People often ask me whether they should go to Madrid or Barcelona. Both are fantastic cities and well worth visiting. With friends in both cities, it is very hard for me to choose.
While both offer museums, sports, nature, great food and wine, history and culture, each has its own personality, and there is definitely a strong rivalry — just ask soccer/football fans!
Barcelona was my first time in Spain when I did a home exchange that planted me in the heart of the tourist area near the Picasso Museum. Though it was January, it was busy and bustling. With almost everything within a thirty-minute walk, it was a great, central location.
Two main things differentiate Barcelona from Madrid. One is its location on the Mediterranean Sea. As a beach lover, I enjoyed visiting its smaller artist-dedicated museums (such as Picasso, Dali, or Miro) in the morning, followed by a lunch of fresh fish at a chiringuito on the beach. After lunch, the cement lounge chairs on the beach are an inviting place to have a siesta while enjoying the modern architecture along the seafront.
The second thing is the architecture of Antoni Gaudí, “God’s architect”, who is currently being considered for sainthood. A visit to la Sagrada Famiglia may convince anyone that it is well-deserved. A day can be spent just visiting this and his other buildings, with an afternoon spent in Parc Guell (advisable to pre-purchase tickets.) That Barcelona embraced Gaudí and his Catalan modernism reflects the spirit of the city.
Evening entertainment can include free concerts such as a free organ concert at the Cathedral or an event at the beautiful and fanciful Palau de la Música Catalana, where I attended a memorable performance by The Barcelona Guitar Trio and Dance.
From Barcelona, possible day trips in its region of Catalonia (Catalunya) are to Montserrat 11th century Catholic monastery, Dalí Museum in Figueres or Girona, Sitges, Girona and the Costa Brava.
Everything about Madrid reminds me that it is the capital of Spain. With its sophisticated yet confidently relaxed, big-city vibe, Madrid feels like a real city, not a tourist city. Full of wide boulevards and monumental buildings, it is both grand and accessible. From my hotel away from the city centre, I walked down the wide boulevard of Paseo de la Castellana, past monumental buildings such as the Bank of Spain, eventually turning on Gran Via to go towards the center.
Instead of turning on Gran Via, continuing on I arrived at Paseo del Prado and 3 world-famous museums –the Thyssen-Bornemisza, the Prado and the Reina-Sofia. Just a block away is one of my favourite city parks, the very large Parc Retiro. From early morning until late evening, people walk or run along the many intersecting paths, use the outdoor exercise area, visit the latest exhibition at the Crystal Palace, ride small boats in the mini lake in its center, or chat with friends while enjoying coffee at a café.
From there a 30-minute walk to the Royal Palace of Madrid goes through the geographical center of Spain (and the tourist center of Madrid) of Puerto Sol, which is full of restaurants, bars and shops.
For sports lovers (especially Real Madrid fans), the Real Madrid Museum and football (soccer) pitch are memorable, but it is even better to attend a game, especially if it is against Barcelona to experience the very strong rivalry between the capital of Catalonia and the capital of Spain.
Restaurants represent all regions from Spain, with fresh seafood from Galicia and the Mediterranean and wine from the entire country, though Rioja wines seem to be favoured.
There are also easy day trips from Madrid to El Escorial, Segovia with its Roman aqueduct, Avila with its 11th century city walls, the cathedral in Toledo. For more royal experience, a 40-minute train goes to the Royal Palace of Aranjuez. Even a visit to the Mediterranean is possible with a 2-hour high speed train that takes you from Atocha station to Valencia.
So, do you choose Madrid with its capital city vibe, royal palace, history, geographic accessibility, excellent restaurants from tapa bars to fine dining, world famous museums such as the Prado and the Thyssen, small museums such as the Sorollo?
Or do you choose Barcelona with its waterfront and beach, Catalonian language, history, food and pride, and the humility and magnificence of Gaudi?
Confident and sophisticated Madrid or fun and fanciful Barcelona? With just a train ride separating them, choose both!
After an international career in sports medicine and sales and marketing, McMaster graduate Chris Wildgen is following her dream of connecting with people and diving into local cultures around the world through travel. Now a digital nomad, Chris is a travel writer, photographer and tour leader. With a natural flair for languages, she can converse in German, French, Italian, Spanish and English. Visit her site www.travelbetterlivebetter.com.
Looking to explore the world? Discover your next MAC adventure with us. http://bit.ly/2Gg1VvQ

Content:

Share
before things get weird, and you wonder why I never mention this world-class city.
I have lived just outside the magestical metropolis of Barcelona for almost six years. I've dragged my husband to see most of the important works of art and architecture and taken my little art-enthusiast son on adventures to museums and shops, cafes, and kids' activities. It's a wonderful city filled with inspiration and mystery, bohemia and affluence.
As well my little family and I have traveled all around the Barcelona region, from days by the Mediterranean sea to skiing in the Pyrenees. Delightful vegan cafes to classy restos which promise vegan or vegetarian options. I've posted photos and maybe some videos on Instagram but never written a proper blog post.
A vegan meat and potatoes post about all my insights and perspectives, notions, and musings of my adopted home. I don't know why that is. To be honest, I could probably JUST write about the Barcelona region for the rest of my blogging days and do quite well. But for some reason, I don't.
I guess that happens. When you live in a world-class city, you eventually take it for granted.
So, it's 2023, and I'm going to start the year off right with a quick and snappy post about Barcelona…here goes.
Barcelona is a wonderful place to visit any time of year. Although, if you are more of an art, shopping, and dining tourist, I highly recommend the winter months. Nice weather without sweltering heat and smaller lineups to all of the beautiful sites to see.
Architect Antoni Gaudí's life work really is unlike anything you will ever see anywhere else. Park Güell, Sagrada Familia, Casa Batlló, and La Pedrera-Casa Milà are just some of the many whimsical buildings that this true patriot of Catalonia created. I say true patriot as Gaudí was a fierce supporter and defender of Catalan culture and language no matter how much trouble it caused him.
Barcelona is for everyone. Although Friday and Saturday nights can be a party, it is a great city for most kinds of travelers. Live large in luxury or stay at a backpackers. This city is a buzzing hotspot of activities for all ages. And if you have kids and stay for an extended amount of time, you will delight in all the activities and classes they have for little ones. I can't think of a better place to raise a small child, with all the festivals and parades, gargoyles, and dragons.
Barcelona is so multilingual. Of course, you will hear Catalan and Spanish the most, but on a busy day in the city center, you will hear almost as much French, Italian, German, you name it.
Barcelona has an amazing airport. Easy to get to from the city center- Plaça de Catalunya — Josep Tarradellas Barcelona-El Prat Airport is a hub connecting you to pretty much anywhere you want to go…or at least to another airport that will take you anywhere you want to go, like Frankfurt, Paris, etc.
Sometimes, I yearn for the south more than my Andalusian husband ever has. I plead with him that we need to move to Seville and start our lives anew, leave all this chaos behind, and set our sights on one of the world's most important historical cities…but then he reminds me of the airport, the Pyrenees and the Mediterranean sea and I calm down for a while.
So, in a nutshell, I truly adore my new home. I feel honored and amazed that I get to live here. I'm so Canadian and monolingual that I sometimes giggle nervously in shock as I hear my small son chattering on in Spanish or translate Catalan into English for my benefit.
I'm forever grateful for that trip I took in 2015 to Barcelona that made me want to come back and stay just long enough to feel what it would be like to live here. And on my second trip in 2016, I met a man from Seville who lived in Barcelona and would one day become mi marido.
So if I never mention Barcelona again, know it's because I'm busy thinking about other things, not because I'm not smitten.

Commonly known as FC Barcelona and colloquially as Barça ([ˈbaɾsə]), is a professional football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain, that competes in La Liga, the top flight of Spanish football.
Founded in 1899 by a group of Swiss, Catalan, German, and English footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto “Més que un club” (“More than a club”).[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the supporters own and operate Barcelona. It is the third-most valuable football club in the world, worth $5.6 billion, and the world’s fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €800.1 million.[3][4] The official Barcelona anthem is the “Cant del Barça”, written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espinàs.[5] Barcelona traditionally play in dark shades of blue and garnet stripes, hence nicknamed Blaugrana.

This season began with a mix of emotions for FC Barcelona fans when the club decided to part ways with Xavi Hernández as head coach. For many, it was a shocking and divisive decision. Xavi had delivered a decent campaign last season, including winning La Liga in his first full season. He also introduced promising talents like Lamine Yamal and Cubarsi to the first team, showing his ability to develop young players.
Read to the end HERE
However, others, including myself to some extent, believed the move was a step in the right direction for the club. While Xavi’s impact on rebuilding the team was evident, his ability to guide Barcelona back to being genuine contenders for Europe’s top honours was unclear. The “New Era” Barcelona needed a coach with elite-level experience and tactical mastery to compete with Europe’s finest, and this is where Hansi Flick comes in.
When the club appointed Flick, fans welcomed the decision with great optimism and hope. His track record, particularly his remarkable feat with Bayern Munich, where he famously dismantled Barcelona 8-2 in the Champions League, spoke volumes about his capabilities. He is known as a disciplined, tactical coach who prioritizes structure and confidence, traits that were desperately needed to stabilize Barcelona.

Title: Reinventing FC Barcelona: A New Era Through Data
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
A data-driven strategy to rebuild Barcelona’s core and prepare them for the 2024/25 season.
Barcelona has faced tough times since Covid, especially after losing their biggest star, Lionel Messi. The club has made several big signings since then, but not all have been successful. As a data scientist, I want to imagine a strategy meeting with Deco, Laporta, and Flick to help rebuild Barcelona. Using my Moneyball approach, we’ll explore affordable solutions to strengthen the team where it needs it most.
To tackle Barcelona’s issues, I studied Hansi Flick’s Bayern 2021, a manager and a team I admire. I analyzed key players from that era to find current, affordable alternatives. For example, I used Lewandowski’s 2021 stats to identify a low-cost striker, as Lewy isn’t getting any younger. I also explored Müller’s 2021 profile after Barcelona signed Olmo as a number 10 and Kimmich’s 2021 profile out of curiosity. Beyond Bayern’s comparisons, I felt Barcelona needed a pacey left winger and a creative right back, leading me to analyze Nico Williams and Cancelo from the 2023–24 season.
Finally, I’ll share my ideal lineup and the reasoning behind each choice. Let’s dive into the data.
For Cancelo, I employed a dual approach: first, I analyzed his aggregated stats from the last four seasons to identify proven players with consistent performances. This method helps to highlight experienced players who have maintained high levels of play over several years. Second, I focused on his stats from the most recent season to uncover any potential hidden gems. This strategy is particularly useful for spotting emerging talents who had standout performances last season and could offer great value as rising stars.
Barcelona’s tradition of dynamic full-backs demands a solid replacement for Cancelo. Last year’s signing was reminiscent of Barcelona’s golden days, but with no clear pursuit of Cancelo now, I explored low-cost alternatives.
Di Lorenzo and Hamari Traoré emerged as top options. Traoré, in particular, shows promise as a strong, reliable choice.
Despite a dip, Cancelo’s playmaking remained elite.
Among new talents, Tiago Santos stood out. He’s quick, skillful, and has the potential to grow into a superstar, though he can be caught defensively at times.
For his age, Tiago Santos shows great potential. Barcelona could lock down the right-back position, a position that since Dani Alves left never looked the same, for years with him. While he occasionally struggles defensively, especially in aerial duels, with the right development and environment, he has the makings of a future superstar. Portugal’s depth at right-back is impressive, and Santos could be the next big name.
Tiago Santos. His blend of youth, skill, and potential makes him the right choice to secure Barcelona’s right-back position for the future.
Nico Williams is a top-class winger — exactly the type of player who is direct, exciting, and can create something out of nothing. There were strong links to Barcelona, but it seems he’s staying at Athletic Club, where he’s been honored with the iconic number 10 shirt. With that in mind, I explored low-cost alternatives through a Moneyball approach using his 2023–24 La Liga stats.
Sávio was another strong candidate, but he’s already settled at Manchester City. After eliminating left-footed wingers and those recently transferred, Chris Führich from VfB Stuttgart became the standout choice. Führich shares many qualities with Williams: he’s quick, direct, and has a knack for creating opportunities in tight situations. His playstyle could make him an effective and low-cost option for Barcelona.
Although it may not have the same allure as a big-name signing, this is about finding under-the-radar talents that fit the needs. In fact, Führich could also be a great addition to a team like Arsenal, known for their creative and dynamic wingers.
So, while it may not be the headline-grabbing signing fans might hope for, going for Chris Führich would be a smart and pragmatic decision for Barcelona.
Lewandowski’s 2020–21 season was his peak — a complete striker at the top of his game. Although he’s still delivering for Barcelona, it’s time to plan for the future. Using his 2020–21 stats as a benchmark, I analyzed current players to find a similar profile.
Top names like Haaland and Kane naturally showed up, but they’re either unattainable or don’t fit Barca’s needs. Jonathan David, however, stood out as the ideal low-key option. With one year left on his contract, he’s an affordable, long-term solution who can grow into the role.
Based on the data, Barcelona should strongly consider Jonathan David as Lewandowski’s heir.
In the 2020–21 Bayern squad, Müller and Kimmich caught my eye for their extraordinary performances, so I decided to explore how Barcelona could benefit from similar players.
Müller is often underrated, but in 2020–21, he was truly world-class. Using our Moneyball approach, we explored potential alternatives to Müller, identifying players who exhibit similar qualities.
And who do we see among the top alternatives? None other than Dani Olmo — a player who might just be the key to Barcelona’s future under Flick. It’s intriguing to see Olmo here, and it feels like a promising sign for what’s to come.
Also, a special mention to one of my favorite playmakers in Europe, Lorenzo Pellegrini, whose inclusion here highlights his underrated brilliance. These insights could be vital in shaping a creative and effective midfield for Barcelona.
It feels like more than just a coincidence that Olmo appears among the top alternatives. His presence here might be a significant indicator of how well he could fit into Flick’s system at Barcelona. Let’s wait and see how Olmo performs under Flick’s guidance — there’s a lot of potential for something special to develop.
When news broke that Tuchel didn’t see Kimmich as a central midfielder last season, it sent shockwaves through the football world. To me, it was baffling, given how Kimmich was one of the best in that position during the 2020–21 season. A move to Barcelona seems like a perfect fit, though it would be costly this summer. Perhaps next year, with his contract nearing its end, it might be more feasible.
Here’s what I found when comparing his 2020–21 stats with current players.
The list of top names didn’t surprise me, but one detail might have slipped by — yes, Ilkay Gündoğan from last season is in there. With news of him leaving for free, it’s a significant loss for Barcelona. It will be interesting to see how they adapt and what strategies Flick might propose to fill that gap.
With all the key positions addressed and some interesting insights uncovered along the way, it’s time to visualize how Barcelona could shape up for the 2024/25 season using the data-driven approach we’ve explored.
Let’s take a look at the proposed lineup and see how these carefully selected players can help Barcelona reach new heights under the guidance of Hansi Flick.
If Barcelona were to follow my data-driven approach, this lineup would reflect not only the numbers but also my vision of football.
I opted for Christensen because he has exceeded expectations in the deeper midfield role, especially crucial in the first leg against PSG where his absence was felt in the second leg. De Jong’s ability to carry the ball from deep is invaluable, but with Pedri and Gavi’s injury issues, especially Gavi’s serious one, it’s wise to manage their workload.
I also prefer having a left-footed center-back for optimal passing angles. The full-backs should be balanced, with one focusing on direct play and the other offering creativity. On the wings, a skillful player paired with a direct one complements an all-round forward to complete the ideal setup.
I might be stepping into Flick’s shoes, but this lineup is inspired by his best side.
This approach demonstrates how a data-driven approach can offer practical solutions for squad building, even for a club as prestigious as Barcelona.
The proposed lineup represents a balanced approach, incorporating a mix of youth, experience, and players who align with Flick’s tactical philosophy. While it might seem underwhelming compared to Real Madrid’s recent signings, these players are chosen based on their fit within the system and potential to grow into key roles.
What do you think of this lineup? Who would you suggest using your data-driven approach to strengthen the squad?
For those interested in the technical details, you can find the complete code for this project on my GitHub repository.
If you’re interested in football analytics or data science, I encourage you to check out the full project on GitHub. Feel free to experiment with the code, apply it to your favorite team or other struggling teams, and share your findings. Let’s continue to push the boundaries of football analysis together!
As a Football Data Specialist with a rich academic background and hands-on experience across diverse sectors, my journey has taught me the power of knowledge sharing.
I firmly believe that sharing our experiences is not only a powerful way to help others but also a means to evolve ourselves. That’s why I’ve launched my newsletter, please subscribe to my newsletter Dream Databall and join me on this exhilarating journey through the world of football analytics. Let’s dive deep into the data, explore new insights, and advance the game together.
Check out my Payhip store for resources that can kickstart your journey to becoming a distinguished football analyst. Embrace the learning process; it’s where your true potential unfolds.
I welcome collaboration and exchange of ideas, so feel free to connect with me to discuss insights, offer feedback, or if you need advice at marwanehamdani@gmail.com.
Enjoy the content, and I’ll see you on the dugout!

Title: My top 10 places to see in Barcelona
Content:
Sign up

Share
Recommended time of stay 1.5 weeks
Overall Vibe of the place: fun, touristy, energetic, friendly
Barcelona! Wow what a perfect place to start off my solo trip, it is full of life, architecture, friendly people. It just has this fun, friendly party vibe to it with so much to see. But it also has a huge amount of tourists so be ready for lots of people walking around with camera’s, there are also a lot of pickpockets especially in the touristy areas so be sure to watch your stuff. My friend came to visit me in Barcelona and got his wallet stolen and was only there for like 4 days. It’s definitely a huge problem but you should be fine as long as you are careful.
There really is so much to see in Barcelona but here are my top places that just really stood out.
If there is one place you need to go to in Barcelona it is the Sagrada Famillia. My heart literally jumps every time I see it, the architecture is just so detailed and fantastical, I was amazed to find a new thing every time I examined the structure. With detailed carving all around, mosaic tiles, and words all around the building it is the most interesting beautiful building I’ve ever seen in my life. It kind of reminds me of a magical and very detailed sand castle.
Now to go over the inside, I would say it is worth is to see it on the outside just onlooking the building but it is even MORE worth it to go inside. I got so emotional inside I literally had to cry a little because it was just so beautiful I couldn’t believe it. With tall grand high ceilings meant to replicate trees, and rainbow colors of light reflecting through the windows it just had this sacred feeling to it. I’m pretty sure I stayed inside for at least an hour just looking around taking it all in. I honestly can’t compare it to any other place I’ve been to. It sort of has this sci-fi feeling to it like your in a futuristic spaceship or something. I love Gaudis work for his uses of curves, and combining classical architectural ideas with natural subjects and designs.
A little about the building, it was built by Antoni Gaudi and it is so detailed it is still not complete yet but is projected to be done in 2026 (I can’t wait to see it completed!) to coincide with Gaudi’s death in 1926. Gaudi’s body is also buried inside of the Sagrada Famillia which makes sense since he dedicated part of his life to working on this structure and never worried about how long it would take. I guess this really teaches you truly great things take a lot of time.
Also I recommend you purchase your tickets AT LEAST 3 days in advanced I bought mine 2 weeks in advance which you don’t need to do but they sell out very fast.
Another building designed by the great Antoni Gaudi (he really is a genius and I wish I could’ve met him). Located in the Illa de la Discòrdia and commissioned by Josep Battló who was a wealthy textile manufacturer. He gave Gaudi full creative access to do whatever he pleased and boy did he. Their are no straight edges throughout the entire building and it has this sort of under water playful aquatic feel to it. When I was climbing up the stairs I felt as if I was in a pool of some sort. Once you get to the top you have an stunning view of the city along with mosaic designs throughout the top area. I’ve never been in any place like this and I don’t think there are many building out there with these types of designs so it is a must see especially for architecture lovers.
I will admit this is a very touristy area but I can definitely see why, I love walking through the small alleys with beautiful windows and architectural designs with every step you take. Also I’m not a big person for tourist shops but these shops seemed less basic and more interesting. I bought a handmade leather bracelet as my tourist item and the women makes all of it there she even sized it in front of me to fit my tiny wrist haha. The restaurants are all fantastic in this location and be sure to buy some hot chocolate they have rich, thick hot chocolate almost everywhere you go, its basically hot pudding and it is heaven.
Right in the Gothic District is the Gothic Quarter and it is free to go in at the right times (From 8 a.m. to 12:45 p.m. and 5:45 p.m. to 7:30 p.m) otherwise you just need to pay a donation fee. The building took almost 2 centuries to build, yeah thats right and you can tell walking past it you can’t help but stop and stare and it to take in all the elegance of it.
This is the beach to go to just to sit and relax, its right next to the Gothic Quarter so its the perfect place to take in some sun after walking around all day. The water is really warm I even checked it out at night and it was still warm and swimmable. Theres a lot of young tourists here and it’s next to all the nightlife happening so this is the place to be.
The Picasso Museum is one of the best museums to go to for all you Picasso fans out there. It shows his evolution as an artist and how he did different things at different periods in his life. I have to say I was very pulled into his simple pencil and paper drawings since I like to draw myself it was refreshing to see some his mistakes and messy lines which really reassured me as an artist that everyone makes mistakes. It also showed me that it is completely normal to go through different design periods throughout your life. His work really took me away and brought me into his most memorable times in his life. I didn’t realize this till later but the museum is free Thursday nights from 6:30–9:00pm to try to check it out then.
Another wonderful achievement by Antoni Gaudi, originally a garden city and later commissioned by Eusebi Güell to redesign it. He continues with his playful, colorful, and smooth designs throughout the park. He wanted to keep its natural design and just build on top of that. While adding detailed mosaic tiles and keeping the natural ground stones all over the park. Not to mention the spectacular view you get of the entire city in the park, this is definitely a place you wouldn’t want to miss.
This is the club I went to to see one of my favorite bands and the show was amazing but I was blown away by the club myself. This is a place where people come for music and I can tell I even made some friends on the rooftop of the club. There is a stairwell section with red lights and the design of it just really surprised and delighted me. No one was pushy here and the drinks weren’t too much definitely a place to check out if your into live music.
Since I was in Spain I had to try out the rich thick hot chocolate that they seemed to have everywhere and hands down this place is the best. I can really tell the quality and taste is truly exquisite. I love the interior of this place also it’s really great for just working on your computer and relaxing and the staff was very friendly and polite.
Located in Catalonia, Spain this huge museum is surely a place to check out while you’re in Barcelona. They have all different types of artwork throughout history ranging from gothic artwork to renaissance showing how history has made art evolve throughout time. They also have a featured side exhibit at the museum, when I went it was Dali and Gala and how they both inspired each other with their artwork. This is a huge museum so be sure to plan staying for the full day (I would say 2–4 hours at least).
I really hope this helps you out on your next trip to Barcelona and let me know if you do go to any of these places!
--
--
My goal is to share my journey, experiences and designs with you. I try to bring in a unique perspective into everything I see.

Title: My Top 4 Breakfast Spots in Barcelona — As a Local
Content:

Sign in

Listen
Share
Intro
As someone who wakes up early, I have come to appreciate breakfast out of the house more and more. Either as a solitary occasion to gather my thoughts, take time out, and plan for the day, or as a social event with a like-minded early riser, usually a fellow entrepreneur in my case, such as my good friend and local businessman Gunter, who is in the sex shop business, but that is a curious side note. We all know having variety in your personal and business network is wise!
So, after doing the rounds and trying several breakfast places out, a few good, some mediocre, and many terrible, I want to document my own personal top 4 in Barcelona.
If you are looking for coffee shops or patisseries, this will not be the article for you. There is an abundance of these in the city. Being an amateur athlete (I say that very loosely, as if football and gym sessions count for something) and a growing boy, I need some protein for breakfast, so to qualify for my list, the places needed to have some solid egg-based or protein dishes as menu mainstays. Also, and I must be pedantic on this, I am talking strictly about breakfast, and not what has come to be the trend in recent years — dare I say it — brunch! Please allow me to go on a tangent here before we get to my list, but I am pretty much anti-brunch and anti a lot of what brunch represents. Don’t get me wrong, the dishes are nice, but the concept of mid-morning eating of what is essentially breakfast for late risers and posers is not my cup of tea. I’m here for the good old-fashioned pre-10:00 a.m. breakfast, or 08:00 on the dot if I can get it.
So here is my list, as a local in Barcelona and in no particular order of ranking:
№1: El Corte Inglés
Plaça de Catalunya, 14, 08002 Barcelona
Classic, no-nonsense, and great price point. Open from 09:00, you can choose from either an omelette and toast or freshly made Tortilla de Patatas with toast. Located pretty centrally in Plaza Catalunya.
№2: Café de l’Architecte
Rambla de Catalunya, 76, 08008 Barcelona (attached to Hotel Condes de Barcelona)
A bar and restaurant attached to the hotel Hotel Condes which sits on the corner of Rambla Catalunya with Passatge de la Concepció. It’s a nice spot and an intimate meeting point. Open from 09:00, it would be great if it opened at 08:00, but I guess they don’t see too much demand for that. They offer a nice variation of choices and additional ingredients for your omelette or scrambled eggs. If they were to add some artisanal coffee and tea options, to their menu it would be a plus, but I will cut them some slack on this, as the establishment has an air of the traditional to it.
№3: Billy Brunch
Various locations throughout the city.
One of the best for options, variety, and choice. It’s probably better known as a brunch spot, but it opens at 09:30 for people like myself who value breakfast over brunch. I’ve been to various locations of theirs throughout the city, and I’m yet to be disappointed by the service. There is thought attached to the attention to detail of the service at Billy Brunch, which I love especially because Barcelona restaurants often struggle to offer good service, mainly because they probably don’t feel they need to make an effort with such a high footfall of tourists and transient clientele walking in. Billy Brunch however bucks that trend, and they make a fantastic Chai Latte, one of the better ones in the city actually which is always a plus for me as someone who doesn’t drink coffee.
№4: Citizen Café
Pl. d’Urquinaona, 4, L’Eixample, 08010 Barcelona
One of the few good breakfast places in Barcelona that opens from 08:00. This spot became my place for post-early-morning gym session fuelling. Located in Urquinaona and with a wide variety of menu options, this is breakfast done well and at the proper time for those of us who have busy days ahead and things to get on with. The staff have been very pleasant here in my experience. Like the other options that serve brunch, this place starts to fill up quite quickly. It’s been a few weeks since I’ve been myself, so I’m looking forward to heading back here soon.
There might be some options that are new or that I am not aware of. I typically value a central location if I am meeting people, so maybe there are local spots in Barcelona’s neighbourhoods that I should consider. By the way, if you’re local and in business like myself and fancy joining me next time for a networking breakfast, shoot me a message. Remember, breakfast not brunch! And if you are visiting this wonderful city and looking for some early-opening, good options for breakfast, then I hope you enjoy these recommendations and let me know how you get on with them in the comments.
--
--
Barcelona-based founder. Building stuff, breaking down, rebuilding again, and writing about all of it.

Not good defensively, but the offense doesn’t compensate for it.
