Title: My Barcelona Adventure: Embracing the Perilous Path
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
In the words of the celebrated author Paulo Coelho, “The danger of adventure is worth a thousand days of ease and comfort.” With this profound quotation in mind, I embarked on a thrilling journey to the captivating city of Barcelona. Armed with an open heart and a sense of wanderlust, I set out to explore the enchanting streets, immerse myself in the vibrant culture, and discover the untold stories that lay hidden beneath its façade. Little did I know that this adventure would lead me to encounter unexpected encounters with diverse souls from across the globe, each contributing to the kaleidoscope of experiences that shaped my time in Barcelona. Join me as I unravel the tale of my adventurous sojourn, where the allure of the unknown merged seamlessly with the promise of self-discovery. This is a chronicle of courage, resilience, and the magic that unfolds when we dare to step outside our comfort zones and embrace the uncharted path. Welcome to My Barcelona Adventure.
Making the trip
Attending an international school with the power of a Schengen passport and having a bunch of GenZ classmates, I felt the pressure to travel, explore the world, and find peace out of my comfort zone. It took me five months to gather the courage to leave Madrid. Initially, I had plans to visit a Liberian in Barcelona whom I didn’t know much about, but she had assured me of taking good care of me and showing me around the city. Our conversation started back in November 2022, and I had considered traveling in December 2022 during our most extended school break when everyone was going to their home country to see their family and loved ones. However, I had to prioritize completing my NIE process — to obtain a resident permit for my studies at IE Business School. Then, I postponed the trip to January 2023, and later to February 2023, feeling unsure and indecisive. Finally, I decided to take the plunge and booked a train within a week, thanks to the stipend from my scholarship.
I informed my Liberian “host” that I was finally coming to Barcelona. I shared my travel details and attempted to have a phone conversation, but she was primarily busy or unresponsive. Nonetheless, I didn’t ask her directly if she would be hosting me, as she had previously promised to show me around.
The scheduled trip was set for 8 pm after the end of our second term, and while everyone else seemed excited, I found myself feeling a bit bored (details that I will highlight in a subsequent blog). But despite the mixed emotions, there was an underlying sense of excitement as I was finally going to spend an amazing weekend in Barcelona. Everything was seemingly set for my adventure.
Dammit!
Just as I was about to board the train to Barcelona, I received a message from my host:
“Did you book an Airbnb?”
Oh no! I realized that I had made a mistake. I should have clarified the accommodation arrangements with her beforehand. I replied, admitting that I hadn’t booked an Airbnb, but I also didn’t explicitly mention my assumption that she would be hosting me. During the two-hour trip from Madrid to Barcelona, I frantically searched for a suitable and affordable Airbnb, but to my dismay, the prices were about 20% higher in Barcelona compared to Madrid. I couldn’t find any suitable option during the train journey, and so I arrived in Barcelona Sants, the train station, without a place to stay.
My Liberian “host” had initially assured me that she would pick me up from Barcelona Sants upon my arrival. However, as I reached out to inform her of my presence, she regretfully informed me that she couldn’t fulfill her promise. Her friend, who was supposed to provide the transportation, had become occupied with other matters. I found myself stranded at Barcelona Sants, the clock ticking closer to midnight, and the weight of the situation settling upon me.
In this unexpected situation, I had no choice but to find an available Airbnb and get myself out of the train station as soon as possible. The stress of the moment was mounting, and I knew I had to act swiftly to secure a place to stay for the night.
Fortunately, I managed to find a suitable place called Hola Hostel, which perfectly fit my criteria of being affordable and charming. The added bonus was its convenient location, just a short 3-minute walk away from Spotify Camp Nou. With a sense of relief, I made my way to the nearest metro station, ready to face the challenges of navigating Barcelona without the aid of Google Maps since my phone had switched off.
Despite the hurdles and occasional moments of uncertainty, I arrived safely at Hola Hostel. The staff was welcoming, and I arranged my accommodation for the next two nights. It felt like a small victory, given the earlier setback, and I was eager to make the most of my time in Barcelona, even without my phone’s constant guidance.
I went to bed by 2:00 AM
The Indian Couple
When I arrived at Hola Hostel, I immediately headed for a refreshing shower in one of the bathrooms. The following day, on February 25, 2023, I returned to the bathroom to brush my teeth but inadvertently left my toothpaste behind. Upon getting my toothpaste and exiting the bathroom, I bumped into a friendly lady named Divya, who was standing at the door. I could tell from her expression that she was a bit surprised to see me, as the bathroom was probably designated for females only. Realizing my mistake, I felt a bit embarrassed, but Divya was understanding and welcoming, which helped ease my discomfort.
In an attempt to make up for my awkward encounter, I struck up a conversation with Divya. Curious to know more about her, I asked where she was from. She shared that she was from India and currently studying in Austria. Learning that she was also a tourist like me, I asked about her plans for the day. I had little faith in my Liberian “host”, given the earlier miscommunication, and was looking for an enjoyable day out in Barcelona. Divya mentioned that she and her boyfriend, Kabir, were going to the stadium, specifically Camp Nou. To my surprise, she kindly invited me to join them.
Although I had initially hoped for a spontaneous adventure with a fellow solo traveler, I was still excited to explore Camp Nou with the couple. Despite my mixed emotions, I found Kabir to be friendly and welcoming as well. Our trip to the stadium turned out to be a wonderful experience, and I was grateful for the unexpected company and the opportunity to share this adventure with new friends.
After Camp Nou, what’s next?
Everyone should visit Camp Nou or a football stadium as beautiful and historic as Camp Nou at least once in their lifetime. Even though I am not a Barcelona fan, my visit to Camp Nou brought me closer to the team, enriched me with its history, and made me appreciate the beauty of football even more. We embarked on a comprehensive 360 tour of the stadium, and in my enthusiasm, I found myself lagging behind a couple of times, giving them some privacy for romantic moments, and bombarding them with numerous questions. Divya and Kabir, while initially patient, seemed to become a bit exasperated with my curiosity.
At the end of the tour, they mentioned that they were planning to find an Indian restaurant to have lunch. However, when I asked to join them, they hesitated and said they would be meeting some friends, leaving me to figure out my next move. It was already 1:00 pm, and I hadn’t received any communication from my Liberian “host” yet. The uncertainty of my situation started to weigh on me as I contemplated what to do next in this unfamiliar city.
After the somewhat awkward situation at Spotify Camp Nou, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I spotted a McDonald’s nearby and saw it as an opportunity to charge my phone and grab some lunch. It was a relieving break, allowing me to regroup and plan my next steps.
Around 2:00 PM, I finally received a response from my Liberian “host”. She once again apologized for not being able to pick me up from the Hostel as promised, explaining that her friend was occupied. While I appreciated her honesty, I couldn’t help but feel a bit disappointed by the turn of events. Nevertheless, we had a brief chat, and she recommended some places for me to explore in Barcelona.
Equipped with her suggestions and a charged phone, I set out to make the most of the remainder of the day. I embraced the idea of navigating the city on my own, using the newfound freedom to delve into the sights and sounds of Barcelona, appreciating every moment of this unplanned adventure.
With a sense of excitement and curiosity, I made up my mind to visit the renowned Sagrada Familia, the largest unfinished Roman Catholic church in the world. I navigated my way to the nearest metro station, and to my delight, I encountered a kind-hearted Colombian individual who communicated with me through sign language. Sergio’s warm demeanor and willingness to assist me made me feel at ease.
With Sergoi’s help, I confirmed that I was headed in the right direction to reach Sagrada Familia. He even suggested a sightseeing tour of the exterior of the magnificent building, which seemed like a wonderful idea to me. Instead of paying 50 euros to see the interior, I opted for the chance to marvel at the breathtaking architecture from the outside.
Throughout the journey on the metro, Sergio continued to wear a beautiful smile, making me feel grateful for their company and guidance. He reminded me to be careful and watchful during our ride together, emphasizing the importance of safety.
I arrived at my destination and bid Sergio farewell as he was stopping at the next metro and I couldn’t help but feel a sense of gratitude for this serendipitous encounter. I embarked on my sightseeing adventure, eager to explore the awe-inspiring beauty of Sagrada Familia, while cherishing the memory of the unexpected friendship formed through a shared moment of communication.
Oh my gosh!
Sagrada Familia is indeed a breathtaking marvel. This awe-inspiring cathedral, designed by the visionary architect Antoni Gaudí, commenced its construction in 1882. Gaudí’s artistic genius and innovative architectural concepts have left an indelible mark on the world, making Sagrada Familia a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate hearts and minds.
Standing outside Sagrada Familia felt like stepping into a diverse paradise. Conversations in English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese intermingled, creating a vibrant tapestry of languages and cultures. The scene was nothing short of beautiful, with a lively and diverse crowd filling the air with excitement and energy. Among the approximately 200 people surrounding me, all on their own purported pilgrimage to this grand cathedral, I stood as a solo traveler, somewhat frustrated with my Liberian “host”, yet elated to be present at Sagrada Familia in that very moment.
At the cathedral’s entrance, a multitude of tourists buzzed with activity, some trying to enter, while others were exiting. The atmosphere was warm and electric, as people chatted, danced, sang, and savored their meals. The ambiance was alive with a festive spirit.
I took my time exploring the surroundings, capturing precious moments through photographs, walking amidst the crowd, and savoring the melodic tunes of Spanish guitarists. However, after about an hour and thirty minutes, I craved a different experience. The time neared 5:00 PM, and still, there had been no word from my Liberian “host”.
Abdelali and how we found each other
Just as I was about to check my phone and prepare to leave the grounds of Sagrada Familia, a gentle touch on my back startled me. Hoping to find a fellow solo traveler, perhaps an English-speaking lady, eager to explore like myself, I turned around, only to meet the gaze of a fair-skinned young man with a shy expression. He stood at an average height, and with a friendly smile, he made a simple request, “Can you take my picture?”
Intrigued, I gladly obliged and inquired about his name. He introduced himself as Abdelali, a Moroccan student studying in France, who had come to Barcelona for a vacation. Abdelali, as it turned out, was quite the seasoned traveler himself. Having lived in Ukraine and explored various destinations within the Schengen area, he had accumulated a wealth of experiences and stories.
Our conversation flowed effortlessly as I expressed my eagerness for the next adventure and sought his recommendations. “Can we go to the beach?” I asked him. Graciously, Abdelali agreed to accompany me on this new escapade, explaining that he also had a booking issue to resolve with an Airbnb on the nearby beach.
With a newfound travel companion by my side, I felt a renewed sense of excitement and anticipation. Barcelona’s beach beckoned, and with Abdelali as my guide, I knew this impromptu journey would be filled with unforgettable moments and the shared joy of exploration. Together, we embarked on our beach adventure, ready to embrace the unknown and cherish the bond formed through the serendipity of travel.
Within about 30 minutes, Abdelali and I managed to find the nearest metro station, and with ease, we hopped on a bus that swiftly transported us to Barceloneta, the most renowned and beloved beach in Barcelona. As my eyes beheld the splendor of the beach, the swaying palm trees, and the vast expanse of the ocean, my soul felt an immediate revival. The stress and worries of the day seemed to dissipate, replaced by a profound sense of relief, and I prepared to immerse myself in the wonders of nature.
It had been a long five months since I last set eyes on a beach, and Barceloneta turned out to be the most stunning one I had ever encountered. The beach exuded a lively and vibrant atmosphere, adorned with the rhythmic sounds of Spanish music and the delightful aroma of typical Spanish cuisine that enveloped the air. The sun radiated warmth, casting its golden rays upon everything in its path, bringing joy to every heart and a smile to every face.
As I strolled along the shoreline, my spirit lifted with every turn and every glance at the people around me. The beach was a lively tapestry of young and old people engaged in joyful activities such as singing, dancing, riding bicycles, or simply relishing delightful conversations with their friends. After assisting Abdelali in resolving his Airbnb issue, I couldn’t resist the allure of the ocean any longer. With a hunger to inhale its salty breeze and bask in its refreshing embrace, I rushed towards the waves, ready to surrender myself to the soothing rhythm of the sea.
At that moment, under the azure sky, surrounded by laughter, music, and shimmering waters, I felt a profound sense of gratitude. Barcelona had unexpectedly gifted me a beautiful beach experience, and with Abdelali by my side, the day unfolded as a serendipitous tale of camaraderie and delight. The wonders of nature had worked their magic, and I couldn’t help but sigh in relief, cherishing the blissful escapade that was Barceloneta.
Abdelali and I continued our exploration of Barcelona, hopping on a bus that traversed the city’s vibrant streets. Our journey led us to two more captivating destinations — the Arena de Barcelona and the Barcelona Magic Fountain. At each location, I couldn’t help but marvel at the exuberant merrymaking, the infectious music, and the palpable joy of adventure that surrounded us.
Throughout our day together, Abdelali and I forged a deep bond, sharing laughter, stories, and a genuine sense of camaraderie. As the clock neared 8 pm, we found ourselves at the mesmerizing Barcelona Magic Fountain. The atmosphere was nothing short of enchanting, with the grand building overlooking the fountain, creating a mountain-like backdrop that added to the fountain’s allure. The music that resonated through the air had a captivating effect on Abdelali, making him hesitant to leave the scene.
However, despite the temptation to stay longer, I needed to see my Liberian “host” who had been elusive throughout the day. We made a compromise; I assured Abdelali that I would find her and catch up afterward. He understood my situation, and with a sense of excitement, we made plans to explore Barcelona’s vibrant nightlife, heading to clubs and reveling in the city’s after-dark magic.
Our shared adventure had been a rollercoaster of emotions, from the initial frustration with my “host” to the serendipitous encounter with Abdelali that led to a day filled with joy and discovery. As we set off on our respective paths for the moment, I knew that this chance encounter had added a touch of magic to my Barcelona adventure. With the promise of an exhilarating night ahead, I felt a renewed sense of anticipation, eager to embrace whatever the night had in store for us.
Dammit!
I must admit, I found myself in quite a predicament. As I bid farewell to Abdelali, my phone battery was barely holding on at a mere 1%. I felt a tinge of embarrassment, knowing that I had my charger with me but no power bank to rely on. The truth was, I had underestimated how terrible my iPhone 8’s battery life had become, simply because I spent most of my time either at school or home, where a stable electricity supply was always at hand.
Despite the low battery, I couldn’t shake the urge to meet my elusive Liberian “host.” There was an inexplicable determination within me, perhaps fueled by the need to confirm her existence or to consider this trip a resounding success. Regardless of the reason, I knew I had to see her. There was no room for giving up now.
With the address she sent me, I asked Abdelali to help me navigate using Google Maps. Together, we discovered the nearest metro station and embarked on the journey. The destination seemed distant, approximately 45 minutes away, spanning 11 metro stations, and requiring two train changes.
As I reached the final metro station, I finally managed to charge my phone and mustered the courage to call my Liberian “host.” A deep breath of relief escaped me as I spoke to her in our familiar Liberian parlance, “I am here oo, come for me na.” There was a mix of emotions swirling within me, ranging from anticipation to trepidation, as I eagerly awaited her arrival. This moment would mark the culmination of a day filled with unexpected twists and turns, making it all the more meaningful
But apparently, I had gone to a different province. The address Abdelali put on the map was the name of the address as my Liberian “ host”, but it was in the wrong province. She lived out of central Barcelona and when I checked Google Maps, it was about 1 hour by metro and 30 minutes by taxi at the cost of 35 euros. Should I visit my Liberian “host” by 11:00 PM? If yes, how?
Stuck on the train with a Chinese lady at midnight
After an intense period of brainstorming and careful consideration, lasting about 30 minutes, I finally reached a decision. I opted to take the metro, convinced that it would offer a relatively seamless journey, granted I exercised a fair amount of patience. Thus, I embarked on the one-hour metro trip to reach my elusive Liberian “host.”
As the journey commenced, I was filled with a mix of anticipation and determination. The initial phase consisted of the first two metro stops, followed by a train transfer to reach Cardanyola del Valles in the Ripollet province of Barcelona. Navigating my way to the train station posed quite the challenge, compounded by my phone’s meager 20% battery life and the time being around 11:45 PM. The streets were dimly lit, and the cold night air only added to the intensity of the situation.
Undeterred, I forged ahead, maneuvering through the darkness with a blend of courage and concern. The gravity of my determination to meet my Liberian “host” kept me going, outweighing the difficulties I faced. At this point, the journey had transformed into a personal mission — a testament to my refusal to surrender and my unwavering commitment to finally meet the person I had been seeking throughout the day.
I boarded the train to Cardanyola del Valles with a sense of immense relief. At long last, I had reached the final leg of my journey, even though I still had to walk approximately 12 minutes from the train station to my Liberian “host’s” residence. I repeatedly checked my phone, ensuring that I was on the correct train and that the timing was right. Everything seemed to be proceeding as planned until an unexpected turn of events occurred when the train abruptly stopped, just two stops away from my intended destination. The other passengers disembarked, and I couldn’t help but wonder if there were more people boarding, or if there was some other reason for the halt. However, my assumption was swiftly proven wrong when the train’s Spanish-speaking driver stepped off and exclaimed, “Estamos deteniéndonos aquí,” which translates to “We are stopping here” in English. Though my Spanish was quite rusty, I grasped the meaning of “aquí,” which meant “here.”
It was at that very moment that a surge of fear coursed through me. The time was around 12:45 AM, and after an entire night of navigating challenges to meet a fellow Liberian, I was now trapped on a stationary train. Looking outside, all I could see were bushes, and the sound of young Spaniards conversing loudly and smoking cigarettes filled the air. Inside the train, I encountered a Chinese lady who appeared shy and possessed a beauty reminiscent of my Chinese classmate, Shuwen. While I couldn’t recall her name, I distinctly remembered the flood of relief that washed over me upon seeing her. Unlike me, her English was limited, and her Spanish, much like mine, left room for serious improvement. Despite the language barrier, we managed to engage in conversation, during which she revealed that she was headed to the second-to-last stop to visit a friend.
At that moment, my sense of altruism took hold. I became more concerned about helping my newfound Chinese friend solve her predicament than I was about finding my Liberian “host.” The night had woven together a fusion of unexpected connections and challenges, revealing the shared threads of humanity that linked us all, regardless of language or origin.
About Alex, the Russian who save my life on the train tracks
After approximately 20 minutes of wandering and conversation, we spotted a train approaching. I halted, and my Chinese friend-in-adventure and I quickly boarded the train. We could not find a Spanish speaker to help us and after the first stop, my friend decided to get off the train. Outside, the night seemed even colder and darker. In the span of 30 seconds, I bombarded her with about five questions, seeking to understand her decision. It became clear that her exit wasn’t due to reaching her intended destination; rather, she appeared quite fearful. Driven by concern for her well-being and a genuine curiosity about her journey, I chose to disembark as well. The time was now around 1:00 AM. Once off the train, she explained that she needed to make this particular stop as it was en route to her destination. However, undertaking this part of her journey alone felt risky, and I pondered whether tagging along might be both a wise and foolish choice for me. I was now faced with the task of charting my own course, yet I had absolutely no clue about my whereabouts.
A few minutes later, we spotted a small group of people across the train tracks. Approaching them, we sought their assistance. As it turned out, they were all headed to the same destination as my friend-in-adventure. A train was due to arrive in just about two minutes. However, when I inquired about my own destination, they appeared to lack information. In those two minutes, I ensured my friend-in-adventure safely boarded the train and bid her farewell. By this point, it was around 1:30 AM, and I found myself alone in an unfamiliar place, my phone powerless and surrounded by the symphony of crickets and frogs. With no inkling of my next steps, I was neither exhilarated by the adventurous thrills nor paralyzed by fear for my safety. I existed in a state of numbness, yet my mind remained incredibly sharp, retaining every encounter and every detail of my intended destination. While placing my faith in God, I desperately needed a tangible guide to direct my earthly path.
After around 10 minutes of aimless contemplation under the dim, cold darkness, I spotted a figure on the other side of the train tracks. He had apparently been standing there for some time, but I hadn’t noticed until now. Swiftly, I made my way towards the man, who possessed distinct Asian features and carried a red Ghana must-go bag. Though I knew nothing about him other than his vague outline, he represented my best chance at finding my way. Upon reaching him, I initiated the conversation in English. While he didn’t respond verbally, his attentive gaze indicated he was listening. When I queried in broken Spanish, “¿Tú hablas español?” (Do you speak Spanish?), he didn’t reply verbally but signaled his inability. This encounter made it evident that he was neither fluent in English nor Spanish. I surmised that he might be from Eastern Europe or Asia, far from home like myself, wandering to his next destination.
Drawing from my limited knowledge of sign language acquired during my brief stint in the Ivory Coast and my early days in Madrid, I managed to communicate with him. Employing these rudimentary gestures, I conveyed my need to use his phone. He gave me his device, and we embarked on a conversation through Google Translate. He introduced himself as Alex, a Russian awaiting the last train that was bound for the same destination as mine. Alex was going to the final stop, and my destination, Cardanyola del Valles, was only one stop away.
Alex was the first Russian I had ever encountered, and his demeanor was as kind as Sergio’s and his willingness to help was reminiscent of Adullai’s. If Alex hadn’t been willing to engage in conversation, provide access to his phone, and offer assistance, I might have spent the night in the middle of nowhere. I might never have met my Liberian “host,” and the course of events could have taken an even more unpredictable turn.
Through a series of coincidences, connections, and the kindness of strangers, I was granted a lifeline just when I needed it most. Alex became an unwitting guardian angel, guiding me out of uncertainty and ensuring I continued my journey, determined to finally meet my Liberian “host” and unlock the mysteries that the night held.
Palm Butter at 3:00 AM
Around 2:00 AM, I arrived at Cardanyola del Valles. The early morning atmosphere was tinged with gloom and solitude. A final challenge lay ahead: a 12-minute walk to reach my Liberian “host.” As I disembarked from the train station, a faint light caught my attention in the distance. I presumed it was a shop, and with a willingness to seize any opportunity, I walked for about five minutes until I reached it. There, I intended to grab a drink and recharge my phone. The women at the shop were hospitable, providing a momentary respite. I used the opportunity to charge my phone and dialed my Liberian “host’s” number. She offered me the most quintessentially Liberian direction: “Walk straight, and as soon as you cross the bridge, turn right.”
Around 2:15 AM, while the ladies at the shop were accommodating, they were also closing for the night. Following my Liberian “host’s” instructions, I proceeded to walk straight and made a right turn after crossing the bridge. However, I couldn’t locate the street address on any of the buildings. After asking numerous strangers and continuing to walk straight while crossing the bridge, I found myself in a perplexing situation. It was then that a couple of helpful strangers informed me that I needed to cross the second bridge, which was around 5 minutes away from the first one I had crossed.
My unease was amplified by the darkness and the unpredictable behavior of some of the strangers I encountered. Observing a nearby McDonald’s, I decided to reach out to my Liberian “host” and inform her that I was unable to proceed any further. The sense of vulnerability I felt in that unfamiliar environment prompted me to prioritize my safety, especially given the hour and the unfamiliar surroundings.
I stayed at the McDonald’s, and within three minutes, I spotted my Liberian “host” walking in, accompanied by another woman. The sight of her erased the earlier feelings of anger, pain, and frustration I had experienced due to her initial inability to provide the support I had expected. In hindsight, I realized that my emotions were more about my own journey than just meeting my Liberian “host.” I felt a surge of happiness, not just because I was seeing her, but because I had refused to give up. I persisted, demonstrated resilience, and come out stronger despite the challenges.
Shortly thereafter, at around 3:00 AM, I found myself on my Liberian friend’s couch, indulging in a familiar dish from Liberia: palm butter and rice. It had been about seven months since I last enjoyed this meal, and its rich flavors and satisfying taste were a welcome treat. Sitting there, I felt a sense of belonging and comfort that I hadn’t experienced in a while. The moment was surreal — encountering a fellow Liberian, savoring a dish from my homeland, and conversing in our native Liberian parlance. No longer did I need to slow down my speech, alter my accent, or speak in standard English, nonstop. I could simply be myself, unapologetically embracing my identity and roots.
My Liberian host was nice after all
My Liberian host greeted me warmly, embracing me with open arms and a genuine sense of hospitality. She willingly shared stories of her own experiences living in Madrid, revealing the mutual connections we had. As we conversed, she emerged as someone who enjoyed a good time but was also driven by a hustling spirit. Having completed her MBA a few years back, she had chosen Spain as her home away from home, embracing it as a place of growth and opportunity.
Finally, the moment arrived when I had the chance to ride in my Liberian host friend’s car, a sleek gray Highlander. Throughout the journey, we played Liberian songs, immersing ourselves in the melodies that connected us to our roots. Eventually, they dropped me off at Hola Hostel, my Airbnb, around 4:00 AM.
The next morning, I awoke and embarked on the train back to Madrid by 1:00 PM.
My trip to Barcelona will forever hold a place as my second most cherished experience in Spain. I am grateful that I allowed myself to fully live through it and finally got the opportunity to share my story with you. I anticipate sharing this story with my grandchildren someday.
Above all, this adventure taught me the importance of proper planning, but even more significantly, it unveiled the beauty of embracing spontaneity.

How I Felt Watching Barcelona Lose – A Fan's Honest Thoughts
It’s not just a football match. It’s not just a scoreline.When Barcelona loses, it feels like a piece of my heart gets bruised.
I still remember the feeling. The final whistle blows. The players drop their heads. And I just sit there, silent, staring at the screen. Not because of the loss—but because of the love. The deep connection I’ve built with this club since I was a kid.
When I watch them lose, I’m not just disappointed. I feel helpless. Because no matter how much I scream at the screen, nothing changes. And yet—I stay. Every game. Every season. Because I believe.
But this loss… it hit harder. Maybe because of how it happened. Maybe because we expected more. Or maybe because I’m just tired of defending a team that sometimes forgets how much they mean to people like us.
Still—I’ll never walk away. Because true fans don’t run when it hurts. We just keep loving harder.

The House on Tibidabo in The Shadow of the Wind
One day during our trip to Barcelona a few years ago we decided to ride all the way to the top of Mount Tibidabo, the highest hill in the city. We had to ride on three separate means of transportation to get to the top, but we did it!
First of all, we walked to the Metro station at Placa de Catalunya and boarded the brown line (L7) train which took us to the base of Avenguda Tibidabo. Then we walked across the street from the Metro exit to board the Tramvia Blau, an old streetcar line, which brought us halfway up the mountain. Finally, we transferred to the Funicular de Tibidabo to get to the top.
There at the top we found an old amusement park adjacent to a Catholic church called Temple Expiatori del Sagrat Cor (The Expiatory Temple of the Sacred Heart). You can see this church and some of the park’s rides from just about anywhere in Barcelona. And we soon found out that you can get one of the best views of Barcelona from the roof of this church.
In Carlos Ruiz Zafon’s masterpiece The Shadow of the Wind we follow Daniel Sempere as he traces the journey of Julian Carax (the author of a book also called The Shadow of the Wind) to the Tibidabo mansion where his love Penelope resides. Zafon himself loved to ride the tram and then the funicular to the top and gaze at the view of Barcelona. The tram opened in 1901 and the blue cars reminded me of San Francisco’s fabled cable cars. It was thrilling to consider that we may have ridden on the same car that carried both Zafon and Sempere up Tibidabo.
There are many turn-of-the-century mansions that line the slopes of Tibidabo. The most prominent is El Pinar, the home of the banker Manuel Arnus near the base of the funicular and the end of the line of the blue tram. I photographed this house after exiting the funicular on the way back down Tibidabo. I at first thought that this was Zafon’s mansion but later discovered that Zafon himself told us that the address of Torre Aldaya in The Shadow of the Wind was Avenguda Tibidabo 32, which is a few hundred meters down the hill. The building at this address is not as gothic looking like El Pinar and Zafon probably combined the appearances of several Tibidabo mansions when he imagined Torre Aldaya. The building at # 32 is now the Hotel Mirlo, a five-star boutique hotel.
El Pinar was designed by the famous architect Enric Sagnier in 1902 and the house was completed in 1904. Sagnier also designed the magnificent Sagrat Cor at the top of Tibidabo. The church’s crypt was built between 1902 and 1911 and construction of the upper church began in 1915. Sagnier’s son Josep Maria Sagnier completed the construction in 1961. The original statue of the Sacred Heart on the roof of the church was destroyed during the Spanish Civil War in 1936. The present statue, by Josep Miret, was completed in 1950. In this photo one of Christ’s apostles overlooks Barcelona and the huge communications tower on the next hill.
I understand the Tramvia Blau is presently closed for reconstruction. There is a bus (# 196) that now connects the Metro with the funicular.
Zafon wrote The Shadow of the Wind in 2002. It was translated into English by Lucia Graves in 2009. I came across it in early 2015 and immediately began plans for a trip to Barcelona and we flew to Spain later that year. The second book in the cycle Zafon has named The Cemetery of Forgotten Books is called The Angel’s Game. I read most of that book on the plane and finished it during our stay in Barcelona. It is a prequel to The Shadow of the Wind. I then read the third book in the cycle, The Prisoner of Heaven, shortly after returning from our trip. Lucia Graves, the excellent translator of Zafon’s Spanish works, completed the translation of The Labyrinth of the Spirits in 2019. I didn’t get around to reading it until last year. Then I reread the other three books and enjoyed them considerably. I’ll probably read all of them again someday.
Zafon was born in Barcelona in 1964 and later moved to Los Angeles where he wrote screenplays in English. But he wrote all of his fiction in Spanish. He died of cancer in 2020 at the age of 55.
Most of the actions in The Shadow of the Wind take place in the Bari Gotic and Raval neighborhoods south of Placa de Catalunya. Visitors to Barcelona can sign up for a three-hour literary walking tour that covers these areas. Tibidabo is too far away to be included in this tour, however. We didn’t take the walking tour, but we came across many of Zafon’s landmarks while following a couple of walks that Rick Steves recommends in his Pocket Barcelona.
Tibidabo gets its name from two Latin words: dabo meaning “I will give” and tibi meaning “to you.” For more info on Barcelona’s highest hill see my Crow Canyon Journal blog postings here and here. Better yet, read either an English version of the Bible or St Jerome’s translation into Latin of Matthew 4:09. And then read all four books in The Cemetery of Forgotten Books cycle for the full story of the Semperes, Daniel’s friend Fermin Romero de Torres, and that haunted mansion halfway up Mount Tibidabo.

Title: FC Barcelona Femení 2024/25 —what have we seen this season?
Content:

Share
Last summer, I published an article taking a comprehensive analytical approach to FC Barcelona Femení’s 2023/24 season by discussing the principles underpinning their attacking play. When the piece was published in July, it was official that then-head coach Jonatan Giráldez would leave the club for a new challenge in the United States. Later in the summer, it was announced that Giráldez would be succeeded by his assistant, Pere Romeu. Given Romeu’s internal promotion, it was reasonable to expect minimal changes, though every coach brings their own ideas that can fully flourish under their leadership.
Over the summer, some squad changes influenced the team’s autumn dynamics: forward/attacking midfielder Mariona Caldentey left for Arsenal, and right-back Lucy Bronze returned to England to join Chelsea. At the same time, prolific striker Ewa Pajor was signed from Wolfsburg, and forward/attacking midfielder Kika Nazareth arrived from Benfica, as forward Salma Paralluelo was sidelined with an injury/playing overload.
Since the start of the season, Barcelona have been remarkably strong in the 2024/25 campaign. In the league, they currently boast 13 consecutive victories with a staggering goal difference of +50, averaging 4.38 goals per match. In the domestic competition, they convincingly defeated their only serious challenger on paper, Real Madrid, who had strengthened their squad significantly over the summer, with a 4–0 away win. However, the Champions League revealed a rare blemish: a 0–2 loss to Manchester City in the group stage opener highlighted defensive vulnerabilities that are harder to detect in league play due to the game dynamics.
Throughout the autumn, I have closely followed Barcelona and watched all their matches. This article builds on my summer analysis of the team’s attacking principles, comparing their style of play this season to last year. All video material referenced is from DAZN or SVT.
As in the summer article, we begin with a statistical review of Barcelona’s autumn to get a comprehensive picture of their season so far. Are there any differences in the data compared to last year? Does anything stand out? Data is sourced from FBref and Opta, last updated on December 16. Visualizations are courtesy of Ben Griffis’ match report site.
Offensive output
When examining offensive output, there is virtually no difference from last season. Notably, the team maintains the same level of goals per match (4.4), while averaging one more shot per match (26.4 to 27.6). Their efficiency remains consistent, with 0.16 goals per shot compared to 0.15 last season and 0.14 npxG per shot compared to 0.13. In some matches, the team’s xG has reached absurd levels; for instance, in the 10–1 win against Granada, their xG was 7.1. For perspective, the highest recorded xG in the Premier League is Liverpool’s 7.3 against Newcastle on January 1, 2024. Unfortunately, I could not find the highest recorded xG figure globally.
Passing statistics
To identify stylistic differences in the data, we can look at passing statistics. Broadly, there is no change in passing accuracy or the total number of successful passes per match (approximately 680 with 86.9% accuracy). However, there is a noticeable increase in the number of short passes per match, rising from 349 to 393, while the number of medium and long passes has decreased. This suggests closer player positioning. Additionally, there has been a decline in passes and crosses into the penalty area, as well as overall switches of play and crosses.
Possession data
Barcelona’s possession has risen to 74.6% this season compared to 71.1% last year, showcasing their dominance in controlling matches. The team’s field tilt — an indicator of territorial dominance — remains at an extraordinary 89%, a full 30 percentage points ahead of second-place Real Madrid.
A related metric, the difference between field tilt and possession, measures how much more possession a team has in the final third compared to the rest of the pitch. Barcelona leads this category with a 15-percentage-point differential, reflecting the unmatched height of their average possession. Their style of play pushes center-backs far up the pitch, underlining the gap in quality between Barcelona and their league opponents, as well as the respect and caution their opponents exhibit when facing them.
Only Lyon in France surpasses Barcelona in combined field tilt-possession metrics across Europe’s top women’s leagues, while Arsenal matches Barcelona’s levels in England. However, neither team matches Barcelona’s extreme possession and field tilt values, as their possession rates hover around 60%.
Barcelona’s Offensive and Defensive Metrics
Barcelona ranks top in every offensive and defensive possession-related category. These include passing, shooting statistics (shots and xG, both from open play and set pieces), and metrics like xT (expected threat), which measures how much a team creates danger through possession. However, there are two categories related to effciency where they do not place themselves top of the league.
Key Statistical Outliers
Efficiency and style
Despite this deliberate approach, Barcelona scores the most goals in the league by far and boasts a +7.3 goal difference above their xG, a testament to their superior finishing and decision-making. This strategy leverages the squad’s collective intelligence and ability to assess scoring opportunities. The outcome? A high-efficiency attacking style that capitalizes on possession dominance, excellent decision-making, and the technical superiority of their players.
Defensive issues exposed against Manchester City
As briefly mentioned in the introduction, Barca has one blemish on their record, when they lost 2–0 to Manchester City away in the first round of the Champions League group stage. The match was played in early October, with Barca riding a streak of five straight wins against league opposition that they had brushed aside with ease. This was thus the first real test of the season. The match exposed what could actually be called a slack or naïve approach from Barcelona to their defensive game. It demonstrated how a team playing with patience and sometimes speed in their build-up play, and daring to play threatening balls between and over the lines, could realistically challenge Barcelona. City managed to exploit a nonchalant Barcelona team that mistimed their pressing and at times didn’t even show intentions to defend against their opponents with the intensity required against a top-tier City side, featuring players like Lauren Hemp, Khadija Shaw, Vivianne Miedema, and Jess Park. Let’s look at some examples.
Here, Manchester City succeeded by exploiting three factors:
Key (creative) players at fault for this included Aitana Bonmatí, Alexia Putellas, and Patri Guijarro, which led to others like Keira Walsh, Mapi León and Esmeé Brugts having to compensate, affecting the defensive structure and the spaces left behind in their defensive play. These points can partially be boiled down to a question of the players’ attitude toward the defensive work required but also to the team’s approach to risk aversion in their play.
Pressing in league play, and naïve buildup from opponents
In the league, they are used to taking greater risks, as they are so dominant that conceding a goal here or there due to a ball behind a high line or attackers sprinting past an undermanned rest defense doesn’t matter, since they still average 4.38 goals per match. For instance, they often dare to push their center-backs into the final third (which is the main reason they have such an extreme field tilt), and they prefer to keep their attacking forces higher up the pitch after losing the ball to maximize their impact when regaining possession, compared to a more deliberate rest-defense perspective. As a result, they’ve conceded occasional goals in league matches, having kept just six clean sheets in 13 games. However, in the Champions League opener, Barca showed no clear signs of modifying their game plan toward greater risk aversion against stronger opposition.
In the return match against Manchester City at home, they had identified the problem and approached the game out of possession much more aggressively. They chose a man-marking-based approach to their pressing, a method increasingly common in European football at the time, and implemented it right from the start. With the required intensity, they managed to completely smother City, limiting them to just three shots for a total of 0.2 xG, compared to 13 shots and 1.6 xG in the opening round. Let’s look at a clip of how this could play out.
The ever-recurring tactical question regarding the man-marking approach to defending without the ball is how long a team can sustain the required intensity when facing strong opponents with players technically skilled enough to handle such marking pressure. If you try to defend with such intensity while also maintaining a high tempo in possession, energy levels can drop quickly. Therefore, teams must either change their defensive approach later in the game by lowering the tempo and focusing more on covering spaces or slow down their own tempo in possession. In my view, this depends on the specific game plan, as the importance of certain defensive elements will largely depend on the opponent’s skill in possession.
Barca realized after the first match (although they should have seen this in the opponent analysis before the first game) that City were technically skilled enough to hurt them in their possession play. As a result, they opted for an intense approach in defending without the ball and slowed their possession tempo just enough to sustain the defensive intensity for about 80 minutes, which was sufficient. They returned to their “normal” levels of 74% possession and, in this match, 850 passes, where short passing sequences after ball recoveries were key to calming the tempo and gaining the control of the match they never had in Manchester. Leading 3–0 with ten minutes left, they slowed the pace somewhat, where two of City’s three shots came in the last ten minutes. In this match, they were thus skilled in the crucial tactical balance of tempo.
In the league, we often see teams trying to play out from the goalkeeper in their build-up. In this phase of pressing, Barca usually shows great discipline (it’s sometimes in certain transitional moments defensively that certain players may lack this) and are very skilled at shutting down their opponents with a form of hybrid press, which I consider more marking-oriented but still with elements of players in hybrid roles. We see an example in the match against Real Betis.
After watching several Liga F matches where the same patterns can be discerned match after match — where Barcelona’s opponents attempt to build from the goalkeeper but are quickly stopped, leading to a rather destructive effect in transitions — I am increasingly struggling to understand why opponents’ game plans continue to emphasize this approach. Even if it aligns with their principles, I still find it difficult to grasp why opponents persist in this way when it so often actively works against them when facing Barcelona.
The conclusion from my first article about Barcelona was that I viewed them as a team that values principles over structures. In the final section of the article, I reflected on how these principles borrow elements primarily associated with positional play but also principles tied to discussions around relational play. Most principles from last season remain intact, although some have evolved further. An example is evident in the statistics showing an increase in shorter passes, a consequence of closer player proximity. Barcelona often overload the left side in what, in relational play terminology, is frequently referred to as a “tilt.” You’ll often see a “right-back” like Ona Batlle coming centrally into the pitch, with “six” Keira Walsh moving wide to join her teammates, and winger Caroline Graham Hansen typically maintaining width — a feature they value for creating an outlet.
However, just because a team plays with a clear tilt doesn’t mean it adheres to “relational play.” A team fully embracing relational principles works clearly with inside diagonals and concepts like tabelas, escadinhas, and corta luz. When these movement-based principles aren’t utilized — either due to limited understanding among players of each other’s movements and intentions or because a coach doesn’t sufficiently encourage them — such overloads can become static and ineffective. Defending teams can then fairly easily contain attacks in their defensive third without conceding threatening shots.
How can a tilt look?
In the clip below, we see a relatively static tilt on the left side. However, note in particular how the players position themselves relative to the (fairly small) spaces created on that side but at angles that allow them to receive passes and maintain progression. They constantly adapt to spaces created in the opponent’s defensive structure.
We also see an example of an attack in the final third through an inside diagonal.
In these moments of attacking play, Barcelona have successfully combined forward movements out of a tilt with varying effectiveness depending on the match. How well this works largely depends on which players are on the pitch and who participates in the tilt.
In a video analysis of Barcelona’s men’s team by the YouTube channel The Purist, three qualities were identified in players that make their attacking play so threatening:
A Master at Delivering to Space, a Creative Combination Player, and a Game Breaker
When Alexia Putellas was absent from the team during a period from late November to mid-December, her decisive role as a creative combination player became evident. This was especially noticeable in the league match against Valencia. She served as a crucial link in the left-side tilt, making short-passing sequences effective in breaking down defensive structures by doing what defenders seldom expected. Together with Aitana Bonmatí, they form a sharp and unpredictable duo capable of creative combinations. Alexia often initiates the unpredictable action — whether it’s a backheel, a no-look pass, or participating in a tabela — while Aitana interprets it by either attacking the space where the ball lands or extending the play to the next player in a threatening position.
We see this in the clip below, where Claudia Pina receives the ball from Alexia, and Aitana finishes.
This isn’t to say other players cannot combine creatively, but based on watching Barcelona with and without Alexia, I’ve observed that these combinations emerge more naturally with her as the link. In many other cases, it has taken several attempts before players fully understood each other’s intentions.
Here’s an example where left-sided winger Esmeé Brugts looks to play a one-two but Aitana doesn’t grasp her intent.
Later, we see another instance where the situation is right, and Patri understands what Brugts wants to do. Shortly after, Claudia Pina breaks the deadlock in the match.
Something else that characterizes Barcelona is how frequently they use inside diagonals to attack the box, much like The Purist highlighted in their analysis of the men’s team’s approach in the final third. In many matches, Barcelona rarely appears restricted by a structure or framework-based ideas when attacking the box.
A significant advantage Barcelona gains when executing a tilt is the opposition’s need to respond to the overload, the rotations and movements within it. As noted earlier, Keira Walsh, playing as a “six,” is often directly involved in a tilt rather than serving as a traditional central balance player when attacking the penalty area. If Walsh draws a defender, it allows Barcelona’s opposite “ten,” who is usually positioned more centrally but can shift outward if an outlet is needed, to almost always be free for a switch of play. Walsh also enjoys rotating with her midfield colleagues, who in turn attack the space she vacates. This forces the opponents to shift further if they want to keep up. In this way, Barcelona can confuse defending teams, who suddenly don’t know whom to press.
A clear example of this can be seen in a clip where Walsh (#21) makes a run into an open space on the right side. Manchester City’s Yui Hasegawa (#25), initially responsible for Aitana Bonmatí (#14), must now contend with both Walsh and Aitana. Hasegawa eventually tracks Walsh, leaving Aitana free to receive the ball and play it forward. Barcelona then breaks the press with successive third-player combinations, culminating in Patri finding the perfect angle and delivering a sublime cross-field pass to Salma Paralluelo.
Since Barcelona’s tilt often occurs on the left side, switches of play frequently target the right side. And on that side, we find Barcelona’s most prominent “game breaker” — Caroline Graham Hansen. Her ability to challenge defenders one-on-one, both inside and outside, makes her a formidable weapon. Leading the Spanish league in expected assists (xA) and shot assists, she is crucial to Barcelona’s offensive dynamism. Even in matches where Barcelona slows the tempo with the ball, Graham Hansen can suddenly break away from her marker, drive into the box, and deliver a ball into the most dangerous areas.
We’ve discussed how Barcelona often utilizes tilts in the final third, diagonal attacks into the penalty area through penetrating passes, and creative combinations when the “right” players understand each other. These are examples of relational tendencies in their attacking play. However, when it comes to buildup play — or what might more accurately be called possession establishment — things can look different. In league play, “buildup” from the goalkeeper or deep in the defensive line rarely occurs, as opponents seldom choose to press Barcelona. They know that Barcelona’s players are too technically skilled; any minor error in the press will allow them to bypass it in an instant. Instead, opponents often adopt a compact shape as soon as they lose the ball.
Last season, we saw a Barcelona side that frequently resolved such situations in diverse ways depending on the game’s immediate state, but with clear principles like third-player combinations and overloads in tight spaces — even in their own half. Interesting tactics included forwards dropping deep (as Mariona Caldentey often did), rotations that drew defenders and opened spaces for diagonal progression during the establishment phase, and movements that seemed to create artificial transitions in the game.
In another article, I attempted to define a concept for what Barcelona executed in this part of their play, which I called adaptationism. The term was used to describe how teams use principles to continuously adapt to the game’s immediate state, considering space, ball position, and the positions of opponents and teammates. This occurs regardless of whether one adheres to relational, positional, or a hybrid approach — or perhaps none of these at all.
Barcelona’s evolving possession “structures”
This season, Pere Romeu has chosen to implement clearer structures during the establishment phase in certain matches. This could partly be due to Romeu’s autonomy as a coach but also due to the specific player resources available to him. One notable example is Mapi León, who returned from an injury spell last year and has become the team’s top performer in passes into the final third and progressive passes. León often operates from an advanced position as a left center-back, with Irene Paredes covering behind her. With León’s exceptional passing ability, Barcelona have been able to deploy other players in more advanced roles during attacks.
For instance, Claudia Pina has played much more as a forward this season than last, where she primarily served as a central midfielder. Pina is a player who often doesn’t get the credit she deserves, overshadowed by her high-profile teammates. Statistically, she ranked higher than both Aitana Bonmatí and Patri Guijarro last season, even as Alexia Putellas was out injured during certain periods. Pina also had the most minutes on the pitch last year and is equally indispensable this season.
In one clip, we see Barcelona patiently lure the opponent’s midfield into pressing by baiting them. When they bite, space opens up, allowing Pina to attack it and flick the ball forward to striker Ewa Pajor. Simultaneously, Aitana Bonmatí recognizes the situation and makes a decisive run, setting herself up for a clear scoring opportunity that she later converts.
Structural variations in the establishment phase
During the establishment phase, Barcelona frequently employs the 3–2–5 structure commonly associated with positional play. Occasionally, they use what resembles a three-back formation with a “six” operating fluidly just above, while the “rest” of the team positions themselves slightly further upfield. While this might look like a 3–1–6 numerically, it doesn’t entirely reflect the practical dynamics on the pitch.
In one sequence, Barcelona demonstrates patience, waiting to see if Manchester City will press their central double pivot. However, City opts for a compact shape to block central progression. This narrow defensive setup leaves more space and time for Barcelona to exploit the flanks and maintain their attacking momentum. Mapi León’s progressive passing comes to the fore, as does Esmeé Brugts’ deep ball to Ewa Pajor.
In another example, Barcelona plays with a three-back setup and a “six” during possession establishment, positioning players between the opposition’s defensive lines to disrupt a compact 4–4–2 or 5–3–2. Initially, patience in the backline is key. Then comes horizontal stretching of the defense, followed by a switch of play to create larger spaces on the opposite side. Barcelona advances through shorter passes and carries, culminating in another switch of play. Notably, Aitana continues her run into the assist zone, accompanied by multiple players attacking the penalty area.
Blending football philosophies
These examples illustrate how Barcelona employs principles from various football philosophies in different phases of their attacking play:
Barcelona’s rotations are not confined to a predefined structure but rather aim to influence both their own shape and the opponent’s defensive organization. This interplay of ideas from multiple football ideologies makes it difficult to assign a single philosophical label to the team.
FC Barcelona Femení as a Case Study
The blending of concepts from different football philosophies and their interaction within individual matches — as well as forming the foundation of an entire team strategy — is a fascinating subject. In this regard, FC Barcelona Femení serves as an intriguing case study. Their tactical versatility and innovative approach challenge conventional categorizations, making them a standout example of modern football’s evolving complexity.

Studying maths at University of Gothenburg, analyst at IFK Göteborg Women. Driven by working with mathematical modelling and football analysis in all its forms.

Title: Why are Barcelona crossing so much?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
For almost a decade, Barcelona was the football club of the purist. Led by its unassuming superstars, the team was hailed not just for its sporting achievements, but its artistry. It was an era of talent, technical elegance, and complete reverence for the football.
Those days are long gone.
You can trace the metamorphosis back several years. Perhaps as far back as the days of Luis Enrique, whose reign saw an emergence of direct football, spearheaded by MSN; Messi, Suárez and Neymar. Under subsequent managers we saw variations on the theme. Ernesto Valverde’s team took on a rugged, pragmatic demeanour. Quique Setién, trying to reverse the trend, only created confusion and contradiction.
But it wasn’t until Ronald Koeman arrived, and Lionel Messi departed, that the flame was truly extinguished.
Barcelona were at home to Granada. 1–0 down in the 82nd minute, accompanied by whistles from the outraged Camp Nou, the Dutch manager pioneered his own forward trident: Gerard Piqué, Ronald Araújo and Luuk de Jong. The ball was flung hopefully into the box, and Barca’s goliaths did whatever it took to bludgeon the ball into the net.
The purists wept. Their club was unrecognisable.
The Ronald Koeman era is over, but the scars remain. On Sunday, against Rayo Vallecano, Barcelona attempted a ludicrous 40 crosses, and ended the game with a front line of Luuk de Jong and Ronald Araújo. Ironically, this happened under the stewardship of the crown prince of ‘tiki taka’ himself, Xavi Hernández.
How did it come to this?
Perhaps there’s method to this madness, or more likely, it’s a symptom of the team’s serious deficiencies. To shed light, let’s examine Xavi’s rebuild project and identify why exactly this is happening, and what the alternatives might be going forward.
Let’s start with the diagnosis.
Forget about ‘tiki taka’ for a moment, or any other fabricated label. Xavi’s goal as Barcelona coach is to reintroduce positional play. A philosophy developed chiefly by Johan Cruyff. It’s a cerebral way of seeing the game, based on angles and distances between players, creation of triangles, instinctive movement. Cruyff claims it took ‘10,000 hours of training to finally reach the level of the Dream Team’. Mastery takes years.
We are seeing only the genesis of Xavi’s version, but it’s clear already that he wants to be a little more expansive than his predecessors. More switches of play, more direct passes, more crosses. As long as the space and movement allows it.
Xavi wants to stretch the opposition and exploit space quickly. To punish teams that stay compact by attacking the wide areas. It has worked. Barca have scored 57 goals in 32 games. Astonishingly, 40% of those open play goals have come from wide crosses.
So what’s the problem? Well, scoring from wide positions is one thing. When Barca have the game under control, there are signs they are acclimatising to the new philosophy. The faults appear when they are losing. When the opponents defend stubbornly and the clock is ticking down.
This is the recipe for a different type of crossing game. One that abandons positional play and ball circulation for low-percentage, high-volume balls into the box. This isn’t a considered approach. It’s a knee-jerk reaction. A response from a team, and a coach, that has no solution to a problem. And it happens for three reasons:
1. Opponents defend deep, with numbers
In each of Barca’s last three defeats, the opponent has finished the game with the same system: 5–4–1. They defend deep, in numbers, with very little space between the lines.
It is the kryptonite for any possession-based team. A nightmare to break down.
Pep Guardiola, another Cruyff disciple from whom Xavi has taken a lot of inspiration, has spent much of his career facing such dilemmas. It took years for him to develop a blueprint. Working from scratch, with an inherited squad, Xavi hasn’t cracked the code. Not yet.
2. Barca’s attack is one dimensional
In this first edition of ‘XaviBall’, Barcelona attack almost entirely down the flanks. Combinations through the centre are limited, largely because of the positions of attacking midfielders (the ‘interiors’). Rather than patrolling the centre, Barca’s interiors stay high and wide. Pedri and Frenkie de Jong are typically closer to the centre forward than they are to the pivot, Sergio Busquets.
Unfortunately, when the opponents nullify Barca’s width, they do not have a practiced alternative. Instead of looking for space in other areas, they double down on the wings, usually with the arrival of Adama Traoré. And the cycle of crossing begins.
3. The squad is limited
None of this is entirely Xavi’s fault. Take a look at the squad and you realise it’s missing a few crown jewels. Centre forward is a particularly barren. While Aubameyang is an excellent goal scorer, he is no creator. His impotence during buildup seriously limits Barca’s attack. Aubameyang has, time after time, lost the ball when it goes into his feet. Attacking through the middle becomes futile.
What the squad does have is two very direct, very effective crossing wingers: Ousmane Dembélé and Adama Traoré. It also has two imperious aerial threats, Luuk de Jong and centre back Ronald Araújo.
Together, these are the ingredients for ‘cross and hope’. Stubborn opponents, no ‘Plan B’ and a deficient squad.
The question for Xavi is obvious. What changes next season?
The solutions to these problems are not easy. But they are simple. Do these three things, and the demons of desperation will be exorcised for good. They are:
Solution 1: Prepare the team more thoroughly for deep, compact defences.
This requires time, patience and above all maturity. To some players it might seem counter-intuitive to take an extra touch, or look for an extra pass, rather than throw the ball into a dangerous area. But composure is crucial, and it has to be learned.
Solution 2: Improve the squad in key positions.
Particularly with a centre forward who can bring another dimension to Barca’s attack. Right back will also be important, to reduce reliance on Dembélé (should he stay) on that side.
Solution 3: Take the emphasis away from winning, and focus on performance.
This might sound controversial. But it’s the mentality that separates Xavi, a relative rookie, from a veteran like Pep Guardiola. Xavi’s language is ‘must-win’. Guardiola says ‘we play our game’. When you take away the pressure of the final result, and focus on executing your game plan, you develop a culture that’s resilient to wins or losses. One that doesn’t rush, or become desperate. You create the conditions for a long-term successful project.
With Xavi’s tenure still in its infancy, and some important transfer windows on the horizon, much can change in the near future for Barcelona. Only months ago this was a sinking ship; now some holes have been plugged. It’s going to take a lot more hard work, and disappointing performances, before we set course for something special. We’re nowhere near Cruyff’s 10,000 hours.
Regardless of a few deficiencies, or blind spots in the system, this is a project that demands time and support.
Given both of those things, the purists will return. And Barcelona will be recognisable again.
Thanks for reading, be sure to leave a ‘clap’ if you enjoyed, so I can keep making more Barcelona content!
Follow The Purist on Twitter.

Title: Catalan or Spanish: Deciding which language to speak in Barcelona
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Originally posted on alexrawlings.co.uk
A few days before my big move to Barcelona, I found myself talking to my now ex-colleague, Jesús. It was late at night, and we were on the Gatwick Express, heading into Victoria on our way back from the Polyglot Conference in Slovenia. Jesús is from Valencia, and so he took a particular interest in my decision to move to Spain. He asked me if I already had any friends in Barcelona.
“Yes,” I said, quickly. “Lots of friends. So many people, from all over the world. I know all of them.” There was a pause, which I interrupted to re-emphasise: “I have lots of friends.”
“OK,” Jesús replied, cautiously. “Just that I know you know lots of people, but just in case you need anything, my sister’s been living in Barcelona for years now, and she lives very close to where you’re going to be, so if you ever need anything just give her a call.”
I was taken aback. Not only was this so incredibly kind and thoughtful of Jesús to suggest, but the reality is that whenever you move to a new country, you never really know as many people as you think. There are fleeting connections that come and go, occasional numbers exchanged at meet-up groups, people you get on with who then mysteriously leave the country without saying a word… Knowing somebody who actually lived there, permanently, and was from there was like finding water in the desert. I graciously accepted.
The next day, a TV crew from the Catalan News Station TV3 had come to find me at work in London and shoot a short interview about why I was moving to Barcelona. When I met them at reception, the journalist greeted me in Catalan. I then turned to greet the cameraman in Catalan too. He turned out to be from Madrid, and although he understood Catalan, he said he didn’t really speak it because, well, he was Spanish.
The journalist, Sergi Mulero, then told me that actually, although he was Catalan, he came from a Spanish speaking family in Catalunya as well. He’d learned Catalan at school and grew up bilingually, but actually, his first language was Spanish. That was that. We spent the rest of the morning speaking just Spanish.
The day I arrived in Barcelona, the main Catalan TV channel had been playing that report on repeat pretty much all day. When I logged into Twitter, I found hundreds of messages from people all across Catalunya welcoming me, thanking me for choosing them, and wishing me all the best.
That evening, I got a WhatsApp. It was Jesús. “My sister and her family have been watching you all day on Catalan TV, and they want to invite you to join them for lunch,” he said.
I got in touch with Jesús’s sister, Maria, and we messaged in Spanish and arranged to meet that Saturday at 2pm — lunchtime in Spain — by the newly refurbished Mercat Sant Antoni.
Needless to say, I got totally lost. After 20 minutes of walking in circles around the outside of the gigantic, €80 million crucifix that was the Mercant Sant Antoni, I received a phone call. It was Maria, asking where I was. I explained I had no idea, but that I was by one of the entrances. Eventually we found each other, and walked to the restaurant to meet her, her husband, their daughter and her godfather. After we finished greeting each other, Maria asked a question that nobody would ever ask in London.
“Pues ¿qué idioma vamos a hablar? So what language are we going to speak?”
I was taken aback. Weren’t we already speaking a language? Wasn’t it already decided? Every centimetre of my body began to fill with fear that they were going to ask me to speak English to them. How many times had that happened to me when living abroad? How many friendships had I started that turned out to just be glorified free English lessons? I groaned.
“Bueno, es que el idioma de nosotros es el catalán,” she explained while my head exploded. “Cuando salimos a comer los sábados, siempre hablamos en catalán. It’s just that our language is Catalan. When we go out to eat on Saturdays, we always speak in Catalan.”
My head was exploding for lots of reasons. The first, was that I knew Maria was from Valencia. When I lived in Valencia, I remembered distinctly that Catalan (or Valencian, as it’s known there) was always the elephant in every room. Everything — all street signs, all addresses, bus timetables, etc. — was always written in valencià, but nobody really spoke it. I remembered so clearly when I went to the town hall to register my existence in Spain, asking the civil servant behind the desk whether she spoke any Valencian.
“Nos obligan a aprenderlo en el colegio, pero… They force us to learn it at school, but…” she leaned closer, to whisper: “Nadie lo habla aquí. Ni palabra. Nobody speaks it here. Not even a word.”
The other reason was that I knew that although Jesús was very proud of Catalan and had done most of his school in it, he tended to speak Spanish. I’d just assumed that, like the presenter from TV3, he came from a Spanish speaking family.
“Si, és molt estrany. Yes, it’s very strange,” Maria said, switching to Catalan when I asked her about this. “En Jesús era sempre el meu germà castellanoparlant. Tots parlàvem català, i ell sempre contestava en castellà. Jesus was always my Spanish-speaking brother. We all spoke Catalan, and he always answered in Spanish.”
I told them that I loved Catalan, that I thought it was the most beautiful of all the Romance languages, the missing piece of the puzzle between Spanish, French, Italian and Portuguese. But I apologised, explaining that although I wanted to learn more Catalan, I had just arrived and my spoken Catalan was weak. I asked them to please continue speaking Catalan as though I weren’t there, but that I would feel more comfortable expressing myself in Spanish.
Of course it was no problem, but as the conversation went on, everyone by default shifted into speaking Spanish. I felt terrible. I felt like that one annoying person at a group of internationals in Berlin who all spoke German but who kept saying “Could we just speak English please so everybody understands?” Forcing people to use a major world language instead of their beautiful ‘minority’ language so they could speak to me was certainly nowhere to be found on my list of things to do when I moved to Catalunya. Yet I’d just arrived, and that’s exactly what I was doing.
It was so lovely to meet Maria and her friends and family, and I really couldn’t have imagined a nicer way to start my new life in Barcelona. I had sudden flashback half way through to last time, when I was living in Valencia, and I used to go out to restaurants on a Saturday for lunch that were always packed full with huge tables of Spanish families and friends eating, drinking, talking and enjoying. I’d always observe them from the tiny table they’d put me on in the corner, thinking that I would never feel the same connection to this beautiful place that they did. I would always be an outsider, a permanent tourist, a guiri. Those thoughts are partly what took me back to the UK, convinced that really you had to live in your own country to be happy. Yet three years later, here I was sitting at the table, chatting away in Spanish and dishing out huge plates of arroz negro.
Yet I felt so bad about forcing everyone to speak Spanish, that I made a pact with myself. From now on, I was only going to use Catalan. Everywhere, and with everyone. Why not? After all, all the signs everywhere were almost always just in Catalan. In most cafés and restaurants you had to play this weird game where you’d decide what you want by reading the menu in Catalan, then translate it back into Spanish so that you could order it from the waiter. Why not make life easier for everyone and just speak Catalan to everyone instead?
Well, almost everyone that is.
Armed with my new Catalanophile confidence, my first target was the new Tim Hortons that had opened up near my house. I’d never heard of Tim Hortons, but apparently it was the place to go in Canada, which is why it made total sense for it to open just off Plaça de Catalunya in Barcelona, where, once again, every single word inside it from the ‘push’ and ‘pull’ signs on the doors to the list of coffees was written in Catalan.
I awaited my turn, and eventually was served.
“Hola, ¿qué te pongo? Hey, what can I get you?” I was asked, in Spanish.
“Bona tarda,” I replied proudly, in Catalan. “Em dones un cafè negre sisplau, i un donut de dolç de llet. Could I get a black coffee please and a dulce de leche donut.”
There was a silence. I had been concentrating so hard on remembering how to say dulce de leche in Catalan that I’d made the whole order focusing on the display case, without looking up. Clearly I had made some horrendous grammar mistake. Clearly I had used some kind of Castillian Spanish word. Something had happened. Something had gone wrong.
Eventually I looked up. As my eyes made their way up to meet dark circles of the man behind the till, they passed over a name badge.
First I saw the name ‘Eduardo’. Then I saw the Colombian flag next to it.
“Oh shit,” I thought.
“Molt bé,” he answered in perfect Catalan with the most beautiful Colombian accent. “És per aquí o per emportar? Is that to have here or take away?”
--
--
Writer, traveller and polyglot from London. UK’s most multilingual student (2012). New book out: “From Amourette to Żal“ (History Press, 2018)
