Greetings, football enthusiasts! Today, I’m taking you on a timeless journey through one of FC Barcelona’s unforgettable nights. Join me to discover the magic that unfolded in the clash against Chelsea (2009), a night engraved in the annals of football history.
“Each second felt like an eternity”
The story begins in a hub of pure excitement. Chelsea already led 1-0, and Barça faced a mountain to climb. At that time, as a 12-year-old schoolboy, I returned from school with indescribable excitement. I couldn’t wait to see how my heroes would tackle this colossal challenge.
I remember sticking to the TV, still wearing my school uniform, eagerly anticipating the spectacle. It was more than just a match for me; it was an immersive experience, a magical interlude in my adolescence.
As the match progressed, stress mounted. Every whistle, every pause in play, everything seemed to decide Barça’s fate. My heart raced; each second felt like an eternity.
Then came the 93rd minute, a moment etched in my mind. Andrés Iniesta, the football genius, triggered an explosion of emotions. I remember leaping with joy, unable to contain the excitement. It was a moment of deliverance, where football transcended the sport to become a pure emotional experience.
Let’s be honest—beyond the scoreboard, there were refereeing decisions that could have altered the narrative. As a fan, I couldn’t help but acknowledge the whims of fate. Football, with its imperfections, added to the drama of that unforgettable night.
Ultimately, beyond the scoreboard, it was a fan’s journey—a roller coaster of emotions, from doubt to belief, from anxiety to jubilation. Join me next time to relive other unforgettable football moments.
Don’t forget to subscribe, and share your own stories in the comments. Until next time, keep the football spirit alive!

Stories from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking lands and cultures

Member-only story
Featured

Barcelona was never on my radar as a place to visit, let alone move to. In 2024, nearly 12 million tourists visited this city, which is now my home. After four and a half years as a resident, I’ve seen its good and its bad, but moving here has still been my best big life decision, and I’ve made more than my fair share of bad ones.
Before you question, “I wonder what it’s like to be an American expat living in Barcelona,” let me make something perfectly clear. I identify as an immigrant. Expats, in my opinion, have large sums of disposable income, something I do not have.
My decision to move here had nothing to do with its beautiful architecture, fabulous food, and comfortable climate. I moved here because, while visiting Tuva, a small Siberian republic in the Russian Federation that shares a border with Mongolia, for a third time, I met a woman there who happened to live in Barcelona. What started as a friendship turned into a romance, and after several visits to see her, I took the dive into the deep end of the pool and eventually moved here permanently.
Anything worth doing usually has a few bumps in the road, and my decision to move to Barcelona was hit with a huge one. Three days before my flight from New York to Barcelona, the pandemic shut the world’s borders…

Title: How I Learned to Blend in With Locals in Barcelona: Tips from a Grateful Foreigner
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I first arrived in Barcelona, I was wide-eyed and clumsy — like a tourist trying too hard not to look like one. I’d been dreaming of Gaudí facades, sangria by the beach, and a Mediterranean lifestyle full of late dinners and even later conversations. What I didn’t anticipate was how long it would take to actually feel like I belonged.
Here’s what I learned — sometimes the hard way — about blending in with locals in this magnetic, complex city.
1. Start with “Bon dia,” not “Hola”
I knew Spanish (Castellano), but I quickly discovered that Catalan is everywhere — on street signs, in supermarkets, and yes, in everyday greetings. Saying bon dia (good morning) instead of hola showed respect for the local culture. No one expected me to be fluent in Catalan, but trying a few words — si us plau (please), gràcies (thank you) — opened a lot of doors, literally and figuratively.
Tip: Download a basic Catalan phrasebook or app. Just trying a few phrases goes a long way.
2. Eat when they eat, not when you’re hungry
I once sat down for dinner at 7:00 PM and got a confused look from the waiter. In Barcelona, lunch is at 2 PM, and dinner doesn’t start until at least 9 PM. Adapting to this schedule was challenging at first (especially with my American stomach), but it helped me sync with the rhythm of the city.
Tip: Join the menú del día (menu of the day) crowd at lunchtime. It’s affordable, filling, and a great way to observe locals in their natural habitat.
3. Dress the part, subtly
Barcelona style is chic but effortless. Locals somehow make sneakers look elegant and never seem overdressed or underdressed. I learned the hard way when I showed up to a casual dinner in flip-flops and got side-eyes from every direction.
Tip: Leave the touristy sandals and loud prints at home. A well-fitted tee, stylish sneakers, and a light jacket can help you blend in instantly.
4. Embrace vermouth culture
I didn’t expect vermouth to become part of my weekend ritual, but “fer el vermut” (having a vermouth) before lunch on weekends is a sacred tradition. It’s not about getting tipsy — it’s about slowing down, snacking on olives, and chatting with friends for hours.
Tip: Go to a neighborhood bodega on a Sunday around noon. Order a vermut negre and some anchovies. Just sit, sip, and soak it in.
5. Avoid La Rambla — except at 5 a.m.
Everyone goes to La Rambla once. But locals? They avoid it like the plague — unless they’re walking home after a night out. If you want to see the real Barcelona, head to neighborhoods like Gràcia, Sant Antoni, or Poblenou.
Tip: Wander into the smaller plazas at night. You’ll find kids playing soccer, couples drinking wine on benches, and old men arguing about Barça. That’s the magic.
6. Be a regular
One of the best decisions I made was committing to a local café. I went every day, even if it was just for a cortado. Eventually, the barista started greeting me by name, and I was invited to a neighborhood calçotada (a Catalan barbecue). That’s when I knew I was more than just a visitor.
Tip: Pick a small bar, café, or shop near where you live. Consistency breeds community.
7. Understand the pride — and pain — of Catalan identity
Conversations about identity, politics, and language run deep here. I learned early on not to assume Spain = Catalonia. People here have a distinct sense of self, and respecting that nuance showed I wasn’t just another tourist trying to “do Spain in a week.”
Tip: Listen more than you talk. Ask questions, and stay curious. You’ll gain trust.
Final Thoughts
Blending in doesn’t mean pretending to be local — it means respecting the flow, showing genuine interest, and participating instead of spectating. Barcelona rewards patience and presence. It taught me to slow down, look around, and become part of the scenery.
I came to Barcelona with a suitcase and a guidebook. I stayed because of the people who welcomed me when I finally stopped trying so hard — and just started being.
--
--

Title: #SoloFemaleTravel: The strangers in Barcelona, Spain
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Earlier in 2023, I thought of fulfilling my wanderlust and taking off on a solo trip in Europe — something my younger self wouldn’t have even dreamed of.
In my attempt to live in the present (coupled with my habit of tardily posting photos), I felt it was important to journal my experiences to capture my raw thoughts and feelings while I travel.
I’m glad I wrote them as it took me months to finally get around to sharing my travel stories, but here we go.
Barcelona, Spain || June 2023
I am on my way to the airport as I started writing this.
A few days ago, I flew to Spain to begin the first leg of my solo trip around Europe. There’s no deeper reason why I’m taking this trip except I know that, whatever the outcome is, I need to do it and it will reveal its beautiful purpose in time.
It’s too early to write my reflections about my experience, and there is definitely so much to be written. But, I’m about to fly out of Spain today to my next destination, and I can’t help but feel overwhelmed by the kindness around me, especially that I am far from home.
From that metro guy who brought out his phone to use Google Translate so he could better give me instructions,
that other passenger who help me carry my luggage upstairs because I didn’t know you can go around and maybe find a lift,
that guy from Albania on a holiday who walked me to the bus stop ‘coz I’ve been literally going circles, looking for my ride to my hostel,
that guy from Germany, who was also on a holiday, but who explained the route of the bus I took to assure me and who also made suggestions on what touristy things I should do,
my roommates from Egypt, Brazil, and Chile who already feel like long-time friends, offering help and suggesting to meet up again in my next destinations,
Viki from Hungary, who provided me company on my first day, sharing stories as well as the same love for sports and dogs,
Mary Margaret from the US, who helped me book a tour and let me pay her in cash because my card wouldn’t work for online purchases because of its registered local number,
Miquel, a true blue Catalan from Esparreguera who adjusted his sched so I could go hiking in Montserrat — the reason why I added Barcelona to this trip,
all the fellow tourists and travelers who offered to take my photo (regardless if they turned out good shots or not) because I was alone,
the Spanish girl who lives near my hostel who taught me the best way to the airport,
David, a guy from Slovenia who works at the hostel, who gleefully (but not sure if legally) offered to keep my luggage and carry-on bag at the storage room free of charge for two days,
the ladies at the buses and the metro who weren’t articulate in English but still entertained my questions and went out of their way so we could find the lift for my heavy luggage,
the guy on the wheelchair, who was, of course, an expert to accessing the elevators, who kept on reminding me not to ride the train that runs through the same line as the train to the airport,
the Spanish girl who sat closer to my luggage at the airport terminal when I had to leave and check my flight details on the screen, and who then told me where to find assistance.
I have been just less than a week away, and I have many people to thank for — especially my family. But let me start with these strangers. I hope I got to know all their names and keep communication, but it warms my heart to think that even strangers can play magical cameos in anyone’s life.
When I arrived in Spain, I knew that getting lost should be enjoyed just as much as getting to one’s destination in a breeze. And true enough, I got lost, I doubted my direction and decisions multiple times, but I survive, learning lessons and making memories.
I am about to leave Spain, convinced that the world is beautiful. Yes, because Barcelona and Catalonia are a sight to behold. But more so, because of the kindness all around us.
--
--
An introspective and adventurous soul in a tireless search for self-improvement, she shares her story to help others find their story of personal redemption.

Title: 3-Day Trip to Barcelona: A Colorful Journey Through Culture, Nature and Food
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Barcelona is a city I visited without many expectations, but I saw how wrong I was. Before the trip, my knowledge was limited only something such as urban planning, building structures, big Gaudi’s structures, football club and generic things. But after spending three days there, I felt like I could actually live in Barcelona.
I want to share my experience and what I learned when I walked through the city. There are still some places I couldn’t visit; unfortunately, I didn’t have enough time. In this writing, I shared only some places that I went.
First, I gave a 3-day trip itinerary. Then, I explained each place in detail, organized by category.
Start your journey in the heart of the old city, dive into Gothic architecture.
Explore the green side of Barcelona with views, art, and calm spaces, plus a beautiful evening at the beach.
Today is all about imagination, emotion, and big symbols of Barcelona’s identity.
I organized my trip into the following categories:
🏰 Historical & Architectural Landmarks
1.Baslica de la Sagrada Famlia
The Basílica de la Sagrada Família is one of the most iconic landmarks in Barcelona and the largest unfinished Catholic church in the world. Designed by Antoni Gaudí, it looks like something out of a fairytale with its towering spires and intricate facades. Construction began back in 1882 and is still ongoing today.
Antoni Gaudí was a Spanish architect born in 1852 in Catalonia. He studied architecture in Barcelona and became known for his innovative use of materials and structures. Gaudí worked on several major projects, including Park Güell, Casa Batlló, and the Sagrada Família, which he focused on from 1883 until his death in 1926.
Gaudí didn’t start the Sagrada Família project himself — it was already planned as a Catholic church by a local organization called the Spiritual Association of Devotees of Saint Joseph. They wanted to build a church dedicated to the Holy Family (Sagrada Família) to promote Christian values in response to the rise of secularism.
Gaudí took over the project in 1883, after the original architect resigned. He saw it as a chance to combine his deep Catholic faith with architecture. For Gaudí, the church wasn’t just a building — it was a way to tell the story of Christianity through art, structure, and symbolism. He dedicated the last 40 years of his life to it, turning it into his life’s mission.
If you want to see the inside, it’s best to buy your ticket at least a week in advance.
2. Baslica de Santa Maria del Mar
The Basílica de Santa Maria del Mar is a beautiful Gothic church built in the 1300s by local sailors and merchants. It feels peaceful and grand inside, with tall stone columns and soft natural light. Tucked in the heart of El Born, it’s a quiet gem full of history and charm.
3. Baslica de Santa Maria del Pi
The Basílica de Santa Maria del Pi was built in the early 1300s and finished around 1391. It’s a quiet Gothic church in the middle of the old town, named after a pine tree that once grew nearby. With its tall bell tower and simple stone walls, it’s a peaceful place to rest and enjoy a bit of history.
Both churches were built in the 1300s and look Gothic, but they feel different inside. Santa Maria del Mar is brighter and more open, while Santa Maria del Pi feels stronger and a bit darker.
4. Cathedral of Barcelona
The Cathedral of Barcelona, also called the Cathedral of the Holy Cross and Saint Eulalia, was built between the 13th and 15th centuries. It’s a grand Gothic church with tall spires, stone carvings, and a peaceful cloister inside. Right outside is Plaça de la Seu, a lovely square where people often sit, watch street performers, or take photos of the cathedral’s front.
5. Palau Reial Major
The Palau Reial Major was the royal palace of the counts of Barcelona and later the kings of Aragon. It was mainly built between the 13th and 15th centuries and sits in the Gothic Quarter. Today, you can explore its old stone halls and the Plaça del Rei in front, a quiet square that feels full of medieval history.
In this narrow area, I felt a deeper connection to history.
6. Palau de la Generalitat
The Palau de la Generalitat is the seat of the Catalan government and has been used for that purpose since the 1400s. It has a mix of Gothic and Renaissance styles and is still a working government building today. You’ll find it on Plaça de Sant Jaume, right across from the City Hall.
In the square in front of this building we saw an old man talking about how much damage tourists were doing to Barcelona.
We saw a “tourists go home” protest in Barcelona. However, a touristic environment was created throughout the city and apart from this person, I did not see any attitude towards tourists; on the contrary, everyone was very interested.
7. Barcelona City Hall
Barcelona City Hall, also known as Casa de la Ciutat, has been the city’s main government building since the 14th century. Its front mixes Gothic and Neoclassical styles, showing how the city changed over time. It faces the Palau de la Generalitat on Plaça de Sant Jaume, a square full of history and political life.
8. Casa Batlló
Casa Batlló is one of Antoni Gaudí’s most famous works, designed in 1904. The building looks like something from a dream, with colorful tiles, flowing shapes, and a roof that looks like a dragon’s back. It’s on Passeig de Gràcia and often called the “House of Bones” because of its bone-like balconies and windows.
9. La Pedrera — Casa Milà
La Pedrera, also known as Casa Milà, was designed by Antoni Gaudí and finished in 1912. Its wavy stone façade and twisted iron balconies make it look like a moving piece of art. The rooftop, with its strange chimney shapes, is one of the most unique spots in Barcelona.
As I saw these works of Gaudi, they changed my perception a lot as they differed from other works of art.
10. Monument als Castellers
The Monument als Castellers represents the traditional Catalan practice of building human towers, called castells. These towers are made by people standing on each other’s shoulders, sometimes reaching up to 10 levels high. The sculpture shows the strength, teamwork, and trust needed to create these towers — core values of Catalan culture.
11. The World Comes To Life With Each Kiss
The mural “The World Begins With Every Kiss” (El món neix en cada besada) symbolizes love, freedom, and unity. Created in 2014 by photographer Joan Fontcuberta and ceramist Antoni Cumella, it commemorates the 300th anniversary of Barcelona’s fall during the War of the Spanish Succession. The artwork comprises 4,000 ceramic tiles, each featuring photographs submitted by citizens depicting personal moments of freedom. Together, these images form a mosaic of two people kissing, representing the enduring spirit of love and resilience in the face of adversity.
A nice area to take photos.
12. Camp Nou
The Camp Nou is FC Barcelona’s iconic stadium, originally opened on September 24, 1957. Camp Nou, FC Barcelona’s iconic stadium, is currently undergoing major renovations to expand its capacity to 105,000 and modernize its facilities.
I think they design great museums to introduce their teams. Additionally, it was amazing to see the Champions League trophy with my own eyes.
🏞️ Parks, Viewpoints & Nature
13. Montjuc & Montjuïc Castle
Montjuïc became a key part of Barcelona’s growth and global image in the 20th century. Many of its buildings and spaces were first developed for the 1929 International Exposition, a world fair that helped show off the city’s culture and progress. Later, in 1992, the area was transformed again to host the Summer Olympic Games, bringing new life to old buildings and adding new sports facilities.
Today, Montjuïc is a mix of history, art, and nature. You can visit the Montjuïc Castle, explore museums like the National Art Museum of Catalonia (MNAC), walk through peaceful gardens, or watch the light show at the Magic Fountain. It’s a place where locals and visitors come to relax, learn, and enjoy some of the best views in the city.
14. Plaça de les Cascades
Plaça de les Cascades is a beautiful square in Barcelona, located just below the National Art Museum of Catalonia on Montjuïc Hill. Built for the 1929 International Exposition, it features a series of cascading fountains that lead up to the museum, creating a stunning visual effect. The square is a popular spot for visitors to relax and enjoy the views of the city.
15. Ciutadella Park
Ciutadella Park is one of the most loved green spaces in Barcelona, perfect for relaxing, walking, or enjoying a boat ride on the lake. It was once a military area but turned into a public park in the 1800s. On weekends, the park comes alive with events, music, and people dancing near the big fountain.
It easily ranks in my top 5 favorites.
16. Park Güell
Park Güell is a colourful and imaginative park designed by Antoni Gaudí, built between 1900 and 1914. Originally planned as a housing development, it became a public park filled with winding paths, mosaic-covered benches, and playful architecture. Today, it’s one of Barcelona’s most iconic spots and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
It costs 18 euros, but totally worth it.
17. Barceloneta Beach — Playa de la Barceloneta
Barceloneta Beach is one of Barcelona’s most famous and lively beaches, located in the old fishing neighborhood of La Barceloneta. It was transformed in the early 1990s for the Olympic Games, turning into a wide, sandy beach with a long promenade. Today, it’s a favorite spot for sunbathing, swimming, beach volleyball, and enjoying fresh seafood at the nearby chiringuitos. The beach is also known for its vibrant atmosphere, with street performers, music, and people dancing along the promenade, especially in the evenings.
PERFECT!!!
It was full even though we didn’t go swimming. I can’t imagine summer.
🖼️ Museums & Cultural Sites
18. Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya
The Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya (MNAC) was built for the 1929 International Exposition to show off Catalan culture and art. It’s located in the Palau Nacional on Montjuïc Hill, a grand building that became the perfect home for a national museum. Today, it holds one of the best collections of Romanesque art in the world, along with Gothic, Renaissance, and modern works.
⛲ Monuments & Squares
19. Plaça d’Espanya
Plaça d’Espanya is one of Barcelona’s largest and most important squares, built in 1929 for the International Exposition. It was designed to impress visitors and serve as a grand entrance to Montjuïc, connecting major roads like Gran Via and Avinguda del Paral·lel.
20. Plaça de Catalunya
Plaça de Catalunya is the central square of Barcelona, connecting the old city with the modern Eixample district. Inaugurated in 1927, it covers 5 hectares and serves as a major hub for transport, shopping, and city life. Surrounded by shops, cafes, and fountains, it’s a popular meeting point for both locals and visitors.
21. Plaça Reial
Plaça Reial is a lively square in Barcelona’s Gothic Quarter, just off La Rambla. Built in the mid-1800s on the site of a former convent, it was designed to honor the monarchy. The square features palm trees, elegant arches, and a central fountain called the Three Graces. Notably, the ornate lampposts were among Antoni Gaudí’s first public works. Today, Plaça Reial is a popular spot for dining, nightlife, and enjoying open-air events.
If you are looking for a nice place to eat, I recommend this place.
22. Plaça de la Vila de Madrid
Plaça de la Vila de Madrid is a peaceful square in Barcelona’s Gothic Quarter, known for its hidden Roman cemetery. In the 1950s, during construction, archaeologists uncovered 85 Roman tombs dating from the 1st to 3rd centuries AD. These graves belonged mostly to ordinary people — freedmen, slaves, and lower-class citizens — who were buried along a road leading out of the ancient Roman city of Barcino. Today, visitors can view the tombs from a raised walkway and learn more at the small museum on site.
23. Arc de Triomf
The Arc de Triomf is a big red-brick arch built in 1888 for a world fair held in Barcelona. It wasn’t made for war, but to welcome people from around the world. Today, it’s a popular place to walk, take photos, and enjoy the wide promenade that leads to Ciutadella Park.
🛍️ Markets & Shopping Streets
24. Mercat de la Boqueria
La Boqueria Market is Barcelona’s most famous food market, found right on La Rambla. It started way back in the 1200s and became a proper market in the 1800s. Today, you can walk through colorful stalls, try local street food, fresh fruit, and even grab some tasty tapas.
25. La Rambla
La Rambla is a famous street in the center of Barcelona, running from Plaça de Catalunya down to the sea. It’s always full of life, with street performers, small shops, cafés, and flower stands. It’s a fun place to walk, grab a snack, and feel the city’s energy.
🚡 Rides & Attractions
26. Telefric de Montjuc
The Telefèric de Montjuïc is a scenic cable car ride in Barcelona that takes you from Montjuïc Park up to Montjuïc Castle. Opened in 1970 and upgraded in 2007, it offers panoramic views of the city and the sea. The ride has three stops: Parc de Montjuïc, Mirador, and Castell.
27. Transportation Tickets
🍽️ Food & Drink Spots
28. Les Quinze Nits
Located in Plaa Reial, this popular spot offers quality Mediterranean dishes at great prices. The atmosphere is lively, especially at night with the lights of the square.
29. TKO Tacos Barna
A fun place to grab flavorful, creative tacos with a twist. A cool mix of Mexican street food and Barcelona’s chill vibe.
30. El Tastet de l’Artur
A cozy, local eatery known for authentic Catalan dishes. It’s a hidden gem where you can enjoy a more traditional, homemade meal.
31. Gelati Dino
One of the best spots in the city for gelato! With lots of flavors and smooth texture, it’s the perfect treat during a hot afternoon walk.
🛏️ Hostels & Accommodation
32. Party Hostel Kabul
A legendary spot for backpackers, known for its social vibe and rooftop parties. It’s right on Plaça Reial, so the nightlife is literally at your doorstep.
33. St Christopher’s Inn
A modern and comfortable hostel with clean rooms and great facilities. It’s super close to Plaa de Catalunya and perfect for meeting other travelers at the in-house bar.

Title: Moving Abroad. Part 2: Living and working in Barcelona
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Is moving abroad for a job on your mind? Follow along for some practical tips for job hunting, visa and relocation experiences, and behind-the-scenes of living in a different country.

--
Listen
Share
TL;DR💛 ProsUpcoming tech and product communityVibrant cityEasy to live day-to-day life without learning the language
🚧 ConsSalaries lower than other European citiesLots of paperwork for visa/residency in SpanishFlat-hunt can be a challenge
If you are up for reading the long part, we have🤔 Why Barcelona💬 Interview Process📑 Spain Visa🏦 Working in N26🏠 Flat-scene & Utility Bills🥘 Food💸 Budget☎️ Language👯‍♀️ Friends and Indian Community💔 Pandemic☀️ Day-to-day Life in Barcelona
If you followed along, I had decided quite early I wanted to rent a studio apartment in Paris and live there as an adult. After graduation, and while working in Bangalore, I was looking for reasons to travel or move abroad as my weekend side project.
With my experience and profile, I figured I should diversify my options. So I applied to a lot of places for jobs — Ottawa, London, Berlin, Amsterdam, New York (yes yes I know how impossible the US visa situation is!). I was pretty much open to any city for the experience!
I had applied to an N26 opening that had Berlin/Barcelona/Vienna mentioned. During one of the interviews, the recruiter mentioned I was being considered for the Barcelona office.
Recruiter: “So what do you think Chhavi?”
The open-source community I contributed to back in college, had roots in Barcelona. I had visited Barcelona before twice and had absolutely loved it. I had tagged it as “my city” pretty much on the first visit. I was always super grateful to be in Barcelona, but never thought I could ever live there. It just never crossed my mind.🙃
The recruiter stared back at me through the zoom call.
Me: “I love Barcelona!”
A friend of a friend used N26, and he mentioned it to me. Mobile banks were still a new concept to me, so I did a little bit of research. A quick Google search listed all of these fin-tech darlings — Monzo, Revolut, Starling, and N26.
I found a mutual on LinkedIn and requested a referral. I saw on LinkedIn that they had a few folks from India, so I thought maybe…maybe they do sponsor visas. Long haul, but worth a shot. I waited for a bit and heard back from a recruiter 2–3 weeks later.
I was super excited to make it to the interviews. The “funnel” is so dramatic when you apply abroad — that this feels like an achievement. First I ordered and ate a lot of ice cream through Swiggy. Then I spent a lot of time preparing. More on this in part 1.
chhavii.medium.com
1. Phone call with a Recruiter to discuss my background, and expectations.2. Design Exercise. I was asked to design a mobile application for reading curated books.3. Video-call to discuss the Design Exercise. My first chance to interacting with product designers on the team. We talked about the exercise, about the team, and in general how I could contribute.4.Video-call with a Product Manager and a Product Designer. Here we talked more about product thinking, our take on MVPs, using data, making trade-offs, and working as a cross-functional team. 5. Video-call with Head of Design. We talked about my career aspirations, how they see the team growing, how I could contribute, and on giving back to the design community and making the product more inclusive.
1. N26 was looking for someone with my level of experience. Most of the times it’s not you. It’s just about what the team needs right now.
2. N26 was building a truly international company, hence was open to sponsoring visas.
3. The extra effort I had put to balance out my years of experience — I had prepared an analysis of the N26 app, and the ways I could contribute to the team.
The whole process felt pretty organic and I think took around a month. The part that was the biggest selling point for me was the people I talked with. I found all of them super respectful, and great listeners. We talked a lot about how they see the team growing, and how I could add to it. In hindsight, these conversations were such a strong indicator of why the team would be perfect for what I was looking for!
My last interview went really well, and my recruiter asked me for a “quick call” just the next day. I still remember taking the call, and asking her to wait a minute so that I can tell this to my family before we discuss other details!
It wasn’t much of an upgrade salary-wise, it was just a translation to a Barcelona salary level. I was also aware this means moving to a city where I don’t know the language or anyone from the product community. I also wasn’t sure what I would do after this career-wise.
My key priority was to live in another country, learn a new language, and meet new people. Folks I talked to during interviews showed immense confidence in me, and N26 is a cool product. This clarity really made my decision easy.
N26 applied for a highly professional working visa in Spain. There is also an EU Blue Card, but this was a Spain-specific visa. I could travel freely within Schengen area with my visa, and my work status was tied to my company.
The process and paperwork were extremely long. It took months, at the end of which I had collected every piece of written evidence that I exist. Some of the documents were a police check, educational degree check, martial status check, (and many more)— and all of these documents had to be translated into Spanish by a verified translator.
I had almost given up on this and carried on with my life as usual. That’s also the reason I did not tell friends or family, it still seemed very unlikely things will actually work out. It took forever, and then it all happened very quickly.
Almost 4.5 months after I was offered the job, I received an email that my work permit was done. In less than 30 days, I was on a one-way flight to Barcelona!
Where do I start? All my memories are filled with love, friends, and laughs.❤️
On workWe worked in cross-functional agile teams. Funny enough, most of our team joined at the same time. So we set up our ways of working and rituals (aka meetings) from scratch.
It was my first time designing for a consumer product (that too with 5+ million customers at that point). I worked closely with my product manager, developers, user researchers, and fellow designers. Together, we built and released two big features and several small improvements to the app in like a year.
I also got a chance to work with data more closely, building dashboards for features, and our design team. Working with a localization platform was another skill I picked up.
The office is in a pretty cool barrio of Barcelona, 15 mins walking from the beach. It was the office of my dreams —a pastel colour palette, filled with dogs, and some of the coolest people I’ve met. We had folks from 40+ countries at one point I think, and we had regular get-togethers and office parties!
On design teamWe call it the NXD team, and it has all my heart.❤️ N26’s design team is a very mature, multi-talented team of warm people. They provided the foundation and time for me to climb that steep learning curve in such a short time.
We had very fun, evolving rituals — be it the design standup, share backs, critiques or team celebrations. Within the Barcelona team, we also started something called Get-Togethers where we shared our lives beyond work. Pre-covid, we hung out after work, tried out fancy restaurants with our team budget, and also cooked for each other.
Honestly the people I met at N26 are why I could survive the pandemic, and am still super close friends with most of them.
Side note: I will share some more pictures on my Instagram stories here.
This was one of my biggest challenges in Barcelona — just in like a year, I lived in 3 AirBnbs, 2 apartments, and had 4 flatmates. 🙃
You cannot move to Barcelona thinking it would be like Bangalore — I will just find a house with a few of my mutual friends from college and hire help to cook and clean.
Barcelona is a very multi-cultural diverse city, with the majority of folks having no relation to tech or Twitter. A lot of people treat it as a hallway, they come and go. It’s also a tourist city, rents can be crazy and landlords crazier. So you definitely have to relax your filters a bit and go out of your comfort zone here.
My first flat which I found did not work out for me. Just three months after moving, and right before the pandemic I moved flats. I got super lucky with my second flat and flatmates (and the neighbors).
I had to find a flat twice, and also find flatmates for my flat twice. I used Badi, Idealista, and Facebook groups. I still have nightmares I will have to use Badi again in my life.
I have no idea how much poorer I am because of the money I had to pay in bills which seem obscene for one person — all because I could not understand the language, or talk to customer service, or simply because landlords found me an easy target. 😩
At one point I paid like 115 euros for electricity per month. One month, our flat was charged with like 1200 euros for water — that is equivalent to filling 3 swimming pools!! 😳
We could do nothing to challenge it — except send Google translated messages to find out. We did not find out.
It took me a few hits and trials to figure out grocery shopping. Uff how I missed Swiggy and Zomato in the first few days. With time, I found these magical recipes called one-pot recipes. 👀
Again, Barcelona being a tourist city, there is (almost)authentic food from all corners of the world. My favorite thing about Barcelona is the Menu del Dia — it is offered by most restaurants and includes a starter, main course, a dessert and a drink for a very reasonable price. It made my lunch hours pre-covid super fancy and exciting!
I also found an Indian store to stock up on garam masalas, and get that occasional Haldiram’s ras malai.
It took me some time to start thinking in Euros. Like every Indian, for the first few months, I kept converting all costs into Rupees and freaking the hell out.😂
A rough breakdown of my monthly budgetRent — 650 EurosUtility Bills — 150ish Euros (when I wasn’t being scammed!)Groceries — 200ishTransport — 50ishTravel (pre-covid) — 400ish
Since Barcelona is a tourist city, navigating daily life through public transport, and restaurants is relatively easier. However, doing paperwork for residency, public health, utility bills, etc is when the language barrier hits you!
I took Spanish classes while I was there, and it definitely helped, but I still had to find help from either my friends or colleagues to do some pretty basic stuff.
Most of my friends were from my work. We became quite close, as we navigated the first few uncertain months of the pandemic together.
I had few friends from the hiking group I went to pre-pandemic, and then I had a really nice flatmate and neighbours (+ their friends!)
I am not sure about Indian community in Barcelona, as I was there for a very little time and there were no Indians in my office. I am sure there must be though!
It was hard. We had started hearing things were bad in Italy, but like everyone, nobody expected that it will hit us so bad.
I remember the day we hit the highest number of deaths in Spain, the mood was so somber on the streets. You could feel the shock and the hopelessness.
I was privileged to be able to stay home, and work from home. Shops were still stocked with basics, and apart from being in a complete lockdown for months, things went along like they did in rest of the world.
I have already told you this — Barcelona is my city. I feel like my true actual self when I am walking around. It cleanses my soul and makes me happy.
Even though most of my time there was spent in lockdown, I made the best out of it. I joined a hiking group, took Spanish lessons, practiced yoga in a fancy hip studio in Gothic Quarter, and went to walk on the beach after work most days. I even dared to use a bicycle and became a pro at it.
I sat in churches for hours, got lost by taking the wrong buses, tried all the weird yet super tasty sea food, and tried my Spanish on whoever would listen.
I would stop here, but you get the overall idea. I would definitely recommend you Barcelona, if your priorities match mine. I also mentioned some things which could be a deal breaker for you. Overall, I hope you found some of it helpful!

Title: Barcelona 2023/24— The end to Xavi’s successful but complicated stint.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
On November 6th 2021, Xavi Hernández Creus, one of Barcelona’s biggest legends and best midfielders ever, was appointed as the manager of FC Barcelona following the sacking of previous manager and club legend, Ronald Koeman — after a run of poor results, caused by the lack of identity and dynamism in football, that led to Barcelona being 9th on the La-Liga table when he was relieved of his said duties.
Xavi took the same team, with a couple of reinforcements in the following January transfer window of 2022, took the same team to 2nd place with an impressive period — playing some fluid and entertaining football, and also beating Real Madrid 4–0 in the process, ensuring the first El Clasico win since Ernesto Valverde’s departure.
The football witnessed initially under Xavi seemed very refreshing to a fanbase that had witnessed consistently underwhelming seasons of football prior to this — which prompted hyperbolic conversations regarding him being the ‘2nd coming of Pep Guardiola’.
He instilled an identity — provided a tactical foundation to a squad that lacked it very much; he deployed a 4–3–3, a more direct version than the conventional Barcelona style, but an entertaining and fluid style due to how the players inter-connected and understood their environment, which declined overtime due to the departures of some of the key ‘connectors’.
The following season (2022/23) — Barcelona proceeded to win La-Liga and the Spanish Super Cup very convincingly. Barcelona opted to play the box-midfield (midfield of 4) gradually as the season passed by, which helped neuter some of Barcelona’s core issues in the league, but were again exposed in some of the European nights (like Manchester United, Inter Milan).
Although Barcelona suffered a UCL group stage exit that season, the feelings around Xavi’s future / tenure were very positive, especially going into next season. Most seemed convinced that he was Barcelona’s man long-term. But, things went downhill this season with Barcelona’s levels of performance completely regressing while also going trophy-less, overall.
“Signing Xavi Is The Best Decision I’ve Ever Made Since I Became President”
These were the words of Joan Laporta, the Club President in April 2022, and in over 2 years — On 24th May, FC Barcelona announced that Xavi’s last game in charge as manager will be against Sevilla (the last game of the season) and he will not be continuing next season. There’s been such a drastic change in the perception of him as a manager over a year, something must’ve changed, and something did change.
Barcelona’s feelings coming into this season were relatively positive; the aim for this season was clear — an establishment of threat in Europe while maintaining the impressive domestic success we possessed, but did no one see coming this level of regression with regards to our overall style of play, rather than just losing out on trophies due to marginal differences.
Barcelona’s board parted ways with the previous sporting director, Jordi Cruyff (son of Johan Cruyff) and appointed Deco as the new sporting director; The club also parted ways with Mateu Alemany — which, essentially meant there was more responsibility in Yuste’s and Laporta’s hands — which was unhealthy, because neither have the credentials to be holding authority involving them to make sporting decisions.
Now, certain issues seemed to come with the power gradient — there was a lack of respect / consideration with respect to the manager’s decisions / preferences when it came to certain decisions that’d affect the manager the most, like the Vitor Roque situation. No board should sign a player with a manager you’re aiming to keep when he’s insisting against a particular signing, because it becomes unhealthy within the board & for the player’s future, as well.
A few issues became seemingly clear, and primarily, it was the unwarranted amount of influence Jorge Mendes (the agent) possessed on Barcelona’s footballing operations, when in reality — he has no authority to have such grave involvement, and it brings in an inherent level of bias in transfer operations, that could result in Barcelona settling for players with Mendes as agent, despite them being suboptimal for Barcelona’s squad, like the pressure make the Cancelo / Felix deals permanent, the heavy links with Ruben Neves last season etc.
So, in reality, there has always been suboptimal conditions in terms of board structuring and planning that can make it infeasible for managers to succeed at this club, and it was made much worse with the departures of Jordi Cruyff and especially, Mateu Alemany.
The handling of certain situations — including Xavi’s sacking has been extremely poor from the board. Poor treatment of personnel who genuinely commit their all towards the betterment of the club is an attitude that cannot last long at a club such as this, and will / can ultimately lead to the downfall of this particular mandate.
This was a ‘decent’ transfer window considering the financial limitations and there was a good initiative to complete sales of players that weren’t exactly contributing to the club in anyway, anymore. Oriol Romeu seemed like a very good signing at first, but it didn’t go as planned as the season went on due to confidence issues and also primarily — systematic issues that aggregated his flaws and didn’t provide him suitable conditions to succeed.
Felix and Cancelo seemed to be decent reinforcements due to their high technical potential and talent. The issue came with Cancelo’s and Felix’s mental profiles — often ignorant, unwarrantedly complex, reckless, more flair, less effectiveness, which, as expected, led to improper application of their high technical qualities and inconsistent showings in possession, combined with poor showings in general out of possession;
Regardless, Ilkay Gundogan, hands down, proved to be Barcelona’s best signing for this season by a mile. A footballer of the highest level — mentally, physically and technically. He is a true Swiss-Army Knife in every sense of the word due to how versatile, resilient and intelligent he is.
Transfers regarding personnel has been decent at best, but the overall squad planning and direction regarding overall club’s structure has been unconvincing and seems very unsustainable due to the lack of rational basis behind most decisions this particular dispensation has made. Far too ‘individualistic’ and preference-based without looking at the overall larger picture.
Despite current transfer planning / direction being slightly off, the investment in youth for the B team has been pretty impressive, especially under Deco, with signings like Noah Darvich, Ibrahim Diarra and Mikayil Faye. Although, there’s no balance with respect to elevating the 1st team while doing it sustainably on a financial level — hence, the lack of direction and planning I stated.
It’s been a disappointing season overall, from Barcelona, in the tactical domain, on both offensive and defensive fronts. As shown in a graph created by “Markstats” on X :
Barcelona’s deep entries in the opposition graph has massively declined while the opposition deep entries increased as the season progressed. Although, it is very important to note that most teams don’t look to threaten Barcelona through consistent entries / pressure in their box, rather — they use transitions / counter-attacks to try and exploit / attack Barcelona’s defense. But, Barcelona, being a dominant team in possession, in La-Liga, not being able to create enough deep entries, and it going to an extent that it’s not too dissimilar as opposition deep entries suggests poor effectiveness in and, also out of possession.
Barcelona’s issues this season showcase the fact that Xavi is an inexperienced coach with ideas that need proper maturing, multi-dimensionality and clarity in implication. It could, either, be an issue regarding a lack of transcendence of the ideas clearly or a lack of applying these ideas properly, or both — either way, both are co-related mechanisms. Let’s get into some detail.
Barcelona didn’t change much, in terms of their structural base or their formation in terms of positioning. There was a continuation on the 4–3–3 with often one forming a double pivot in build-up, as done last season, except it became more rigid, and horizontal relative to its surroundings. The reasoning is definitely due to Busquets’ departure — which essentially meant that Barcelona needed more dynamism / technical prowess in build-up, without a Busquets.
The replacement came in the form of Romeu, and the build-up responsibility gradually shifted more to Frenkie De Jong with Romeu assisting in build-up. Barcelona seemed ineffective on a consistent basis when it came to enabling effective progression when playing against opposition presses and already seemed to hit some road-blocks regarding fluidity last season, especially in terms of de-compacting opposition defenses (like Inter) but, this season, it got much, much worse.
What seemed to be the issue was — Barcelona had a structural idea in mind, but were incompetent in executing or even understanding how to utilize / implicate the structure to progress efficiently. Barcelona were too rigid / unpredictable, because of an obvious lack in fluidity.
This came due to one major factor, and that’s the DISTANCING. The distances between players became much larger to try and gain positional / numerical advantages, but it came at a cost of compromising for compactness and fluidity.
There was often the lack of an extra receiver between the lines, and instead there was an increased emphasis on playing extremely direct passes which came with the intent of exploiting space that exists, not creating or controlling. This can also be validated by how often Barcelona have to go long to feed runners, or put it on top of defenses to feed runners that does not sustain because it is a high ‘variance’ style and also, an easily readable and predictable style.
It also clearly explains how Pau Cubarsi’s inclusion has made Barcelona much more efficient on the ball — due to his immaculate tactical awareness and manipulation using his body language and footwork which results in creation of gaps / openings of lanes through which Barcelona can find a player better, like how Cubarsi often opens up the middle of the pitch to find Lewandowski directly.
Players do not move in closer proximities to combine, create space and release to the runners. Rather, Barcelona try to do the latter before-hand which is ineffective due to the opposition still maintaining numbers at the back, and the lack of proximity which can undermine the level of reception, and provide a higher risk to the pass.
This showcased the fact that this team had not culminated a set of consistent principles / a basis of automation in possession that would help them play through the opposition and utilize the potential of their structural knowledge into something much more useful and effective.
A conundrum that Barcelona often found themselves is that they were not given the clarity on when to keep the ball, how to keep the ball, and why to keep the ball. What leads to players playing extremely direct passes, and often turning games into chaos is a clear lack of clarity with regards to collective intent, and how to approach the game. That, combined with the larger distances between players, leads to what we call as — over-verticality.
Barcelona have become increasingly rigid in its style of play — a great example being, how often players out wide are completely isolated and have no pathway but to complete their take on, or lose the ball and concede a turnover — which made Balde an easy target to retrieve possession off if Barcelona ever went out wide to him, because he’s not a 1v1 monster; rather, he’s someone that would thrive on more rotations when wide, and more license to carry in the middle — that’s been clearly failed to be addressed due to the high and wide policy of our full-backs in build-up and attacking phases.
The rigidity and lack of fluidity transcends onto why the particular idea of Xavi’s Barcelona are so reliant / obsessed on / with 1v1 dribblers (Yamal / Dembele), and that’s primarily because that’s Barcelona’s only pathway (often) to creating space or progressing out wide due to the lack of rotations, when the whole idea of exploiting said ‘openings’ leads to not much good in the era of modern football due to the increasing amounts of compact defenses — opposition teams are constricting space very well and as often as possible.
There aren’t enough rotations, whether it is deep with the full-backs and midfielders, or whether it’s ahead with the wingers and full-backs. The rigidity prompts individual prowess and spontaneous solution-finding that leads to unreliability / inconsistencies in possession and often a chaotic style against better teams — because the players are playing at their own rhythm, understanding and intent, due to the lack of a collective idea of execution — which shows the lack of a principle base.
The lack of movement has caused Barcelona to become a static and predictable side, lacking basic combinations in possession due to rigid occupation of zones, rather than arrival and exchange of zones between players, often leading to predictable and pointless sideways circulation / forced passes forward to win 2nd balls or over the top of the last line.
The reason Barcelona look much more fluid with Pedri and looked more fluid with Busquets because these two players had a clearer picture of how to progress and play as a collective with the ball — they tried to receive and create shorter distances, dictate movements on the pitch and tried to retain possession when possible, as well.
Their INTENT was / is to extert control on the pitch, which is something Barcelona have massively lacked this season. There’s no quest for territory — that has led to the patchy form this season. Lack of territorial control leads to a game-model with high variance, which is basically, you don’t control enough possibilities to narrow games down to your favour and leave it out more in the open.
This can be validated by some of Barcelona’s poor field tilt statistics against competent opposition :
— Against Athletic Bilbao on March 4th (36.4%) — Against Real Madrid (30.1%) — Against PSG 1st leg (30.0%)
Barcelona play into chaos too much — there is such lack of re-organization for the team to even play in settled possession and when they do, these are the conundrums they face in possession. It’s very unlike a usual Barcelona team, to be honest.
To sum it up — lack of clarity, lack of emphasis on being more risk-averse, controlling and sustaining attacks / pressure has led to an incredibly patchy season, showcasing clear deficiencies with our play-style, despite Barcelona having the personnel to deploy a better style of football with more control, clarity and fluidity.
Barcelona have been very inefficient out-of-possession, and it shows in their massive increase in xGA (Expected Goals) by almost 6 (from 29.7 to 35), from last season. A more leaky defense, something that’s not anticipated from the team who was the best defensive team (on output) in La-Liga last season.
Barcelona’s press has been very lackluster against teams good on the ball. Teams like Girona and Real Madrid have been able to consistently play out of it with ease, and it goes beyond the personnel at the manager’s disposal.
Barcelona do press with a 4–4–2 structure, with often the advanced #8 and Lewandowski leading the front 2. Lewandowski, usually, aims to angle the opposition into playing out towards one flank, but the opposition can often find the free man pretty comfortably against the press, because the center is not compact, at all.
There’s a spacing issue with Barcelona — often, Barcelona find themselves so far apart from each other, that they cannot compact / constrict enough space to restrict their opponents. This is caused due to the extremely rigid man-to-man nature of the press. The players seem to be glued to one player of the opposition team irrespective of rotations / dropping deep that drives Barcelona’s key players out of position and also help teams find the free man with ease using overloads from deep.
(Source : @CaptnGuardiola from X)
This scatters the whole team — which leads to poor spacing and larger distances between each other. This level of complacency and rigidity in a team’s out of possession leads to a very exploitable approach — especially because Barcelona don’t have the highest intensity / dueling capacity, as well.
The last line of defense is also much deeper (out of cautiousness) which means the last line is looking to concede pressure / absorb pressure more than looking to close down / prevent the opposition’s by-passing to further continue until Barcelona’s box — which is one of the main causes of the uneven spacing. There’s also a clear lack of co-ordination on timing / jumps and collective movement when the press is initiated.
It seems very individualistic, with a lack of coherence and each individual with a different intent / approach to the press and that’s the sign of a lack of collective principles instilled; It’s clear that, this is more than just a personnel issue, and there’s an issue with Barcelona’s intent in covering space / the ball, that goes beyond the press.
A team’s ability to adapt to different game-states also depends upon how well-drilled and compact their blocks are. The low / mid blocks have been suboptimal from Barcelona — which, after the PSG games, many would consider a fair assertion.
Multiple games are evidence to this; the distancing between the lines has allowed too much central access to opposing teams BTL. The block tends to be too passive, allowing enough leverage around the box and solely relying on box defending, blocks and clearances.
The shifting leaves many gaps due to the larger distances between players and lack of coherence in intent. The intent in defending as an overall unit seems inherently flawed — too much of being ball-oriented and unnecessarily passive, rather than coverage of space, and compacting of space.
These are the major causes behind Barcelona’s inflation in xGA numbers and also general leakiness and lack of compactness in defense — defensive record being very poor compared to last year.
To sum it up — Barcelona have principle issues with how the football has been played, and that’s because the key enforcers on the pitch have left and we’ve been unable to put the structure to top use with coaching. Spontaneous dictators of play and solution finders like Busquets (mainly), Alba, Dani Alves and Dembele (1v1 prowess) leaving has caused a degradation in style of play due to Barcelona’s style of play, and effectiveness in style of play.
The core issue requires a manager change, unfortunately and that’s because the manager seems to be slightly inexperienced and his ideas on how to execute needs more maturation and learning — which is normal, but it also showcases that Xavi has a high potential if he can reflect on his mistakes, and what he needs to do to coach teams as a collective, better, without enforcers like Busquets.
Despite all the tactical shortcomings, Xavi has shown he is an excellent man-manager and can manage players very well by instilling a level of confidence and trust in them. He’s more than capable of pleasing a dressing room and motivating them, as a coach, and that’s an impressive quality to possess.
Barcelona have appointed Hansi Flick as the new manager, which is a slight philosophical change, but an ambitious and bold one — which only time will tell, if it pays off.
Thank you for reading; if you liked it, I would appreciate as many claps/likes, shares and comments as possible.
Much love, AM.

Title: Reflections from Barcelona & Italy: What I Learned Along the Way
Content:
Sign up

Share
I recently went on what should’ve been the trip of a lifetime to Barcelona (Spain) and cities Bari, Noci, Aversa, Florence, Caserta, and Naples in Italy.
Like many trips, it was full of mishaps, twists, and surprises. But I ended up learning a lot about many things, myself included, and walked away with valuable lessons and a deeper understanding of what truly matters when exploring the world and reflecting on my own life.
And don’t let anyone else tell you otherwise.
I had initially planned to visit Rome and Pompeii in Italy, but due to time constraints, my friend and I decided to explore nearby cities instead, including Caserta. We toured the Royal Palace of Caserta before catching a train to Florence. We also ventured into lesser-known cities like Bari and Noci and had the chance to experience the vibrant Carnival of Putignano during our stay.
In Barcelona, I omitted places like the Sagrada Familia from my itinerary for several reasons: I hated crowds, was terrified of being pickpocketed, and didn’t want to go just to say I went. Additionally, since it was Ramadan for us Muslims, attending Mass at the Sagrada Familia felt sacrilegious, even if it meant gaining free admission.
Instead, I immersed myself in experiences that were more meaningful to me. I spent most of my time trying out exotic fruits I couldn’t find at home, browsing local grocery stores, learning about racial demographics and local history, talking to locals in Urdu and broken Spanish, researching the Romani people (as known as Gypsies), and studying the architectural details of everyday buildings. I have a particular fixation on doors, so I snapped as many pictures of them as I could as I roamed the city.
And I was perfectly happy doing so.
This is not to say that I didn’t do touristy things. I took a paella-making class in El Raval, where I learned how to make paella, danced around the kitchen, and had enjoyable conversations with people from Moldova, Turkey, Argentina, and the US. I tried tiramisu from every cafe I could. Afterward, I oohed and aahed at paintings in the Picasso Museum, marveled at the World Culture Museum artifacts, got lost on my way to the Chocolate Museum, and pondered the different tastes of Coca-Cola in Europe and the US at a cafe. And I shopped till I dropped, with bags full of spices, magnets, postcards, keychains, and chocolates from La Rambla.
Truthfully, I did feel guilty about “wasting” my trip. The voice in my head shamed me, telling me, “What’s the point of flying all the way here if you don’t check out Park Guell and the other tourist spots?”
But I listened to my body — my anxiety — which was screaming to be heard and decided to conserve my energy for another day of exploration. Instead of pushing my feet to walk the scenic mile home at peak traffic hour, I opted for an Uber, where I enjoyed pleasant conversation with the driver and saved my aching feet from further torment.
It’s not to say I played it completely safe.
Despite being told to avoid El Raval in Barcelona, I ventured there to check out vintage clothing boutiques, satisfy my homesick cravings for Pakistani foods, and buy custard apples. On the way, I went into a Pakistani jewelry store where I bought earrings for upcoming weddings and spoke to the kind store owner in Urdu. She was more than happy to discuss her son’s engagement drama and gave me a discount and free earrings. I wandered alone in the evenings, avoiding the dark alleys and blending in with a tourist group, and enjoyed the city lights. It was a peaceful way to enjoy the city’s vibrant lights and grew my confidence in solo travel.
They say travel broadens the mind and sheds light on the true nature of friendship. During this trip, I was lucky enough to experience both.
In Naples, I reunited with my high school bestie, who went above and beyond to ensure I had the best trip possible. She planned most of our itinerary, booked us a stay at a beautiful old apartment in Noci as a surprise for me, handled our high-speed train tickets for Florence, drove me around everywhere I needed to be, and indulged my constant whims for tiramisu. When it became clear that Italian food wasn’t meant for me, we loaded up on groceries and decided to cook paella at home, where we laughed, sang, and enjoyed one another’s company as we did so.
She also offered me the best of what she had — the master bedroom in her home, her nicest jackets, and the choice of going to Rome or Florence, Bari or Materra. She didn’t want me to pay for anything, but I insisted anyway because, despite the many problems in the way I was parented, one thing I was taught was never to take advantage of anyone’s kindness.
Our parting was more bitter than sweet. Despite doing almost nothing on my travel to-do list, the permeating odor of rotting garbage on the streets, and the death-defying traffic, I had the time (and the best tiramisu) of my life in Naples, the “trash can” of Italy, and couldn’t wait to come back and explore everything else.
Fast forward to Barcelona, where nearly every interaction with my other friend was wrought with tension, resentment, and impatience.
She nitpicked everything I did and said, walked ahead without stopping to wait for me, and made it clear that she didn’t want me around. She also claimed the nice double room in our Airbnb and had me choose between two closet-sized rooms so she could use the remaining room as her closet. I put my foot down and voiced my disapproval, where she eventually relented but gave me the silent treatment for the next couple of days. Despite my initial reluctance to explore alone, I braved my fears instead of putting up with my friend’s rudeness. To socialize, I called friends and family in the US and talked to them for hours. As miserable as I felt, I was touched that many people back home were rooting for me to have a great time in Europe.
Needless to say, this “friend” and I have parted ways, and I realized how disrespected and dismissed I felt in our friendship, as well as the many insults and snide remarks I overlooked throughout our time together.
Piggybacking on my previous point, we didn’t have the nicest lodging. It was clean, in the Sant Antoni neighborhood, surrounded by many things to do. And affordable. You do pay for what you get, especially for AirBnBs.
Our AirBnB had one double room, two single rooms, and no laundry services (despite them being advertised) or microwave. Our AirBnB hosts also failed to mention that there were no elevators in the building and that the walls were very thin. The beds in our rooms were hard and we woke up with sore, stiff backs every morning. The AC unit often turned on when it wanted to and I sweated right through my bedsheets at night.
It wasn’t an entirely bad place to be. Still, I would’ve appreciated an actual dryer machine instead of relying on the unreliable solar-powered clothes dryer on the terrace. And neighbors who were less vocal in their babymaking.
In several cities across Italy and in Barcelona, I quickly became a target for street vendors who could spot me as a tourist from a mile away. At first, I indulged them, buying a few gifts for my family back home. But the problem arose when I started being followed out of shops and booths, bombarded with pleas to “buy this” and “buy that,” often accompanied by sob stories about being an immigrant in a foreign country with large families to feed.
I get it — trust me, I do. As a former people-pleaser, I understand the urge to help. Most people-pleasers are empaths who want to save the world and make life better for the less fortunate.
But let’s be clear: traveling isn’t the way to fix everything wrong with the world. Europe is full of scammers and hustlers who won’t hesitate to overcharge you for something you could easily buy for a couple of euros at the local bodega. Learn to recognize the red flags. If someone is overly pushy or offers you something “for free” on the street, respond firmly with a resounding “NO!” Don’t worry about being rude — nice people make easy targets.
If you do want to tap into your empathetic side, try supporting local small businesses rather than money-laundering souvenir shops or tourist traps. Take the time to learn about the culture around you, try exotic fruits and vegetables, and always assert your boundaries.
Travel is one of those rare situations where I genuinely appreciate my resting bitch face. If you’re a soft-spoken people-pleaser like I used to be, one of my best tips is to put on a serious resting bitch face. It may be hard if you weren’t born with one, but trust me — this facial expression helped me ward off scammers, pickpockets, and hustlers. It also made saying “no” a whole lot easier. People tend to leave you alone when they think you look like someone who won’t tolerate their bullshit.
If mastering a resting bitch face feels impossible, at least look like you know where you’re going. Project confidence. Don’t act shifty; whatever youdo, don’t pull out your GPS in the middle of a sketchy area. If you need to check your phone, step into a store and ask the shopkeeper for directions.
If you’re from a country where seasoning is a way of life, like I am, you might find most European food a bit lackluster. Your best bet is to seek out Latin American or Asian restaurants or bring your spices as you explore.
I’m a huge fan of what Americans consider Italian food. When I was in Italy, I expected the food to be mind-blowing. Instead, I was met with disappointment. I found the dishes surprisingly underseasoned, missing the bold flavors I was used to in the US. For example, the pizzas I ate felt like they were missing key ingredients — salt, dried red chili pepper, and garlic powder. The carbonara at the cute local diner was far from the creamy indulgence I knew and loved in the States. Even the curry chicken pasta tasted like it was seasoned with nothing more than a Maggi instant noodle packet. For a foodie like me, it was almost heartbreaking.
Barcelona had a much better food scene, but by then, the damage was already done.
Despite the confusion, panic, and disappointment I encountered during my trip, I still had an unforgettable time. If anything, I’d happily redo my Barcelona trip knowing what I know now. Along the way, I’ve learned to embrace spontaneity, find joy in the unexpected, and trust in the good people I know. I also learned not to question the blessings that come my way — like the $150 I saved in baggage fees thanks to the kindness of airport staff in Europe. My ability to appreciate life’s simple pleasures — like admiring doors, staircases, and the frames surrounding iconic artworks — turned out to be the perfect way to ground myself amid the chaos.

Title: Riqui Puig — The Full Story
Content:
