Riqui Puig was supposed to be the chosen one.
He arose from a truly desperate era for Barcelona, one of sporting failure and institutional turmoil. A squad bloated with miscalculated signings, a board involved in criminal activity, and a team utterly reliant on the powers of Lionel Messi.
And yet, despite that mayhem, Riqui emerged. And he shone brightly.
“It’s a spectacle to watch players like him play,” said former AC Milan Coach, Gennaro Gattuso. “He’s got a kid’s face, but he has football inside. It’s something I marvel at.”
He wasn’t the only one marvelling.
An academy graduate and a born Catalan, Ricard Puig Martí, ‘Riqui’, was given almost heroic status upon his ascent to the first team. Through him, it seemed written that Barcelona would recover their identity and rule the world again.
But football is cruel.
Two years later, Riqui is nowhere to be seen. Since his emergence three seasons ago, his appearances have dwindled with each successive campaign. Now, he is a footballing outcast.
What happened? Was his quality enhanced by nostalgia? His destiny purely emotional?
Putting aside all biases, I want delve into the nuances of this tale. To unravel the downfall of Riqui Puig, and explain what went wrong once and for all.
This is going to be an in-depth analysis. It isn’t a quick read. If you want to skip any sections, here is your table of contents:
Without further ado, let’s get into this story.
I have to preface this with a disclaimer. In total, at the time of writing, Riqui Puig has played a grand total of 1,539 minutes for the Barcelona first team. That’s the equivalent of just 17.1 games.
As a result, the data behind his performances is limited. The sample size is too small to draw any definitive conclusions. For the majority of this story, we’ll be relying on what we can see on the football pitch.
I will be using some data where appropriate. For example, to point out general trends and measure certain attributes over time. But it will not be a stats-heavy analysis. Nor can it be.
With that in mind, let’s talk about football.
The context behind Riqui’s appearance was of injuries, financial impotence and COVID-19.
Still technically a B team player and only 20 years old, he was called up by Quique Setién to bolster a midfield during the relentless post-covid Liga schedule.
Frenkie de Jong was injured. Arthur Melo’s sale to Juventus was incoming. Arturo Vidal and Ivan Rakitić were ageing, the latter of which was the only cover to Sergio Busquets.
It was necessity that forced Riqui into the squad. But his footballing prowess kept him there.
Setién used a variety of systems in his short spell; 4–3–3, 4–4–2 and 3–5–2. But each was based on the same, possession-based principles:
It was a team that, despite its talent, often looked clumsy and confined. The cerebral, positional football of Pep Guardiola and Tito Vilanova had been long forgotten.
Here is a clip that sums up that Barcelona. Unforgivably narrow, with a string of short passes through the centre, ultimately looking for Messi to produce something.
In this environment, Riqui Puig was revolutionary. Why? He took this version of Barcelona, a sort of knock-off ‘tiki taka’, and injected a shot of the real thing.
In a tired, uninspiring Barcelona attack, Riqui was admired for his raw exuberance and quality. He brought a sense of urgency and imagination that was lacking from anyone not called Messi. Like Leo, Riqui had that ability to break the mould; to produce something unexpectedly brilliant.
These qualities were the basis of his wide acclaim. Of course, at that time, nobody was focusing on the nuances of his game. His movement, his decision making, his versatility, or defensive contributions. He was only young after all. Years later, we can look at these things with more objectivity.
With this context in mind, the next section is an in-depth profile of Riqui Puig the footballer. It will be largely based on his performances under Setién, but won’t completely exclude his later cameos under Ronald Koeman and Xavi Hernández.
I’ll try and paint as complete a picture as possible.
Starting with the obvious, Riqui Puig is short (5ft6), slender, and nimble. He’s abnormally quick over a short distance, but this is obviously compensated by his lack of strength and physical presence.
As you’d expect of a La Masia graduate, he is technically proficient with the ball at his feet. Excellent first touch, exceptional close control, and a precise passer across most distances — almost exclusively using his favoured right foot.
Riqui compliments his technical skills with a sharp mind, enabling him to make quick decisions in tight spaces or under pressure. This is one of his biggest strengths, which we will talk about shortly.
These attributes obviously lend themselves well to a creative midfielder in a possession-heavy team.
Under Setién, he played as a left centre midfielder (left interior) in a 4–3–3, or central attacking midfielder in a 4–4–2 diamond. In the current Xavi Hernández regime, he’s made his cameos as a left interior in a 4–3–3; his preferred position.
In terms of role, Riqui is what we might call a ‘connective’ player. Left to his own devices, he likes to receive the ball from the defenders, combine with the other midfielders in the centre of the pitch, and help turn low-threat defensive possession into final-third opportunities. Through precise passing and fluid movement.
This complimented perfectly the way Setién’s Barca operated. A lot of passes, mainly through the centre, to players in close proximity. It put Riqui in his element, and he performed brilliantly. Delivering moments of quality that turned deep possession into threat — like this disguised pass through the middle to Vidal:
Or this first touch flick between his legs, again to Vidal.
With workmen like Rakitić and Busquets behind him, and mercenaries like Messi and Suarez ahead, Riqui was the bridge between order and chaos. And it got the best out of his abilities.
Here is a typical heatmap to demonstrate his zone of operation, as an interior in a 4–3–3. You can see how deep he likes to drop, and how infrequently he goes beyond the 18 yard box. This is Riqui’s comfort zone.
In possession, Riqui showed promise for a few reasons:
Precise passing and movement
Riqui is all about moving the ball — both to keep possession and generate threat. His ability to pass accurately, and in a variety of ways, is paramount. While the data is limited, we can see a clear trend in terms of pass accuracy and chance creation.
You can also see he likes to play short and safe, with a relatively low number of progressive passes.
Part of what makes this possible is his off-the-ball movement. He’s a player that is drawn to the ball a lot. It means he gets a lot of touches, and his team maintain high possession. Later on we’ll see why this is a limitation as well as strength.
Rapid decision making
Riqui has an great close-quarters radar. When he drops deep to receive the ball, he doesn’t just do so for the sake of it. Often, he has a pass in mind before the ball arrives. It’s why he can moves the ball with just one or two touches.
This also leads to some decisive, imaginative progression, like the passes to Vidal we saw earlier. In his very best game for Barca, against Deportivo Alavés, this awareness turned into ruthlessness. In that game alone, he managed 5 shot creating actions and got 2 assists. A sign that he could be decisive, as well as responsible.
Close control and dexterity
To round off his positive traits, Riqui is a difficult player to dispossess. Despite his lithe frame, his control, awareness and acceleration make him particularly ‘press-resistant’.
The clip below gives a great example of that.
On to his weaknesses. And it’s here we get a glimpse of the story to come. Starting with his most regrettable:
Careless off-ball movement
While Riqui has a sharp mind for passes, his awareness is limited when it comes to the bigger pitcher: creating and exploiting space. His tendency to come short for passes is useful, but there are times when it hurts his team.
In the example below, his movement to the ball compresses space, congests the middle of the pitch, and makes it easier for the opponents to squeeze Barca.
Moments later, Nico González visibly waves Riqui away, telling him where to move.
This ties into a second weakness: not recognising where the space is. As a result, Riqui is hesitant to run in-behind the defence. He does it occasionally, but it’s not natural for him. This was a trend I saw in almost every game of his.
Riqui’s awareness of the immediate space around him is good, but his sense for the bigger picture, the fluid mechanics of a high-level football team, is not so.
Lack of versatility
What this amounts to is an inability to play any offensive position other than his own. He couldn’t be a winger, not because he is a poor dribbler, but because he wouldn’t understand the necessary movement and positioning.
Nor could he be an effective false nine, because he would not know when to drop deep, and when to occupy space.
The conclusion is very important: Riqui is excellent in his niche, but lacks versatility outside of it. At least, that’s the current situation. He’s still only 22, lest we forget.
The final pass?
This is difficult to judge, purely because of the sample size. Riqui shows flashes of decisiveness, against Alavés for example. But in many other games he’s shown a reluctance (sometimes a lack of ability) to execute the final pass. It was either too late, as he preferred a safe option, or it didn’t hit the target.
The remedy could simply be confidence, which is developed through game-time.
That’s why I’m also going to refrain from commenting on Riqui’s finishing ability. Perhaps he could become a decent goal-scoring midfielder, perhaps not. One way or the other, he would need the chance to prove it.
Unfortunately, when his team is out of possession, we have to skip over any strengths and move straight to the weaknesses.
I’m going to have to lean heavily on stats for this. I would rather not, but the consistency from game to game suggests that the numbers are reflective of Riqui’s defensive ability.
No matter what metric you look at, Riqui’s weakness is clear. I’m going to jump the gun and compare him to Barca’s current midfield options. Below are Riqui’s defensive actions across all his first team games, vs the current Barcelona midfielders in the 21/22 season.
Here’s the data — underneath I’ll list the key takeaways.
Applying pressure
If Riqui were to excel in any defensive metric, it would be here. In fact, he does make a lot of pressures. But they rarely lead to successful turnovers — only 21%.
Tackling
Not only does Riqui have the lowest number of tackles, but is also the least successful with his attempts. He wins the ball back just 18% of the time, leading to more players dribbling past him than his colleagues.
Interceptions and positioning
Of course, many midfielders make up for a lack of physicality and tackling by being excellent readers of the game. Riqui is not one of them. He intercepts less passes than any other of Barca’s midfielders.
This should give you a good idea of Riqui Puig’s footballing attributes. A player with undeniable quality in possession, but one whose profile narrows the more you look at it.
His defensive weakness is glaring, but perhaps more pertinent is his limited understanding of the wider game.
Both of these things bring us nicely to the modern day, where Xavi Hernández is building a team based on a very relevant principle: positional awareness. If you came here wondering why Riqui doesn’t get game time, these next two sections try to answer that.
Many Barca fans, especially those who had praised Riqui in the Setién days, were certain he would get his chance under Xavi.
In fact, reading Riqui’s profile, it might have occurred how similar Riqui Puig is to Xavi Hernández himself.
But it hasn’t happened for our boy. Why? We can only speculate. Based on what we know about Xavi’s Barcelona, there are a couple of relevant clues:
The fundamental pillar of Xavi’s Barcelona is positional play. It’s a philosophy developed most famously by Johan Cruyff, mastered by his Dream Team of the early 90s, and revived by Pep Guardiola in 2008/09.
In this system, the players aim to position themselves relative to their teammates, in order to circulate the ball effectively and be suitably placed to win it back. It’s all about angles, distances, and supreme awareness of the game around you.
Looking at some of Riqui’s movement off the ball, it’s apparent that his positional awareness isn’t always fantastic. We can only imagine that for Xavi, this is a big deal.
Despite being excellent on a micro-level in possession, it’s possible that Riqui doesn’t have enough understanding on a macro-level to use his qualities effectively.
This becomes more of a problem when we look at the new role of the interiors in Xavi’s Barcelona.
Rather than just controlling tempo in the centre of the pitch, turning defence into attack (which is what Riqui does best), the interiors in Xavi’s system are much more expansive.
In build-up, they play high and wide, often along the same line as the centre forward.
That means they’re tasked with much more than just keeping the ball. Along with the wingers, they’re the chief goal creators from wide positions. They are responsible for:
Xavi’s interiors carry a lot of responsibility, perhaps more than any other position on the pitch. They’ll frequently find themselves out wide, in the box, and orchestrating from deep all in the same game.
This requires a unique trifecta of quality, awareness and versatility. And as we’ve discussed, awareness and versatility are two of Riqui’s biggest offensive weaknesses.
In isolation, Riqui’s reliability in possession and ability to create goal-scoring chances would merit some degree of patience.
He might not have all these other attributes now, but given time and guidance, why not? We have seen enough raw quality to believe he can produce at the highest level. That’s surely worth investing in.
The problem is, he doesn’t have time. In his second year at Barcelona, as he wallowed on the bench under Ronald Koeman, the gates opened for a new crop of young, talented midfielders. Players that have stunted Riqui’s development more than any other factor.
Their names are Pedri, Gavi and Nico González.
If you want a quick and diluted conclusion to this story, you can discard everything I’ve said and walk away with this:
The long-term development of Pedri, Gavi and Nico are more important to Xavi than that of Riqui Puig.
We’ve already seen the defensive handicap Riqui has compared to his colleagues. That alone would be enough for most managers to sideline him. But considering how influential the interiors are in Barca’s goal-scoring— and considering this is a team that usually dominates the ball — their respective offensive abilities becomes much more relevant.
For the sake of simplicity, I’m going to compare each player to Riqui in turn, and give the top reason why I think each has won Xavi’s favour.
At only 19, Pedri is already one of best midfielders in world football. Utterly reliable in and out of possession, a full range of precise passing, a talented dribbler in tight spaces, and capable of match-winning goals. Most importantly, he understands positional play as if it’s second nature. Pedri is always moving. Not just looking for the ball, but creating and exploiting space for himself and others. A preposterous talent.
Advantage over Riqui: Higher quality on and off the ball, with a better understanding of positional play. There is no debate here.
At just 17 years old, Gavi is raw talent. Like Riqui, his close control makes him incredibly difficult to dispossess, regardless of space. But what sets Gavi apart is his tenacity off the ball. Under Xavi, Barca’s defence relies heavily on man-to-man pressure, quick turnovers and even tactical fouls. In all of these aspects, Gavi is far more capable.
Combine that with greater versatility, and a natural tendency to run in-behind, Gavi is imperious despite his youth.
Advantage over Riqui: Provides more cover off-the-ball, and has shown better awareness of Xavi’s system.
Nico, at first glance, appears the least remarkable of the group. While very tidy in possession, he lacks the imagination and unpredictability of Riqui. But he has something very important going for him: his physicality. Having been coached as a pivot in La Masia, not only is he clearly the best defensively, but is arguably the most versatile. Despite his size he’s shown impressive dribbling skills and intelligent off-ball movement.
With Sergio Busquets ageing, the team’s only ball-winning midfielder, Nico perhaps has a future in a more reserved role. If so, developing him now becomes absolutely crucial.
Advantage over Riqui: Better defensively and more versatile, able to play in any midfield position. He may be the future heir to Busquets’ throne.
In each case, there’s a reasonable argument for Xavi to leave Riqui on the bench.
Of course this is Barcelona, so there may be other factors involved. Political or otherwise. I would rather not speculate on those purely because we don’t have all the information. But from a purely footballing point of view, it’s not criminal to prioritise these other young talents ahead of Riqui. Xavi has said it himself:
“He has a lot of competition, fierce competition and I feel bad not giving him more minutes. He trains very well, I’m happy with him, he’s improving but the pity is that there is a lot of competition in midfield with Pedri, Nico, Gavi, Frenkie.”
Which brings us to the end of this piece. With Xavi’s first season nearly over, and a vital transfer window coming up, has Riqui simply run out of time? Or, perhaps, is there one last chance?
In 2018, Sport projected that Riqui would become one of the best players in the world. The latest news is that Barca have decided to sell him.
Riqui himself seems unmoved, recently claiming that he wants to fight for his place. But with so many players ahead of him, and the imminent signing of 7th midfielder Frank Kessié, it doesn’t seem reasonable to bet on the young Catalan.
If Barca want to register more players, they’ll be technically obligated to move others on.
In other words, it looks like the writing is on the wall for Riqui. And that’s a huge shame.
Like Gattuso, like thousands of others, I have always been a fan of Riqui Puig.
He does things every Barcelona fan wants to see. He plays one and two touch. He’s inventive and electric. His football language is pass and move.
But in the circumstances, none of that will be enough.
If Xavi had arrived in 2020, instead of Ronald Koeman, it could have been a different story. Perhaps Riqui would have been coached into the new system while his confidence was high, and without the burden of competition.
Now, as it is, his stagnation has left him too far down the pecking order. Talent only gets you so far at Barcelona, and sadly for Riqui, he’s never had the support or belief behind him to make the most of it. But for a miracle, time looks to be up.
Of course, football being football, you can never make any definitive conclusions. Perhaps, some day, the stars will align and Riqui will prove everyone wrong. Perhaps he’ll avenge his lost career. Like Gerard Piqué, Jordi Alba and Cesc Fábregas. Or perhaps not.
For a player with so few opportunities, the fan base he’s established is remarkable. If nothing else, it shows that patience, passion, and a love for your club go a long way. Whichever way your career turns, I’ll be rooting for you, Riqui.
And I won’t be the only one.
Thanks for reading, if you enjoyed be sure to leave a ‘clap’ and follow the page for more Barcelona content. I’d really appreciate it!
You can also follow me on Twitter for in-depth analysis of every Barcelona game. I hope to see you there.

A comparison of Madrid and Barcelona’s historical and cultural significance.
I. Introduction
Brief history of Madrid: Madrid is the capital and largest city of Spain. It has a rich history dating back to the 9th century, when it was founded as a small settlement. Over the centuries, Madrid grew and developed into an important political and cultural center, playing a key role in Spanish history.
Brief history of Barcelona: Barcelona is the capital of Catalonia and the second largest city in Spain. The city’s history dates back to the Roman era, and it has played a significant role in the history of Catalonia, Spain and Europe. It has been an important cultural, architectural and commercial center for centuries.
Overview of the importance of historical and cultural significance in city comparisons: The historical and cultural significance of a city is an important factor to consider when comparing cities. It can have a significant impact on the overall experience of a city, and can shape the way the city is perceived and remembered.
II. Madrid’s Historical and Cultural Significance
A overview of key historical events and figures associated with Madrid: Madrid has a rich history and has been shaped by many key historical events and figures. One of the most significant events in Madrid’s history was the Spanish Civil War (1936–1939) which had a major impact on the city and its people. Some of the historical figures who had an impact on Madrid include King Philip II, who made Madrid the capital of Spain, and artist Francisco Goya, whose works are now housed in the Prado Museum.
Overview of Madrid’s cultural heritage including art, architecture, and landmarks: Madrid is home to many cultural treasures, including the world-renowned Prado Museum, which houses works by great Spanish artists such as Velázquez, Goya, and El Greco. Additionally, there are other museums like the Reina Sofia Museum which features some of the most renowned modern Spanish artists like Salvador Dalí, Joan Miró, and Pablo Picasso. The city also has many architectural landmarks such as the Royal Palace, the Almudena Cathedral and the Gran Vía, which is a famous shopping street.
Madrid as a political and economic center: Madrid has long been a political and economic center of Spain. The city is home to the Spanish government and many of the country’s major companies, banks and other institutions have their headquarters there. Additionally, Madrid is also known for its business districts, like Azca and Four Towers, which are home to some of the most important companies in Spain. Overall, Madrid is an important city not only for its historical and cultural significance but also for the economic impact in Spain and in the region.
III. Barcelona’s Historical and Cultural Significance
Overview of key historical events and figures associated with Barcelona: Barcelona has a long and rich history, which has been shaped by many key historical events and figures. One of the most significant events in the city’s history was the Spanish Civil War (1936–1939), which had a major impact on the city and its people. Some of the historical figures who had an impact on Barcelona include Antoni Gaudí, a famous architect and designer, whose works such as the Sagrada Familia and the Park Güell, have become symbols of the city. Another important historical figure is Pablo Casals, a renowned cellist and conductor, who was a major figure in the city’s cultural scene.
Overview of Barcelona’s cultural heritage including art, architecture, and landmarks: Barcelona is renowned for its unique architectural style, known as Catalan Modernism, which is characterized by a combination of medieval and Art Nouveau elements. The most iconic examples of this style are the works of Antoni Gaudí, including the Sagrada Familia and the Park Güell. The city also has many other cultural attractions such as the Picasso Museum, which houses one of the most extensive collections of works by Pablo Picasso, and the Joan Miró Foundation, which focuses on the works of the Surrealist artist.
Barcelona as a cultural and architectural center: Barcelona is considered as a cultural and architectural hub, not only in Spain but also in Europe. The city has a strong tradition in art, design, architecture, and gastronomy. Additionally, is known for the celebration of festivals and events like La Mercè, a festival that celebrates the city’s patron saint, which features music, parades, and fireworks. Furthermore, the city has also become a popular destination for tourists who are interested in architecture and design.
IV. Comparison of Madrid and Barcelona’s Historical and Cultural Significance
A side-by-side comparison of the historical and cultural significance of Madrid and Barcelona: Madrid and Barcelona are two of the most important cities in Spain, both with a rich history and cultural heritage. Madrid is home to many of Spain’s most famous museums, including the Prado Museum, which houses works by great Spanish artists such as Velázquez, Goya, and El Greco. On the other hand, Barcelona is renowned for its unique architectural style, known as Catalan Modernism, which is characterized by a combination of medieval and Art Nouveau elements. One of the most iconic examples of this style is Antoni Gaudí’s Sagrada Familia, which is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Discussion of the similarities and differences between the two cities: Both Madrid and Barcelona have a rich cultural heritage and are renowned for their art and architecture. However, Madrid is more associated with political and economic power, while Barcelona is more known for its cultural and architectural significance. Additionally, Madrid has a strong tradition in fine arts, and it is home to some of the most famous art museums in the world, while Barcelona is known for its unique architectural style and the works of Antoni Gaudí.
Overall conclusion on which city has the stronger historical and cultural significance: Both Madrid and Barcelona have a strong historical and cultural significance. Madrid is home to some of the most famous museums in the world and it is an important political and economic center, while Barcelona is renowned for its unique architectural style and the works of Antoni Gaudí, and it is considered as a cultural and architectural hub. Ultimately, the stronger historical and cultural significance of each city will depend on individual preferences and interests.
V. Conclusion
Summary of key points discussed in the blog post: The blog post provided a comparison of the historical and cultural significance of Madrid and Barcelona. It gave an overview of key historical events and figures, cultural heritage including art, architecture, and landmarks, and how these cities differ in terms of political and economic power. Furthermore, it also made a side-by-side comparison of the historical and cultural significance of Madrid and Barcelona, discussing the similarities and differences between the two cities and overall conclusion on which city has the stronger historical and cultural significance.
The importance of historical and cultural significance in city comparisons: Understanding the historical and cultural significance of a city is essential for understanding the city’s character and for evaluating the overall experience of visiting the city. This can help people to better plan their trip and make the most of their time in the city.
Final thoughts on how historical and cultural significance can affect the overall experience of a city: The historical and cultural significance of a city can greatly affect the overall experience of visiting the city. Knowing more about the city’s history and culture can help people to appreciate the city’s landmarks and attractions, and also help to understand the city’s unique character and personality. Furthermore, historical and cultural significance also play a role in shaping the city’s identity, that’s why it’s so important to understand this aspect when you are traveling.

Residents of Barcelona turn away from tourism amidst record economic growth
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
“Visit Barcelona”, was once the slogan of the Barcelona Tourism Consortium, but in August last year it was replaced by “This is Barcelona”, after 15 years.
The change marks a new strategy of targeting “higher-value visitors who generate greater social return”. But it is also telling of the times, as mass tourism becomes increasingly unpopular within the city.
In 2024, some of Spain’s most visited cities saw anti-tourist protests, with demonstrations in the Balearic and Canarie islands, as well as Barcelona and Malaga. But these protests also came during a year of record tourism that proved to be vital in helping shape the Spanish economy for 2024.
This raises the question, why have the Spanish people fallen out of love with tourism?
Spain’s economy is thriving. In comparison to the five largest European economies (not including Russia), Spain had the most real growth in GDP in 2024, outpacing Germany, France and Italy — The Economist named Spain as their top economy for 2024.
Tourism contributed 0.76 percentage points to Spain’s 3.2% GDP growth, accounting for nearly a quarter of total economic expansion, according to Caixabank. Furthermore, the sector’s contribution to the GDP of Spain in 2024 reached 13%, and is predicted to continue growing in 2025, marking the significance of the sector on the Spanish economy.
But every silver lining has its cloud. Graffiti across the streets of Barcelona show a different side to the story. One such example (pictured in the beginning of the article) tells tourists to go home — others use far more colourful language.
There are several motivations for the turn away from the tourist industry, despite its positive economic effect. One of the most notable is that of housing.
A quick search on any popular listing app will show several rentals that must be vacated in the summer months so that the properties can be rented to tourists and other visitors who will pay more money for fewer days stay.
Jordi Nicolás Soler, 35, a lifetime Barcelona resident, explained the difficulties in finding a place of his own to live in. After nine years he was able to rent a flat, but it is small, on the ground floor, and has no natural light.
The problem, says Jordi, is exacerbated by short-term rentals and foreign residents who can afford to pay more than locals, pricing them out of the city. “Sometimes Barcelona feels like an amusement park; it’s not for locals anymore.”
Looking at the stats, there has been a steady increase in the price per square meter of renting in the last 5 years within Barcelona, according to Idealista, a property listings site.
In 2022, residents in Catalonia (the region where Barcelona is situated) on average spent 58% of gross income on rent, putting them in joint first place with the Balearic isles and beating out the Community of Madrid (home of the Spanish capital of the same name) by one percentage point.
“You feel like a foreigner in your own country.”
The increase in tourism has also put a strain on local culture and language. Barcelona is the capital of the autonomous region of Catalonia, which has its own distinct culture and language. But as more people have been visiting Barcelona, fewer people are speaking Catalan in their daily lives within the city.
A Catalan government survey conducted every five years found a decline in the use of Catalan as the primary language, alongside a rise in Spanish usage between 2018 and 2023.
“Spanish is probably the most spoken language in Barcelona,” says Jordi. “With English becoming more and more popular.
“As a Catalan speaker, it is very common for us to go anywhere like a supermarket and not be able to speak to the cashiers or the shop assistants in our own language because they already speak Spanish, and they know all of us speak Spanish, so why should I bother learning another language.
“You feel like a foreigner in your own country.”
The Assemblea de Barris pel Decreixement Turístic (ABDT), an organisation working against the process of “touristification”, stress the need for regulation by the authorities. They state that regulation will be “inevitable” because if not the city will be reduced to “a mere stage set” that is “emptied of its population”.
The Generalitat of Catalonia has vowed to bar apartment rentals to tourists by 2028 and has forbidden the issuing of new short-term rental licences in an effort to combat the rising cost of rent. However, such a drastic move has raised concerns regarding an increase in unlicensed rentals.
Even if regulation of rentals does improve the housing market in Barcelona, the AFBD are still concerned with other major issues caused by touristification.
Economic dependencies on a sector that requires stability to survive leaves the city vulnerable to crisis that can hurt the economy. The COVID-19 pandemic is the clearest example of this, as seen in the massive downturn of GDP production from tourism in 2020 and 2021 in Chart 2.
The ABDT also point out the issues with the labour market within the tourism sector. They say that it is one of the most exploitative sectors in the city in terms of working conditions, with hyper-flexibility, undeclared work, and outsourcing of services. Moreover, the average salary in the tourism sector is approximately 60% of that of the national average for all over sectors.
With around 9.1% of the population of Barcelona employed in the tourism sector, these are factors that affect almost one in ten residents.
Pushing for further specialization in tourism is essentially asking the local population to become poorer while others get even richer, says the ABDT.
“Don’t come.”
The ABDT make a point that their message is not directed at individual tourists, as they see little potential for a solution from that angle, instead advocating for a change in production rather than consumption.
However, this does not let tourists off the hook. They make it clear that in the current context, there is no possibility of a respectful form of tourism that benefits the local economy. If they had to say something to tourists, their message would simply be: “Don’t come”.

Title: How I lost “myself” taking a selfie in Barcelona
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Opinions expressed by Community contributors do not reflect the opinions of Thrive Global or its employees.

--
Listen
Share
Everyone deserves a nice relaxing vacation. And I really felt the urge for my long-awaited dream vacation, when summer started.
Fortunately, we could get some last-minute deal and were able to book our first Mediterranean cruise. I was so excited to find that it was departing from Barcelona. I always wanted to visit Spain in my life and now here was my golden opportunity to explore this wonderful city.
In my heart, I could hear the lyrics of the song beating softly: “The Rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain…!” How could one forget the musical My Fair Lady and Julie Andrews singing this beautiful song?
So, we booked our flights to arrive in Barcelona two days prior to our cruise, hoping to spend time in this city filled with history, art and culture. My husband had spent time in figuring out how to quickly get around in the city and visit different places easily without spending much money and time. He also warned me that Barcelona is the capital for pickpockets and we decided to be extra careful. But that was it!
After our long flights, we finally reached our hotel in Barcelona. That evening, we bought our two-day Metro pass and set on our first day adventure to visit Las Ramblas. It was pretty hot and streets were over crowded, but I was thrilled to be in a city displaying beautiful architecture, art around everywhere. That was good enough for me to bear the heat and long walks. While enjoying sips of fresh coffee, tasting different flavors of ice cream, I also had some fun with bargain shopping. We returned to our hotel quite late, but I was glad that we were safe and sound. Since we made it safely through one day in this busy city, it built my confidence level more to travel by metro and wander around busy streets. However, it all lasted only for one more day!
Next day morning we set on our new adventure. We took the metro again and then hopped into the cable car to visit MontJuic Castle. I will never ever forget this day. No, I am not talking about the breathtaking scenery or historical landmarks, but about something unthinkable that happened to me. We enjoyed our cable car ride up the hill and exploring the castle. Everything went well until we decided to take the first stop on our descend by the cable car. I always love taking pictures, but this time I made sure to carry a selfie stick with me, so both of us could be in picture with the beautiful scenery in the background.
We found a beautiful spot, perfect with a railing to lean on and gorgeous view behind. Just as we were getting ready to take our selfie, two guys from the crowd came rushing as if they wanted to take pictures from the same spot. I politely told them to move away, so we can take our picture and then they can take theirs. They moved away a little bit and I clicked for our selfie. Oh, no! I could see the same guy in my selfie standing behind me. How did he even get in there? I was extremely upset but asked him again politely to stay away for a min, so we could get a clean selfie of just both of us. Another try and just as I am getting ready, he again comes rushing behind me, almost hits me from the back. Now I was about to lose my temper when I saw him photobombing my selfie. I quickly lectured him about good manners. Next minute they were gone. Well, I could finally take our selfie of just both of us, with great background and both of us wearing smiles.
Unfortunately, our smiles did not last much longer! Within a few minutes, I felt my bag was much lighter and realized that my wallet was gone from my bag. The zipper of the bag was wide open and the wallet that was so tightly fitting in the bag that even I would have trouble taking out was gone!
How could this be happening to me, when I have been so careful in crowded streets?? Oh NO…!!! Who and where?? How could this be happening? Suddenly I realized that I must have got tricked by those two strangers who posed like tourists and photobombed my selfie. I got distracted only for a few seconds, never even suspected those phony tourists trying to get closer to me. How did I not know their intentions? I quickly looked at my pictures that I took and there it was — the clear evidence of how this crime was committed. I could clearly see in one of the selfies the guy fiddling with my bag behind my shoulder. In the second selfie, same guy was holding my wallet in his one hand and holding his phone with other pretending to take picture. I tried to scream, warn other tourists — but surprisingly not a single person seemed to care. I asked for help to call police and again it seemed no one was worried. One of the street vendor said — “It happens all the time. Just cancel your credit cards, Police will be at lunch now and they don’t have time.” Such a cold atmosphere! I rushed to the cable car station and the lady there said she has no ability to directly call police but will try calling the main office and request them to call police.
Almost after 50 min, we saw two police officers taking rounds. We shared what happened with them, but they could not even take police report from me. I was about to enter in panic mode, but then I recalled my “calming mantra”!
My mom shared this Mantra with me — “Always try to be calm. Never lose your mind in any adverse situation and instead plan wisely to take correcting steps.”
“Crying does not help, take action,” my mom would always say.
What do we need to do now? We are out of country and on our vacation and here I lose my wallet with cash and all precious items. First things first! We started with calling the bank and others to report stolen wallet. It seemed as if it took forever.
Next, we headed to the police station. This was certainly not a planned destination on my vacation. But after 15–20 min walk, we arrived at the police station. This could really make another interesting story. A long line was extending outside of police station. This was only to speak to someone at the window. Every single person in the line had something stolen — either a wallet or their smart phone. After half an hour wait, finally I could speak to the person at the window. Then I was directed to the waiting room to see a police officer. Another 30 min wait time and I became restless. It was quite a large group of people and most of them shared that they had been waiting there for almost three hours. Such a long wait to report a theft! Meanwhile some of them shared their stories of how they got robbed. It was all shocking to me. Some lost their wallets/phones in Metro, some while walking on the streets and some in restaurants/bars or shops. That means no place was safe in this city. Some suspected small kids stealing, some had young girls luring them and some thought those were middle aged men/women dressed decently. No wonder it is called the capital of Pickpockets.
In any case, I could not bear the idea of waiting there for 3 hours. I felt my throat dry, but it was not possible to get even a cup of coffee. I tried my best, but I was asked to wait until my turn came. Maybe it was me complaining or it was my luck, but I was called in within an hour. We lodged the police complaint, shared the pictures of the suspect.
“What are the chances of finding this suspect and recovering my stolen wallet?” I asked.
“Not likely. We will inform you if someone returns the empty wallet. File with your insurance.” The officer said in a cold tone.
It was very clear that nothing was going to be done by police there. Now I know, why thieves make this place as their wonderland. There is no legal action taken unless stolen money is more than 400 euros. Oh well — it is a vicious circle! Thieves rob hundreds of people daily, police tired with making reports and have no intention of taking any action. This is like an infectious disease and it will continue to grow unless treated. Unless it affects tourism and economy of this city, there may not be any wakeup call for the officials.
We returned to our hotel after grabbing a soggy sandwich at McDonalds. The entire drama was physically exhausting and mentally draining. I was angry, but also sad inside. It was humiliating and at the same time I felt as if I lost my faith in all humanity. I considered myself quite smart and alert, but how could someone make me a fool? The entire incident replayed in my mind multiple times making me feel so silly and stupid. How could I fail to judge these people? And why me…?? I thought, this would make me crazy.
Okay, time to stop thinking and chant my mantra — “Keep calm”!
I tried to get all cluster thoughts out of my mind and then tried to sleep quietly thinking about our upcoming cruise. Just because someone stole my wallet does not mean they can steal my happiness and heart.
Amma, the renowned humanitarian has a great message. Remembering her words was a solace for me — “Don’t waste your time and never get attached to material things in life. Instead, build ever lasting relationship through love and compassion.”
I decided to follow Amma’s advice and stay positive. I also tried to build new friendly relationships on my cruise with an open heart. What a miracle! I met so many wonderful people on our cruise coming from different parts of the world. Language was no barrier here and age did not matter too. I made so many new friends.
Nature was splashing its beauty around. It was so nice to hear ocean waves singing at night and see the full moon rising over the ocean. I eagerly watched sunrise and sunset each day. I forgot all worries including my stolen wallet. Those were joyous moments that helped me overcome my stress.
Yes, occasionally I was haunted with thoughts of my stolen wallet and felt the pain. But there was nothing I could do. So why worry? After our cruise, I wanted to give one last try just for peace of my mind and get a closure with the incident. I decided to call Barcelona police stations as well as lost and found places in the city. Not a single phone call was answered. I was not surprised at all. What else to expect? So that was the end of story for my stolen wallet.
If you happen to visit Barcelona anytime, beware! Be careful taking your selfie and try not to lose your wallet or yourself, the way it happened to me!
Also next time, when I plan on taking my selfie — I will certainly make sure nobody is photobombing my picture!

Content:

If you watch Barcelona at this point, you would understand how aptly this gif epitomizes the current situation of the club, as we’re halfway through the season its looking like another one of those trophyless outings for the Catalan side. After already being out of the Spanish Super Cup & the Copa Del Rey technically they still have 2 major trophies to fight for including La Liga and the Champions League (yeah good luck with that!) but most fans have lost hope with this season. And now with Xavi leaving the club in the summer things are not looking good this season.
Let’s take a closer look at the underlying issues plaguing this club and how might Barca actually turn this around if they can that is.
Xavi as a player has been a core part of the Spanish national team and the mighty treble winning Barcelona squad which purely dictates his instinct as a manager and how he means to preserve the Barca DNA.
Since his arrival, Xavi has been using his 3–2–2–3 formation in possession or a 2–3–5 shape to great effect as seen below, this shape offers a lot of advantages in build up from the back and chance creation upfront.
This formation consists of a lone striker upfront as Lewandowski, two inside forwards preferably Pedri/Gavi & Gundogan, two wingers/wide players to hug the touchline preferably Balde & Lamine/Raphinha, two pivots preferably Frenkie & Cancelo/Romeu and 3 centrebacks preferably Christensen, Araujo & Kounde.
There is absolutely nothing wrong with Xavi’s approach as he has used the same structure to win the league last season by scoring a lot of goals but also maintaining a solid rest defence at the back. Xavi wants his players to equally spread around the pitch and occupy each zone so that every player has passing options around them and can combine easily to escape pressure. Having 5 players in the front line enables them to frequently pull opposition players from the backline to create space with smart off-the ball movements.
With highly technical players deeper such as Frenkie, Gundogan they create loads of chances every game with balls over the top, line breaking passes, swerving crosses. Having Pedri, Gundogan & Gavi between the lines is important as they can easily receive the ball under pressure and turn in tight spaces to play the final pass. With young players such as Balde & Lamine Yamal in wide areas you get runners in-behind as well as players willing to take on fullbacks everytime. And with 3 solid centre-backs in defence they should (in theory) be able to defend well right?
But that is not the case this season, now let’s take a look at some of the issues holding this team back
After getting rid of Fati, Dembele, Eric Garcia and Ez Abde in the summer window Barcelona were mainly looking to add to their squad depth upfront. But with Barca’s never ending financial struggles, it meant that they can only look for less costly replacements, as a result Oriol Romeu and Inigo Martinez were signed to improve their squad depth at the back.
After showing interest in both João Félix and João Cancelo, Xavi was able to get both on loan, all thanks to them falling out with their respective clubs. Where Félix was looking for a fresh start while Cancelo was purely looking for regular playtime under Xavi. With this Barca capped of a decent summer window as compared to their Spanish rivals who went gung ho to improve their squad as well.
After a bothersome start to the season which saw Pedri & Frenkie getting injured and missing some important games in the first half of the season, Barca mostly relied on its youngsters with Lamine Yamal, Gavi and even Fermin getting some minutes every now and then.
Midway through the season they were hit hard by 2 more major injuries on regular first team players: Gavi and Ter Stegen which would see both of them missing the whole 23/24 season. Both of them were integral to Blaugrana’s success and the way they played last year which makes them difficult to replace.
A simple search query tells us that Barcelona have recorded the most xG in all of Europe’s top 5 leagues seconded only by Bayern Munich. But their lack of finishing up top has been a major concern as they have failed to hit the mark time and again. Though xG can be deceiving sometimes when teams attempt a lot of shots at goal, but if we look at npxG per shot Barca still ranks the highest in the league along with Girona.
While most top teams have exceeded their xG by scoring more with a fair margin Barcelona have struggled to put the ball in the back of the net, in fact among the top 15 teams in Europe they have the worst (Goals-xG) stat along with Chelsea (which is obviously not great company at the moment!).
Robert Lewandowski who has been a stellar striker throughout his career has been struggling to even make an impact this season, he’s been pretty subpar when it comes to linking up, making incisive runs and even controlling the ball in the penalty area.
Part of this decline is understandable as he is not in his prime any more and is probably enjoying what might be his last few years of playing at the top level. But, with lack of clear striking options for Barcelona where they loaned out Fati in the summer window, and Ferran & Felix both reluctant to fill the #9 position it has become quite tricky and definitely raises questions on the squad depth.
Though Vitor Roque who was signed in the winter as a long-term prospect might be able to challenge Lewandowski and provide cover for him at this moment.
Generally when we think of Barcelona we think of fast free flowing football, a team boasting of highly technical players all over the pitch playing proper Cruyff football. We rarely see Barcelona being associated with the word “defensive solidity”, but that is what happened last season when Barcelona displayed the best defensive record not just in the league but all over Europe!
A big part of this performance was Barcelona’s newly formed Back 4 which consisted of new summer signings Kounde & Christensen along with Araujo and a young academy prospect Alejandro Balde. This back 4 was Xavi’s preferred combination when fit which conceded just 20 goals in 38 league games and 46 goals in 55 matches across all competitions!
But this season, fans have seen a mere hint of past glory achieved by this combination as they’ve failed to keep clean sheets time and again and keep conceding goals to every opposition they play. Defensive errors at the back have become quite common and their defensive structure seems deformed most of the time. But, who is to blame?
Marc Andre Ter-Stegen who has been a loyal servant for the Blaugrana for almost a decade now, a club where he established himself as a world-class keeper and is undoubtedly the best ball-playing goalie in Europe right now is definitely being missed by everyone. He is a core part of the Barcelona defense as he vastly overperformed his expectations last season by keeping the most clean sheets in the league.
But Barca aren’t just missing his spider-like reflexes on the goal line, they are also missing his great passing range and ball playing prowess from the back. His ability to take charge against high pressing sides and playing a pinpoint ball to a free man upfront has been his career highlight and part of what makes him world-class.
Iñaki Peña who is currently filling for him in his absence has been subpar at best with a poor save percentage, he also clearly lacks the skillset Ter-Stegen has and still needs time to develop as a proper first team goalkeeper.
Conceding early goals almost every time has been the story so far this season as Barca conceded first in 7 out of 19 games before the winter break, with most of these goals coming just within 10 minutes post kickoff. As a result of the game state, Barca are bound to chase games every now and then which causes a lot of impatience among the players as they look to create chances as soon as possible.
Though this in theory should work in their favor but it has instead worked against them as an impatient pass during build up leaves them outnumbered at the back leading to a turnover at times when the defense isn’t expecting. This coupled with the fact that Barca have no natural ball-winners in midfield meaning their counterpressing has been pretty wasteful this season.
Of all injuries that have plagued this team, Barca were hit the hardest by Gavi’s absence, yes a 19-year old midfielder from La Masia is literally the heart and soul of this Barcelona team. His pressing intensity and passion for winning the ball back is unmatched not just in Barca but all over Europe.
The Golden Boy winner is already a regular starter for club & country and has been hailed by Xavi as irreplaceable in his side, despite his short stature he is brimming with confidence and always gives his best in every duel despite the odds. With Barcelona boasting of a highly technical midfield in Frenkie and Gundogan, Gavi provides the bite it needs to dominate every game.
After Busquets’ departure, who was arguably the greatest holding midfielder of his generation and someone who perfectly fit the job description and the style of play at Barcelona, Barca have struggled to match his numbers whether it maybe in defensive actions or the ball-playing abilities he had. Gavi definitely does not match his profile but has stepped up his game alongside Busquets and after his departure in the defensive shift he puts in each game. His ability to man-mark Bellingham and nullify his presence for 70 minutes in the El-Clasico is what amazed me the most this season.
Gavi’s still leading the charts in the number of tackles put in by Barca players despite being out for a major part of the season as shown below. In fact, he’s the #1 ball winner for the team in the attacking 3rd phase of the game and significantly reduces the number of turnovers Barca face.
Gavi is a player I personally adore a lot and he is someone whose mere presence would fix a lot of issues with this team right now. My personal favorite memory of him will always be winning an aerial duel against Wout Weghorst in the Champions League who with all due respect towers over him 😅.
The left-back role provides a tricky problem for the Catalan side in recent times which was sought to be over until the start of this season but instead grows even deeper. A 19-year old academy prospect Alejandro Balde in his breakout season showed the world why he deserves to be on the first-team sheet ahead of veteran full-back Jordi Alba. Balde exceeded everyone’s expectations and completely obliterated his critics with his stellar performances, despite that he has struggled this season and has definitely failed to make the same impact this year. But is it even Balde’s fault?
As discussed earlier Xavi wants to stretch the opposition backline by playing 5 forwards when in possession and in this system Balde is the one who provides width on the left hand side of the pitch. This totally suits Balde’s traits as he is a naturally offensive fullback who can easily slip past defenders relying solely on his pace.
Which brings me to my main point: Balde is an offensive fullback and NOT a WINGER! Look at these stats below comparing wide players from this and last season. Comparing his stats to a proper winger we can see that he attempts less take-ons than actual wingers and instead likes to go around the opposition backline.
While Balde definitely found success by taking on players last season he has been a shadow of his former self this season and part of the reason is that his game is not about taking on fullbacks or dribbling his way through the opposition backline with the ball. Instead it is more about the off the ball movements and the burst of pace he provides to attack space to play dangerous passes/crosses in the penalty area, which brings me to my final point.
Well “A picture is worth a thousand words” and if there is any truth to that adage here it is. Look at this image below, this picture clearly explains some issues with this squad that often go unnoticed.
This snapshot is from Barca playing against Real Betis which was also Balde’s last game after he was sidelined for the whole season. As we talked about Xavi’s structure before how he wants his players to occupy all zones when in possession so that every player has an outlet to play the ball to, in this case the left-half space is completely empty meaning that Balde has no one to combine with and has to play 1v2 against the two Betis players. This sequence results in Balde trying to take-on the fullback and playing an uncharacteristic cross which finds no one and possession is lost.
This issue is not limited to a particular sequence in this match, it has become a common theme among all matches this season which hinders Balde’s ability. The major issue here is player profiling, since the front five in possession consists of Lewandowski and Ferran playing together, both of whom like to drift into central areas and hence create this gap. Last season, this was not a problem as the front five usually consisted of Gavi and Pedri playing as the interiors so the wide players always found it easy to combine with them under pressure. But with Gavi, out of the picture Balde has been totally isolated on the left flank and can barely prove useful.
Barcelona have been blessed to have a Lamine Yamal among their ranks as the youngster has been beyond outstanding in his breakthrough season. In fact, Barca have been heavily reliant on this young prodigy this whole season who has lit up the league and is taking on every player left, right and center.
For me personally, Lamine has been the best forward in this team by a long shot and reminds me why I love watching this team. Despite being a 16-year old he is overflowing with confidence and is ready to take on defenders at will, escape from pressure and mature enough to release the ball at the right time. What amazes me is that he still has a lot of time to develop and with regular playing time in the coming seasons I’m thrilled to see what the future holds for him.
Gündoğan has been nothing short of world-class since the start of this season and has easily become the most consistent player in the squad. While all the other midfielders have been ridiculed with some form of injury in different phases of the season Gündoğan has been Xavi’s go-to-man in the middle of the park.
Due to his technical brilliance and reliability he has played more minutes than other player in the squad and has contributed in single phase of play. Though his preferred position is as an interior upfront, he has also played as a pivot covering for Frenkie in his absence making him extremely flexible. With the season coming to an end Barca could definitely use his clutch potential and big game mentality to save this season.
Though most of these issues and problems discussed above just seem to be small tactical tweaks & psychological issues with the players and their dropping intensity this season, which is not as bad as it looks. Since, Barca don’t necessarily need new personnel they just need to reinvigorate themselves and a couple of good results might just do that.
I hope this blog was worth your time if you made till the end, this took a lot of time & effort and was also my first attempt at bringing my Football knowledge & Data Analysis skills to the table.
Thank you for reading and have a good day! 😅

Listen
Share
by Ryan Johnson, Planner, Alta Planning + Design
I recently returned from a two-week trip to Europe, and I obviously spent a lot of time observing pedestrian and bicycle culture and infrastructure. Rather than simply envy our neighbors across the pond for their walkable and bike-friendly cities and believe that we Yanks could never match their high active transportation mode shares, I was constantly thinking how I could translate my experiences and observations into on-the-ground change here in the U.S. I also realized that we have some progressive transportation infrastructure on our own soil to be proud of.
We first made the pilgrimage to Copenhagen — the Promised Land for many Americans in the bicycle/pedestrian profession… And it lived up to the hype! The comprehensive network of physically separated cycle tracks was incredible and refreshing, of course, but I was more impressed by how easy it was to walk around the city. Several of the major streets were actually pedestrianized, with motor vehicles prohibited. While some examples of this concept exist in the U.S. — including Santa Monica’s Third Street Promenade — they feel rather manufactured and not organic.
Even with the dreary weather, we were sad to leave the playground of Copenhagen. But Paris was awaiting us! I had a mental image of Paris as the small, charming town along the river that is shown in films and travel magazines. However, I was immediately made aware of the city’s sprawling size and wide, auto-clogged boulevards. In a way, I was reminded of my hometown of Los Angeles, except that Paris’s Metro system blankets the region. In a flip from my experience in Copenhagen, I had gone to Paris expecting a walker’s paradise, but instead saw a budding cycling haven. The city had already squeezed cycle tracks along many of the major boulevards, and the famous Vélib’ public bicycles were as common a sight as sidewalk cafés and baguettes. The bicycle network appears set up to help Parisians close the “first mile/last mile gap” that often exists in a trip using public transit. I would love to see Los Angeles and other U.S. cities with mass transit networks pursue a similar course.
Finally, we ended our vacation by hanging out in the pedestrian paradises that are old Spanish cities. Barcelona, our first stop, was seemingly built to make walking a pleasurable experience, with interesting side streets, promenades, and commercial districts around every corner. Barcelona and other Spanish cities like Granada and Toledo also make good use of shared streets, or woonerfs, to make streets safe in constrained neighborhoods.
Finally, the many plazas and parklets in Spain’s cities were a never-ending source of resting space and excellent people watching.
Although very different in many ways, Los Angeles can and should follow the lead of European cities by creating safe and pleasurable spaces for people to walk or bike and be outside enjoying our near-perfect weather. And I’m proud to say that the LA region is beginning to seriously take on that mission. Both Long Beach and Temple City now have cycle tracks. LA County Metro is planning a regional bike share program. And through the LA Department of Transportation’s People St. program, several plazas and parklets have been created or are planned for previously underused road space. I’m excited that our leaders are beginning to push for progressive changes to restore some balance to how we move around our own cities.

Commonly known as FC Barcelona and colloquially as Barça ([ˈbaɾsə]), is a professional football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain, that competes in La Liga, the top flight of Spanish football.
Founded in 1899 by a group of Swiss, Catalan, German, and English footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto “Més que un club” (“More than a club”).[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the supporters own and operate Barcelona. It is the third-most valuable football club in the world, worth $5.6 billion, and the world’s fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €800.1 million.[3][4] The official Barcelona anthem is the “Cant del Barça”, written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espinàs.[5] Barcelona traditionally play in dark shades of blue and garnet stripes, hence nicknamed Blaugrana.

Title: Are Barcelona Easy To Press? A Recap.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you asked a fan on what Barcelona’s worst match of the season was, I’m sure they’d tell you it was Barcelona’s 1–0 loss at the Anoeta. As far as I’m concerned, that match left nothing for the viewer to enjoy after the first 15 minutes or so, and it was concerning for the fans who had been so confident regarding Flick’s football. The score-line in itself wasn’t the issue, it was the way Sociedad completely nullified any pathway for Barcelona to create or capitalize.
That performance sort of gave fans an impression that Flick’s football is very predictable, nullifiable, and a few rough games later, Barcelona are back with fans fully confident of Flick’s football.
For viewers who looked at the game tactically — the concern was, is Flick’s Barcelona inefficient against a M2M pressing side? At that point of time, the question was valid, but Barcelona has gradually proved that it’s principles in possession are not that easily contained, even if it is by a M2M side, and the game against Sociedad itself has instances where Barcelona seemed to be playing through them effortlessly.
Barcelona’s recent game against Atalanta is also validation to its ability in-possession. It definitely did not struggle as many did expect, although there was a lack of risk taking which led to a lack of penetration, but there was an overall lack of conviction within that performance.
Some nuance is needed to the whole ‘Barcelona are freelancing in possession’ discourse.
Barcelona have exceptional success against mid-blocks, that’s of absolutely no contention. 7–0 vs Valladolid and 7–1 vs Valencia are some great examples. These teams offer space ahead and behind, even if they’re not abundant, it’s enough for a team like Barcelona who have some great technical precision in possession.
But, with high-presses? Especially, a M2M? They give you no space and time in the 1st phase — which requires a proficient build-up. The assumption among a section of the fanbase is that, there’s no build-up with Barcelona, that I firmly disagree with, and the game against Sociedad is also an antithesis to that assumption.
Barcelona’s whole attack is like a flow, it really doesn’t have much segregation between phases — when it gets going in proper motion, obviously. The most intriguing part of Flick’s philosophy is how he’s much more focused on superiority via relationships and combinations rather than numerical advantages. Barcelona’s performance with Olmo as false 9 was so fluid due to the fact that he added much more fluidity in the combinations, and also provided situational numerical advantages in the middle of the pitch.
That movement and comfort dropping deep is a key feature of Barcelona under Flick and should be something the recruitment team should take a look into, when signing the next striker.
This flow begins with something (Jamie Hamilton) coined as ‘inside diagonals’ that’s usually played by the FBs to find either one of the #8s or the #9 to feed 3rd man runs. The movements are coordinated and it’s intentional, not coincidental, because these movements are consistent. A
An example from the Sociedad game :
First, Balde receives the ball and immediately cuts in to get in a position to play a diagonal between the two pressers.
Secondly, Lewandowski receives it slightly more vertical in a difficult angle with pressure from behind, so lays it off to Frenkie (who’s being marked) but has a dynamic advantage due to anticipating the combination beforehand. These details also tell you it’s not coincidental or just ‘winging it’ — it’s coached.
Thirdly, Frenkie plays it out wide to Fermin who’s free due to Sociedad committing very high with FBs and CBs which gives Barcelona an advantage in counter-attack.
It’s hard to believe considering the narratives that were fueled post this match, but there were multiple instances of space creation and combinational play like this, especially in the 1st half — but the imprecision and lack of wide threat helped them re-shuffle, compact themselves and prevent penetration inside the box.
Barcelona had much lower xG than Sociedad, but had a higher xT (it means they were in more threatening positions) which validates this point to an extent (considering for data irregularities).
The 1st goal vs Atalanta is also a prime example of this :
The same — Balde plays an inside diagonal, Lewandowski orients his body sideways to play a direct, perfectly weighted pass for a Raphinha running at full speed.
Secondly, Raphinha plays the pass to a free Lamine converging into the middle for him to score. Simple, dynamic, precise.
This is what I mean by, Barcelona don’t focus too much on numerical advantages, but dynamic advantages — anticipating space before the opposition does to create advantages while progressing.
Finding this diagonal is not always easy, because the FB requires space to find this diagonal but Balde’s very effective at doing so. Beyond that, there’s been an improvement at creating and finding space through such combinations, primarily due to 2 reasons :
It’s entertaining because it’s so expressive. Players have the license to carry, dribble, find their solutions, combine and interpret solutions based on the situation, but they’re guided with a set of principles, structure. Look at the movements of the players — they’re playing off the understanding they’ve of each other. There’s no one-dimensional role for any of them.
One element of Barcelona’s offensive competence is definitely its variety in attack. Let me explain — the best attacks have to be apt at creating and finishing their chances in different type of situations. Barcelona are excellent on the counter, are excellent at utilizing quick built attacks and are also excellent at slowly manufacturing chances.
This variety in their offensive dynamics is precisely their biggest success, because there’s no 1 pathway that limits this team from breaking you down. It’s what Flick’s Barcelona is all about. Flick’s the exact opposite of Arteta in the sense, he defends to attack and attacks to attack.
It comes down to the complementing nature of the 3 attacking profiles that’s supported by a strong midfield, with players like Pedri that create their own pace and rhythm to the game, and are able to give their team an advantage in possession against any team.
Lamine Yamal’s a proper maverick — he’s got that freedom to express himself and for a solid reason. He’s easily one of the best players in the world right now. He’s able to manipulate defenses through his dribbling and passing equally. He’s also developing the ability to be a consistent goal-scorer. He’s Barcelona’s X-factor in attack. He’s simply a chance creation machine because of his ability to read situations so well and do the appropriate thing accordingly.
Raphinha’s a proper runner. A prolific finisher and runner — it’s beyond the technique. His mental profile is one that needs commendable praise. He’s relentless, ruthless and keeps pursuing chances till the game ends. He keeps making these runs despite a shortage of delivery to be on the receiving end of at least 1 of them. The game vs Benfica is a great example, so is the Getafe one if he didn’t miss the final chance. He’s also very well rounded which doesn’t make him a liability in general play and he also aids in dropping deep to receive and adds a lot of transitional firepower for Barcelona — which is necessary in a team full of technicians.
Lewandowski is an all rounded striker. He’s losing his touch, imprecision is creeping in, but he’s still able to make ends meet with whatever he’s still got. On his day, was an incredible finisher and had a great skill-set that is visible till this date. There are instances where he makes certain flicks or passes that shows how good his link-up play was and how he’s still got glimpses of it. His hold-up play to generate separation is still class and would’ve been even better at his peak. A prime Lewandowski would’ve taken this attack to another level.
The 3 complement each other because you’ve one winger who’s like a machine at chance creation, the other who consistently runs into the box to be on the receiving ends of these chances and a striker who’s able to do both upon the situation’s necessity. That balance and understanding is why this attack has been so successful this season.
Barcelona’s probably been the best attacking team in the world this season — relentless, constant chance creation and a level of expressiveness from players with genuine talent that you don’t see that often. Watching this team gives me the impression that the players ‘feel’ the football they play — and that’s Barcelona’s biggest success of the season. A fundamental set of principles have been instilled that have made Barcelona ready to compete against any football club in the world — that’s precisely the progression arc this team needed and has gone through. A team that finds space and in the process harnesses each individual’s strengths, gives room to interpret situations and solve problems based on the team’s requirements.
So much emphasis on on-field relationships between players that makes the football truly entertaining to watch. Players understanding each other’s movements, combining in close proximities to release one another, build quickly and move in synergy.
It’s entertaining, it’s enticing. It comes with its risks, but it’s worth it if managed properly. That’s Flick’s Barcelona for you.

Title: Reinventing FC Barcelona: A New Era Through Data
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
