When we began planning to relocate to Portugal in 2022, I was excited for the opportunity to ditch my car and use public transit — especially trains — to get around.
And for the most part that's what we've done: we don't own a car, and we get around the center of Lisbon by public transit, with the occasional bit of frustration when a bus arrives late or a metro carriage is packed to the brim with commuters.
Comboio Portugal's trains can get you around most of Portugal without too much difficulty, but we were disappointed to discover that there were no easy routes out of Portugal and into Spain — much less into the greater continental system of trains that crisscross Europe.
But what do I mean by an "easy route?"
The main issue is that — due to a limited number of train schedules — it is not possible to travel from one end of the peninsula to the other without an overnight stay somewhere near the middle. The limited number of departures — and indeed the speed of the route itself — mean that it's not possible to do even if you catch the first train out of Lisbon or Barcelona early in the morning.
Badajoz is a Spanish city in the ancient and contested border region of Extremadura (Estremoz in Portuguese). It’s a medium-sized city that seems to be well-accommodated, with historical relevance dating back to pre-Roman times.
But key to our attention is the fact that Badajoz is the current nexus of Portugal's train service, Comboio Portugal, and Spain's primary rail carrier, Renfe. Here the two services join at a small but functional station.
But your problems originating from Lisbon actually begin before you reach Badajoz, at a small city in Santarém called Entroncamento.
Entroncamento is where the relatively-fast Intercidades train service from Lisboa Oriente switches to the slow, frequently-stopping Regional service from Comboio Portugal. There are no direct trains from Lisbon to Badajoz, and you must switch at Entroncamento, with the same being true going the other direction.
The Regional service from Entroncamento is on a small, two-carriage train that makes 16 stops along the way and takes almost 3 hours to make the journey between Entroncamento and Badajoz. It's not entirely uncomfortable, but it is not fast, and the stops are frequent. But they are also some of the most charming stops along the route, and they offer some of the most beautiful vistas of Portugal's interior.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is likewise beautiful. It's accomplished on Renfe's Alvia service, and is much more comfortable than the journey between Badajoz and Entroncamento. The Alvia has comfortable, assigned seats, air conditioning, and a cafeteria car. It's much more like the Comboio Portugal Intercidades service, and it offers gorgeous views of Spain's snow-capped Sierra de Gredos mountains.
Gazing out the window of either the Renfe or CP trains, it's easy to imagine the Iberian countryside of Hemingway's cock and bull stories — gentle brooks that wind past the ruins of old stone fences, among low-slung green hills dotted with the outlines of black bulls and cork trees. This scene blends uninterrupted on either side of the border for a 100km stretch, making it impossible to know which country you're in.
On the Portuguese side of the line, I saw a farmer with a plow yoked to a mule, manually plowing the soil with equipment that Iberian farmers have used for a thousand years. I could barely believe my eyes.
Our goal is to reach Barcelona, and we don't mind leaving on the earliest train out of Lisboa Oriente. And in all of our scenarios we will select the fastest services available.
That will be the 07:39 AM Intercidades (IC) departing from Lisboa's Oriente station. Oriente is a lovely station that's easy to navigate and can be reached from the Lisbon Metro's red line. The IC ride from Oriente to Entroncamento is the shortest leg of the entire journey, clocking in at a little under an hour and placing you there by 08:30 AM assuming everything goes right (it often does not on Comboio Portugal).
Here you have a few moments to top off snacks and water and locate your train to Badajoz. The Entroncamento station is pretty spartan and has limited facilities, so it's really best to get anything you'll need for the entire stretch to Badajoz before you leave Oriente.
In Entroncamento, you switch trains onto the slow-rolling and frequently-stopping Regional service departing at 09:06 AM. This train has two cars and unassigned bench seating. It's far from comfortable and at 3 hours it can be a test of patience.
By the time you roll into Badajoz at 12:54 PM you will have lost an hour crossing the Spanish border.
You will also need to find some way to occupy several hours, as the next train departing for Madrid is at 05:43 PM on Renfe's Alvia service.
Here is where a key decision emerges on your trip from Lisbon to Barcelona — spend a long evening and night in Badajoz, waking the next morning to catch the first train to Madrid at 08:16 AM, or continue on to Madrid, arriving at 10:39 PM, where you will spend the night and have many options for reaching Barcelona the following day. Your choice basically comes down to: where would I rather sleep?
The good news, I suppose, is that 10:39 PM is a perfectly acceptable time to find a meal in Spain, where dinners often do not begin until 9:00 PM or later. But if you are already tired, Badajoz seems to have plenty to offer and — at least as far as I can tell — would not be a bad place to spend the night. And spending the night here would certainly allow you to eventually roll into Barcelona a little earlier in the day.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is a little under 5 hours whether you take the 08:16 AM or the 05:43 PM, but it is comfortable, with the Alvia offering assigned seats and both 1st and 2nd class carriages. There is a well-equipped cafeteria car and frequent trips up and down the aisles by the food cart.
Assuming that you decided to spend the night in Badajoz and take the 08:16 AM Alvia the following morning, you would arrive in Madrid a little past noon, and would then have many options for traveling on to Barcelona. All of them can be on Renfe's AVE high speed rail service, which was slightly nicer than the Alvia service and comparable to Comboio Portugal's Alfa Pendular high speed service.
This is the route I actually took a few weeks back. It was long — and I made the trip hung over from a night of drinking with colleagues in Barcelona — but it got me home.
As with the trip originating in Lisbon, we want to get as far as possible in a given day, so we don't mind leaving early. During my trip a few weeks ago, I intentionally chose a later train as I knew the earliest train out — at 5:50 AM — would be too early for me, and as we'll see in a moment, sacrificing sleep to get out as early as possible is not going to do anything for getting home faster when going west.
The AVE service is nice and fast, with comfortable seats that you can select in first and second class. I bought a first class seat because I wanted to be as comfortable as possible with a belly full of last night's cocktails — not that it helped much as the train jostled from side-to-side as it chugged slowly out of the ancient Catalonian principality.
The countryside here looks a lot different than it does coming from the west, but during this time of the year it was beautiful. Fruit orchards (I couldn't tell if they were cherries, plums, peaches, or some other variety of stone fruit blossoms) were in full bloom, creating rows of pink and white blossoms that striped the countryside all the way to Madrid.
The AVE service should drop you in Madrid at a very respectable 9:10 AM. But the problem is that on most days, there are only two trains departing Madrid for Badajoz: 8:30 AM and 4:17PM. And you've already missed one of them.
So you must again ask yourself where you'd prefer to spend the night.
Even though it feels like you haven't made it very far, there's a strong case to be made for spending an evening in Madrid vs. Badajoz. Madrid is a major city with many restaurants and attractions that can be used to blow your time. It's almost worth it just to exit the train station here so you can see the beautiful edificio of Madrid's Puerta de Atocha railway station. But there are also museums, parks, the botanical gardens, and more just a short distance from the station.
I chose to spend the night in Madrid and got a small room near the train station so that I could pull out on the first train to Badajoz the next morning. Given the hangover, I did not do any sightseeing. But you're smarter than me and won't have that particular problem. Right? I did eat some of the worst croquettes I've ever had that night.
Sorry Spain — Portugal's are just better.
That first train leaves at 8:30 AM, and at least for me, navigating the train station was a little confusing, so I suggest leaving yourself enough time to figure out how to get to the right train. The arrival and departure terminals are in separate buildings, so make sure you go to the right one.
The Alvia train to Badajoz is fine, with all of the amenities you need to be comfortable, but with slightly less-comfortable seats than the AVE even in first class. It speeds along just south of Spain's Sierra de Gredos mountains. With their snow-capped peaks, they make for a gorgeous backdrop to the aforementioned cow pastures and cork trees. It's a little like Texas hill country, but with some very serious hills.
By the time you reach Badajoz at 1:34 PM in the afternoon you will have made a 5 hour haul across the Iberian peninsula, but it places you in Badajoz with enough time to catch the trains on to Lisbon, where you will pick up an hour as you cross the border.
The first train to Portugal departs at 2:09 PM in the afternoon, so you have a bit of time to get snacks and water before moving on. If you miss it, there's another train to Lisboa Oriente station at 7:41 PM, but it obviously puts you in Lisbon much later at night (after 10:00 PM). This may not matter as much for a tourist, but as I was eager to get home to my family, my calculations were always focused on getting home as early in the day as possible.
Both services require taking the slow moving Regional service to Entroncamento — the reverse of what I described in the first westward-bound trip — and switch to an Intercidades service for the final leg of the journey to Lisbon's Oriente Station.
The Regional service to Entroncamento sits on an inconspicuous track that's on the perimeter of the main platforms. It's clearly labeled as a Comboio Portugal train, and when we arrived I assumed it was the train I needed to board. But we were made to enter the terminal anyway, and not permitted to re-enter the platform until its scheduled departure.
The Regional service to Entroncamento also departed late, but the conductor mostly made up the time during the trip. It was interesting to observe the people getting on and off along this route. Many of its stops were extremely rural, and I saw a mixture of different commuters: cyclists fully-decked in their cycling gear who brought bicycles aboard and got off after a few stops, grannies with grocery bags in either hands who rode the train for just one stop, and younger folks who looked like they were taking the full ride for a weekend of partying in Lisbon. Sometimes the conductor stepped out to help the older passengers on or off the train with their grocery bags or boxes, and it was easy to imagine that this cast of regulars were people he knew well and saw multiple times a week.
We arrived about 10 minutes late and discovered that CP had held the outbound train to Lisbon, allowing us to board and make the 4:52 PM arrival time in Lisbon.
This was much to the current passengers' consternation, but much to my relief and gratitude.
While I'm glad I made the cross-peninsular trip by train, it's not something I would want to do regularly. Nor, perhaps, would I want to do it with a large family and lots of luggage in tow.
But if you have a few days to burn and nowhere better to be, and you don't mind a slow moving tour of the Iberian countryside, this is an excellent option.
I should point out that overall the cost of the trip was actually comparable to a round-trip airline ticket. The Portuguese leg of the trip comes out to about €25 one way. The leg between Portugal and Madrid is another €45. And a first class ticket on the AVE between Madrid and Barcelona, in either direction, comes out to about €119. This is all in one direction.
If cost is your limiting factor — and especially travel time — air travel makes more sense.
But there are plenty of good reasons to take the train if you can: reduced environmental impact, the ability to get up and walk around to stretch your legs and take in views, choices for food and drink in the cafeteria cars, and beautiful views of the countryside are all compelling reasons to consider travel-by-train. And while the trains (at least in Spain) require you to run your bags through a screening process, it was nothing compared to the headache that is air travel in the year 2025.
I'd like to see more options for getting places by rail, so I try to take the trains whenever it's feasible. My hope is that the more we use trains, the more countries see the demand for expanded routes and increased optimization in existing routes.
While I might not take this route frequently, I'm at least comfortable in the implications that it brings and can pack and plan accordingly. And if you believe the hype, plans are in the works to bring high speed service between Lisbon and Madrid. If accomplished, this would result in something like 3 hours of travel time between the peninsula's capitals and would make getting on to Barcelona in a day an easy feat.
But I'm afraid the Portuguese cynicism for major works like this has already worn me down, and I'm not expecting this to be the case any time soon.
Even if I don't plan on going from coast to coast, I know I can make it from capital to capital in a single day, and that's a thing I might try to do more often now that I've done it once.
And maybe at some point, I'll make the cross-peninsula trek and just keep going — into France and the heart of Europe. But that's a feat for someone with way more time on their hands than me right now.

Edge‑of‑the‑pitch hot takes on Champions League, Premier League, Serie A & La Liga — seasoned with dry humor, a dash of philosophy, and the occasional self‑roast. Brace for laughs… and foot‑in‑mouth moments.

Alright, Barça fans — with love, truly — but who told you to walk into San Siro like you were on a guided tour of the Colosseum? Yes, the Camp Nou is majestic, yes, the Barça DNA, positional play, and all that jazz. But the Champions League isn’t a stroll down Las Ramblas — it’s the Iliad: every match is an epic, and the gods — fickle as ever — love flipping the script right before the final note. And in this opera, the twist came from a character nobody saw coming.
Because watching Barça up 3–2 in the 89th minute, at San Siro, no less, felt like watching Achilles casually sipping tea. “It’s done,” you thought. Victory in hand, job well done. The Inter players looked half-dead, folded back like they knew how this was going to end. But there’s always a Hector ready to charge in — except this Hector was 37 years old, had beaten cancer twice, wrestled with alcohol and depression, and answered to the name Francesco Acerbi.
And this is where it gets good — and beautiful. Tancredi Palmieri told the story on The Iñaki Angulo Show with that mix of awe and disbelief: Inter, on the ropes, legs gone, out of breath — and suddenly… Acerbi! What the hell was he doing up there? Nobody knows. Inzaghi didn’t send him. There was no arrow on the tactics board saying “90th minute, Acerbi turns into last Roman standing.” Even his own teammates had no clue. Darmian summed it up in the mixed zone like a man still dazed: “Nobody told him to go up.”
And there he was. In the 90th minute, body probably screaming, Acerbi showed up in the box like a centurion who missed the retreat call, crashing through the chaos like an old wolf smelling blood in the fog. A loose ball, a single opening — and bang. With his foot, not his head. No flourish, no elegance — just pure grit. He struck it like a man who’d had enough. Goal. Barça stunned. San Siro exploding. Wojciech Szczęsny frozen like a marble statue watching history unfold.
Because Acerbi’s move wasn’t tactical. It was faith. Rebellion. A refusal to accept the script. That goal wasn’t a play — it was a soul cry. A man who’s stared death in the eye — the real kind, and the kind that creeps in silently — knew that some moments don’t wait for permission.
De Rossi nailed it: “Acerbi thought, this can’t happen to me.” And that right there? That’s not football anymore. That’s pure Nietzsche — the will to power. That raw, vital force that doesn’t just want to win, it wants to affirm life, to scream yes in the face of pain and limits and fading odds.
At 37, scarred more than stat-padded, Acerbi ignored the clock, the fatigue, the script — and rewrote the ending. A guy who’d never scored in the Champions League picked that moment to make his mark. As if to say, “I choose when this ends.”
In that improbable leap, in that lone-wolf instinct, the brutal beauty of sports came alive: the best don’t always win, but sometimes the most human do the impossible. And right there, in the chaos and the glory, a story was born. One Barça probably still doesn’t fully understand. But the rest of the football world does.

Written by: Shane Emch, student contributor, Foster School of Business
My study abroad experience has undoubtedly been the most memorable quarter of my time at UW and one of the most transformative experiences in my life so far.
Through my classes, I’ve had the chance to observe the distinct teaching approaches in Spanish education. The country’s remarkable transportation system has allowed me to travel weekly, visiting destinations beyond Barcelona such as Madrid, Tarragona, and Granada. I even had the eye-opening opportunity to spend five days in Morocco with a school group, where I was immersed in a culture vastly different from my own.
The highlight of this journey has been my homestay with a local Spanish family, where I’ve been fully immersed in both the language and culture. Their incredible warmth has made me feel at home, and I feel my Spanish has improved significantly.
This experience has solidified my long-standing interest in a global career, strengthening my desire to pursue a path filled with international opportunities that will continue to fuel my curiosity and passion for cultural exploration.

Title: The “best” restaurant in the world & other Barcelona gems
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Restaurants I ate at recently and where I’m heading next

Featured
--
Listen
Share
Eating our way through Disfrutar, Bar Canete, Mont Bar, and more
I made our reservation at Disfrutar a year in advance. Literally 365 days. Right before San Pellegrino ranked it the 2024 best restaurant in the world. We planned a whole trip to Europe around this lunch. However, making that reservation was actually the easy part. The hard part was deciding where to eat our other meals. The options were overwhelming, but I ultimately made some hard choices, and I’m mostly happy with my picks.
I’ll cut to the chase — this restaurant was worth the trip!
PROS: The food was exactly as I’d hoped it would be. It was creative, delicious, and fun. It was surprising, but not too weird or serious. One of my favorite things about high-end Spanish dining is how joyful and playful chefs are with their food. We laughed and tried on chocolate rings and exploded walnut shells all over the table and cleaned our hands with water drops shaken out of a red rose. We ate caviar on top of a butter cloud and inside of a doughy bun, spherical-I olives, and golden eggs. We left stuffed, but not painfully so. It’s not the best meal I’ve ever had, but it’s fully deserving of being in the same category as San Pellegrino’s other best restaurants in the world. It’s a much more casual experience vs. something like Noma (which feels like a special event every step of the way), and it’s closer to the El Bulli style with innovative food in an unexpected setting. While I leave most fancy meals thinking one time was enough, this is a meal that I’d actually want to eat again soon. I’m including more photos at the bottom of this post.
CONS: Just two gripes…
(1) When we first arrived, I was horrified that they sat us at one of the two worst tables in the restaurant located in the entry hallway instead of in the dining room. Those two tables should not be used for regular bookings. I feel bad for the staff who have to disappoint two groups at every seating by showing them to these tables. I was worried the lack of atmosphere was going to ruin the whole meal, but luckily, it ended up allowing us to focus more on the food.
(2) The sommelier did not know their wine list and was unable to give a recommendation for a Spanish wine Chablis drinkers might enjoy. Later in the meal, he suggested a second bottle that did not pair well with the richer, hearty final courses. I’d expect more at a restaurant of this caliber. However, the rest of the team provided excellent service.
While the trip was planned around Disfrutar, we certainly didn’t go hungry for our other meals…
Mont Bar — World-class fine dining in a bar
I’m so sad that this restaurant isn’t in San Francisco, because I would eat here regularly if I could. Since reservations for Disfrutar are so impossible, this is the restaurant that I will recommend to everyone I know. They manage to strike a unique balance between a fancy special occasion restaurant and an informal tapas spot (they self describe as “fine dining in a bar”). The restaurant is tiny with space for about 20 people. Most diners are eating the tasting menu or creating their own tasting menu like we did. When I read the menu online, I was worried that the combinations of ingredients were going to be too unusual, but everything came together beautifully. We all agreed the chicken skin squid canape was our favorite bite of the night, but we also loved the sea bass ceviche, mochi with sobrasada, and tuna belly. The nori seaweed and caviar ice cream sandwich was a wonderfully weird way to end the night.
Berbena — Hip newcomer, still finding its footing
The vibe of this restaurant was perfect. It was upscale but casual, with an open kitchen and a small dining area that was full, but not too cramped. The waiters had a warm style, and it felt like they were all friends and you got to be their friend for the night too. They did a great job offering us a range of wine options based on our preferences. The food menu was interesting and diverse, but only had a few standout dishes. You must order the bread with sides (sliced ham and butter), the tapioca & cheddar dadinho (delightful texture and cheesy taste) and all the desserts. Somehow I did not take pictures of any of the best dishes! The vegetables and main courses were all underwhelming, but I would go back again in a different season since the menu changes regularly.
Bar Canete — Old school tapas, worth the hype
I was worried this famous spot would be full of tourists, and it was — but I still loved it (supposedly the locals arrive around 10pm). You’ll have to force your way to the front of a crowd to check in with the host, but as long as you have a reservation they operate efficiently. We were seated within 15 minutes of our reservation. The waiter was high energy and funny and helped steer us towards all the best dishes. We ordered way too much, but I’m glad we didn’t miss the tuna tartar, steak with foie gras, or crema catalana.

Title: Seven Wonders of Spain.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Barcelona — Zaragoza — San Sebastian — Cudillero — A Coruña — Madrid — Valencia.
This November I turned 30 years old and decided to celebrate it with my friend Eugene, traveling across Spain. Though I grew up in the far east of Russia, it was a long awaited return to a place where, five years ago, I lived and studied. Spain is also a place that I once called my “foreign homeland.”
After landing in Barcelona, we rented a car, named it “Pepe,” and embarked on our Spanish journey. Throughout the trip we visited seven cities in seven different Spanish regions, going from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic coast and back to the southeast of Spain.
Here are some personal impressions of the places we visited.
We arrived in Spain during the pinnacle of a political conflict: “Catalonia v. Spain“ — a perennial debate that has engulfed the region, culminating in Catalonia’s recent independence vote. The day we landed there was a demonstration in favor of a unified Spain in la Plaza de Ayuntamiento de Barcelona. Semi-sober protesters, draped in Spanish flags, were yelling, singing, drinking and dancing in favor of not dividing the country into two.
The following day we went to listen to Estrella Morente’s heart-touching voice. The widely renowned star of Spain’s traditional flamenco music headlined a concert at the iconic Palau de la Musica in Barcelona with her band. While purchasing the tickets I asked the woman at the box office if she liked Señorita Morente. The attendant charmingly looked at me and said, “Of course. She’s the most important singer…from a country that is next to us.”
In Zaragoza, in the Aragon region in between Barcelona on the south coast and San Sebastián, near the French border on the north coast, I met up with my friend Nick, a photographer who recently moved with his family from New York City to a small village near Lleida in Catalonia.
Nick said that after living in New York he feels way more relaxed in Spain. He’s discovered a new lifestyle. Life on the outskirts has its own advantages, including fresh food and a chill vibe, but also its flaws, namely a lack of art that is vital for the nourishment of any artist. Nick loves the region and terribly misses his work, photographing people and making portraits. Gladly, he brought his camera to our luncheon and we did a few shots in the streets of Zaragoza. Ever since meeting Nick in New York a year ago, I’ve considered him my photo inspiration. Every time I face his camera we get lost in the collaborative process and find creative images together.
Barcelona is my favorite city and the most beautiful I’ve ever seen. Or so I thought until I re-discovered San Sebastian, a resort town that is located near the French border on the north coast. Six years ago I visited but I don’t know how I failed to fully appreciate all of its beauty. Walking the streets of the old city and experiencing the sunset from atop a mountain was perhaps was one of the most beautiful experiences I’ve had — ever.
While wandering around San Sebastián, I happened upon a local bakery in town where I randomly met an 18 year old young kid from Guatemala. We sat for coffee and talked. Our surface conversation led us a to a deeper level, sharing personal stories. He told me that his parents found out that he is gay and did not take it so well. He turned sad when talking about his family and said that he didn’t want to have contact with them anymore. He left his home and rented a small room in this city. Now he goes to college in the morning and works at the bakery in the evening. He dreams of being a model and a flight attendant. I was amazed by his strength and focus at such a young age. I was touched by his coming out story. He reminded me of myself and my own.
In Cudillero, a small village in the northwest of Spain, we rode horses for a stroll through the rugged forest to observe the sea from the top of the mountains. It was one of the most therapeutic experiences I’ve had. The beauty and harmony of green Asturian nature mixed with the rhythm and sound of the horse’s hoofs created a sense of pure bliss.
Right before we began the afternoon journey, a small dog approached me. Her fur was matted and messy from the rain, and, she had sad gaze. I caressed the dog and said, “hello.” She was friendly and even with a coat that could use a brushing, quite cute. Five minutes later, as we mounted our horses and made our way to the main road to start the trail into the woods, our guide, Jesus, noticed that the dog was laying on the grass along the narrow road. The dog was dead.
Although we didn’t see what happened, probably a passing car hit the dog. She belonged to Jesus’s co-worker and Jesus started to weep deeply. Tears of sorrow also struck my own heart. It made me think of life and instant death. Five minutes ago I was caressing a dog and looking into her eyes and then …bah… and the soul is gone.
A few days later we went to see Goya’s “Black Paintings” in the Museo del Prado in Madrid. Among all of them there was one that grabbed my full attention. Perhaps I would not have been so struck by it if it had not been for the recent accident. The painting, called “Drowning Dog,” represented fatality and mortality. I still keep thinking about it — the painting, the dog and the message.
In A Couña, a port city in the Galician region, I had the most delicious Pulpo a la Gallega. In general, food all over Spain is fantastic. I could eat cheese with bread and drink wine endlessly, as long as its Spanish. The cuisine embraces the pure art of a simple food. No need to go to a fancy restaurant approved by magazines, or entitled with the stars. Just stop by a local bar and ask for un pincho de tortilla con un cortado. Simple and easy … and damn good!
My new acquaintance Davide commented that if you are born in Galicia you have to say that you are Gallego, not Spaniard. In some areas of Galicia if you, as a Gallego, proclaim yourself a Spaniard first, “you might be beaten up,” he said. Two other friends from Galicia were in total disagreement with Davide’s statement when I shared it with them.
Traveling through Spain we faced, on several occasions, statements from people proclaiming their regional pride. Throughout Cataluña we heard how proud people are to be Catalan first, and later in Cudillero, locals expressed pride at being born in Asturias region, then in A Coruña, in Spain’s far corner above Portugal, girlfriends of mine did not let us buy them lunch proclaiming, Vamos a pagar nosotros porque somos chicas Gallegas (We will pay for ourselves, because we are Galician girls)!
Later in Valencia, south of Madrid and back on the Mediterranean coast, people speak Valenciano and feel deeply rooted in their language and its preservation. It was interesting to observe how one single country is so diversely separated by it own dialect, food, language, culture and economics. People throughout the nation persistently point out these differences. It felt foreign as coming from Russia, it never occurred to me, nor any of my friends, to proudly declare that we are from a specific region.
I turned 30 between day and and night somewhere on the road between Madrid and Valencia. I was driving a car, accompanied by an exceptionally beautiful sunset that scattered around the sky and minute by minute as if it were a perfectly composed playlist, changing colors as if they were tracks of music, from mild light blue to loud poisoning red to eventually calm and quiet dim orange. It felt deeply symbolic, driving forward towards new experience without looking back.
Heraclitus once said, ”No man ever steps into the same river twice, for it’s not the same river and he’s not the same man.“ The more I age the more I get it.
In 2010 I came to Valencia from my home country of Russia to get my Masters degree. I studied Communication at the University of Valencia and graduated in 2012. When I got a job offer in New York City, I left Spain. Needless to say, I felt quite emotional coming back after five years of separation.
The morning after we arrived, I was showing my friend Eugene my favorite places where I spent the best times of my youth. I took him through the river from the City of Arts and Science to the Old City and the City Center. On bikes, we rode to my language school where I studied Spanish, and I wandered through the halls of my university and somehow found myself in the cafeteria. I recall that I was always hungry during that time and looked at the faculty terrace and saw students smoking in groups and chatting about university life sitting on the stairs. I did exactly the same a half decade ago.
It felt surreal.
We greeted the sunset atop Torres de Serrano, where the old town starts. If you climb the stairs of the tower you can observe a spectacular view of the city. At the top there was one young guy playing guitar and one girl clapping in the rhythm of flamenco. The sound of the music, the towers, and the sunset all together were so harmonic that I could not help but dance.
My trip ended in Valencia. Eugene left for the U.S. and I stayed in the city for a few more days meeting new people, discovering and rediscovering old friends and simply walking around Valencia, absorbing the Spanish air, voices, smells and sights. It made me realize that I fell in love with Spain — again. Or perhaps my Spanish romance never stopped, it just took a five year break.
I hope our long distance relationship will continue to develop in some way no matter how far we are from each other.
Traveling by car across the country is the best way to discover Spain. Our car “Pepe” took us from the south all the way through the north and back to the south, more than 2,100 km. Spanish highways are high-end!
Barcelona — Sail the Mediterranean with Enric and see the city from the sea boathttps://www.meetup.com/es-ES/Barcelona-Fun-Sailing/members/204961128/
Zaragoza — It’s impossible to avoid passing it but Basilica del Pilar is an astonishing architectural legacy.
San-Sebastian — Among of the best Pinxos I tried were here at Atari Gastroteka. Calle Mayor 18
Cudillero — Climb to the mirador and take a look at the village from above. It worth it to travel all the way there just to see the view with your own eyes.
A Coruña — Have lunch at Pulperia de Melide ask for Pulpo a la gallega — OMG — this Octopus with potatoes was EVERYTHING. You can not imagine.
Madrid — Dine at Sobrino de Botin — one of the oldest restaurants in the city founded in 1725. Calle Cuchilleros 17
Valencia — Cozy atmosphere, tasty coffee and way too tasty pastries are at coffee shop Dulce de Leche. You can sit there forever and it’s not going to be enough. A place I always want to come back. Carrer de Pintor Gispert 2
--
--
Filmmaker based in New York City. Official website CallMeSasha.com

Title: The Many Dogs Of Barcelona
Content:

Sign up

Member-only story
--
7

Before we went to Barcelona, we thought that Boulder, Colorado, north of Denver, might be the world’s dog-loving capital. In Boulder, you can take your dog practically everywhere, and people do. They’re in restaurants and grocery stores, running alongside their bike-riding owners, playing in dog parks, and going on walks. According to one website, there are 15,000 dogs in Boulder, and one out of three households has a dog.
Then, after our 10 days there, I had to believe that Barcelona residents had to love dogs more. There were dogs everywhere we went.
Imagine my surprise when I looked on Google to discover that neither Boulder nor Barcelona is the biggest dog-loving city. There are lots of cities with more dogs per capita, including Houston, Seattle, Bern, Budapest, and others, including Paris and Denver. But I have to wonder if this website is truly up-to-date.
Barcelona may not be the biggest dog-loving city listed on Google, still perhaps it’s the city that cleans up after its dogs the best.
Only once in 10 days did we encounter squished dog poop on the sidewalk, unlike in Paris, where you have to watch where you step, even in the nicer neighborhoods…

Title: The Day the Lights Went Out in Barcelona
Content:

Your concierge to the city of Barcelona, Spain.

Member-only story
Featured

4

On Monday, April 28, a power outage disrupted travel and daily life across Spain, Portugal, Andorra, and parts of France and Belgium — grounding planes, halting trains, and leaving hundreds stuck in elevators. This is a first-hand account of what it was like to be in the middle of the outage.
“Everything all right? You seem tense,” my wife remarked from the passenger seat. We were in the car, a roaring Peugeot 3008 with brake calipers screaming to be replaced, driving our six-month-old to his pediatrician appointment across town.
I’m a calm driver — somewhere between your grandpa and a limo chauffeur — except for the occasional curse word. At least normally. Yet yesterday, the streets of Barcelona were unusually jammed even for a Monday. I could feel myself getting more tense by the minute. And, apparently, so could my wife.
“Half the traffic lights aren’t working,” I pointed out. “Oh, sh — “ I slammed on the brakes. “That guy on the left thinks he has the right of way.”
“Must be some kind of power outage.”

Title: Care-informed Urban Governance in Action: Notes from Our Barcelona Fieldwork
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This project is an international and interdisciplinary collaboration between researchers, artists, and educators for a meaningful, fair, and forward-looking participation of youth in sustainable spatial planning processes.

--
Listen
Share
What does it look like when the idea of care as a practice that sustains life, communities, and cities is considered in an urban context? How can this idea be used to inform projects and planning interventions? Those were some of the questions we brought with us to Barcelona (Spain) where we have been conducting fieldwork this week. Today, we completed our visit as part our ongoing research into care-informed urban planning. The project titled “Care-Informed Urban Planning: Learnings and Exchange Across Countries and Sectors” aims is to generate insights into how care ethics are operationalised in the context of planning and urban governance in selected cases. The insights, exchanges, and warm welcomes we encountered in Barcelona have left us both intellectually energised.
Barcelona is truly intriguing. It is a city that is not shying away from pioneering projects, programs, and interventions informed by ideas around inclusion, Ethics of Care, and feminism. We learned that the Barcelona City Council has set up the Area for Feminisms and Equality, a department with a commitment to gender equality, has established the Councillor’s Office for Feminism and LGBTI Affairs and set up a Gender Impact Assessment (GIAs) tool used in policymaking processes, particularly in urban planning and budgeting. These initiatives are part of Barcelona’s broader Gender Justice Plan, aiming to work on inequality through proximity and diversity and reflect a broader commitment to feminist municipalism, integrating equality into urban governance and public policy.
During our fieldwork, we aimed to understand and gain a clearer perspective on how considerations about care are integrated into urban governance. We are incredibly grateful for the warm welcome and generous engagement we received from everyone who we spoke with.
Barcelona has a rich and dynamic approach to urban governance, where multiple actors are involved in shaping living environments. Care concerns seem to be informing many activities of urban governance. We had the chance to learn more about a range of innovative interventions that make care visible and actionable within the urban fabric.
These include the time use initiative, climate refuges, the justice-based approach to culture, Vila Veïna, and the city’s superblocks (in Esp. superilles). Most of these initiatives are run at the neighbourhood level, and a common thread across these efforts is the idea that care is not just a private matter confined to the home. Instead, care is increasingly recognised as a collective, social, and spatial issue. It is an issue that belongs in the public domain. And as such, it deserves institutional recognition, public investment, professional expertise, and spaces for diverse voices to be heard, especially those historically underrepresented in traditional planning processes.
We’re leaving Barcelona inspired and full of ideas and reflections. Thank you to all those who shared their time, knowledge, and reflections with us.
With gratitude,Romina & Miriam
Acknowledgment This fieldwork was made possible through the support of the RJ Forskningsinitiering grant [F24–0076], awarded by Riksbankens Jubileumsfond for the “Care-Informed Urban Planning: Learnings and Exchange Across Countries and Sectors” seed project. Miriam’s work is funded by Macquarie University.
--
--
This project is an international and interdisciplinary collaboration between researchers, artists, and educators for a meaningful, fair, and forward-looking participation of youth in sustainable spatial planning processes.
Senior Researcher & Associate Prof in Env Management and Governance. Depart for Environment, Development and Sustainability Studies, Södertörn Univ, Sweden.

“Gun store, liquor store, gun store… Where the fuck you taking me!?!” -Dave Chappelle (Killing Em’ Softly)
April 12, 2006
My 3 cabinmates were far lamer than the ones from my other long train trip, so I drank in the bar car by myself and bit my nails until I was drunk enough to pass out. My dad bit his nails too, and I’ve always been extremely embarrassed of the habit as a result. It’s just so hard to quit a drug you grow yourself.
When I woke up, we were in the French countryside, which had no graffiti, but was still quite beautiful, with its’ rolling hills, herds of sheep, and never-ending rows of grapes to be transformed to wine.
That reminds me of a Mitch Hedberg joke…
“I saw this wino, he was eating grapes. I was like dude you have to wait.”
I could feel the temperature, and the moods of the passengers change as soon as we crossed the border into Spain and saw the sea. Only the sea, or maybe a bucket of Xanax, can calm an anxious crowd of travelers so quickly. Anticipation turned to relaxation, as we watched the waves crash into the shore. Redemption was in the air, and I was more than ready for mine.
Stepping off the train, I felt like Uma Thurman in Pulp fiction when she takes the shot of adrenaline to her heart. I was born anew, my past mistakes forgiven. The Berghain, the prostitute, the near arrests… Those mishaps were soon to be a thing of the past. Barcelona, I told myself, would be my travel baptism.
My hostel was only a short walk from the train, and when I got there, I was impressed. It was very much righton the beach. The sand reached the entrance. There were a few guys drinking outside with their shirts off. One of them had a brindle hound he let me pet. Everything was falling right into place.
I was greeted warmly by the manager, who, to my surprise, bought me a beer while I waited for the room to be cleaned — a fine protocol, if you ask me. As soon as my room was ready, I threw on my shorts, along with the flip flops I’d been using to shower, and headed for the beach with my book in tow. On the way, I stopped in a little shop, which looked very much like a New York bodega, and bought a few 20oz Heineken cans. I had my book, my cigs, and my drinks. I was set until dinner.
There were only about 100 people peppered along the beach, most of them drinking in small cliques. I found an isolated area and made myself comfortable. I was almost done with my book and had every intention of finishing it that day.
As soon as I fixed my eyes on the page though, I heard a voice, an American sounding one, holler in my direction.
Guy: What book are you reading?
I looked up and saw three men walking towards me. The one leading the way was pale and gruff looking, maybe 35 years old, with a mullet. He was wearing jeans and a jean jacket.
Me: Hunter Thompson. Ever heard of him?
Guy: No. It sure is big though.
Me: Yep, lots of words.
Guy: Are you making fun of me?
Me: No, not at all. I’m Sam. Here, have a beer. I have one more if you fellas don’t mind sharing.
Guy: Sure, we can share. My name is John. That’s Carlos, and that’s Aaron.
I pulled the remaining two beers out of my bag and tossed them their way.
This was my thinking… Here we had three odd strangers who had been nothing but nice thus far, though I was sensing some odd undercurrents. So, I made a generous offer of friendship, one that would allow me to gather additional information from a position of kindness and generosity, as opposed to weary skepticism. That approach has gotten me far in life. The other benefit was that I was now out of my remaining beers and had an excuse to leave our soiree as soon as my can ran dry. Not bad, right?
Aaron was about 30 years old and didn’t talk so I couldn’t determine where he was from. His skin was weathered from the sun, his blue tank top tattered from years of wear. He wreaked of beer like he’d been drinking for two straight days. And he seemed a bit touched, but that could have been the result of a sun-soaked bender. It was hard to tell.
Carlos looked to be about 20 years old. He was quiet, with dark skin and a 90’s bowl cut. I could tell he was much more innocent than the other two. I assumed he was a local but couldn’t be sure. [SR1]
Both guys gestured towards me but none of us shook hands. We were a crew now, whether I liked it or not. At least until my beer ran out.
John: We need more beer.
He flipped his can over to show me he’d finished it.
I thought, “FUUUUCK, that was remarkably fast,” realizing the trap I’d fallen into. It was now becoming clear that they were homeless people, and John was the leader of the crew. He had me in his sights. I was the mark, and he was going to work me for as much as he could. I scrambled for an out but came up with nothing, so I went along. What were they going to do, kill me after I’d given them beer?
Me: Ok, I’ll go grab a few more.
John: Wait, I’ll come with you.
Me: It’s just right there. I can —
John: I’m coming. Let’s go.
We walked 2 blocks to the store I’d previously been in and grabbed four of the same 20oz. Heineken cans. As I approached the counter, I saw John talking to the clerk, who was handing him a pint of Jack Daniels from the shelf behind the register.
John: Let’s get this too. And some Cheetos. I haven’t had Puffs in like 15 years.
I thought, “What the fuck does he mean by that? Was he away somewhere? WHY WOULD HE NOT HAVE HAD CHEETOS IN SO LONG?”.
Me: Yeah, fine, just total it up. But that’s it. I need have dinner soon and I can’t get that drunk.
I lied. That was exactly my plan.
John: Sure. Of course. You’ll get to your dinner.
John held the bag as we walked back to the beach. We’d only just exchanged names, and I was already 30 Euros in the hole. What little leverage I had was gone.
John: Sam got us food and drinks!
Everyone rejoiced, except me. John pulled the bottle of Jack out and took a big swig, handing it to me after.
John: Here, have some.
Me: Oh, no. I’m good. I don’t even like Jack that much.
John: You’re not going to drink with me…?
Me: I mean, I bought it. That must count for something, no?
John: Still, rude.
I took the bottle and wiped the mouthpiece.
Me: (sarcastically) Is that rude too?
I took a swig and looked back at John. For the first time I noticed the burn marks around his mouth. He saw me staring.
John: Don’t worry, they’re burns, not herpes.
Me: That’s good… Or bad… I’m not sure what you want me to say.
John: My parents burned me.
I ignored him, hoping the subject would change, or a plane would fall out of the sky and crush us all into mush.
John: That’s why I killed them.
I looked up hoping to see the plane. Nothing. Carlos and Aaron were still sitting silently, sharing their beer. They didn’t even look particularly bothered or uncomfortable. All just terrible, terrible signs.
John: I’m not joking, I killed them both.
Me: I believe you. No disagreements here.
John: You can Google it when you get back to your hostel.
He pointed to my hostel, which he’d apparently seen me come from. Another awful sign.
Me: No need. I believe you.
John: Seriously. Give me your book.
He reached out and snatched the book from me, removing the pen I used as a bookmark. He opened it to the last page. That’s when I noticed his nails. They were caked in weeks’ worth of sand and dirt, and there were sores everywhere. He handed me the book back and I looked down at it. It read: “John _____.”
John: Just Google that name and the word “murder,” and it’ll come right up.
Me: Gotcha. Will do. Thanks John.
Just as I slunk back down into the sand, John took another swig of Jack Daniels and yelled, “Hey, check this out!” before tackling Aaron to the ground. It quickly escalated to a fight. People were looking on, but no one seemed to care enough to jump in. People don’t really break up homeless people fights, do they?
Sitting next to Carlos, away from the other two, I tried to gather more intel. Unfortunately, Carlos barely spoke any English. I had some experience from high school and working in kitchens so I did what I could with what I had.
Me: Los conoces?
Carlos: Los conoci hoy.
Apparently, Carlos had just met John and Aaron that day. “What the fuck is going on here?” I asked myself, “I thought they were a roaming band of brothers.” I knew what I had to do at that point; I needed to separate Carlos and I from the murderer(s) before we met a similar fate.
Me: Quiero escaper de ellos conmigo?
I asked him if he wanted to escape with me.
Carlos: Si.
I looked over at John and Aaron. They were still fighting, now even closer to the shoreline, about 100 feet away. I slowly started to gather my stuff, leaving the Cheetos and booze behind as to not raise suspicions.
I looked at Carlos. Surprisingly, we seemed to have an understanding.
Me: Sigueme.
He followed me and we walked as nonchalantly as possible, too scared to glance back. I picked up the pace once we hit the cobblestone road.
Me: Only, 20 more paces. Please, God, don’t let that murderer turn around.
We rounded the corner together then peeked back. John still had Aaron in a headlock. They were all twisted up. We were safe. Carlos looked at me and we both sighed. Then we broke out into laughter, delirious from the fear. Or at least that’s why I was laughing. I wasn’t sure why he was, given he probably didn’t understand John’s admission. I thought about trying to explain it to him in Spanglish but decided against it. Hell, I didn’t even want to know.
The Adderall was wearing off, and I still wanted shellfish, so, in a giant leap of faith, I asked Carlos out to dinner. There I go again.
Me: Tienes hambre? Voy a pagar.
I offered to pay.
Carlos: Por que, no?
He was in.
We walked down a street parallel to the beach, trying to get to know each other. From what I gathered; he was homeless. He was a mechanic by trade, but currently not working. He used to stay with his mother, but that bridge had burned. The only thing he’d eaten that day were the Cheetos.
He spoke pridefully, not seeming to have been broken by the world yet. He had a confident smile and looked me directly in my eyes when he addressed me. That’s always important. He’d lived a lot of life for a 20-year-old but seemed up for the fight.
We passed a couple of oceanfront restaurants before I chose one with a patio that opened to a small dock. It was a lovely place, perhaps too lovely for some underdressed fellas like us. Regardless, we were welcomed in without judgement.
Have you ever seen the scene in The Wire where Bunny Colvin takes the corner kids to Ruth’s Chris, and they don’t know how to behave because of the culture shock? When Carlos accidentally shattered a wine glass, I felt like Bunny, conducting a misguided social experiment. Who was it all for, me or Carlos?
When Carlos came back from cleaning and bandaging his thumb, I ordered us a variety of shellfish, along with a paella to share. I figured we might as well fill our bellies regardless of the awkwardness. And that we did. For the next hour we sat in relative silence, stuffing our faces like garbage-can racoons. The food couldn’t have been better, same as the wine, which I continued to order until there was nothing left on our plates, three bottles in total.
Drunk and extremely full, I paid the waiter and thanked him repeatedly for putting up with us. Then, we exited towards the beach.
That would have been a good time to end the night, I know. But then, I did what I always do.
Me: Donde esta la mota?
Of course, I asked him to find me weed. I knew it was risky, but I was almost out and still had enough Adderall to last for 2 weeks. I needed it. That’s the problem with balancing drugs; if you don’t have enough of one, you can’t fully enjoy the other. I know, it’s madness.
Carlos: Si, Seguro. Necesitamos un taxi.
I got us a taxi and Carlos gave the driver directions.
We drove for much longer than I expected, almost 30-minutes, all of which I spent rationalizing the situation. “Maybe this is where the best weed is? Yeah, that’s probably it… Carlos won’t set you up, you just bought him the meal of a lifetime… At least you have a knowledgeable liaison if things go sideways…”
When we pulled up to our destination, I knew I was in trouble. There were large brick buildings, with bars on the windows, and a centralized courtyard. It was a fucking housing project. Carlos took me to the goddamn projects. Granted, I didn’t tell him the projects were off limits, but for fuck’s sake.
When I exited the car, everyone loitering in front of the building turned to me. They pointed and laughed at my pale legs. I must have looked like an alien to them. My confidence was shot.
Carlos: (hand out) Treinta Euros.
I went in my pocket and gave him the money. He placed it in his underwear and took off into the housing projects.
Me: (sarcastically, to no one) I guess I’ll just chill here with my new friends.
I waited out front of the building, pacing back and forth, smoking cigs, trying to think of an exit plan in case the situation went even more haywire. I popped another 10mg of Adderall too, realizing the night may still be young. A few guys yelled things at me in Spanish, but no one seemed like they wanted to take it to the next level. Still, I was so fucking paranoid.
Then I saw Carlos. He came out of the building with his thumb up and motioned for me to follow. When we got to a more secluded area, he pulled the goods out of his underwear. I was relieved to see a plastic baggie filled with approximately 3.5 grams of green, seedless weed.
Me: WOW! Great job Carlos.
Carlos: De nada, amigo.
He handed me the weed, then pulled a joint from his pocket. I was happy that he didn’t pull it from his pants, but I was confused. “Did he have it the whole time? Was it a freebie from the drug dealer?”.
Before I could contemplate any longer, Carlos lit the joint, took a hit, and passed it to me. I took a hit too and immediately started coughing. I took another hit and did the same. The taste was weird and it made a crackling sound with each puff. “Huh, never seen that happen beeeefffooooor.”
It was at this point I realized that, to my surprise, I was not smoking weed. I was smoking angel dust. The hallucinations started almost instantly. I could barely stand. Carlos, realizing that I was unstable, came to my aid.
Me: Whaaaat wwwaaasss thaaaat?
He leaned in closer, his arm propping me up.
Carlos: I kiss?
His question half-sobered me. Then he leaned in further, his lips pursed.
Carlos: I kiss?
I pushed him away.
Me: No! You do not kiss!!! What the fuck?!
He was pissed. I turned and ran as fast as I could toward the main road where we’d entered the housing project. I looked back and saw Carlos chasing me, screaming at the top of his lungs like a madman.
Carlos: I kiss! I kiss!
I jumped in the first taxi I saw. Carlos was only 40 feet behind us and gaining speed. In my state, it looked like there were 2 of him.
Me: (to driver) VA! VA! VA!
Driver: Tranquillo, senor.
Carlos: (banging on the window) Kiss!! Kiss!!
Me: (to driver) Tranquillo!?! FUCKING DRIVE. VAAAAAAAAA!!
The driver took off and fearfully sped away with Carlos still sprinting behind us. I looked back at him, my heart pounding. He was feral.
Me: Sea Hostel, por favor, y lo siento.
He looked at me quizzically in the rear-view mirror, I think because he assumed I was skipping out on a prostitute without paying. I’m not sure, but it was certainly a look of judgment.
We rode in silence, the cabbie alternating his gaze between me and the road. I kept checking my pulse but lost count of the beats every time my eyes fixated on the bright lights outside my window. I was still hallucinating, but I was at least beginning to calm down.
I had the driver drop me off a few blocks away from my hostel so I could scope out the area before entering. I needed to make sure John wasn’t waiting for me out front to knife me. I wouldn’t have put it passed him. I mean, he slept on the beach only a few hundred feet away and knew I’d be returning at some point.
High out of my mind, I tiptoed quietly up to the front door and slid in. The front desk person saw me and looked concerned.
Guy: Are you ok? Is someone after you?
Me: I think I’m high on PCP. Long story… If a guy named John comes looking for me, tell him I went to Portugal.
Guy: Umm… Ok. How come?
Me: Do me a favor. Please Google “J-O-H-N, _-_-_-_-_-_-_ , M-U-R-D-E-R”
Guy: Why?
Me: I just want to see something.
Guy: It says he killed his parents when he was 16. Do you know him?
Me: May I please check out?
*
April 13, 2006
The next morning, I woke up feeling like I’d recently smoked PCP and almost made out with a homeless person, which I had, so before eating, I walked a mile to a more private beach and plunged myself into the ocean for a literal baptism. Like Lady McBeth though, no matter how hard I scrubbed, the stain of the previous night wouldn’t come out. In 18 hours, I’d managed to turn my PG-rated redemption story into an R-rated horror film. I’d missed the mark, by A LOT. I needed to get my act together and stop trusting everyone. And I definitely needed to stop hanging out with vagrants. I’ve always had a penchant for hanging out with homeless people. I remember going to a Bar Mitzvah in downtown Chicago when I was 13, and instead of dancing inside with everyone, I took a 2-hour walk around the city and mixed it up with homeless people. Spiritually, I relate. I think it’s the pain that attracts me. Or maybe it’s because I too cannot hold down a job.
Breakfast went down, then came right up, like I assumed it would, so I went to the same shop I did the previous day to get some Tums. The same clerk was working.
Me: Have you seen the guy I was with yesterday again today?
Clerk: John?
Me: You know him?
Clerk: He’s in here every day.
Me: Have you seen him today?
Clerk: (Smiling mischievously) Not yet.
Then, I felt a hand touch my shoulder.
John: Sam! Where’d you go yesterday? You and Carlos just ran off.
Me: I wasn’t sure how long you and Aaron would be fighting, so we went out to dinner.
John: You didn’t invite me?
Me: Sorry, man.
John: Did you Google me?
Me: I did. You weren’t lying.
John: Lying is a sin.
Me: I’m going to take off now.
John: Where to next?
Me: Portugal. Then Russia.
John: Well, it was nice meeting you. You mind buying me some more Jack before you go?
Me: Um… sure.
I paid the cashier, like the pushover I am.
John: Carlos is on the beach, you want to say hi?
Me: No. I gotta go. Madrid awaits.
John: Don’t you mean Portugal?
Me: That’s right, Portugal.
John: You’re not lying, are you?
Me: No, I meant Portugal. I’m going to Portugal.
John: Remember, lying is a sin.
Me: Ok, I’m going to Madrid. My train leaves tonight.
I lied again.
John: Don’t worry, I’m not going to follow you.
Me: Uh, good. It was nice meeting you.
I lied again.
John: Same.
I left the store and booked it to the train station without looking back. Madrid, I thought, was where I’d have to find my redemption.
