Title: Barcelona Wine Tasting: The Sweet Wines of Spain
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Nearly every European country with a long wine-making tradition produces at least a few sweet wines, some of which have survived the ages and are still considered to be some of the worlds greatest expressions. To this day some Tokaji wines from Hungary, Sauterne from the south of Bordeaux, Trockenbeerenauslese from Germany and others command premium prices, despite the world drinking less fortified and sweet wines than ever before. Spain joins them in the production aspect, if not the price, with a plethora of sweet wine styles from Sherrys, sweet Muscats, Pedro Ximenez, Monastrell and others, and indeed has been making ‘rancio’ style wines since the beginning of our wine making history.
As with all sweet wines, the historical significance is really related to the practical issues of getting them around the world in one piece; going back even a little over a hundred or so years ago, moving a table wine from one country to to another was a good way to risk turning it into unpalatable vinegar. Sweet wines, on the other hand, with their stronger, headier flavours, higher levels of sugar and often higher levels of alcohol due to fortification were the drink of choice, as they would arrive at their destination more or less intact. This was particularly important in warm countries such as Spain, where a single hot day in the baking Mediterranean sunshine is enough to turn your fresh, fruity red wine into something quite dull and uninteresting.
However, with the advent of modern technologies, sweet and fortified wine sales have fallen through the floor over the last 40 years, with most modern consumers opting for lighter, drier wines that are usually a little easier to pair with food. Wines no longer need to be powerful and sweet to survive before being consumed and as a result, the market for sweet wines is dwindling away. One silver lining of this, of course, is that it’s generally the best producers who are left making the remaining wines, and they’ve been recently joined by some ambitious attempts to recreate different styles, often using very new technologies such as cryo-extraction in places not previously renowned for these styles of wine. It was my pleasure to introduce 5 such wines to our tasting last week and showcase the depth of options available in Spain alone, which whilst may not become the mainstay of an individuals collection, certainly have their place at the dinner table.
Gramona “Vi de Glass” Riesling 2011: We kicked off the evening with probably the least traditional style of fortified wine made in Spain; ice wine made not be the natural elements dropping down well below zero, but using a chamber designed to artificially freeze the grapes prior to pressing. This has been a technology used in France since the late 1980s but was started to be used by Gramona in 1997. The premise is identical to that of the natural production of ice wine in both Germany and Canada; freezing the water in the grapes and squeezing out a thick, viscous juice from the resulting press with a lot of varietal flavour, sugar and acid. However, doing this artificially gives a great deal of control over the process as you can choose at which temperature you’d like to freeze the grapes. The higher the concentration of sugar, the lower the temperature needed to freeze the water in the grapes themselves, and the less juice you receive per ton. Therefore, winemakers can now choose the quantity of the icewine they need and adjust the temperature accordingly; lower temperatures mean that only the ripest juice is allowed to leave the press, but lowers quantity substantially. In France the common practice is to freeze grapes at -6ºC. Gramona by comparison choose to make their wine at -15ºC. I was surprised at how good this was, retaining both the youthful fruit and minerality of the Riesling in a good balance with the sugar levels. The bottle is a little difficult to store, but makes for a wonderful centre piece!
Jorge Ordonez №2 Victoria 2015: We went from perhaps the least typical style of Spanish sweet wine to perhaps its most; sweet Muscat from Malaga. DO Malaga is interestingly the only DO in Spain to focus entirely on the production of sweet wine, having been influential in the courts of Medieval Europe and peaking in popularity in the 19th century with its recently revived “Mountain Wine”. Muscat de Alexandria, the ugly ducking to Muscat a Petit Grains, is rife here with its grapey, floral aromas, naturally high sugar and delicate nature. Jorge Ordonez has a range of 4 in total, all made in a naturally sweet style from over-ripe grapes, increasing in sugar level and flavour intensity. We went for number 2, Victoria 2015 which is a lovely, softly honeyed wine with a very approachable 10% ABV and a lovely light, delicately floral character. Of all the wines poured over the evening, this probably lasted the least amount of time in the glass!
Perelada Garntaxa de 12 Anys: Our first meeting with a fortified wine and we went for a sweet Grenache from the Emporda, a region in the very north of Catalunya bordering France. In fact, this proximity to France goes some way to explain the style of this wine, made as it is in a Solera system. The south of France, Roussilon in particular, is home to a great deal of appellations famous for producing sweet wine and the effects are felt in the north of Catalunya, where many of these old constructions still exist and are making top quality wine to this day. This is actually my favourite style of sweet wine from Catalunya, combining the lovely dried red fruit character of the Grenache with the long, slow 12-year ageing process of the Solera system to provide a complex, sweet and very endearing wine as a result. Perelada are a big company producing a lot of very good, and some decidedly average, wine, but I’d be happy to have a few bottles of this lying around at any given time!
Castaño Dulce 2013 — We headed down to the Levant for wine number 4 and a chance to try perhaps the least obviously sweet wine of the day. I say this because the sweet Monastrell, made from grapes dried in the sun and often fermented in open wooded vats, is more akin to a structured red wine with a lot of sugar than a traditional sweet wine. The Castañofamily have been revolutionary in DO Yecla, from helping win the DO regulatory system to investing heavily into opening international markets for the region and with the quality of the wine they’re producing now, I can safely say that it’s been a successful drive for a still relatively unknown area. Bold, bright and tannic, this would be a delicious pairing for medium-strength cheeses, light chocolate desserts and almost anything with red fruit in it.
Don PX Toro de Albala Gran Reserva 1986 — It wouldn’t be a sweet wine tasting if we didn’t dip our toe into the sweetest of them all; Pedro Ximenez, made in DO Montilla-Moriles with almost 380 grams of sugar a litre. Pedro Ximenez is one of the worlds naturally sweetest grape varieties, accumulating sugar rapidly, encouraged by exceptionally late harvesting when they’re essentially raisins on the vine. These dry grapes are then picked, pressed and fermented to a few degrees of alcohol before being fortified to retain this incredible level of sugar. PX, as it’s more commonly known, is still used to sweeten certain wines, often Sherry destined for ‘Cream’ status of some sort, but more often is aged in a Solera system for an incredibly long time, becoming deeply oxidised, concentrated and dark in the process. There are also single vintage PX wines like the above, aged in oak barrels for a staggering 28 years before commercial release. My personal preference is to drizzle this over vanilla ice-cream with walnuts and almonds, but a small glass is also a hedonistic pleasure from time to time!
This was certainly not a tasting for the faint of heart, but a real treat to try so many sweet wines from across the country. The general feeling before the tasting was one of “I don’t really drink sweet wines, so I’m interested to see how they fare.’ Based on the evidence, I hope we’ve converted a few more lovers of dessert wines, the industry certainly needs a few more! If you’d like to learn more about Spanish wine and attend a tasting in Barcelona, make sure to check out the options here, from private tastings to our weekly published tastings. Until then, salut!
--
--

The non remote events are back, which is great!
I had the opportunity to attend for the first one (for me) after the pandemic and I did a little summary to share my thoughts about it.
I am Borja Pernía, a Venezuelan software developer who has lived in Barcelona since 2012. I have been working at ManoMano since January 2020 and I like to assist to different events related to software development.
For personal reasons, I only could assist the first day during the morning and this is the summary of the talks that I assisted.
They talked about the necessity to use OpenTelemetry
Important concepts in observability
First steps into the Voxel implementation
What is OpenTelemetry?
Demo time!
Questions & Answers
Quick overview of data disciplines
The infrastructure for handle data in Hotjar
About data qualityImportant: accuracy, consistency, completeness, timeliness, validity, uniqueness
Lessons learned
As a summary, the talks that I assisted had interesting topics that could help us to improve our day-to-day work in several levels (to know several ways to have a better functional programming experience, to understand how to monitorize our applications in a correct and simpler way or starting to build a BI infrastructure based on the experience of somebody that already lived it).
I enjoyed coming back to a face-to-face event with a great set of speakers, , and a good mood among the crowd. I hope to attend next year’s edition too :)
If you want to continue the conversation about this or other events, contact or chat with me on LinkedIn.
As usual in this kind of events, the opening was a moment to present the team involved and thanked to the sponsors (ManoMano included! \o/ ). Something that was new for me: the post-covid protocol during the event (use of masks, leave the rooms at the end of the talks, etc.) and the presentation of two organizations (BCN women who code and Codebar).

Title: I Felt Safer in Mexico Than in Barcelona
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story

2
Share
About a month after moving to Barcelona, I learned that one of my co-workers also lived there. I was ecstatic to meet another digital nomad in their 30s. The prospect of meeting someone I enjoyed working with for over a year was even more exciting. I couldn’t wait to see her!
I called a cab, and Uber directed me to Las Ramblas to wait. If you don’t already know this, Las Ramblas is known as “the World’s Most Pickpocketed Street.” I followed my usual precautions and stood with my back against a hotel wall.
As I waited, a gentleman approached. He was young, pulling a large suitcase as he walked toward the hotel’s grand entrance. The person next to him seemed to playfully snatch an item out of his hand. He turned around and grabbed the person by his shirt. They jumped into oncoming traffic to get away.
At first, I thought, “Look at these two fools in the street! They’re about to get hit by a car.”
But then I realized they weren’t friends. It wasn’t two guys roughhousing each other recklessly. One had just been robbed.
It was broad daylight: around 2 PM on a rainy Saturday afternoon. I couldn’t believe it.

Title: Marathon results are boring, so I made my own. aka Barcelona Marathon 2019 results over-engineered
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
I like to participate in boutique-like forest trail ultras where there are only a handful of runners but last month I somehow managed to run the Zurich Barcelona Marathon with 16000+ runners signed up.
I usually don't care about my finishing time as any finished ultra is a success for me regardless of time. But now I ran a marathon distance with many other runners and this made me think about the end result.
I found this presentation of my result clean and simple but incredibly boring.
My finishing time was 3:31:44. I'm relatively happy with that time but I know that I got tired in the end. How did that compare to the people around me? How fast are the pro runners compared to me?
I decided to take all the results I could find and write a small program that would give me a more visual overview of the event.
First thoughts:
I also took a look into the finishing times and it seems that people who aimed under 3h and under 4h were pretty successful (no peak after the time in a graph) but it seems that a lot of runners with aim of 2h45min, 3h30min and 4h15min barely missed their mark.
The slower you are, the more you slow down in the second half of the race. People around the 4h finishing time were avg 10% slower in the 2nd half, that means a whopping 24min added.
And the race starts from the 25th km :) Almost everybody is able to hold the pace till 25th km but every next kilometre is getting harder to keep the pace.
Regardless of your results, it's amazing to see so many people running! We are all winners!

Each new trip announced by Celebrity sounds better than the last. Clearly the trip of a lifetime for many would be to spend some time in Rome, then cruise through the Greek Islands, and end up in Barcelona. That is the opportunity you will have if you book this incredible journey for ten days beginning in Rome on September 5, 2022. What makes it even better is this trip is on Celebrity’s newest ship BEYOND.
Now that alone sounds exciting, but add Celebrity has announced celebrating the BEYOND, and traveling with you, will be no less than Celebrity Cruises’ President and CEO, Lisa Lutoff-Perlo. Just imagine being on the ship with her, with Captain Kate McCue at the helm, and special host and Greece native, Captain Dimitrios Kafetzis, who will lead everyone on amazing tours throughout the sailing. It doesn’t get better than this.
This cruise gives regular Celebrity travelers a chance to reconnect with fellow Captain’s Club members meeting old friends and making new ones. There will be special events like a Santorini sail away with local entertainment, cuisine, and as usual in the Greek Islands one of the most beautiful sunsets in the world.
Now you begin your journey in Rome where you will meet the ship. If you are like me, you will want to spend a few days in Rome before you board. One can’t help love this Eternal City. The incredible Trevi fountain where you will throw a coin in to guarantee you will return again and again.
Then if you haven’t seen it before you must take this opportunity to embrace the power of Michelangelo’s vision at the truly inspiring Sistine Chapel in Vatican City. Then you board your ship on September 5th and take a walk around to start to appreciate its incredible beauty.
The excitement mounts for your visit to eight different ports. First Olympia, where the first Olympic Games were held in 776 B.C. Then among other exciting adventures discover the prehistoric Akrotiri ruins in Santorini, and enjoy the world-famous sunset while sipping some wine from a local vineyard. Hike to the spectacular Lindos Acropolis summit in Rhodes, and marvel at the Temple of Poseidon’s ancient glory in Athens. In Malta, admire the glittering baroque interior of St. John’s cathedral. Of course, no trip through the Greek Islands would be complete without a stop in beautiful Mykonos with its narrow white washed streets, my favorite Island, where I have spent many memorable vacations over the years.
Then while onboard this incredible newest of the Edge® Series ships, you can experience a signature restaurant by the renowned Chef Daniel Boulud (make your reservation early); the reimagined Grand Plaza inspired by the piazzas of Italy; a Rooftop Garden that extends out beyond the ship’s edge; and the new expanded two-tiered Sunset Bar. The Sunset Bar being one of my favorite places on any Celebrity ship.
You will be treated to great entertainment in the BEYOND’s theater which surpasses all other ships with its state-of-the-art technology. Then you end your cruise in the exciting city of Barcelona and what could be better than that?
I have been told by friends who took BEYOND’s maiden cruise that once onboard you will understand what Celebrity has said; this ship was designed to change the way you experience the world. Even the incredible artwork on board is worth the trip.
So look at your calendar. It you have the time, or can make the time, get in touch with Celebrity or better yet my travel agent Scott Moster, an expert on Celebrity and all cruises, at scott@myluxcruise.com; and book this exciting cruise today.

Title: Solving FC Barcelona’s centre-back issue
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hop on the time machine for a moment. We are going back to 2011. FC Barcelona was arguably the best club in the world. Nobody can forget their attacking, quick-passing, total football display versus a stacked Manchester United side managed by Sir Alex Ferguson under the lights of the great Wembley Stadium in the Champions League final. The match ended 3–1 with a goal apiece from Barcelona’s starting front 3 as they were crowned champions of Europe. Experts and pundits predicted a decade of dominance from the Blaugranas with Pep Guardiola at the helm and exciting youngsters from La Masia under his wing.
Fast-forward to 2021, FC Barcelona are in a financial mess, of around 1 billion Euros, unable to register their greatest player ever and their new signings due to the extreme wage budget. Things on the pitch haven’t been great either, with humiliations vs Roma, Liverpool, Bayern and PSG in the last 4 years being the main talking points. They do have, what many fans believe to be, the perfect leader in Joan Laporta. He has to clean this financial mess and needs to make proper signings to bring the club to where it used to be. He has made a few in Aguero, Depay, Emerson and Eric Garcia. Eric Garcia seems to be the replacement for the ageing Pique. There are other options in that position in Oscar Mingueza and the very promising, Ronald Araujo.
But the glaring void is seen in the left centre-back position. Clement Lenglet has never been the same since the Bayern debacle, with his numerous mistakes leading to costly points dropped in the league and Samuel Umtiti is not even a shadow of himself after constant injuries and pretty much zero game time. I personally think that the club needs a new signing at the left CB position and must look for one in this summer itself, if possible. So, in this article, we see some of the available and affordable options in that position and hopefully, finalize one player to help Barcelona fill the void.
All the data used in this article is from the brilliant fbref.com and the videos used for eye-test is from fullmatchsports.com.
REQUIREMENTS FOR A FC BARCELONA CENTRE-BACK
1. The current manager, Ronald Koeman started out with a 4–2–3–1 upon his arrival and moved to a 3–5–2/3–1–4–2 as he gathered that his CBs were being exposed in a 4-at-the-back system with their lack of pace. His decision to switch to a back three has produced good results and Barcelona has gained a bit of stability since. So, our centre-back should be able to slot in the left of a three-at-the-back system and as the left CB in a 4-ATB, if Koeman plans to revert back to one.
2. The centre-back should have excellent ball distribution. He should be able to play the ball out from the back with minimal errors. He must be able to distribute passes from the back to the LB(Mostly Jordi Alba) and line-breaking passes to the midfielders. He should also be able to carry the ball forward with confidence and find one of the teammates when there is space ahead.
3. He should be very good under pressure and be able to get himself out of it using quick thinking and good decision-making.
4. Jordi Alba is often closer to the attackers than the defenders. So, our new CB must take the responsibility of providing cover in the left flank. Even if he lacks pace, he must be very aware positionally and thus help the team to regain possession quickly by winning the ball when the opponent decides to break and counter.
5. He must be good aerially and make sensible decisions when opponents take the long-ball approach.
6. In a 3 ATB, he will play with Eric Garcia and Ronald Araujo mostly. Garcia is a very ‘Pique’ type defender, not too quick but relies heavily on his positional awareness and a decent on-the-ball defender. Araujo is strong, aerially dominant, faster than the average centre-back but doesn’t possess the best ball playing qualities. Our CB must compliment both the CBs by providing cover for Garcia’s lack of pace and Araujo’s lack of technicality.
7. Brownie points if he has already played in a team which plays possession-based attacking football.
THE FIRST DRAFT
Our first draft of players includes left-footed CBs in top clubs from Europe’s top 5 leagues. The selected CBs play in clubs only from which Barcelona can buy, so players from direct domestic rivals and Euroepan rivals are excluded. The 5 CBs from our first draft in no particular order are :
We will now use the fbref data available to get an idea of what each player offers to their respective teams and what they can offer for FC Barcelona. All the data is from the 2020/21 league season and is adjusted to per 90 minutes. The five-man draft will be deduced to a final shortlist of three for eye-test.
DATA ANALYSIS
Defensive Contribution : In this plot, we measure the defensive capabilities of the CBs using their Tackles+Interceptions numbers and Successful pressures that helped their team win the ball back. From the possession-adjusted data, we can clearly see how Bastoni leads his peers in both metrics. Botman is not far either. Pau Torres fails to impress here.
Discipline : Unsuccessful tackles or pressures might lead to fouls and bookings and this plot gives an idea of how clean/dirty the CBs are. Botman is the cleanest of them all, even though he had higher tackling and pressure numbers. Laporte obviously has higher numbers considering him playing in a team that dominates possession almost every game.
Passing : A very important attribute for a FC Barcelona centreback. Laporte excels in both progressive and final third passes while Botman, Pau and Bastoni have good numbers too. Romagnoli doesn’t make a case for him here.
Carries : While Bastoni leads in final third carries, Laporte once again exhibits his brilliant on-ball ability by completing around 10 progressive carries p90. Romagnoli does not possess the same on-ball characteristics as the others.
Aerial Prowess : Something that is a must for a Barca CB is good aerial ability. Teams tend to exploit the high defensive line of Barcelona and the CBs have to be aware of balls over the top to the forward or in the wings. Laporte once again leads the pack with Romagnoli second and Botman a close third.
From the above metrics, there are three standouts.
Alessandro BastoniAymeric LaporteSven Botman
With eye-test by watching previous matches, the strengths and weaknesses in each of the three players’ game are noted. There are few other factors in each player which are also taken into consideration. They will be explained below. Now, let us take a look at each player.
ALESSANDRO BASTONI
Pros : Bastoni is widely regarded as the future of Italian defence. At such a young age of 22, Bastoni has already established him as an undisputed starter at Inter. He has already played in a 3 ATB under his club manager Antonio Conte. Bastoni is skilled in switching the play to the right wingback with quick and accurate switch passes. He also often finds Lukaku by threading a ball over the top in/around the left half space behind the defensive line. This can be mirrored here, by using Fati/Depay as the receiver. This could benefit Barcelona when they are trying to find a way through low-block teams. He is also a very confident ball carrier and has the ability to find a progressive/key pass following that carry. He is quick enough to recover when he loses possession.
Cons : Bastoni doesn’t have any obvious weaknesses in his personal game. There are some other factors, though. His defensive partners at Inter have been two experienced CBs in Milan Skriniar and Stefan De Vrij. While Barca needs some experience to settle their defence for their pursuit of the league and the Champions League, signing Bastoni means he becomes one of the many young defenders Barca have. It is also a huge gamble to bring him from Serie A to La Liga for such a huge price (60M Euros according to transfermarkt.com, might even be more), which makes him the most expensive defender in La Liga history. A question remains on would he justify the price tag. Barca cannot afford another failed transfer, if Bastoni does fail.
Verdict : Bastoni is an excellent defender and a fantastic investment for the future. He possesses all qualities to become a Barcelona defender but in the current financial situation, he is an expensive, ambitious and risky option who Barca might have to stay away from, for now.
AYMERIC LAPORTE
Pros : Laporte has lost his place to Ruben Dias in the city defence. He is such a quality defender to not be playing regularly. Laporte had a brilliant Euro 2020 partnered with either Garcia or Pau Torres. He has the knack of finding line-breaking passes and is a supreme carrier of the ball, one of the best in the business. He has brilliant positional awareness and commits minimal errors while playing out from the back. He has played in a 3 ATB in City in a few instances. He also plays under Pep Guardiola and Luis Enrique who share the similar philosophy as Barca. He is cheaper(45M Euros according to transfermarkt.com) and has better experience in big stages. There are various news outlets suggesting that he wants out because of his lack of game time.
Cons : Laporte’s only weakness might be his lack of pace. Also, Manchester City might not sell another CB as that would leave them with only three natural centre-backs(Dias, Stones, Ake). They might demand huge money. Barca may have to sell two or more players to meet City’s asking price.
Verdict : Laporte is a low-risk high quality CB, who fits in Barca’s defence like a glove but there are a few complications financially, which should be solved for this transfer to go through.
SVEN BOTMAN
Pros : Fresh from winning Ligue 1 with Lille, Botman is one of the most sort out CBs at the moment. He is 195 cm tall, strong and physically imposing which is very similar to Ronald Araujo. But, he differs from Araujo in the fact that he has brilliant on-the-ball quality. He often finds the LW/LB with a through ball behind the lines that puts them in space to run into. He is also brilliant in 1v1 situations and makes calculated tackles. Due to his height and huge physique, he can be a much needed set-piece threat. He is the least expensive of the three options(28M Euros according to transfermarkt.com).
Cons : Just 21 years old, Barcelona cannot expect any kind of experience from the dutchman. He is not a natural ball carrier like Laporte and is not upto the mark in his aerial distribution. He also struggles a bit when put under pressure and makes some hasty decisions. He has often played in a 4 ATB system, but has never been tested in a 3 ATB system.
Verdict : Though less expensive, Botman has had only one season in the Ligue 1 and it would be a huge gamble if Barcelona decide to keep faith on him, which I think is not the best thing to do.
CONCLUSION
Laporte definitely edges both of them with his experience. Even though his price is a problem, his recent success in the Euros and him sharing the same dressing room with Alba, Busquets, Pedri and Garcia means he would be the most fitting of all the options. 45M is a monstrous price in these circumstances but he has already proven his quality in the PL after arriving at Manchester City with a similar price tag. FC Barcelona receives a centre-back who fits their playstyle and more importantly, brings much needed experience and quality. Come on Mr. Laporta, import Laporte to the Nou Camp !
Thank you for spending your time in reading this article. I hope you enjoyed it.
If you have any suggestions or ideas, you can contact me via twitter.
Twitter : https://twitter.com/ajayg_04
Also, I did a piece on Laporte’s brilliant Euro campaign. Here’s a link to it — https://twitter.com/AjayG_04/status/1413463339271815173?s=20

Title: Finding Creativity Again in Barcelona and Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Have you ever found yourself running on empty, going through the motions without really feeling connected to what you’re doing?
That’s where I was before this trip. There’s a point when you realize you’re just… tired. Not just physically, but emotionally and creatively. I needed this trip not just to escape but to find myself again.
We live in a world that worships hustle, where productivity is often measured by how much we do, how busy we are, and how little we rest. I’ve always been someone who pushes through, who keeps going even when I know I’m running on nothing but coffee and maybe sugar lol. But as I wandered through the streets of Barcelona, from the towering Sagrada Familia to the narrow streets of the Gothic Quarter, I realized something.
These iconic places are filled with life and energy, but instead of feeling energized, I realized I was missing the point. I was so focused on seeing everything and doing everything that I wasn’t truly experiencing any of it. Even on the subway, surrounded by people, I felt disconnected, like I was just going through the motions. It hit me that maybe, just maybe, it was okay to slow down and not do it all.
Rest isn’t just about lying down or sitting still. It’s about giving yourself permission to move at your own pace, to let go of the need to be constantly productive. As I walked through the narrow streets of Alfama, I felt something shift. The colorful buildings, the quiet moments — they invited me to slow down and just be.
Sitting at Castelo de Sao Jorge, looking out over the city, I didn’t feel the usual urge to capture the perfect photo or check off the next item on the list. Instead, I let myself just enjoy the view, the company, the moment. When we wandered into a little perfume store, it wasn’t about buying something; it was about the simple pleasure of experiencing something new, something beautiful, without any pressure. These small moments reminded me that it’s okay to simply exist, to find joy in the present.
Something I hadn’t expected was how much inspiration I would find just by slowing down and paying attention. In the midst of the busy streets, the street art, the intricate tiles, the history embedded in the architecture — even these chairs all over Barcelona — it all started to speak to me in a way I hadn’t felt in a long time.
Everywhere I looked, there was something that sparked my imagination — a piece of street art that made me pause, a beautifully tiled floor that told a story, even the way the buildings stood, each with its own history and character. It reminded me that creativity isn’t always about creating; sometimes, it’s about observing, about letting the world around you fill you with new ideas and perspectives. I realized that inspiration is everywhere if you just take the time to see it.
But beyond the beauty of the cities and the inspiration I found in the streets, what really stayed with me were the moments of connection. Sharing a meal, laughing with friends, those little moments of joy — they’re what made this trip truly meaningful. Like when we finally got our hands on those infamous Pastel da Nata from Pasteis de Belem — AMAZING.
Whether it was enjoying crepes, chatting at the plaza while eating gelato at midnight, or just sitting down for brunch at 4 p.m. because we felt like it — these moments weren’t about doing something impressive. They were about being present with the people I care about, about savoring life in its simplest, most joyful forms. And honestly, that’s where I found the most rest — in those small, meaningful moments that reminded me of what’s really important.
As I walked down the well in Quinta da Regaleira, it felt like a metaphor for what this trip had been — descending into the unknown, into a place of quiet and reflection. And just like that well, this journey brought me back up, feeling renewed, inspired, and ready to move forward. I realized that rest is its own form of productivity. It’s in those moments of stillness and quiet that we find the clarity we need to truly grow.”
I came on this trip looking for a break, a way to recharge. What I found was that rest isn’t just about doing nothing — it’s about finding the space to reconnect with yourself and to rediscover what brings you joy and peace.
So, if there’s one thing I’ve learned from this trip, it’s that it’s okay to take a step back. To slow down, to rest, and to reconnect with what really matters. When you give yourself permission to rest, you’re not just recharging — you’re laying the foundation for everything that comes next.

Title: Barcelona: Best UX City?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in Barcelona for an event last week. Also, it’s the first time in Barcelona for me. I know that the city is one of the best as the “city design” in the world. But I saw it with a different eye. Can it be also the best city as we think in user experience?
First of all, I loved the city. In Europe, there is just Portugal I haven’t visited yet and the only city/country that I want to live in is Rotterdam. It is a “lively” city that has lots of foreigners and everyone knows English (so I don’t need to learn Dutch that I already learned!). Also, there are lots of “expats” so you feel comfortable as a foreign. And, of course, Berlin is the city that I want to go to again and again :). After all, Barcelona is the second city I want to go to again and maybe to live there!
I loved the city not because everyone knew English and I felt comfortable about everything (to be honest, just a few people know English, we had such hard times to communicate). I loved the city because both the city and the people make you feel comfortable about living in the environment.
As I said, I saw just a few people who know English very well, and again just a few who know English “a little” to communicate. But after all, even if they didn’t understand what I was asking, they got the “situation” and tried to help me. In Turkey, we sometimes have fun with these “a little English” people who try to explain the route you’ve asked with “Go go go, left, go go, right, go, there”. And I also saw them in Barcelona! After all, I handle everything with them. So, even if you don't know English, you can communicate with them, just show what you want.
Like they don’t speak that much English, they also don’t use English signs. That is also because they use Catalan as their first language and Spanish is the second, so mostly there is no space for an English word. But you can use the city without a foreign language because of their signs! In the metro, you mostly can’t see an English word but with their sign language, you can go wherever you want. For example in Turkey, at the stations we both use Turkish and English announcements and signs. But if you also don’t know English, you will have a hard time. But in Barcelona, they use the line numbers, the line flow, and some good signs to show where to go and where to wait.
I also see those signs at the airport. For example, if you need to do something about tax-free, you need to go to Terminal 1. But our flight was from Terminal 2 and we just looked at that sign and realized we needed to go that way to find our “shuttle”. Also, they put the same sign at the door that we need to go through.
I need to mention another thing if we are talking about the city's accessibility. I saw so many people with wheelchairs and with a walking stick because they couldn’t see. Those people were all alone, there was no one to help them with the lights, sidewalk, or getting in a store. They can do all of these by themselves.
I try to create websites that everyone can “access”, everyone can use it smoothly and feel comfortable as they do these. From now on, I want to make websites like Barcelona! And hope to see it again :).

I have been to Barcelona several times, but since the last time it had been 10 years now.
A period in which the city experienced great transformations, socially and aesthetically speaking, related to urban regeneration. Fruit of the work of one mayor in particular, Ada Colau, a “grassroots” activist who brought a breath of new air to the city, and of many other figures who believed in positive change for local communities.
For work reasons, I was in Barcelona for a couple of days, and I took the opportunity for a “regeneration tour” in 24 hours, to understand what has changed in the city and what has unfortunately or fortunately remained the same over time.
I walk out of the hotel in Poblenou where I was staying and already I feel happy. In front of me trees and bushes hide the concrete. No horns or engine noise nearby, just the sound of Barcelona’s typical green parrots. The impact that noise pollution has on us becomes much clearer in these moments, yet we struggle to notice it in our daily lives. I keep walking, imagining what the city would be like if it were full of spaces like this, and what all cities would be like if the gray palette of urbanism…

Title: Barcelona 2018
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
— -A fruitful ramble — —
Without a plan or map, we landed on the sun-kissed landstrip of Barcelona airport.
The short flight from London seemed like more of a teleport than a form of transport, zapping us from the soupy grey hue of London into a blossoming explosion of vibrant Catalonian colour. The warm embrace of the sun was enough to send spirits soaring as we rushed through Spanish security and emerged into the heat.
Following our landing, we took an airport shuttle (the A1) from Barcelona airport to plazza Espanya, where we proceded to a quick check in at the Ofelias hotel, located just off the impressive Plazza Espanya. A city square packed with the hustle and bustle of everyday Catalonian life, capped with a monumental fountain by Josep Maria Jujol, one of Gaudí’s main associates.
To escape the crowds and the rising heat, we took a short metro ride on the L1 line to the more quieter Gracia borough, a serene district with shaded backstreets, sloping lawns and bohemian cafe culture.
Gracia was as peaceful as expected. A tranquil setback from the initial and intense buzz of the sweaty Plazza Espanya, a welcome oasis.
After a short walk through shaded alleys, we took a seat at one of Gracias shaded restaurants, located on a Gaudi street corner. Gracia’s solace was complimented with a crisp lager Estrella (the first of many) and a crisp white wine.
Time for tapas. Accompanying the drinks were lobster croquets, cured meats, tomato breads and garden olives; all enjoyed under the shady confines of a terraced side street.
After lunch, we pushed on, stumbling down quieter alleyways, cafes, bars but local shops were beginning to close their blinds to the afternoon sun; with a siesta break approaching.
Pastel painted walls dotted the backstreets backstreets, apartments squeezed down leaning alleys, their astute balconies almost brushing the wall opposite, rising high into the Barcelona rooftops.
Small potted plants and foliage spill through each wrought iron balcony, giving the apartments of Barcelona a living and breathing dimension. The gentle tinker of a Spanish guitar escapes through a bedroom window, a picture book setting.
Following more walking, a pot of earl grey tea was enjoyed (alongside some locally baked pastries) in a charming cafe in the fork of Gothic road.
The Gothic region, and the plaza Rela in particular, is a real diamond in the crown of the sprawling alleyways of Barca.
Elaborately crafted window sills, lined with palm trees and gold leafed figureheads brought a touch of regalness to a public square.
As evening drew and the Sun sank ever lower and closer to the sea, we took a short taxi ride towards a mountainside boulevard. Restaurant Martinez awaited…
A meal of sol-fish, grilled aubergine and a refreshing Spanish white was finished with a Catalonia creme brûlée and a quick macchiato on the moonlight terrace.
The iconic glow of the Martinez neon sign trickled onto the seated patio, as the first day in Barcelona drew to a close.
— — A tale of much Tapas — —
The second day of our Barcelona adventure brought a slower pace after the manic rush following landing.
We rose slowly at the boutique and bohemian styled Ofelias Hotel. After enjoying the waterfall shower, we took the glass exposed elevator to the fifth floor, where a slimly discreet terrace pool sat tranquilly under the morning sun.
Hotel Ofelias is located just off plaza Espanya, it’s black awnings cut an abrasive shade over the sidewalk and two large potted plants keep guard on each side of the door.
A gold wrought iron handle signals to pull and inside the lobby, cushioned armchairs, marble floors and floral wallpapers provide a unique but luxurious decor.
The rooms are simple but well designed, a contemporary luxury with a distinctly bohemian feel. A large terrace provides a courtyard to lounge and relax in, the sun certainly had us smiling.
My fiancee Hope particularly enjoyed the sun trap terrace, with its cushioned lounger and small dining table; an ideal spot for an evening glass of wine.
The rooftop terrace pool was bitterly cold but crystal blue and exhilaratingly refreshing. The sun soaked wooden cladding offered a warm recovery from the waters frosty bite. Nevertheless, a cold swim is a great way to start any day in Barcelona.
After the short swim, it was time for lunch. A short walk from Espanya, is a very good independent coffeehouse — Morrow.
Morrow is a typical new wave coffee joint — artisan pastries, organic coffee and minimalist design; a true sign that Barcelona is certainly no museum city but a living and thriving location for the young and prosperous.
Morrow’s sleek interior design, array of artisan sandwiches, fresh coffee and skilled Catalonian baristas make it an obvious choice for a quick break.
A short conversation with the Morrow owners revealed that the coffeehouse is New Zealand inspired, like many of our favourite coffee haunts back in London.
Following a quick lunch of Fauta (thinly sliced sandwich with cured meat), coffee and pastries, in Morrow; we ventured back northwards into Barcelona to see the world famous Sagrada Familia.
Despite its obvious beauty, the Familia cathedral appeared to be under some heavy restoration work; so we didn’t experience it at its finest.
But the Gaudi architecture is really quite something, it’s curves, shapes and edges so clearly inspired by a living, breathing God muse that it’s no wonder that Gaudi is often dubbed as God’s architect.
We enjoyed wonderful ice cream in front of the Sagrada at an independent store called Farggi.
A short walk from Sagrada, through the quieter Gracia district, led to the Gothic Quarter, where we enjoyed a moment drinking short lagers from a chilled press. Lunch was enjoyed on the backstreet lawns of a college campus.
We then took the L3 metro, as the sun was setting, to the wonderfully authentic Bar Canete. A world renowned tapas location…
Here, the waiters fly around yelling impassioned Spanish; golden goblets of freshly drafted Estrella fly around on silver platters, plumes of steam fill the kitchen as clams are steamed; and micro dishes of endless wonderful delicacies are enjoyed by a marvelling crowd.
A truly special spot for dinner and a real must visit on the Barcelona check list…
— — A face sized beer — —
The final day and the sun was still shining. Barcelona in April brings a glorious warmth, not hot and sticky but a gentle and constant shine that fills you with boundless energy and endless optimism.
It’s a delight to simply sit on the warm concrete of the hotel steps, breathing in the Spanish air and reflecting on the past two days.
Another coffee at Morrow. Irresistible. Their sleekly designed paper cups with the black label make for a good snap…
With our departure time looming, we paid a quick visit to the Barcelona beach front.
A busier and more touristy part of town but nonetheless picturesque. The beach front is dotted with hundreds of small bistros, bars and grills; offering food and drinks on the harbour front.
We finished off the day with drinks at Tapa Tapa, where the beers are ridiculously big.
The final metro journey of the weekend took us back to the Plazza Espanya, where we jumped on the A1 bus to the Barcelona Airport.
Gracias, Barcelona!

Title: Why do Barcelona struggle against 5-at-the-back?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
As I explored in my assessment of Barcelona’s recent victory over Sevilla, there are signs that Xavi Hernández is doing more than just getting good results. He’s moulding a very accomplished footballing system.
But recently, not everything has been rosy in the era of #XaviBall. After a laborious draw against Eintracht Frankfurt in the Europa League, and a narrow victory against Levante that Barca had no right to win, it’s clear that the side is still in its juvenile phase at best.
In particular, it’s suffered against a specific shape and play style. After some analysis, it appears no coincidence that Barca struggles when the opposition plays five defenders.
So having watched some games back, with a keen eye on the tactical nuances, I’ve listed a few key reasons why 5 is an unlucky number for Xavi’s Barcelona.
1.The numerical advantage is lost in buildup
Building up from the goalkeeper, Barcelona have consistently used a 2–3–5 setup. Both full backs go wide, the attacking midfielders are high up the pitch, and the wingers stay wide on either flank. The goal is to make the pitch big, stretch the opposition, and ultimately create space in the wide areas.
Because of the positions of the attacking midfielders, the opposing back four must stay compact. By moving the ball from side to side, Barca can easily find a full back or winger with plenty of space.
And with the centre forward occupying two centre backs, Barca have a free man when the opponents press aggressively.
A back five changes everything
However, when the opposition plays a back five, or three, the man advantage is lost. All of the front players are man-marked, plus the attacking midfielders. Here against Levante, you can see every player, bar the keeper, is accounted for.
Eintracht Frankfurt used a similar idea. But instead of man marking everywhere, they conceded the numerical advantage in the first third of the pitch in order to create their own advantage in the zone Barca loves to attack most: out wide.
The consistent problem here is that the back line cannot be stretched.
With five players defending, both wingers can be marked tightly regardless of where the ball is. No matter how much Barca move the ball looking for space, it will very rarely appear on the flanks.
So how should Barca play out from these scenarios? The answer leads us on to the next problem.
2. Barca’s forwards struggle to hold up the ball
When passing lanes are blocked and the wide players are marked, the emphasis must shift to the centre of the pitch. The most direct solution is to use a ‘third man run’.
This means finding the attacking midfielders indirectly, by going through the centre forward.
The image above is the ideal scenario. Aubameyang makes a run deep and has Pedri in support, who has also peeled off his marker — one of the centre backs. This is the benefit of having the attacking midfielders high and wide.
The theory is easy, the execution not so much. And Aubameyang has been having a torrid time recently trying to hold the ball up.
Unfortunately, neither Dembélé or Ferran Torres are particularly adept at doing this either (á la Mohamed Salah or Sadio Mane). This makes a man-for-man approach very appealing for the opposition.
To summarise so far: a back five nullifies Plan A (to create space out wide), and forces Plan B (go direct into the forwards), which simply hasn’t been fruitful. And perhaps not suited to the current personnel.
So what’s Plan C? Well, here’s the third problem:
3. The system is too rigid
Or, in other words, there is no Plan C. And that’s understandable.
Xavi has modernised the way Barcelona play. It’s not an understatement, after the mediocrity of several managers (that won’t be named), to say that players have had to ‘re-learn’ the game. At least with regards to understanding positioning and movement.
With that in mind, and with the players taking on a new system, it shouldn’t be a surprise that they haven’t yet mastered the next stage: improvisation.
Because improvisation is key when Plan A and B don’t work. That, and a lot of quality.
I’m talking particularly about fluidity of role and movement. Manchester City are the kings of this. Despite having a very defined idea of how to attack, the players interchange positions and responsibilities effortlessly.
We got a glimpse of this in the second half against Levante, as Gavi and Pedri came on and introduced an element of unpredictability. Especially the former, who did something no other midfielder had even attempted: dribble past his marker.
This characteristic, fluidity, should quite naturally mature and evolve with time. It’s reasonable that this is a work in progress.
However, my final point is perhaps more concerning. Especially in the face of some big games before the end of the season:
4. Nobody is marking the wingbacks
If there’s one flaw that everyone has realised, it’s that Barca’s biggest weakness is their defensive transition.
Two of the reasons for this have been touched on already:
The first: the loss of possession through the centre forward. With wingers high and wide, and attacking midfielders supporting, Barca can be very short on numbers in transition. Busquets and Pique become especially exposed due to their lack of pace.
The second: Jordi Alba drifts wide. Usually, Barcelona try to prevent counter-attacks with a 2–3 shape that remains behind the ball. But when Jordi Alba, the leftmost of the ‘3’ breaks beyond the ball, this shape is broken and opposing forwards exploit the space.
The third reason is specific to the five-man backline. You can see it materialising in the image above, in the bottom right corner of the image. It’s the opposition wingback.
Against Frankfurt especially, it was clear Barca’s wingers were not instructed to track back. With the entire backline occupied by forwards, these marauding wingbacks created overloads time and again.
It was the same story against Levante, who should have made much more of their numerous overloads.
And so while Barcelona and Xavi have spent much of these first few months tweaking the offensive setup, more caution will need to be paid to this type of counter attack. Fortunately, the tactical solution seems easy enough: players work harder to get back.
Whether anything more can be done about it (aside from making tactical fouls) remains to be seen.
Despite everything I’ve highlighted, things still look overwhelmingly positive for Barcelona. The speed in which Xavi has implemented his system, and the players have understood it, is credit to his coaching ability.
However, this project is still a work-in-progress. Come the summer, personnel will change, the squad will look different, and things will evolve again. Whether Xavi can fix these problems problems immediately will be a big test of his managerial prowess. But based on his record so far, I wouldn’t bet against him.
If you enjoy these tactical analyses, please give a ‘clap’ and follow the page!
You can also follow me on Twitter for more tactical threads and football related discussion.

Joy and the beautiful game.

Greetings, football enthusiasts! Today, I’m taking you on a timeless journey through one of FC Barcelona’s unforgettable nights. Join me to discover the magic that unfolded in the clash against Chelsea (2009), a night engraved in the annals of football history.
“Each second felt like an eternity”
The story begins in a hub of pure excitement. Chelsea already led 1-0, and Barça faced a mountain to climb. At that time, as a 12-year-old schoolboy, I returned from school with indescribable excitement. I couldn’t wait to see how my heroes would tackle this colossal challenge.
I remember sticking to the TV, still wearing my school uniform, eagerly anticipating the spectacle. It was more than just a match for me; it was an immersive experience, a magical interlude in my adolescence.
As the match progressed, stress mounted. Every whistle, every pause in play, everything seemed to decide Barça’s fate. My heart raced; each second felt like an eternity.
Then came the 93rd minute, a moment etched in my mind. Andrés Iniesta, the football genius, triggered an explosion of emotions. I remember leaping with joy, unable to contain the excitement. It was a moment of deliverance, where football transcended the sport to become a pure emotional experience.
Let’s be honest—beyond the scoreboard, there were refereeing decisions that could have altered the narrative. As a fan, I couldn’t help but acknowledge the whims of fate. Football, with its imperfections, added to the drama of that unforgettable night.
Ultimately, beyond the scoreboard, it was a fan’s journey—a roller coaster of emotions, from doubt to belief, from anxiety to jubilation. Join me next time to relive other unforgettable football moments.
Don’t forget to subscribe, and share your own stories in the comments. Until next time, keep the football spirit alive!

Barcelona was never on my radar as a place to visit, let alone move to. In 2024, nearly 12 million tourists visited this city, which is now my home. After four and a half years as a resident, I’ve seen its good and its bad, but moving here has still been my best big life decision, and I’ve made more than my fair share of bad ones.
Before you question, “I wonder what it’s like to be an American expat living in Barcelona,” let me make something perfectly clear. I identify as an immigrant. Expats, in my opinion, have large sums of disposable income, something I do not have.
My decision to move here had nothing to do with its beautiful architecture, fabulous food, and comfortable climate. I moved here because, while visiting Tuva, a small Siberian republic in the Russian Federation that shares a border with Mongolia, for a third time, I met a woman there who happened to live in Barcelona. What started as a friendship turned into a romance, and after several visits to see her, I took the dive into the deep end of the pool and eventually moved here permanently.
Anything worth doing usually has a few bumps in the road, and my decision to move to Barcelona was hit with a huge one. Three days before my flight from New York to Barcelona, the pandemic shut the world’s borders…

Title: How I Learned to Blend in With Locals in Barcelona: Tips from a Grateful Foreigner
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I first arrived in Barcelona, I was wide-eyed and clumsy — like a tourist trying too hard not to look like one. I’d been dreaming of Gaudí facades, sangria by the beach, and a Mediterranean lifestyle full of late dinners and even later conversations. What I didn’t anticipate was how long it would take to actually feel like I belonged.
Here’s what I learned — sometimes the hard way — about blending in with locals in this magnetic, complex city.
1. Start with “Bon dia,” not “Hola”
I knew Spanish (Castellano), but I quickly discovered that Catalan is everywhere — on street signs, in supermarkets, and yes, in everyday greetings. Saying bon dia (good morning) instead of hola showed respect for the local culture. No one expected me to be fluent in Catalan, but trying a few words — si us plau (please), gràcies (thank you) — opened a lot of doors, literally and figuratively.
Tip: Download a basic Catalan phrasebook or app. Just trying a few phrases goes a long way.
2. Eat when they eat, not when you’re hungry
I once sat down for dinner at 7:00 PM and got a confused look from the waiter. In Barcelona, lunch is at 2 PM, and dinner doesn’t start until at least 9 PM. Adapting to this schedule was challenging at first (especially with my American stomach), but it helped me sync with the rhythm of the city.
Tip: Join the menú del día (menu of the day) crowd at lunchtime. It’s affordable, filling, and a great way to observe locals in their natural habitat.
3. Dress the part, subtly
Barcelona style is chic but effortless. Locals somehow make sneakers look elegant and never seem overdressed or underdressed. I learned the hard way when I showed up to a casual dinner in flip-flops and got side-eyes from every direction.
Tip: Leave the touristy sandals and loud prints at home. A well-fitted tee, stylish sneakers, and a light jacket can help you blend in instantly.
4. Embrace vermouth culture
I didn’t expect vermouth to become part of my weekend ritual, but “fer el vermut” (having a vermouth) before lunch on weekends is a sacred tradition. It’s not about getting tipsy — it’s about slowing down, snacking on olives, and chatting with friends for hours.
Tip: Go to a neighborhood bodega on a Sunday around noon. Order a vermut negre and some anchovies. Just sit, sip, and soak it in.
5. Avoid La Rambla — except at 5 a.m.
Everyone goes to La Rambla once. But locals? They avoid it like the plague — unless they’re walking home after a night out. If you want to see the real Barcelona, head to neighborhoods like Gràcia, Sant Antoni, or Poblenou.
Tip: Wander into the smaller plazas at night. You’ll find kids playing soccer, couples drinking wine on benches, and old men arguing about Barça. That’s the magic.
6. Be a regular
One of the best decisions I made was committing to a local café. I went every day, even if it was just for a cortado. Eventually, the barista started greeting me by name, and I was invited to a neighborhood calçotada (a Catalan barbecue). That’s when I knew I was more than just a visitor.
Tip: Pick a small bar, café, or shop near where you live. Consistency breeds community.
7. Understand the pride — and pain — of Catalan identity
Conversations about identity, politics, and language run deep here. I learned early on not to assume Spain = Catalonia. People here have a distinct sense of self, and respecting that nuance showed I wasn’t just another tourist trying to “do Spain in a week.”
Tip: Listen more than you talk. Ask questions, and stay curious. You’ll gain trust.
Final Thoughts
Blending in doesn’t mean pretending to be local — it means respecting the flow, showing genuine interest, and participating instead of spectating. Barcelona rewards patience and presence. It taught me to slow down, look around, and become part of the scenery.
I came to Barcelona with a suitcase and a guidebook. I stayed because of the people who welcomed me when I finally stopped trying so hard — and just started being.

As an avid traveller, I’m always searching for the heart of a city, that unique pulse that goes beyond the typical tourist trail. In Barcelona, I found it not just in the architectural wonders, but within the hallowed walls of Camp Nou.
While I didn’t get to witness the electrifying energy of a live match, the tour of FC Barcelona’s legendary stadium was an experience in itself. From the moment I approached the colossal structure, I felt the weight of football history. Camp Nou isn’t just a stadium its mesmerising almost feeling hypnotised.
Walking through the stadium, I could almost hear the echoes of roaring crowds and the legendary players who graced that pitch. The sheer scale of the place is breath taking. Standing on the side lines, imagining the thrill of a packed stadium, gave me goose bumps. Visiting the changing rooms, walking through the tunnel the players use, and seeing the press box all provided a unique perspective.
The museum offered a fascinating glimpse into the club’s rich history, showcasing trophies, iconic jerseys, and the stories behind Barcelona’s greatest moments. It’s a testament to the club’s legacy and its deep connection to the city.
Even without a match, Camp Nou vibrated with an almost palpable energy. It’s a place where passion and history collide. To top it all off, the tour concluded with a truly immersive 360-degree cinematic experience ( link at the top of this article make sure to watch it), putting me right in the heart of the action with all the legendary players. It was an incredible way to feel the pulse of the team. This entire experience gave me a deeper understanding of Barcelona, a city where football is more than just a sport; it’s an integral part of the culture.
So, if you’re visiting Barcelona, make sure to add Camp Nou to your itinerary. Whether you’re a die-hard football fan or simply curious, a tour of this iconic stadium is an unforgettable experience. It’s a chance to connect with the soul of the city and understand why football is so much more than just a game.
A trip you need to definitely add to your bucket list!

Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Listen
Share
Earlier in 2023, I thought of fulfilling my wanderlust and taking off on a solo trip in Europe — something my younger self wouldn’t have even dreamed of.
In my attempt to live in the present (coupled with my habit of tardily posting photos), I felt it was important to journal my experiences to capture my raw thoughts and feelings while I travel.
I’m glad I wrote them as it took me months to finally get around to sharing my travel stories, but here we go.
Barcelona, Spain || June 2023
I am on my way to the airport as I started writing this.
A few days ago, I flew to Spain to begin the first leg of my solo trip around Europe. There’s no deeper reason why I’m taking this trip except I know that, whatever the outcome is, I need to do it and it will reveal its beautiful purpose in time.
It’s too early to write my reflections about my experience, and there is definitely so much to be written. But, I’m about to fly out of Spain today to my next destination, and I can’t help but feel overwhelmed by the kindness around me, especially that I am far from home.
From that metro guy who brought out his phone to use Google Translate so he could better give me instructions,
that other passenger who help me carry my luggage upstairs because I didn’t know you can go around and maybe find a lift,
that guy from Albania on a holiday who walked me to the bus stop ‘coz I’ve been literally going circles, looking for my ride to my hostel,
that guy from Germany, who was also on a holiday, but who explained the route of the bus I took to assure me and who also made suggestions on what touristy things I should do,
my roommates from Egypt, Brazil, and Chile who already feel like long-time friends, offering help and suggesting to meet up again in my next destinations,
Viki from Hungary, who provided me company on my first day, sharing stories as well as the same love for sports and dogs,
Mary Margaret from the US, who helped me book a tour and let me pay her in cash because my card wouldn’t work for online purchases because of its registered local number,
Miquel, a true blue Catalan from Esparreguera who adjusted his sched so I could go hiking in Montserrat — the reason why I added Barcelona to this trip,
all the fellow tourists and travelers who offered to take my photo (regardless if they turned out good shots or not) because I was alone,
the Spanish girl who lives near my hostel who taught me the best way to the airport,
David, a guy from Slovenia who works at the hostel, who gleefully (but not sure if legally) offered to keep my luggage and carry-on bag at the storage room free of charge for two days,
the ladies at the buses and the metro who weren’t articulate in English but still entertained my questions and went out of their way so we could find the lift for my heavy luggage,
the guy on the wheelchair, who was, of course, an expert to accessing the elevators, who kept on reminding me not to ride the train that runs through the same line as the train to the airport,
the Spanish girl who sat closer to my luggage at the airport terminal when I had to leave and check my flight details on the screen, and who then told me where to find assistance.
I have been just less than a week away, and I have many people to thank for — especially my family. But let me start with these strangers. I hope I got to know all their names and keep communication, but it warms my heart to think that even strangers can play magical cameos in anyone’s life.
When I arrived in Spain, I knew that getting lost should be enjoyed just as much as getting to one’s destination in a breeze. And true enough, I got lost, I doubted my direction and decisions multiple times, but I survive, learning lessons and making memories.
I am about to leave Spain, convinced that the world is beautiful. Yes, because Barcelona and Catalonia are a sight to behold. But more so, because of the kindness all around us.
--
--
An introspective and adventurous soul in a tireless search for self-improvement, she shares her story to help others find their story of personal redemption.

Title: A Remarkable Development of FC Barcelona
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
When we talk about football clubs, Spanish football clubs, especially FC Barcelona, come to mind. FC Barcelona has emerged as one of the biggest and most renowned football clubs in the world. Let’s take a journey into the development of FC Barcelona and how they have continuously adapted to the demands of the times.
FC Barcelona was formed in 1899 by Joan Gamper and has since become an important part of Barcelona’s culture and history. FC Barcelona shares a strong connection with Catalonia, as it has emerged as a rallying point for Catalan identity, providing a platform for the expression of Catalan aspirations. The club’s motto, “Mes que un club” (More than a club), reflects its social, cultural, and political impact. This identity has evolved over time, solidifying the club as a symbol of resistance and Catalan identity.
One of the most visible aspects of FC Barcelona is their playing style. They embrace a philosophy of beautiful football and ball dominance, known as “tiki-taka.” This style of play is a developed and perfected version of “Total Football” popularized by former Barcelona manager, Johan Cruyff. Cruyff’s influence and tactical approach laid the foundation of FC Barcelona’s philosophy.
Later, under the guidance of coaches Louis van Gaal and especially Pep Guardiola, FC Barcelona refined and implemented the tiki-taka style to its fullest potential. Guardiola played a significant role in promoting and developing “tiki-taka” during his successful tenure as Barcelona’s head coach from 2008 to 2012, collecting 14 major trophies.
The development of FC Barcelona is not limited to their playing style. They have also strengthened their youth player development structure and established the renowned football academy, La Masia. In recent years, Barcelona has also enhanced their approach to using technology and data analysis to improve team performance. They are currently renovating their stadium, now called Spotify Camp Nou.
FC Barcelona’s development is also reflected in their history of success. The club has won numerous domestic and international titles, including La Liga, Copa del Rey, and the Champions League. They have had star players like Lionel Messi, Sergio Busquets, Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, and many more who have become symbols of Barcelona’s dominance.
FC Barcelona has undergone a remarkable evolution over time, both in terms of playing style and as a social institution. The combination of visionary coaching, skilled players, and a commitment to the club’s philosophy led to the mastery of tiki-taka at Barcelona. They continuously adapt to the changing times and follow the path of remarkable development. FC Barcelona is not just a football club; it is a symbol of spirit, identity, and values that define them, just like their motto, “Mes Que Un Club” (More Than a Club).

Content:
