Title: A Disappointing Midseason Barcelona Review: By Numbers
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you watch Barcelona at this point, you would understand how aptly this gif epitomizes the current situation of the club, as we’re halfway through the season its looking like another one of those trophyless outings for the Catalan side. After already being out of the Spanish Super Cup & the Copa Del Rey technically they still have 2 major trophies to fight for including La Liga and the Champions League (yeah good luck with that!) but most fans have lost hope with this season. And now with Xavi leaving the club in the summer things are not looking good this season.
Let’s take a closer look at the underlying issues plaguing this club and how might Barca actually turn this around if they can that is.
Xavi as a player has been a core part of the Spanish national team and the mighty treble winning Barcelona squad which purely dictates his instinct as a manager and how he means to preserve the Barca DNA.
Since his arrival, Xavi has been using his 3–2–2–3 formation in possession or a 2–3–5 shape to great effect as seen below, this shape offers a lot of advantages in build up from the back and chance creation upfront.
This formation consists of a lone striker upfront as Lewandowski, two inside forwards preferably Pedri/Gavi & Gundogan, two wingers/wide players to hug the touchline preferably Balde & Lamine/Raphinha, two pivots preferably Frenkie & Cancelo/Romeu and 3 centrebacks preferably Christensen, Araujo & Kounde.
There is absolutely nothing wrong with Xavi’s approach as he has used the same structure to win the league last season by scoring a lot of goals but also maintaining a solid rest defence at the back. Xavi wants his players to equally spread around the pitch and occupy each zone so that every player has passing options around them and can combine easily to escape pressure. Having 5 players in the front line enables them to frequently pull opposition players from the backline to create space with smart off-the ball movements.
With highly technical players deeper such as Frenkie, Gundogan they create loads of chances every game with balls over the top, line breaking passes, swerving crosses. Having Pedri, Gundogan & Gavi between the lines is important as they can easily receive the ball under pressure and turn in tight spaces to play the final pass. With young players such as Balde & Lamine Yamal in wide areas you get runners in-behind as well as players willing to take on fullbacks everytime. And with 3 solid centre-backs in defence they should (in theory) be able to defend well right?
But that is not the case this season, now let’s take a look at some of the issues holding this team back
After getting rid of Fati, Dembele, Eric Garcia and Ez Abde in the summer window Barcelona were mainly looking to add to their squad depth upfront. But with Barca’s never ending financial struggles, it meant that they can only look for less costly replacements, as a result Oriol Romeu and Inigo Martinez were signed to improve their squad depth at the back.
After showing interest in both João Félix and João Cancelo, Xavi was able to get both on loan, all thanks to them falling out with their respective clubs. Where Félix was looking for a fresh start while Cancelo was purely looking for regular playtime under Xavi. With this Barca capped of a decent summer window as compared to their Spanish rivals who went gung ho to improve their squad as well.
After a bothersome start to the season which saw Pedri & Frenkie getting injured and missing some important games in the first half of the season, Barca mostly relied on its youngsters with Lamine Yamal, Gavi and even Fermin getting some minutes every now and then.
Midway through the season they were hit hard by 2 more major injuries on regular first team players: Gavi and Ter Stegen which would see both of them missing the whole 23/24 season. Both of them were integral to Blaugrana’s success and the way they played last year which makes them difficult to replace.
A simple search query tells us that Barcelona have recorded the most xG in all of Europe’s top 5 leagues seconded only by Bayern Munich. But their lack of finishing up top has been a major concern as they have failed to hit the mark time and again. Though xG can be deceiving sometimes when teams attempt a lot of shots at goal, but if we look at npxG per shot Barca still ranks the highest in the league along with Girona.
While most top teams have exceeded their xG by scoring more with a fair margin Barcelona have struggled to put the ball in the back of the net, in fact among the top 15 teams in Europe they have the worst (Goals-xG) stat along with Chelsea (which is obviously not great company at the moment!).
Robert Lewandowski who has been a stellar striker throughout his career has been struggling to even make an impact this season, he’s been pretty subpar when it comes to linking up, making incisive runs and even controlling the ball in the penalty area.
Part of this decline is understandable as he is not in his prime any more and is probably enjoying what might be his last few years of playing at the top level. But, with lack of clear striking options for Barcelona where they loaned out Fati in the summer window, and Ferran & Felix both reluctant to fill the #9 position it has become quite tricky and definitely raises questions on the squad depth.
Though Vitor Roque who was signed in the winter as a long-term prospect might be able to challenge Lewandowski and provide cover for him at this moment.
Generally when we think of Barcelona we think of fast free flowing football, a team boasting of highly technical players all over the pitch playing proper Cruyff football. We rarely see Barcelona being associated with the word “defensive solidity”, but that is what happened last season when Barcelona displayed the best defensive record not just in the league but all over Europe!
A big part of this performance was Barcelona’s newly formed Back 4 which consisted of new summer signings Kounde & Christensen along with Araujo and a young academy prospect Alejandro Balde. This back 4 was Xavi’s preferred combination when fit which conceded just 20 goals in 38 league games and 46 goals in 55 matches across all competitions!
But this season, fans have seen a mere hint of past glory achieved by this combination as they’ve failed to keep clean sheets time and again and keep conceding goals to every opposition they play. Defensive errors at the back have become quite common and their defensive structure seems deformed most of the time. But, who is to blame?
Marc Andre Ter-Stegen who has been a loyal servant for the Blaugrana for almost a decade now, a club where he established himself as a world-class keeper and is undoubtedly the best ball-playing goalie in Europe right now is definitely being missed by everyone. He is a core part of the Barcelona defense as he vastly overperformed his expectations last season by keeping the most clean sheets in the league.
But Barca aren’t just missing his spider-like reflexes on the goal line, they are also missing his great passing range and ball playing prowess from the back. His ability to take charge against high pressing sides and playing a pinpoint ball to a free man upfront has been his career highlight and part of what makes him world-class.
Iñaki Peña who is currently filling for him in his absence has been subpar at best with a poor save percentage, he also clearly lacks the skillset Ter-Stegen has and still needs time to develop as a proper first team goalkeeper.
Conceding early goals almost every time has been the story so far this season as Barca conceded first in 7 out of 19 games before the winter break, with most of these goals coming just within 10 minutes post kickoff. As a result of the game state, Barca are bound to chase games every now and then which causes a lot of impatience among the players as they look to create chances as soon as possible.
Though this in theory should work in their favor but it has instead worked against them as an impatient pass during build up leaves them outnumbered at the back leading to a turnover at times when the defense isn’t expecting. This coupled with the fact that Barca have no natural ball-winners in midfield meaning their counterpressing has been pretty wasteful this season.
Of all injuries that have plagued this team, Barca were hit the hardest by Gavi’s absence, yes a 19-year old midfielder from La Masia is literally the heart and soul of this Barcelona team. His pressing intensity and passion for winning the ball back is unmatched not just in Barca but all over Europe.
The Golden Boy winner is already a regular starter for club & country and has been hailed by Xavi as irreplaceable in his side, despite his short stature he is brimming with confidence and always gives his best in every duel despite the odds. With Barcelona boasting of a highly technical midfield in Frenkie and Gundogan, Gavi provides the bite it needs to dominate every game.
After Busquets’ departure, who was arguably the greatest holding midfielder of his generation and someone who perfectly fit the job description and the style of play at Barcelona, Barca have struggled to match his numbers whether it maybe in defensive actions or the ball-playing abilities he had. Gavi definitely does not match his profile but has stepped up his game alongside Busquets and after his departure in the defensive shift he puts in each game. His ability to man-mark Bellingham and nullify his presence for 70 minutes in the El-Clasico is what amazed me the most this season.
Gavi’s still leading the charts in the number of tackles put in by Barca players despite being out for a major part of the season as shown below. In fact, he’s the #1 ball winner for the team in the attacking 3rd phase of the game and significantly reduces the number of turnovers Barca face.
Gavi is a player I personally adore a lot and he is someone whose mere presence would fix a lot of issues with this team right now. My personal favorite memory of him will always be winning an aerial duel against Wout Weghorst in the Champions League who with all due respect towers over him 😅.
The left-back role provides a tricky problem for the Catalan side in recent times which was sought to be over until the start of this season but instead grows even deeper. A 19-year old academy prospect Alejandro Balde in his breakout season showed the world why he deserves to be on the first-team sheet ahead of veteran full-back Jordi Alba. Balde exceeded everyone’s expectations and completely obliterated his critics with his stellar performances, despite that he has struggled this season and has definitely failed to make the same impact this year. But is it even Balde’s fault?
As discussed earlier Xavi wants to stretch the opposition backline by playing 5 forwards when in possession and in this system Balde is the one who provides width on the left hand side of the pitch. This totally suits Balde’s traits as he is a naturally offensive fullback who can easily slip past defenders relying solely on his pace.
Which brings me to my main point: Balde is an offensive fullback and NOT a WINGER! Look at these stats below comparing wide players from this and last season. Comparing his stats to a proper winger we can see that he attempts less take-ons than actual wingers and instead likes to go around the opposition backline.
While Balde definitely found success by taking on players last season he has been a shadow of his former self this season and part of the reason is that his game is not about taking on fullbacks or dribbling his way through the opposition backline with the ball. Instead it is more about the off the ball movements and the burst of pace he provides to attack space to play dangerous passes/crosses in the penalty area, which brings me to my final point.
Well “A picture is worth a thousand words” and if there is any truth to that adage here it is. Look at this image below, this picture clearly explains some issues with this squad that often go unnoticed.
This snapshot is from Barca playing against Real Betis which was also Balde’s last game after he was sidelined for the whole season. As we talked about Xavi’s structure before how he wants his players to occupy all zones when in possession so that every player has an outlet to play the ball to, in this case the left-half space is completely empty meaning that Balde has no one to combine with and has to play 1v2 against the two Betis players. This sequence results in Balde trying to take-on the fullback and playing an uncharacteristic cross which finds no one and possession is lost.
This issue is not limited to a particular sequence in this match, it has become a common theme among all matches this season which hinders Balde’s ability. The major issue here is player profiling, since the front five in possession consists of Lewandowski and Ferran playing together, both of whom like to drift into central areas and hence create this gap. Last season, this was not a problem as the front five usually consisted of Gavi and Pedri playing as the interiors so the wide players always found it easy to combine with them under pressure. But with Gavi, out of the picture Balde has been totally isolated on the left flank and can barely prove useful.
Barcelona have been blessed to have a Lamine Yamal among their ranks as the youngster has been beyond outstanding in his breakthrough season. In fact, Barca have been heavily reliant on this young prodigy this whole season who has lit up the league and is taking on every player left, right and center.
For me personally, Lamine has been the best forward in this team by a long shot and reminds me why I love watching this team. Despite being a 16-year old he is overflowing with confidence and is ready to take on defenders at will, escape from pressure and mature enough to release the ball at the right time. What amazes me is that he still has a lot of time to develop and with regular playing time in the coming seasons I’m thrilled to see what the future holds for him.
Gündoğan has been nothing short of world-class since the start of this season and has easily become the most consistent player in the squad. While all the other midfielders have been ridiculed with some form of injury in different phases of the season Gündoğan has been Xavi’s go-to-man in the middle of the park.
Due to his technical brilliance and reliability he has played more minutes than other player in the squad and has contributed in single phase of play. Though his preferred position is as an interior upfront, he has also played as a pivot covering for Frenkie in his absence making him extremely flexible. With the season coming to an end Barca could definitely use his clutch potential and big game mentality to save this season.
Though most of these issues and problems discussed above just seem to be small tactical tweaks & psychological issues with the players and their dropping intensity this season, which is not as bad as it looks. Since, Barca don’t necessarily need new personnel they just need to reinvigorate themselves and a couple of good results might just do that.
I hope this blog was worth your time if you made till the end, this took a lot of time & effort and was also my first attempt at bringing my Football knowledge & Data Analysis skills to the table.
Thank you for reading and have a good day! 😅

by Ryan Johnson, Planner, Alta Planning + Design
I recently returned from a two-week trip to Europe, and I obviously spent a lot of time observing pedestrian and bicycle culture and infrastructure. Rather than simply envy our neighbors across the pond for their walkable and bike-friendly cities and believe that we Yanks could never match their high active transportation mode shares, I was constantly thinking how I could translate my experiences and observations into on-the-ground change here in the U.S. I also realized that we have some progressive transportation infrastructure on our own soil to be proud of.
We first made the pilgrimage to Copenhagen — the Promised Land for many Americans in the bicycle/pedestrian profession… And it lived up to the hype! The comprehensive network of physically separated cycle tracks was incredible and refreshing, of course, but I was more impressed by how easy it was to walk around the city. Several of the major streets were actually pedestrianized, with motor vehicles prohibited. While some examples of this concept exist in the U.S. — including Santa Monica’s Third Street Promenade — they feel rather manufactured and not organic.
Even with the dreary weather, we were sad to leave the playground of Copenhagen. But Paris was awaiting us! I had a mental image of Paris as the small, charming town along the river that is shown in films and travel magazines. However, I was immediately made aware of the city’s sprawling size and wide, auto-clogged boulevards. In a way, I was reminded of my hometown of Los Angeles, except that Paris’s Metro system blankets the region. In a flip from my experience in Copenhagen, I had gone to Paris expecting a walker’s paradise, but instead saw a budding cycling haven. The city had already squeezed cycle tracks along many of the major boulevards, and the famous Vélib’ public bicycles were as common a sight as sidewalk cafés and baguettes. The bicycle network appears set up to help Parisians close the “first mile/last mile gap” that often exists in a trip using public transit. I would love to see Los Angeles and other U.S. cities with mass transit networks pursue a similar course.
Finally, we ended our vacation by hanging out in the pedestrian paradises that are old Spanish cities. Barcelona, our first stop, was seemingly built to make walking a pleasurable experience, with interesting side streets, promenades, and commercial districts around every corner. Barcelona and other Spanish cities like Granada and Toledo also make good use of shared streets, or woonerfs, to make streets safe in constrained neighborhoods.
Finally, the many plazas and parklets in Spain’s cities were a never-ending source of resting space and excellent people watching.
Although very different in many ways, Los Angeles can and should follow the lead of European cities by creating safe and pleasurable spaces for people to walk or bike and be outside enjoying our near-perfect weather. And I’m proud to say that the LA region is beginning to seriously take on that mission. Both Long Beach and Temple City now have cycle tracks. LA County Metro is planning a regional bike share program. And through the LA Department of Transportation’s People St. program, several plazas and parklets have been created or are planned for previously underused road space. I’m excited that our leaders are beginning to push for progressive changes to restore some balance to how we move around our own cities.

I always thought I’d visit Barcelona for the first time during the summer or spring. After all, it’s a city known for its blazing Spanish sun and beaches. The idea to visit for December festivities came about when my boyfriend and I decided to go away somewhere close to Christmas this year, as we wouldn’t be spending the holiday together. Barcelona came up as an affordable option and after researching what the city looked like in winter, we were sold.
It’s safe to say it turned out to be the perfect Christmas break and one I’d recommend to anyone. So here is what I got up to over 2 nights in the Catalan city and what I’d recommend for any future travellers.
The first stop after dropping the suitcase off at our hotel was to go for a late brunch at the vegetarian restaurant Faire Brunch and Drinks. Barcelona is a very vegetarian and vegan-friendly city, and it was not at all difficult to find delicious plant-based food. Brunch also seemed to be a very popular meal in the city. People in Spain seem to eat meals later than in the UK. To that end, one great thing about Barcelona, and I believe Spain in general, is how late many places are open. Many of the cafes we visited didn’t shut until 10 at night or even later and…

Title: What the Downfall of FC Barcelona Can Tell Us About Running a Business
Content:

Listen
Share
All it takes is a few terrible decisions to ruin years of success
The last few months have been shambolic for the once-revered FC Barcelona.
For years, their attacking flair, world-class player development, and a selfless “more than a club” mentality drove them to the pinnacle of the footballing world. Boasting outstanding talents from their youth academy, La Masia, like Lionel Messi, Andres Iniesta, and Xavi Hernandez, Barcelona won every major trophy there was to offer.
But in recent years, things began to falter. The inadequate spending of funds combined with La Masia producing less talent and a brainless short-term player transfer policy soon began to manifest itself on the pitch. Barcelona continued to struggle in Europe’s marquis competition, the UEFA Champions League, and this year’s embarrassing 8–2 defeat to Bayern Munich was the spark that lit the powder keg.
Lionel Messi, the club’s best player who has been at Barca since 2003, tried to enact a clause in his contract allowing him to leave for free at any point once the season was over in June. However, Barca is arguing that the clause is invalid due to the pandemic, and he instead would be sold for the outrageous fee of $700M. The end result is an ugly stalemate with Messi being held against his will by the club he’s given so much to. Talk about a fall from grace.
As fellow fans of the sport know, this disaster is something few could have expected with the vast amount of money and talent at their disposal. But even if you do not follow sports at all, there are lessons to be learned from this success turned disaster. It’s better to learn now since the downfall of a once-great organization is not new and will happen again. You just need to make sure that you take the necessary steps outlined in this piece to avoid your team or organization being one of them.
Leaders have radiating effects that have effects on the entire organization, whether they be good or bad.
A lot of the issues Barcelona currently face were due to one event: the election of Josep Bartomeu as club president.
Despite being someone who had been in the organization for many years, things looked different once Bartomeu took office. He was the one who took all of the things that made Barcelona successful and tampered with them, as I’ll get into in this article.
Consider you and who you appoint as leaders in your organization can impact the morale and the overall success of the people in it. Bartomeu’s stint has shown that leaders need to have a deep understanding of the organization they are in charge of and what has made them successful.
One of the underrated factors that went into Barcelona's downfall is the destruction of Barca’s academy to first-team supply chain fueled by La Masia. Most of the starting XI from Barca’s glory days honed their skills in-house at the academy and learned how to play football under the guidance of important club principles. It’s safe to say that the approach worked.
Under recent leadership, though, things have changed for the worse while under the guise of being better. In a new campaign called La Masia 360, they started straying away from what made the academy so successful in the first place, replacing the famous farmhouse with a glassy, office-like building and diversifying into other sports like basketball and floor hockey.
The changes don’t seem too bad on paper, but slowly the amount of talent that came off the assembly line was not on the same level as the world-beaters of previous eras. Unfortunately, the people at La Masia were too busy focusing on what other clubs like Real Madrid were doing and changing their philosophy accordingly rather than setting the tempo themselves.
Additionally, due to financial problems from irresponsible spending, Barcelona has been forced to sell any talented young players to try and cover their debt. A lot of the best talent from the academy with the best shot of starting for the first team ended up finding success at other clubs.
Without a reference and purpose for employees to follow, or constantly having turnover or having your brightest talents leave, you run the risk of the soul of the company being taken with them. Proper education and the right people in the right places will help define the identity of your organization.
Do not starve your golden goose. Evolution is necessary, but totally reshaping a tradition and philosophy, or straying too far from what made your team great, will only hurt in the long run.
Overreliance on the very few is a problem faced with many organizations and communities and can limit their potential for vast success.
In American football, the Green Bay Packers hit the jackpot when they selected generationally talented quarterback Aaron Rodgers with the 24th pick in the 2005 draft. However, Rodgers’ immense talent meant that the board felt that they should use other picks to strengthen different parts of the team, like the defense and o-line, rather than pick a star receiver that could showcase Rodgers’ talents. They never got back to a Super Bowl after 2011.
The city of NYC is in big trouble because they let so much power be given to so few. With so many rich people living in the Big Apple and contributing to a large part of the city’s economic success, they know that they have a lot of power over the people governing it. So when the COVID-19 pandemic came to town, the city’s rich fled in far larger numbers than other income brackets, leading to Andrew Cuomo’s embarrassing schmoozing of them to come back and talk over dinner.
The message is clear for all organizations: there needs to be a plan in place to make sure that a single unit does not become larger than the whole system.
What that means is different for every group. For Rodgers, it may have helped more to spend draft capital on a receiver than for Barcelona to spend $200M on attackers to help Messi.
The thing is, building a successful team around Lionel Messi in Barca might be the easiest job anyone could do. Even I could probably build a Barca team that could contend for the Champions League, especially after the $220 million influx of cash from the sale of Neymar to PSG.
Unfortunately, Barcelona has gone out and spent hundreds of millions on players that are redundant and do not fit the system. Training sessions went from intense to lazy. Actions like this are frustrating for the millions of fans who follow Barca through thick and thin.
One of the reasons Messi is discontent with the club, as stated in the interview, is that the upper management at Barcelona “had no project” and was mainly focused on plugging any holes in the short term. He could not be more correct.
In fact, after the 8–2 defeat to Bayern Munich president Bartomeu said that things would change in the club. Actions speak louder than words.
They appointed a new manager, but the board that got Barca into this mess is still there. They still are trying to auction off young talent and have not revamped the aging squad, continuing to plug holes and failing to set a long-term vision.
The truth is, short-term decisions aren’t really ones based on rational thinking: quite often, they are reactionary or a response to something like changing sentiment or a consequential event. It doesn’t help that Barca has a very political culture, as the fans vote in who is in charge at the club, which can fog objective decision-making.
The only way to stop a pernicious problem like this is to consciously prevent it. Unfortunately, it seems like nobody on the Barca board is aware of what’s happening.
Now that you know what to avoid, consider what you would do to prevent this situation:
It will be harder to do in practice than just think about but rest assured, history will remember you as the leader of a truly great team.
--
--
Student at University of Pittsburgh

Title: Dynamic Space Tagging: Unraveling FC Barcelona’s Passing Patterns
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication

Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
As a lifelong FC Barcelona fan and aspiring data scientist, I set out to blend my passion for football with analytics in a final project focused on the 2021/22 La Liga season. Motivated by countless hours watching matches at the Camp Nou and a desire to quantify what we saw on the pitch, our goal was to make sense of Barça’s famed passing game, not just through basic stats, but by capturing the spatial context of each play.
We wanted to understand how FC Barcelona occupies and uses space during possessions, and how that might differ from other teams. In this article, we walk through the journey and findings of our project, introducing the concept of dynamic space tagging, the data and methods behind it, the spatial patterns we uncovered in Barcelona’s play (both home and away), and the interactive dashboard we built to explore it all.
Modern football analytics often emphasize the importance of creating and exploiting space — but how can we systematically label where players are in relation to their own team’s shape and that of the opponent? In our project, we tackled this challenge by introducing dynamic space tags: a method to categorize player positions in real time based on team formations. Using convex hulls and simple spatial rules, we drew a hull around all players of a team at any given moment , to represent the team’s shape on the field. Each player was then assigned a dynamic label depending on their position relative to this shape and the goals. The tags we used were intuitive football terms: Inside, Outside, Forward, Back, and a special one for the Goalkeeper. Here’s how it works:
Dynamic tagging captures a player’s spatial role at any moment — for example, a fullback might shift from “Back” to “Outside” to “Forward” as play advances. We apply this to both teams, each with their own hull, so players are labeled relative to their team’s shape. Terms like “Forward” or “Inside” always reflect that team’s formation at that moment.
A schematic showing convex hulls for both teams and example dynamic tags (Inside, Outside, Forward, Back) for players based on their position relative to the hull.
By tagging every player position this way, we capture the spatial context of each pass: who passed the ball from what zone to which zone. For instance, a pass from a player labeled “Inside” to a teammate labeled “Forward” might indicate a ball played from midfield into an advanced attacker between the lines. On the other hand, an “Outside” to “Forward” pass could be a classic wing-to-striker cross or diagonal.
To study these patterns, we needed detailed data from matches. We obtained a specialized dataset that merged event data with tracking data for 25 of FC Barcelona’s matches in La Liga 2021/22. Having both event and tracking data combined was crucial: the event data tells us when and what happened (e.g., a pass, a shot), and the tracking data tells us where everyone was when it happened.
What matches were included? The dataset spans 25 league matches.
Each event (like a pass) comes with a lot of information:
However, analyzing individual events in isolation isn’t enough — football is about sequences of plays. So we needed to group events into possessions.
A key step was identifying distinct possessions and aggregating features over each possession. We define a possession as a sequence of consecutive passes by one team without the opponent intervening. A possession continues until the team loses the ball or the play is otherwise interrupted (out of play, foul, shot, etc.).
We sorted all events chronologically and then walked through them to break the timeline into possessions. Whenever we saw a change in the team with the ball (for example, a tackle or interception where Team A’s event is followed by Team B’s event) or when a certain event indicates a natural break (like a shot that isn’t immediately rebounded, or the end of a half), we marked the end of one possession and the start of another.
The possession outcome, since a possession ending in a goal is very different from one ending in a simple lost ball. This was done by looking at the next event and its subtype — for example, if Team A’s play is followed by Team B taking a kickoff, clearly Team A’s possession ended in a Goal. If Team A took a shot and then the next event is a corner kick for Team A, we know the shot was saved out for a Corner. We created a small catalog of such rules to tag possession outcomes (Goal, Shot on Target Saved, Shot Off Target, Corner conceded, Throw-in, Foul, Half-time, etc.) based on the sequence of events.
By engineering these features, we transformed raw tracking and event data into a possession-based dataset. Each possession (whether it’s Barcelona or their opponent) became a data point with dozens of attributes capturing the nature of that possession.
Handling missing data: We encountered a few minor data issues, such as a handful of passes with missing destination coordinates. These were very few (only five missing entries in thousands of events), and we addressed them by either imputing plausible values or excluding those events, ensuring they didn’t skew any possession metrics. Overall, the dataset was clean and complete enough for robust analysis after this preprocessing.
To clarify how we segmented events into possessions, here’s a simplified pseudocode snippet illustrating the logic:
To uncover patterns in our high-dimensional possession data, we used Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction and K-Means for clustering. Instead of analyzing dozens of stats manually, PCA helped us compress the data by identifying key feature combinations that explained the most variance.
We standardized all features to avoid dominance by larger-scale ones (e.g., number of passes vs. width in meters). PCA then gave us a compact view of each possession, preserving key differences. A biplot revealed that features like pass count, vertical distance, and players involved were influential — hinting at distinct possession styles.
Using the elbow method, we chose a few principal components that explained most variance without extra noise. This also let us visualize the data in 2D or 3D for better analysis and effective clustering.
Clustering (K-Means): We applied K-Means to the PCA-transformed data to group similar possessions, aiming to uncover tactical patterns. After testing different values of k and using silhouette scores for validation, we settled on four interpretable clusters, each representing a distinct possession style.
These clusters weren’t predefined — they emerged from the data. Once identified, we could label each possession and analyze how different teams or matches mapped onto each style.
We wanted to know how FC Barcelona’s possession style compared to other teams. Since each match includes both sides, we had data for Barcelona and their 19 La Liga opponents. By aggregating possession stats, we could profile each team based on how they played against Barça.
Clustering revealed clear differences. About 80% of non-Barça possessions fell into the direct play cluster (Cluster 0), while Barcelona had a lower share (~65%) and more in the elaborate clusters. Notably, 19% of Barça’s possessions were in the wide, multi-player style (Cluster 2), compared to 11% for others. They also had more slow build-up possessions (Cluster 1): 5.6% vs 1.1%.
These patterns matched raw averages — Barcelona had more passes and player involvement per possession, consistent with their possession-focused approach under Xavi and Koeman. The data confirmed that their style stood out through metrics like pass count and number of players involved.
To visualize team differences, we built a hierarchical clustering dendrogram using each team’s possession style. The result was clear: FC Barcelona stood out, joining other teams’ branches only at a high distance — marking it as a strong outlier. Along with Barça, Real Madrid, Celta Vigo, and Villarreal also appeared as distinct in style.
These four teams, especially Barça, Celta, and Villarreal, are known for possession-heavy or unique approaches, so the clustering made sense. Most other teams grouped into a few large clusters, showing similar, often direct styles. Teams like Betis, Valencia, Espanyol, and Real Sociedad clustered closely, with little distinction in how they played against Barcelona.
A 2D PCA plot confirmed this: Barcelona sat far from the main team cluster, reinforcing their unique possession game. While Real Madrid, Villarreal, and Celta were also slightly apart, none matched Barça’s distinct style — even in a season below their usual standards.
A dendrogram showing clusters of La Liga teams based on possession style features. Barcelona (and a few others like Real Madrid, Celta, Villarreal) appear on separate branches far from the main group of teams, indicating their distinct styles.
We also explored how Barcelona’s style differed between home and away games. Teams often adjust based on venue, and even Barça isn’t immune. By plotting each match in feature space and color-coding by location (blue for home, red for away), we saw a clear pattern: home games were more spread out, while away matches clustered tightly. This meant Barça showed more stylistic variety at Camp Nou, but played more conservatively and consistently on the road.
At home, they played wider and more expansive football, with more passes between central and wide zones (like “Forward” to “Outside”). Home games also had slightly more passes per possession, pointing to greater dominance. Away matches featured fewer wide switches and more central or backward play — suggesting a tighter, more controlled approach.
The scatter plot confirmed this: red points (away) were tightly grouped, while blue points (home) varied more. A few matches stood out — like a direct, less typical home game vs Alavés, or a highly defensive or reactive away El Clásico vs Real Madrid — showing that game context still plays a role.
In short, Barça was more dynamic and varied at home, while away they stuck to a more consistent and compact game plan.
A scatter plot of Barcelona match possession patterns on principal component axes, with blue points for home games and red points for away games. Blue points are more widely scattered, while red points cluster together, illustrating the greater variability in home style vs the consistency in away matches.
To make our analysis useful — and interactive — we built a dashboard using Streamlit and Altair. It lets users explore passing patterns and dynamic space tags across any subset of possessions. The goal was to move beyond static analysis and let users ask targeted questions like, “How did Barça move the ball in 10+ pass sequences?” or “What did goal-scoring possessions look like?”
We had a few key design goals: intuitive visuals of space labels (even for non-technical users), flexible filters to define specific game scenarios, helpful stats, the ability to step through full possessions pass by pass, and clear team structure visuals.
The dashboard has two main modes:
This split allows different use cases — like isolating a key turnover or studying buildup to a shot.
For visuals, each pass or possession is shown on a pitch graphic with player positions, colored by team. Convex hulls outline team shapes, and arrows highlight passes. We kept the design clean — subtle field lines and unfilled hulls — to keep focus on player positioning and ball movement. This helps analysts quickly spot things like line-breaking passes or overly stretched formations.
Filters and user input:The dashboard’s main strength is its flexible filters, allowing users to drill down into specific scenarios. The sidebar includes:
These filters let analysts form detailed queries. For instance: show Barça possessions ending in a goal, with 10+ passes, and highlight “Inside to Forward” passes in those moves. This could identify key patterns or moments worth reviewing on video.
Interactive use cases:Imagine a coach wants to study how Barcelona plays out from the back under pressure. They can select “Barcelona” as the team, filter for passes after a recovery, and set the origin tag to “Back” (including the goalkeeper). This surfaces possessions where Barça regains the ball and starts from deep positions. The coach can then see whether the first pass typically goes to an “Outside” fullback or an “Inside” midfielder, and view the opponents’ positions to assess pressing structures — quickly identifying patterns before turning to video.
Another example: an analyst compares how teams handle Barcelona’s press. By selecting each opponent’s possessions against Barça and filtering for short possessions ending in a turnover (e.g., ≤3 passes), they can see whether teams like Granada lost the ball quickly (mostly Cluster 0), while others like Real Madrid managed more complex build-ups (more Cluster 2).
Technical details:We built the visualizations using Altair on top of a static football pitch. Convex hulls are drawn from player coordinates using standard geometry libraries. To keep the dashboard fast, we encourage filtering and limit default data loads. Navigation through possessions was initially done via a manual pass index, but future versions may include “Next” and “Previous” buttons or even animations for better usability.
The final product is a hands-on tool for deep exploration. It complements static analysis by helping coaches and analysts test ideas, validate patterns, and surface tactical insights in an interactive way.
Conclusion and reflections:This project gave us a deeper understanding of how data intersects with football tactics. Personally, it was rewarding to see coaching ideas like “maintaining width” or “playing between the lines” reflected in actual data. We confirmed that Barcelona’s possession style isn’t just something you see — it’s measurable: more passes, more player involvement, and distinct spatial patterns. We also saw how context — home vs. away, opponent quality — affects even a team with a strong identity like Barça.
Key takeaways:Dynamic space tagging added a tactical layer to traditional event data by labeling player positions in real time as Inside, Outside, Forward, or Back. This revealed patterns like Barça’s frequent “forward ↔ outside” passes at home or how opponents often stayed in “back ↔ back” loops when pressed. These findings are practical for scouting or game preparation.
Our Streamlit dashboard proved useful for visual analysis, but there’s room to grow. We lacked consistent feedback from coaches and analysts during development. Better UX — like step-through buttons or animated replays — would improve usability. Expanding the dataset beyond one team and partial season would help test the model’s generalizability. Comparing different tactical systems (e.g., low-block teams) could also validate or refine the tagging system.
Ideas for future work:
Final thoughts:Dynamic space models bring tactical depth to data analysis. By combining positioning with events, we can move beyond surface-level stats and quantify the subtleties of play. This project showed that Barça’s style isn’t just iconic — it’s distinct in the data. We hope this work sparks more interest in adding spatial context to football analytics — because football is ultimately about managing space and time, and now we have better tools to track it.

Title: Could Barcelona become Europe’s Silicon Valley?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Known for its stunning architecture, vibrant culture, and pristine beaches, Barcelona is quickly cementing itself as a booming gravity center for tech and innovation.
The emergence of unicorns such as Glovo (acquired by Delivery Hero), TravelPerk, Belvo and eDreams has spurred the development of the city’s startup ecosystem. This, together with a favorable business climate has bolstered the accessibility of venture capital. According to a new report by Dealroom, Spanish startups now exceed €100 billion in total valuation.
Several experts agree. The Boston Consulting Group has ranked Barcelona as the fifth most attractive city in the world for digital professionals. It also ranks sixth on EU-Startups’ list of the largest European startup hubs. The excitement around the city’s potential is such that Jordi Ribas, corporate VP of Search & AI at Microsoft, said it “has all the necessary elements to become the ‘Silicon Valley of Europe’ in the next 10 years.
In this article, I will assess Barcelona’s potential to live up to this promise, by examining its achievements and prospects in the technology industry.
First of all, Barcelona is strategically positioned as a gateway between Europe and other countries. Thanks to its international airport, as well as the seaport, there is no problem to go to any part of the world and back.
Also, the city’s development strategy has created spaces that facilitate collaboration and creativity. For example, the area of Poblenou was transformed into an urban innovation and technology center — 22@ Barcelona Innovation District. Spaces like these tend to be a magnet for founders, and add a layer of appeal to an already enticing place.
Priscilla Lavoie, a marketing expert based in Barcelona, expands on this. “I think the general attractiveness of Barcelona — the culture, great weather, and central location within Europe — makes it easier for companies in the city to attract tech talent from across the globe. People are willing to move here, which makes the talent pool much larger,” she states.
No innovation ecosystem can flourish without access to capital. Hence, part of Barcelona’s recent prowess is linked to the growth of available funding. According to the Barcelona and Catalonia Startup Ecosystem Report, Catalan startups raised over €5 billion between 2019–2023, 231% more capital than in the previous five-year period. Another report, Mobile World Capital’s Startup Ecosystem Overview, states that Barcelona startups have secured 66.4% of all investments in Spain. It is also worth remarking that according to Dealroom, sectors like climate tech and biotechnology, which hold some of the most promising ventures right now, are snatching most of the capital available for Spanish startups.
This has resulted in a thriving ecosystem. For example, the same Catalonia Startup Ecosystem Report mentions that Barcelona ranks fifth in terms of tech scaleups, with 283. This means companies that have survived the startup stage and have demonstrated their viability. At the same time, projects like the Barcelona Supercomputing Center, which now boasts over 150 research projects, create a cluster effect and foster collaboration between academia, Big Tech — Intel, Cisco and IBM, to name a few, are partners of the center — and innovators.
As sizable amounts of funding now gravitate towards deep tech, Barcelona could even have more to win. “Key developments like the recent addition of international submarine cables and the expansion of the Barcelona Supercomputing Center are making the city a prime location for startups in the quantum, AI, and health sectors,” said Nicolás Ventura, Head of Operations at Club GLOBALS, a growth network for tech leaders.
No ecosystem is complete without government support, as founders tend to relocate to entrepreneur-friendly hubs where they can focus on growing their businesses. To increase the region’s allure and attract talented innovators, the Government of Catalonia established ACCIÓ, the agency of business competitiveness. Through its Startup Capital program, ACCIÓ is granting €45,000 to promising tech-based startups. At the same time, the organization is lobbying for policies that make it easier to set up a company in the region.
In 2023, the federal government introduced a nationwide initiative dubbed the Spain Startup Law, which encompassed reducing the corporate tax rate from 25% to 15% for a maximum of 4 years — as long as the company was still considered a startup — and implementing a digital nomad visa to make it easier for international founders to settle. Other measures, such as a 10-year tax exemption on up to €50,000 on stock-based compensation per year, are intended to make it easier to secure talent.
However, there are caveats. To qualify for some of these exemptions, companies needed to be certified by Enisa, a new government agency. Sifted reported that by the end of 2023, only 600 startups were certified out of an expected total of 10,000. Despite these challenges, though, the move seems to have worked with investors. Even if overall VC funding was meager in the last couple of years, Spain seems to have developed more resilience to the global slump.
In Europe, cities like Berlin, London, and Madrid are vying with Barcelona to attract and retain top talent. Compared to some of these European hubs, Barcelona has several competitive advantages. The cost of living is lower than in London or other places like Stockholm, and the lenient weather and more social lifestyle could also have a say.
This, by itself, is not enough though. For companies to have access to a stable stream of talent, a city needs to have thriving universities and research institutions. This is definitely the case for barcelona. Institutions such as GBSB Global and business schools like ESADE, EADA, and IESE, which are listed in the top ranks in Europe, can provide plenty of talent, mentorship, entrepreneurs, and even interns to Barcelona’s start-up scene.
Incubators and accelerators play a key role in boosting a city’s tech scene. Barcelona abounds with them. One of them is Startup Grind, a global community that, through its chapter in the city, has helped connect innovators through gatherings, keynote speeches, and fireside chats. Norrsken, a Swedish impact tech powerhouse, has also set up shop in the city and opened a startup house, as well as Tech Barcelona, a private non-profit that has played a pivotal role in integrating technology into the city.
There are also many top-notch events, something that Nicolás Ventura alludes to. “The city is home to some of the biggest tech conferences in the world, like MWC/4YFN, which gathers over 100,000 tech leaders annually, and the Smart City Expo, which draws global attention and fosters international collaboration on critical issues,” he says. If some factors are paramount to attracting talented individuals, this might be one of the keys to getting them to stay.
Spain’s economic fluctuations can affect investment in innovation. If the overall country’s economy experiences a downturn, funding for startups and research projects might be reduced, causing the founders of these ventures to flock elsewhere.
Bureaucracy can be another problem. As I mentioned, there have been hiccups in the full implementation of Spain’s Startup Law. Canada had a similar problem and presents a cautionary tale. Even though the Startup Visa program looked good on paper, its long wait times diminished its appeal, until many companies chose to establish elsewhere.
Also, there needs to be a careful balance. While growth is good, something that happened in Silicon Valley, for example, is that the excess of capital benefited people who worked for a few companies, but resulted in a prohibitive cost of living for the rest. This led fledgling entrepreneurs to look for other places to start their businesses.
If Barcelona falls behind in some of the aspects presented above, other cities might capitalize on that. There is an intensified competition not only across Europe, but around the world. And despite Spain’s attractiveness, it is still, according to Dealroom, a mid-tier player.
To make a point of comparison, French startups reached a total valuation of €100 billion six years ago, and German startups nine years ago. Does this mean that Spain is lagging that much? Not necessarily, since growth can be exponential. However, it signals something more important. Ambitious startup founders do not hesitate to leave a place where they don’t feel supported.
Compared to professionally-oriented cultures like the United States, Spain is much more relaxed and focused on work-life balance. Also, business tends to center more around relationships.
This is evident in the Hofstede dimension scores. Spain scores low on motivation compared to the US, and high on indulgence. While overall this is not necessarily bad, it is important to strike a balance. Too much pleasure and too little work could cause Barcelona’s startup dreams to flounder.
Does this mean that talented individuals with a big vision will leave? Lena Shagieva, founder of PreggApp, an AI-powered pregnancy tracker, has an interesting perspective. “There is a reason why there is only one Silicon Valley. After experiencing living there and living here (Barcelona) now, I can tell, these places are built for different lives. Silicon Valley is a place with a laser focus on success, on money. It’s a high-octane rat race,” she remarks.
Finally, it could also boil down to money. While capital available is increasing, deal flow is still slow compared to other hubs. “Barcelona has great potential, however, I believe there is a need for a more virtuous circle of money flowing into the ecosystem for it to become the EU Valley,” said Priscilla Lavoie.
She also commented that, “while we have seen interesting exits in the last 5–10 years, the majority of large investors in these companies were from the US, UK, and France, so most of the money leaves Spain and doesn’t really support our ecosystem at home.”
Lena Shagieva also touches on this. “It can be an optic problem, or because money is expensive here, but at the end of the day, businesses need money and startups need to see actual deals happening — know people who have had big money exits,” she says.
The point of comparing many cities to Silicon Valley has been made countless times. Many places have been there — Tel Aviv, the Kitchener-Waterloo corridor, Austin and Seattle, to name a few. However, it is always a misleading comparison, because every city has unique aspects that contribute to its development or lack thereof.
Hence, the idea of Barcelona becoming the “Silicon Valley of Europe” is not accurate. Silicon Valley has singular conditions that result in a high concentration of unicorns, and setting such standards can create unrealistic expectations for Barcelona.
I rather endorse the vision of Luis Cabiedes, one of Spain’s most well-known VCs and angel investors, who states that Spain needs to develop its own model rather than trying to imitate Silicon Valley. In this regard, it is unlikely that Barcelona can rival Silicon Valley in scale. Yet, it still has the potential to become a significant player in the European tech landscape, and to do it in its own way — leveraging its strengths and distinctive advantages.
--
--
An award-winning global cultural & business strategist; gender equality advocate; founder of Mindset Consulting and Sensity Studio

Title: ⚽️ Barcelona starts acting like a streetwear brand
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
At PWR House, we see sports teams evolving into full-blown media & entertainment brands that want to do more than just play the game.
For example — today FC Barcelona dropped a limited edition jersey with musician Travis Scott. Only 1899 jerseys were released and predictably, they all sold out instantly.
The jersey features Travis’ “Cactus Jack” logo, the same one featured on all the insanely hyped sneakers he releases with Nike.
This is part of a broader collaboration between Travis Scott and Barcelona leading up to the El Clásico on May 11. Travis Scott will be performing for the first time in Barcelona on May 10th and then the entire team will be wearing their Travis Scott jerseys on May 11.
A lot of this comes down to Spotify, who signed a multi-year $308 Million sponsorship deal with Barcelona in 2022.
Since then, Spotify has given Barcelona a VIP pass to the world of music in a way that no other European football club has. This Travis Scott jersey is just the latest in a series of one-off Barcelona collaborations with artists like Drake, Chris Martin, and Karol G.
Travis Scott is a multi-hyphenated cultural phenom that sits on the Mount Olympus of hip hop & streetwear and there’s no way he would have worked with Barcelona without Spotify’s involvement.
Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) had a similar “VIP pass” to the world of fashion when they collaborated with Air Jordan. It’s simply good business for a sports team to embed themselves within a cultural vertical like music or fashion.
If a team works with the right partners (like Travis Scott or Jordan brand), they associate with a deeper part of culture. That increases the desirability of the team, which should impact the sales of merchandise and all other ancillary revenue streams.
While I expect some traditional football die hards to roll their eyes at Travis Scott, there are likely millions of young people around the world who have become significantly more excited about Barcelona now that Travis Scott is associated with the team.
At this point, Barcelona has derived significant value from their Spotify partnership in a way that’s unique and better than a traditional sponsorship.

Content:

Walking tours, food experiences, wine tastings, and so much more.

--
Listen
Share
Gràcia, also known as the Vila de Gràcia (village of Grace) lives up to its name. Many years after its establishment, it is still a small, tranquil “village” in the middle of Barcelona’s vast, urban sprawl. Founded in 1626 as a convent, it wasn’t until 1897 that it became a part of Barcelona. That pivotal moment belongs to the larger story of Barcelona’s transition from small town to metropolis; other neighborhoods, such as Sants and Sarrià, are also formally independent municipalities that were annexed by Barcelona during Idefons Cerdà’s expansion of the city starting with his Eixample Plan in 1859.
Today, the neighborhood lives on as a peaceful zone that harbors small businesses and wards off through traffic. Gràcia’s extensive use of creative urban planning measures, like Salvador Rueda’s concept of “superblocks,” means that cars must share the streets with pedestrians, bikers, and children on scooters. It boasts more than 10 lovely plazas, where you can sit for a coffee or “far un vermut,” while kids play in front of you and their parents gossip beside you.
Though it is not one of the first neighborhoods listed in guidebooks, Gràcia is home to many treasures. Among them is the first home designed by Antoni Gaudì, Casa Vicens. Recognized as one of the Art Nouveau movement’s first buildings, it has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The house was originally built as a summer home for the Vicens family in the 1880s. It was closed to the public until 2017 when it opened as a museum. There is some mystery surrounding its patriarch, Señor Manuel Vicens i Montaner. Records indicate that he was a professional stockbroker and currency dealer, though many historians have referred to him as the owner of a tile factory. Given the tiles ostentatiously engulfing the exterior of the building, the latter is certainly plausible.
In 1992, an air-raid shelter was discovered beneath Gràcia’s Plaça del Diamant. The planes’ main targets were the many factories once situated throughout the area. The shelter protected more than 200 people during the Spanish Civil War and is one of the biggest of the 1,300 shelters that were built in Barcelona during that time. Guided tours are offered every Sunday at 11 AM, but reservations must be made online.
Gràcia is a more bohemian-natured neighborhood. Walking around you will notice many shops with hand-painted murals on their doors. One could say this makes it an outdoor art gallery in and of itself. Some of the murals are exquisite works of art, relating to the store’s offerings. You’ll also come across colorful beer cans painted with quotes and pinned to the walls of buildings. These inspiration messages and love notes are done by a mysterious, unknown couple with a beautiful love story.
Gràcia has several shopping promenades where you’re sure to find many small boutiques and artisanal shops. Start at Olokuti on Carrer d’Astúries. This general store sells just about everything and its wares are produced using sustainable materials and processes. Even if you aren’t interested in buying something, there is a beautiful secret garden, accessible from the back of the store.
For clothing, continue down Astúries to La Comet, a small, independent boutique full of made-in-Barcelona pieces and gorgeous gold jewelry. Others to check out are Ktu Barcelona and Padam, as well as Natural Mediterrani, which sells natural soaps and bath products.
Carrer de Verdi links up with Carrer d’Astúries, just past Plaça del Diamant. If you’re looking for great shoes, try Vialis, Mauro’s BCN or Streeters. Salvador Mallol Joier, Bell Estiu, and Pia Barcelona have exquisite jewelry. For clothing, take a peek at Vos Shop and KLING.
Carrer de Bona Vista is another area for fashion finds, with a few more upscale, haute couture shops. POISON Jewels sells one-of-a-kind adornments. Be Store has great gifts for friends and family. Browse BOO, IKA, and Mushi Mushi if you’re looking for quality, locally-crafted clothing. Rêveries has a variety of vintage luxury items. At the end of the street, turn right onto Passeig de Gràcia and you’ll find Lupo, another local atelier, which makes all of its handbags in-house.
Let me follow this by telling you that Gràcia is also a foodie haven. Smaller versions of the well-known Boqueria, Mercat de la Llibertat and Mercat de l’Abaceria are located on the neighborhood’s borders. In the middle, an old, run-down market on Carrer de Puigmartí is being renovated. As for restaurants, there are simply too many homey, independent, quirky establishments to tell all, but I can highlight a few of my favorites.
Mama’s Cafe offers an excellent American-style breakfast, with great coffee and a small backyard garden. For lunch, Taverna el Glop and Il Giardinetto Di Gracia have tasty, very Catalan dishes. If you go during the week you can experience what is known as “el menu del dia.” For the best pizza in Barcelona, sit down at Garden Pizza by Rafa Panattieri, a Brazilian-Italian chef with ties to the famous Roca Brothers.
El Cafè del Teatre and Chatelet are both wonderful, cozy spots to stop in the late afternoon for a glass of wine before heading to a movie at Cines Verdi, which shows many English-language movies with Spanish subtitles.
Bodega Quimet serves up traditional tapas at good prices and with their house wine. At the end of your meal, you can even take home a bottle of what you’ve tried — the concept is to taste the wines accompanied by small snacks. La Xula Taperia is a more modern, Mediterranean-fusion, experimental take on Catalan tapas.
Plenty of places for a nightcap can be found just by strolling around. But some no-fail recommendations are Viblioteca, whose play-on-words title explains itself, and El Ciclista, the area’s staple hipster cocktail bar. At Bobby Gin you can try variations on Spain’s favorite cocktail, gin & tonic.
Looking for live music? Take your pick: Soda Acústic, Cueva de Lobos, and La Sonora de Gràcia are all reputed venues, though be prepared to snuggle up to strangers if you so choose. If you’d like to move your feet, Gràcia Latina and El Sabor are there for a salsa dancing adventure.
Catalunya and the rest of Spain take their partying very seriously.
If you’re lucky enough to arrive in Barcelona during August, you may get to join in celebrating Gràcia’s biggest party of the year. During summer, each of Barcelona’s neighborhoods puts on a several-day block party, known as the “Festa Major.”
In Gràcia, locals spend weeks preparing for their August party, by building elaborate decorations and stages out of recycled materials. Restaurants sell food and drinks, and musicians and DJs play concerts on almost every corner. The annual festival even has its own website and office space to organize the event.
The best way to arrive is via metro. Though there are no metro stations directly in the center, Gràcia is accessible by the L3 (the green line), L4 (the yellow line), and L5 (the blue line). Metro stations Diagonal and Verdaguer have their exits at the bottom border of the neighborhood, while Joanic and Fontana are further up on Gràcia’s outer edges. Once you get there, you’ll enjoy meandering in as it will give you the chance to experience more of the area on foot, which is exactly how it should be.
About the AuthorSuzannah is the founder of Toureaux.com, a Barcelona-based platform for booking tour guides and experience hosts. In her free time, she loves traveling throughout Europe and sharing her travel tips with other visitors.
--
--
Walking tours, food experiences, wine tastings, and so much more.
Suzannah lives in Barcelona, Spain. She loves visiting more off-the-beaten-path places and helping other travelers discover them.

Title: Barcelona — Places to nurture yourself
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“Peace is not something you wish for; it’s something you make, something you do, something you are, and something you give away.” — John Lennon
We all nurture, nourish, support and sustain ourselves in different ways. Nurture through grounding may not be a way for everybody and vice versa. We are all way too used to hearing people tell us how to take care of ourselves through instagram, tiktok, wellness groups and other channels that surround us. And although it might be a good way to begin exploring and discovering which self-care means work for you — it can be quite overwhelming.
And that is why I am not here to tell you how and give you unnecessary advise, I am here to simply share and reflect on my experiences. On what makes me feel better after a long day, helps to quiet down my anxiety and connect with the present. If it inspires you to visit some of these places — we share a taste in self-care routines, if not — I would love to hear what you have to say about your ways to keep sane in the world that cannot stop moving.
Below, are some of the places and initiatives I discovered in Barcelona that contribute to nurturing my body and soul.
A tiny, intimate yoga studio in Born offers a unique space unlike any other. I am not a fan of the big, sterile yoga spaces that are common in London or gym chains. The studio features a welcoming reception, a single studio, and a chill-out room, creating the perfect environment to feel at home and familiar. The Chill-out Room at the back of the house almost always encourages me to arrive 10–20 minutes before class to cuddle up on the huge sofa with Claudia’s dog Turron, take a couple of breaths, and shield myself from the hectic outside world.
A wide range of classes is available, from early morning to late evening, to help you start or end your day. There are also more focused workshops, such as those for handstands, outdoor yoga classes with views of the sea, and more experimental activities like “Soltar y Estar” movement classes with Anna Viklund (she deserves a special section, so read below).
A few words from the founder Claudia Paz:
The inspiration comes from a personal need. I wanted a place where I could fully relax and disconnect from the busyness of everyday life, a safe haven to practice with teachers who genuinely focus on my practice and connection. I envisioned a space finished to a high standard, where I could feel fully secure. Casa Paz is different because it’s personalized; all the teachers are amazing instructors. The personal touch is very important — we know the names of our students and genuinely care about them. I love seeing this connection transfer to the students, who often walk through the door with a relieved expression, saying, “Finally, I’m here.”
My favorite mantra, which I often repeat to myself, is “This has already been resolved on its own; the universe has already taken care of this. Everything is going to be okay.” This phrase has been with me for over a year. Sometimes we fight or get mad at certain situations, but the reality is that we can’t control everything: what others think about us, what they do, or how situations unfold. What we can do is be aware of ourselves and give our best. If a day is bad or we have a conflict with someone, the best we can do is learn from it and observe how we can do better next time. We have to focus more on our own path, be respectful to others, and treat ourselves with more compassion.
So many come to mind because each has taught me a lot. But one that has been with me for a longer time and brought me a friend to help in my practice is Urdhva Dhanurasana, the wheel pose. It is a challenging pose for me. I remember as a kid just jumping around doing it, but as I grew up, it became more challenging due to the meaning it holds for me. Especially in the drop back to the wheel, it is a moment of full trust in yourself. It requires, in my opinion, a lot of self-confidence, and that is something I have been working on a lot in the last few years. For me, everything is in that pose: the strength, the connection with the earth through your hands and feet, and looking back with your chest fully open really makes me feel a sense of acceptance.
We have a room at the back of the shala that our community calls “The Chill Out Room.” This is where people relax, connect, read, and drink tea throughout the day between classes. It’s a space for all our members to come whenever they need a little break. It’s designed for our community to meet one another and connect away from the mat to form friendships. My thoughts on yoga teachings are that, as instructors, we are in service to the students. They come to practice because they are looking for something, even if that something is only the final savasana (relaxation). We strive to provide a comfortable and safe practice for everyone.
The month of May was a time of reflection on my body. I worked daily to better understand my relationship with my body, identify the traumas that shaped this relationship, and find ways to improve it through various practices.
One thing I realized was that I did not feel comfortable moving in public spaces as I wanted to. I felt constrained and anxious to the point where I would stop dancing altogether or simply mimic the patterns around me without truly understanding what I wanted to do.
As part of this realization, I decided to take some body expression workshops. Almost by design, I came across the Soltar y Estar initiative led by the incredible Anna Viklund.
“Soltar y Estar” — “Release and Just Be” — are spaces free from judgment, instructions, and expectations. They allow you to enter a meditative state and play with your body through movement, meditation, and group connection. For me, this is a space where I come in with no expectations and leave with a tired body, a clear mind, and valuable lessons learned. Anna manages to challenge but never push, encourage but never force, lead but never dictate.
In addition to group classes, which have a special energy due to their communal nature, Anna also offers personalized one-on-one workshops — something I have yet to experience. In just a few weeks, dance transformed from something I dreaded into something I couldn’t wait to do.
A few words from the founder Anna Viklund:
Soltar y Estar is a conscious playground where you get to connect with your own body. It’s a safe space that we create as a group where each session is a unique journey but with a fixed destination- The present. Listening leads us to connection, which leads us to openness, curiosity removes judgment and invites us to move. The movement invites us to play, where we release the control and forget about our identities. And there we find ourselves in pure joy, vitality and compassion. A soft body and a sharp mind. Soltar y Estar is pure Body Expression! It’s a wonderful way to get to know people through a moving body.
Movement for me is feeling myself. Movement is home, it’s expressing and listening. Movement is clarity! Movement is massage, meditation and cleanse. Movement is to get drunk and to get sober at the same time. Movement is to explore, play and create. Movement is getting to know myself. Movement is vitality. Movement is absolutely necessary for me to be able to be a present and conscious person.
Our body is our greatest teacher and we are our own healers. All we have to learn is to listen.
If I am my authentic self, I invite people to be authentic too. When I open up, you open up.
Dance and movement is a very powerful way to get to know yourself and your own body. Dancing in contact with another person is a very powerful meeting. Dance without a shape and without rules is very healing. Dance loses 100% of its magic if you start comparing yourself with others and when you lose the connection with your inner world.
Trying new things is connected with curiosity. Curiosity can replace judgements. What ever you are judging within yourself or in others could completely change perspective if you choose to look at is with curiosity, for example “I can’t dance, I’m feeling like a loser” vs “interesting, every time I move in front of people I get insecure, what would happen if I practiced that’”. Trying new things opens up your mind, breaks your patterns and is a straight portal to self growth.
Yet another multi-experiential space combining all aspects of well-being is located in the heart of Barcelona at Placa de Tetuan. The thinking behind Frizzant is quite innovative; the space is designed to support all the daily activities of our community: working, participating in conscious movement classes (yoga, dance, etc.), socializing, and enjoying meals in a cozy, inspiring environment. Does this cover pretty much everything I aim to do in a day? Yes.
I have to commend the designer of the space — it is one of the most beautiful and thoughtfully designed modern studios I have ever encountered. I was truly fascinated the first time I showed up for a class here. Regarding the classes, Frizzant represents the modern evolution of yoga: a dynamic, social, and urban practice that avoids dogma and encourages body expression and emotional growth.
The café offers a unique selection of fresh fruits and vegetables — something you don’t often see, even in most supermarkets, where cucumbers are suffocating in plastic wrappers.
A few words from the founder Sonia Sala:
(Courtezy of https://frizzant.com/)
For me, there is no better way to ground oneself than by connecting with nature. It’s a free, accessible way to remind yourself where you come from. “Accessible” may sound like an overstatement when living in the chaos known as the city, but I will try to break the stereotype that nature in Barcelona is always at least a day-long escape.
Montjuic
Every time I head to Montjuïc, I end up in a different place. I still struggle to grasp just how big it is, what it hides inside, and where it ends. Apart from a beautiful hike offering a fantastic view of the city, with hidden nature-filled spots, forests, and parks, Montjuïc also offers a wide range of historical gems to entertain your mind. You can easily spend more than a few hours here, breathing much cleaner air than down below. Multiple foundations, Montjuïc Castle, and the Roman Theatre are scattered around the maze of Montjuïc, ready to entertain. I encourage you to walk without a map and see where you end up, because I bet you will discover something new every time you come back.
The Sea
Oh, how incredibly lucky I am to have the sea in Barcelona. Having experienced living by the sea, I can never go back. One of the true sources of happiness, energy, and peace for me is hearing the sound of the waves and seeing them crash along the coast — no matter the weather, no matter the season.
My favorite places to sit by the sea:
Always remember to make time for yourself.
See you in the next one,
Anya
--
--
Stroll, stop and notice. Savour and enjoy. A selection of unique sets of places across the globe.
